Title: Nirmala Sitharaman: Rs 102 lakh crore investment plan for mega infrastructure push
Content:
File photo

NEW DELHI: Finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman on Tuesday unveiled a Rs 102 lakh crore infrastructure investment plan for the next five years, with less than a fifth consisting of new projects to begin with.It hopes to expand the pipeline, which was part of BJP’s election manifesto, in the coming months with Rs 3 lakh crore of state projects to be added in the next few weeks. The announcement came at a time when the Centre is keen to step up investment and the pipeline is seen to be signalling a step in that direction. Infrastructure gaps are seen to be a major reason for hobbling faster expansion of economic activity in the country and faster construction of new roads, power facilities and ports along with irrigation facilities are expected to also result in demand for cement and steel, which have been hit by the current economic slowdown.These projects are on top of Rs 51 lakh crore spent by the Centre and states during the last six years, the finance minister said at a press conference. Nearly 43% of the projects are under implementation, while another 33% are at conceptualisation stage.While the Centre and the states will equally split 78% of the proposed investments, the remaining 22% will come from the private sector with non-government participation expected to increase in the coming years. The mega investment plan will see the Centre’s capital outlay for infrastructure almost treble from an estimated Rs 3.5 lakh crore in 2018-19 to close to Rs 10 lakh crore by 2024-25. Similarly, budgetary allocation is projected to increase from Rs 1.4 lakh crore to over Rs 4 lakh crore during the same period.The largest chunk of the funds are proposed to be spent on creating power sector infrastructure.The investment pipeline came with policy prescriptions — ranging from tapping overseas investors more aggressively and monetisation of existing railway, power and highway projects to raise money, which can then be redeployed for creating fresh infrastructure.“We are looking at various steps to reform the PPP-based contracts, which have to be implemented. Dispute resolution, enforcement of contracts which are very critical components are being looked at when we're talking about reforming the entire process as per the suggestions given by various sub-groups under the task force,” Sitharaman said.The document on the infrastructure pipeline released by the minister also underlined the need for maintaining the sanctity of contracts. “In order to boost private sector interest, it is critical that the sanctity of contracts is upheld by the central, state and local governments. Repudiation of contracts must be restricted only to situations to be clearly defined in the contract. Provisions of contracts therein should be legally enforceable, which makes the parties involved legally abide by these contracts. In case of inability, there should be adequate safeguards built in in the form of clearly quantified termination payments under various possible scenarios,” it said at a time when investors are seen to be risk averse after states such as Andhra Pradesh decided to terminate contracts after the change of government in the state,Sitharaman also announced that the first edition of Annual Global Investors’ meet will be held in the second half of the coming year to meet investors on a single platform.“Creation of the national infrastructure pipeline in a short span of time is a positive step... The front-loading of capex is also positive for construction sector,” ICRA's Senior Vice-President and Group-Head, Corporate Ratings Shubham Jain said.

Title: India lost 110 tigers, 491 leopards in 2019; poaching up: Report
Content:
File photo

NAGPUR: The country lost 110 tigers in 2019, a third of them to poaching. The year also saw the death of 491 leopards, according to figures compiled by NGO Wildlife Protection Society of India (WPSI). As many as 38 tigers were lost to poaching, up from 34 in 2018.While there was a slight dip in leopard deaths from 500 in 2018, what remained a big cause of concern was the high number of leopard fatalities in road and rail accidents, which could be as high as a third of all deaths, said WPSI, which has been compiling data on big cat deaths for years.In case of tigers, there was a marginal rise in the number of deaths compared to 2018, when 104 tiger deaths were recorded.“No general inference can be drawn from these figures. Every landscape has its own set of pressures and problems, but leopards are getting killed in road and rail accidents, which is worrisome. It is the result of not just increasing traffic volumes but also increased speed due to widening of roads,” said Nitin Desai , WPSI’s Central India director.Madhya Pradesh continued to top the list of highest tiger deaths with 29 in 2019, followed by Maharashtra with 22. In 2018, MP had reported 23 tiger deaths followed by 19 in Maharashtra.Of the 110 deaths in 2019, 38 were attributed to body parts seizures and poaching, 26 were found dead, 36 died in fight with other tigers, three due to road/rail accidents and six during rescue.“On the one hand, it shows good detection rate and higher enforcement activity but on the other it also shows increasing demand for tiger body parts. Improving intelligence-led enforcement, addressing impact of linear intrusions and conflict management can help keep viable populations of tigers,” Joseph said.However, the official database of the National Tiger Conservation Authority (NTCA), the country’s apex tiger conservation body, differed with the figures. NTCA recorded 92 tiger deaths in 2019 and 102 in 2018.Tito Joseph, programme coordinator of WPSI, said poaching and seizure of body parts of tigers had slightly increased in 2019. He said the difference in number in NTCA’s data may be due to non-inclusion of tiger deaths inferred from seizure of body parts. “We calculated the number of tigers depending on seizures, which may not necessarily belong to one tiger only,” Joseph said.For example, in Maharashtra the official figures record deaths of 18 tigers but it doesn’t include three tigers poached in Tumsar range in July 2019. The arrested accused have confessed that they killed three tigers there. This may be the case elsewhere as well.“Some mortalities were not communicated by the states to us… As far as the Tumsar tigers are concerned, the number has been split in MP and Maharashtra as some body parts were seized in MP,” an NTCA official said.As per the latest tiger estimation by NTCA-Wildlife Institute of India, there are 2,967 tigers in India. In Maharashtra, the number increased from 190 in 2014 to 312 in 2018. With 526 tigers, MP is at the top but deaths due to poaching remain a cause of concern in both states.There was a marginal drop in number of leopard deaths in 2019. Though NTCA doesn’t have a database on leopard deaths, WPSI data shows that 500 leopards had died across the country in 2018, which included 169 due to poaching. There was no let-up in poaching of leopards in 2019, as 127 of the 491 deaths were attributed to poaching.In 2019, Maharashtra accounted for 97 leopard deaths, with as many as 31 in road and rail accidents.

Title: Railway fare hike: Financial woes force Railways to hike fares for 1st time in 5 years
Content:
File photo

NEW DELHI: In its first fare hike in five years, the railways on Tuesday announced increase in passenger charges that will see ticket prices rise by Rs 55-60 if you travel between Delhi and Mumbai or Kolkata on a Rajdhani from Wednesday onwards but did not touch suburban train fares .Though the fare increase is modest, in the range of 1-4 paise per km for different classes of travellers, the railways expects to generate an additional about Rs 2,300 crore annual revenue at a time when its finances are under acute stress.A hike had become pressing considering revenue shortfall during this fiscal (up to November-end) was close to Rs 20,000 crore. The operating ratio has increased to 121% till November-end during the current financial year as compared to 113% in the same period in 2018-19. Operating ratio is the amount spent to earn Rs 100, a higher ratio indicating poor financial health.While opting for an increase on long-distance travel, the railways has not burdened passengers travelling in suburban trains and season tickets have also been excluded from the hike. With nearly two-thirds of the passenger traffic accounted for by suburban rail, the segment accounts for a large share of losses for the state transporter. Those who have already pre-booked the tickets won’t have to pay extra.Officials said the government decided not to touch commuters in suburban trains since they often board trains multiple times a day and a hike would have escalated their costs. “Long- distance passengers travel more occasionally and since the hike is minimal, it won’t pinch them in a big way,” said a railway ministry official. The railways claimed suburban passengers have been left out, keeping the “affordability concerns of daily commuters”.According to an official statement, the increase in fare per km is 1 paisa for ordinary non-suburban classes (second class ordinary, sleeper class ordinary, first class ordinary) and 2 paise for mail/ express trains in non-AC class (second class mail/ express, sleeper class mail/ express, first class mail/ express). The hike for all AC tickets across trains will be 4 paise per km applicable for Rajdhani, Shatabdi, Duronto, Vande Bharat, Tejas, Garib Rath, Antodaya and Jan Shatabdi trains.“There will be no change in charges for superfast charge, reservation fee. GST, as applicable will be levied,” said the official statement. Going by the norm, if a passenger is taking Delhi-Kolkata Rajdhani, the total fare (AC-2) would be dearer by around Rs 61.Last week, Railway Board chairman V K Yadav hinted at a hike in passenger fares, saying the railways would soon “rationalise” fare and freight charges. He added freight charges were already high. TOI on November 27 had first reported how the PMO asked the railways to increase passenger fare and asked it to “raise public awareness about the need for rationalisation”. Subsequently last month, it had asked the ministry to “explore possibilities of scheduled increase in passenger fare”.

Title: Manoj Mukund Naravane: India reserves right to strike at terror sources: New Army chief
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

NEW DELHI: Warning Pakistan that India reserves the right to pre-emptively strike at cross-border sources of terror if it does not stop state-sponsored terrorism, the country’s new military brass on Tuesday said the armed forces are in a high state of operational readiness and better prepared to tackle the challenges on the western and eastern fronts now.

“Yes, we are better prepared,” said the country’s first chief of defence staff General Bipin Rawat . New Army chief General Manoj Mukund Naravane , in turn, said his force is “fully prepared to meet any eventuality” along the volatile Line of Control with Pakistan, which has witnessed as many as 3,200 ceasefire violations this year to beat all annual records since 2003.

A graded strategy of “resolute punitive responses” is in place to punish cross-border terrorism, said Gen Naravane, who took over as the 28th Army chief from Gen Rawat on Tuesday. “We are aware there are terrorists on the other side in various launchpads waiting to cross over but we are fully prepared to meet this threat. We have strong counter-infiltration and counter-terrorism grids, which we keep modifying as per the inputs that we receive,” he said, talking to news agencies.

“Our neighbour uses terrorism as tool of state policy, as a way of carrying out proxy war against us, while maintaining deniability. However, this state can’t last long. As they say, you can't fool all the people, all the time,” he added.

The Army chief also said the Pakistan Army-ISI combine’s relentless efforts to deflect attention from its state-sponsored terrorism had “totally failed”. There has been “a definite improvement” in the internal security situation in J&K after the abrogation of Article 370 , with the “proxy war” being waged from across the border suffering a major setback due to elimination of terrorists and terror networks. “The incidents of violence in J&K have seen a marked decline, this augurs very well for population of J&K. It’s a step forward towards bringing peace and prosperity to the region,” he said.

The military brass said border tensions with China along the Line of Actual Control had decreased substantially, with the two armies now actively working to reduce and manage troop confrontations after receiving “strategic guidance” from their leaders following the Wuhan summit in April 2018.

While India will continue to build its capabilities and infrastructure along the “northern borders” with China, the post-Wuhan guidelines had been disseminated right down the chain of command to the battalion-level to maintain peace and tranquility on the LAC, said Gen Naravane.

Title: CAA stir: Held ‘mistakenly’, 4 UP men spend 11 days in jail
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

CAA protest in Muzaffarnagar (file photo)

MUZAFFARNAGAR: After spending 11 days in jail, a government clerk and three other men who were “mistakenly” picked up by Muzaffarnagar police after December 20 clashes walked free on Tuesday. Over 73 people are in jail for their alleged role in clashes and arson in Muzaffarnagar. Local police are in the process to identify more “innocent” people it has put behind bars.

Senior clerk in employment office, Mohammad Farukh, was picked up by police and sent to jail on that evening. His family members approached police with proof of his presence in the office after which Farukh was set free.

Three other men — Ateeq Ahmed, Shoib and Khalid — were also set free after it was found that they were taking their ill relative to a Meerut hospital when the clashes erupted.

Superintendent of police (SP) Satpal Antil said, “After an investigation, it was found that all the four men were not part of the mob. So, by using section 169 of the CrPC (Release of accused when evidence is deficient), all the four men were brought out from the jail.” The SP said a probe into all the cases was on, and no innocent man will be punished. “After the violence, we had detained a large number of people. We are looking into the matter very carefully and all the innocent people will be set free,” SP Antil said, adding, “Family members of accused can approach us if they feel someone was sent to jail mistakenly.”

Recently, Ladakh MP Jamyang Tsering Namgyal has sent a text message to his Muzaffarnagar counterpart Sanjeev Baliyan requesting him to intervene and ensure the release of a youth from Kargil, Mohammed Ali, who was also put behind bars in the district. “I am told that he (Mohammed Ali) was not part of the protest but was picked up by police while he was entering the gate of his hostel. I sincerely request you to please examine personally and may kindly release him urgently,” Ladakh MP Namgyal said in his message to Baliyan.

Confirming it, Baliyan told TOI, “I have received a text message from the Ladakh MP, and I have discussed the matter with the police. Hopefully, the Kargil youth will walk free soon. I have asked the police to ensure that youths who were not involved in the violence do not suffer.”

Mohammed Ali, who is studying in Muzaffarnagar, was captured by police when he was entering the Sadat hostel, where police and protesters clashed. Several students from the hostel were arrested after the violence.

Title: Hope efforts to transform India continue in 2020: PM Modi
Content:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi (file photo)

Lovely compilation! Covers quite a lot of the progress we achieved in 2019. Here is hoping 2020 marks the conti… https://t.co/RyGPpGC8Xx — Narendra Modi (@narendramodi) 1577796327000

NEW DELHI: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Tuesday expressed the hope that the new year would mark continuation of the people-powered efforts to transform India and empower the lives of 130 crore Indians.In a message on the eve of the new year, Modi re-tweeted a video titled “Year 2020 song” about the achievements of 2019 by a Twitter user, NaMo 2.0, on the microblogging site.“Lovely compilation! Covers quite a lot of the progress we achieved in 2019. Here is hoping 2020 marks the continuation of people-powered efforts to transform India and empower the lives of 130 crore Indians,” he tweeted.The video showcases significant achievements of the BJP government, including abrogation of separate status for Jammu & Kashmir , opening of Kartarpur corridor, launch of India’s first semi-high speed train and initiatives against single-use plastics.“2019 was an amazing year for India. We changed things that we thought could never change. We achieved things which we never thought were possible. Here is a small recap... Hope you like it. @narendramodiji,” the user tweeted.It also highlighted air-strikes by Indian Air Force on terror camp at Balakot inside Pakistan after the Pulwama attack, the successful anti-SAT satellite test and the Howdy Modi event in the US.

Title: Bihar: Rain may play spoilsport for New Year revellers today
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

People protects themselves from cold near a bonfire on roadside in Patna on Tuesday

PATNA: After witnessing biting cold conditions over the past few days, Patna and most parts of the state are set to welcome the New Year amid rainy conditions as India Meteorological Department (IMD) on Tuesday issued forecast for rainfall in parts of state from January 1 to 4. Forecast for lightning has also been issued for January 2 and 3.

A Patna Meteorological Centre official said rainfall would occur mainly in southern parts of the state. “Cloud cover is expected to be observed in most parts of the state from the second half on Wednesday, but the showers are likely to remain confined in the southern districts. The intensity of showers will be comparatively higher on January 2 and 3 and it will start subsiding by January 4,” the official added.

The expected showers have been attributed to western disturbances – the weather systems originating from Mediterranean Sea, Red Sea and Caspian Sea – which cause snow and winter rainfalls in northwestern Indian subcontinent.

The official at local Met office said the western disturbance would form a cyclonic circulation over Haryana and trough line over Chhattisgarh and Jharkhand. “This system will lead to rain primarily in Chhattisgarh and Jharkhand and comparatively lower in intensity over Bihar between January 1 and January 3,” he said.

Rains apart, IMD issued forecast for cold wave in Bihar on January 1.

Meanwhile, sub-10 temperatures continued to prevail in the state on Tuesday with minimum temperature in Patna plunging to 5 degrees C. Sabour in Bhagalpur remained the coldest place in Bihar for the second consecutive day with a minimum temperature of 2.6 degrees C.

In its daily weather bulletin issued on Tuesday, Patna Meteorological Centre stated that cold wave condition was observed at a few places and severe cold wave at many places in the state.

The local meteorological centre has issued a forecast for cold day condition in Patna and severe cold day condition in Purnia on Wednesday. Besides, forecast for cold wave condition has been issued for Gaya and Bhagalpur for Wednesday.

Cold day condition is declared when the minimum temperature touches 10 degrees C or low and there is a departure of 4.5-6.4 degrees C in maximum temperature on two consecutive days. Severe cold day, on the other hand, is declared when the minimum temperature touches 10 degrees C or low and there is a departure of more than 6.4 degrees C in maximum temperature.

Cold wave condition, on the other hand, is declared at a place when the normal minimum temperature is 10 degrees Celsius or above but the actual temperature is recorded at seven degrees C or lower.

Title: Don’t allow NPR in Bihar: Tejashwi Prasad Yadav
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Tejashwi Prasad Yadav

PATNA: Leader of opposition in the state assembly Tejashwi Prasad Yadav on Tuesday asked chief minister Nitish Kumar not to allow National Population Register (NPR) in the state till Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) was repealed.

The Union cabinet had on January 24 approved funds for updating NPR and the exercise in this regard is to commence from April this year. Tejashwi tweeted, “Assuming turncoat, rudderless, fickle Nitish has an ounce of intent to not to implement NRC in Bihar , he must order suspension of preparation of national population register (NPR) with immediate effect until this unconstitutional law of #CAA is repealed! Walk the talk Mr CM! (sic).”

Even a day before, AIMIM chief Asaduddin Owaisi, while addressing a rally against CAA and NPR in Kishanganj, had asked Nitish to pass an order against NPR and severe his ties with BJP.

When asked to comment, JD(U) national spokesperson KC Tyagi told TOI on Tuesday that the central government should clear the confusion of each and every person regarding NPR. “There are various talks going on about NPR and some are saying it is linked with NRC. This has also been said in Parliament earlier that NPR is the first step towards NRC. Now it is the government’s (central) job to clear these doubts. They must come very categorically to denounce all such statements,” Tyagi said. He also said his party will study NPR in detail and find out its probable impact on society.

But Tyagi rapped Tejashwi and said the RJD leader had little knowledge about Parliament functioning. “Once CAA has become a law, how can it be repealed? Also, can JD(U) do it single-handedly. It is very much clear that CAA is irrelevant without NRC and our chief minister Nitish Kumar has made it clear that there was no question of implementing NRC in Bihar. Tejashwi is uselessly raising this issue. If he (Tejashwi) gets the mandate and comes to power, let him repeal it,” Tyagi added.

Title: Bihar: Rajapakar BDO arrested for accepting Rs 1 lakh bribe
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: The sleuths of the Vigilance Investigation Bureau (VIB) arrested the BDO of Rajapakar block in Vaishali district Rajiv Ranjan on Tuesday on charges of accepting Rs1 lakh as bribe from a local resident for providing him documents pertaining to PACS election.

A team of bureau officials from the headquarters led by DSP Sarvesh Kumar Singh raided the office premises of the BDO at Rajapakar following a complaint lodged by Purushottam Kumar, a resident of Birnalakhan village under Mahua sub-division in Vaishali district.

The BDO was caught red handed while accepting Rs1 lakh as bribe from the complainant in the office. Rajiv Kumar, stated to be the husband of the mukhiya of Bakarpur panchayat, who was present in the BDO’s office at the time of the operation, was taken into custody by the bureau team for interrogation.

Both the BDO and the mukhiya’s husband were subsequently taken to Muzaffarpur. Earlier, Purushottam had lodged a complaint with the bureau office alleging that the BDO was demanding Rs 2 lakh as bribe for providing him documents related to PACS election.

The allegations against the BDO were found to be true during preliminary investigation. On Tuesday, a trap team led by DSP Singh carried out the raid at the BDO office and nabbed him soon after he accepted the bribe.

The money was seized from the BDO’s possession. Sources said that the mukhiya’s husband, Rajiv, had played an important role in finalizing the deal between the BDO and the complainant of the case. “Both the BDO and the mukhiya’s husband were being questioned by a team of officials in Muzaffarpur,” a senior bureau officer said in Patna.

He said the accused would be produced in the special vigilance court in Muzaffarpur after interrogation.

Title: Fun, frolic mark New Year Eve celebrations in Patna
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Patnaites celebrate New year at private hotel in Patna on Tuesday

PATNA: From starting the day with worshipping the God to spending the afternoon at parks, zoo and movie theatres and concluding the day at DJ nights and parties, people in the city entered the New Year in the most happening way.

Thousands of people geared up at city’s major hotspots to ring in the New Year at midnight.

With hotels, clubs, restaurants and coffee shops illuminated with lights, the city saw colours of the New Year on Tuesday. The major hotspots arranged for food, dance and music for the revellers, who were seen dancing to the tones Bollywood and Bhojpuri numbers. Many celebrities, including singers and dancers, too joined the New Year’s Eve fun .

“I had an amazing New Year’s party after ages. I attended a DJ night at a private hotel in the city,” said Ankush Verma, a resident of Mandiri.

Major restaurants, eateries and coffee shops offered mouth-watering delicacies to the people. Vishal Sharma, owner of a restaurant on Boring Road, said, “More than 150 people visited my restaurant on Tuesday. The rush increased between 8pm and 11pm.”

Over 1,000 police personnel were deployed in the city to avoid any untoward incident. “Special patrolling teams were deployed at hangouts and crowd points,” said Patna SSP Garima Malik.

Many people also organized private parties and celebrated New Year’s Eve by dancing, singing and eating with their family and friends.

“I took my son to the zoo on Tuesday. At night, I hosted a party for my friends and family and kickstarted New Year with utmost enthusiasm,” said Radhika Sharma, a resident of Boring Road.

Title: 29,387 criminal cases pending in 13 Haryana districts
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

CHANDIGARH: With Faridabad and Gurugram districts topping the chart, as many as 29,387 cases are pending investigations in the police stations of 13 districts of Haryana.

The list includes 2,484 year-old cases, while 1,139 cases are found to be pending investigations. The number of cases pending for past six months is 3,485. Upset over the figure of pendency of cases, Haryana home minister Anil Vij has sought explanation from the superintendents of police (SPs) and deputy commissioners of police (DCPs) of the concerned districts.

In a communication to SPs last week, the minister had sought explanation by January 10, sources said. The minister claimed to have resorted to this after he had been receiving the complaints related to inaction in the cases registered at various police station.

He had been getting nearly 200 complaints every day related to police department, largely related to highhandedness of police or inaction in registered cases. “We have just started the process. Let the SHO or investigating officer explain through SP the reasons of pendency. Any kind of lapse on the part of police department will certainly attract the action,” said the home minister.

Apart from Faridabad and Gurugram, Yamuanangar, Kuruskhetra, Panipat, Hisar, Sirsa, Jind, Fatehabad, Rohtak, Sonpiat and Bhiwani and Karnal are the districts with maximum number of pending cases.

According to information, Gurugram had 3,329 cases pending, followed by Faridabad at 3,271 cases. CM’s district Karnal is third with 1,905 cases, while Yamunanagar and Jind are on fourth and fifth place with 1,813 and 1,475 cases pending.

Title: Big co-operative banks to have management board
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

(File photo)

MUMBAI: The Reserve Bank on India ( RBI ) on Tuesday asked all urban co-operative banks (UCBs) with deposits of over Rs 100 crore to constitute a board of management (BoM) comprising experts to oversee their functioning which in turn will report to its board of directors (BoD).

The RBI also said that these banks should have a BoM for seeking approval to expand their area of operation and also open new branches. It also said that large UCBs should obtain prior approval of the RBI for appointment of their CEOs.

The change in rules came against the backdrop of a scam at the city-based PMC Bank that had over nine lakh depositors. The establishment of a BoM in addition to a BoD is aimed at separating the executive and supervisory roles in an UCB. Earlier, all these roles were vested with the BoD. “Since UCBs are accepting public deposits, it is imperative that a separate mechanism be put in place to protect the interests of depositors,” the RBI said in a circular.

The RBI asked all UCBs to constitute a BoM under the directions of its BoD within a year. A BoM should have a minimum of five members, excluding the CEO, and a maximum of 12 members. The CEO would be a non-voting member in the BoM. “The BoM shall exercise oversight over the banking related functions of the UCBs, assist the BoD on formulation of the policy and any other related matters specifically delegated to it by the BoD for proper functioning of the bank,” the circular said.

The guidelines also stipulate that the central bank will have powers to remove any member of BoM, including the CEO if the person is found to be not meeting the criteria prescribed by it or acting in a manner detrimental to the interests of the bank or its depositors or both.

Title: Axis Bank appoints risk, banking ops heads
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

(File photo)

MUMBAI: Axis Bank has appointed Naveen Tahilyani as group executive — head (banking operations and transformation) — with effect from January 6. It has also named Amit Talgeri as the chief risk officer (CRO) of the bank for three years from January 1.

“Cyril Anand, the incumbent CRO will retire from the services of the bank, from close December 31, 2019,” Axis Bank said in a statement. Tahilyani will take charge of the position to lead operations, technology, strategy and analytics from January 6, 2020, it said.

Talgeri has been a banker in the Middle East for more than a decade. Before joining Tata AIA, he was a senior partner with management consultancy firm McKinsey & Co. Both Tahilyani and Talgeri will report to the bank’s MD and CEO Amitabh Chaudhry.

Title: Bank credit to industry slips 3.9% in 8 months
Content:
(Representative image)

MUMBAI: Bank credit to industry shrunk by 3.9%, or Rs 1.13 lakh crore, during the first eight months of the current financial year, according to data released by the Reserve Bank of India ( RBI ). Despite this, overall bank credit continues to be up 1% largely due to home loans and other personal loans.According to bankers, there is no fresh demand for bank credit for investment. At the same time, several corporates are trying to improve their financial position by deleveraging. This has partly been facilitated by reduction in corporate taxes and stake sales by some companies. As a result, bank credit to industry, which was Rs 28.85 lakh crore as of end March 2019, has fallen to Rs 27.7 lakh crore as on November 22, 2019.The biggest accretion to the bank’s loan books came from mortgages that grew by Rs 1.14 lakh crore to Rs 12.7 lakh crore. While overall loans in the personal segment (including home loans) grew 8.3% to Rs 24 lakh crore, contraction was seen in consumer loans, loans against FDs and shares.According to Soumya Kanti Ghosh , group chief economic adviser at SBI , there is indication that consumers are also reducing their borrowing. “During April-November 2019, the consumer leverage increased only marginally to Rs 65,337 crore as against Rs 62,886 crore during the corresponding period in previous fiscal. This means that consumer demand will continue to remain depressed till the time consumer leverage declines to comfortable levels,” he said.He added that a rate cut will, therefore, be unlikely to help arrest the current downturn and only a proactive fiscal policy could facilitate growth.

Title: Counting tables increased to 1,182 in Madurai
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: The number of counting tables has been increased to 1,182 for counting of votes in the 13 unions where the local body polls were held on December 27 and 30. Election officials said that there were around 1,050 tables for the counting in these unions during the previous local body polls in 2011. The increase is to expedite declaration of results despite the tedious process of manual counting on Thursday (January 2).

It is learnt that in 2011, results for Thiruparankundram union were declared only the next day at 11.30 am after counting commenced. This is because of high number of electors in the union. There was similar delay in Melur union too. The 1,182 tables will be spread across 13 locations where ballot papers will be opened for counting. It includes the primary segregation tables and counting tables.

“A total of 3,965 officials will be involved in the counting process,” additional director (panchayat) A Chelladurai said. Votes will be first segregated for the panchayat ward member, panchayat president, union ward member and district ward member and will be tallied against the total votes polled. These ballot papers will then be taken to the respective tables for counting.

On the instructions of district collector and electoral officer T G Vinay, as many as 476 CCTV cameras have been installed at the counting halls for uninterrupted monitoring of the entire counting process and to avert confusions or clashes.

Fire tenders have been stationed at all the 13 counting centre. Heavy duty generators have also been kept ready at the counting centres for uninterrupted power supply. Barricades and metal meshes have been installed at counting centres to separate the counting officials from candidates and their agents. Police have stepped up security arrangements at the strong rooms and counting centres.

Kanyakumari district electoral officer Prashant M Wadnere expressed confidence that counting in Melpuram Union – the only union where EVMs were used for the local body polls in the state as a pilot project – will be completed way ahead of the other counting centres in the state. He said the votes polled in the 114 booths will be conducted in nine tables in 13 rounds.

“Counting in the EVMs will be done in three halls at three tables. Officials will first count and display votes polled for the panchayat ward member, followed by panchayat president, union ward member and district ward member. Once the counting is completed for the panchayat ward member and president in each table they will leave the room to give way for the candidates from other localities,” he said.

Title: A 5-year low: Fewer individual investors backed startups in 2019
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Chennai: As investible cash dried up due to economic slowdown, fewer number of new individual investors backed startups in 2019.

This comes at a time when PE/VC investments in startups were at record highs of $14.5 billion through 1,185 funding rounds as per data from research firm Tracxn.

2019 saw only 372 investors, hitting a 5-year-low since 2015 which saw 385 new investors. Last year, the percentage of first time investors dropped by 8% and the numbers have been seeing a downtrend after the initial jump in 2016, data shows.

Global angel network Keiretsu Forum’s Chennai and Singapore division saw 6 new investors join in 2019, while only 3 wrote cheques. In 2018, five new joined the network, but all had cut cheques for investments.

The forum’s co-president Rajan Srikanth said, “This clearly was a rough year with election uncertainty in the first part, and market volatility in the second. New angels may have been unsure of their own ability to evaluate deals, and probably were spooked a little by the hesitation they saw even from other more seasoned angels.”

Sanjay Swamy, managing partner, Prime Venture Partners said that the ecosystem was seeing fewer members for late stage investments.

“For series B and above, we need more investors coming on board even as the system continues to see new names among angel and early stage investors,” he said.

Market observers add that after the peak in 2018 — which saw an influx of foreign investors and new additions to the Indian funds — potential investors are taking a step back. “Besides, a lot of PE/VC funds raised capital in 2018 and are deploying them this year. It could be another reason to see a drop in the number of first time investors this year. And since the fundraising cycle happens roughly every 3 years, we would see fewer first time investors next year as well,” said Arun Natarajan, managing director, Venture Intelligence. The research firm also saw a similar drop in the number of first-time investors.

Title: Sterling Solar promoters repay Rs 1k cr
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Reeba Zachariah | TNN

Mumbai: Sterling and Wilson Solar said on Tuesday that its promoters — Shapoorji Pallonji and Company (SPCL) and Khurshed Daruvala — have repaid Rs 1,000 crore they owed to the firm. December 31 was the deadline for the promoters to repay part of their dues to Sterling Solar , the world’s largest engineering contractor of solar farms. The promoters now have to clear a balance of Rs 1,644 crore, which they intend to settle in a staggered manner by September 30, 2020.

The Rs 1,000-crore was used to retire the company’s debt, Daruvala, chairman of Sterling and Wilson Solar told TOI.

Another Rs 408-crore cash, which was generated by the company in the last five months, was used for the same purpose, he added. Sterling Solar now has a debt of Rs 1,440 crore, Daruvala said. SPCL’s financial challenges came to the fore in November when it sought time to repay dues it owed to Sterling Solar. It then raised Rs 742 crore by selling 37 lakh shares of TCS in two tranches in the open market. The company now holds 19.7 lakh TCS shares, representing 0.05% of the software giant’s equity.

SPCL had sought time to meet its financial obligations as it, like other real estate and infrastructure players, has been impacted by the liquidity crisis triggered by the collapse of IL&FS. This coupled with low realisation from Sterling Solar’s offer for sale (OFS) issue left the promoters in a spot.

Though Sterling Solar has low working capital requirements, the payment delay by promoters impacted the company’s share price. On Tuesday, Sterling Solar closed at Rs 324 on the NSE, up by 3%.

Title: Lakshmi Vilas Bank CFO S Sundar resigns
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Chennai: Lakshmi Vilas Bank’s chief financial officer S Sundar, who was appointed on a two-year contract ending April, 27, 2020, has resigned from the position on Tuesday. “I have resigned due to administrative reasons,” S Sundar told TOI.

“I cannot comment anything on this matter till tomorrow,” he said, even as there was speculation that he could be elevated as the CEO of the bank. Sundar said, “At the end of the day, I was discharging the duty of MD also, besides the COD who discharged his duty. With regard to any information on the next MD and CEO, one has to wait till tomorrow.” The troubled private sector bank had seen multiple exits since August. The bank’s board in a filing to exchanges said, “The resignation letter was placed before the Board Meeting held today and the Board has accepted the same.” In September, the banking watch dog, RBI had initiated prompt corrective action on LVB which imposes restrictions on lending and other operations.

Title: Fear of failure can freeze innovative ideas, progress
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

By Paul Dupuis

He was fired from the Kansas City Star with an editor’s scathing remark that he “lacked imagination and had no good ideas” as an animator. Unfazed, this young man bought an animation studio Laugh-O-Gram, but that had to fold up too.

Another young man faced the disappointment of being the only one of 24 applicants who failed to get a job at KFC. Neither could he get into Harvard in all the 10 times he applied. And his first two ventures met with failure. Do these stories spell failure? Seemingly so. But they were precursors to game-changing success — and both the young men went on to become iconic business leaders in their respective industries. The first was none other than Walt Disney, whose animation films and studios created and defined a genre. The second is Jack Ma, whose blockbuster e-commerce company Alibaba’s $150-billion IPO was the largest offering for a US-listed company in the history of the New York Stock Exchange.

There are many examples of leaders who experienced failure as a positive element in their saga of success. Their stories stand as testimonials to the fine line that waits to be stepped over between failure and success — the tipping point, you could call it.

Failing matters, if it creates value

Successful leaders know this profound truth only too well. The greatest failure lies not in the errors we make, but in fearing and assiduously avoiding the path of risk and possible errors. Here is an immense opportunity and potential to path-breaking success — do not limit yourself by a blinding apprehension of challenges in breaking the mould. Michael Jordan knew what he was saying when he asserted, “I’ve failed over and over and over again in my life. And that is why I succeed.”

Assuredly, errors are integral to taking calculated risks. They are the result of out-of-the-box thinking to achieve unprecedented outcomes. They throw amazing insights into how to forge ahead as leaders. Because, success is not measured by how rarely you make mistakes — it is measured by how high you dare to set the bar and persevere to vault it.

Break free of a culture that only rewards perfectionism and penalises intelligent risk-taking when it fails. For this deters us from innovative thinking, looking ahead and moving forward. The value of failing is that it positively focuses on the upbeat excitement of trying and creating game-changing outcomes, and weans us away from the fear of failure that paralyses progress.

But beware: Failure is not always an honourable excuse

It is a paradox one cannot deny. Understanding success needs you to know failure. However, it is a trap too — the idealising failure as a ‘must have’ for success. It is one thing to take the stigma out of failure, and present it as an opportunity to transcend and transform. But it is quite another to treat it as a thoughtless badge of honour.

Of course, there are valuable lessons to be learnt from failure when we encounter them. But glorifying them makes us impervious to learning the more important lessons from the successes we achieve. For success is the reward for the meticulous diligence we demonstrate, and we need to define, plan and intelligently chip away at obstacles to achieve it. Hone your plans, skills, capabilities and execution for success, and build in how you will manage the odd failures to reach your goal.

And here is the true tipping point. Resilience in handling failure is a great attribute. But let us not fall into the comfort zone of exploiting it as an ultimate shield of emotional wallow. Let us aim to be gritty in handling failure, but let us primarily be smarter in planning for success with innovative and well-reasoned risks. Have a razor-sharp focus on success, but without the fear of failure.

In achieving our vision and goal, we have a choice. One is to wade through mistakes, and re-invent the wheel by trial and error. But here is a better option. Pursue your thirst for exploration and discovery. Tap into success factors of people who have cleared the thickets before us.

Imagine the great opportunity to smartly accelerate our journey into the exciting realms of the unknown. And this is what Sir Isaac Newton sums up beautifully in his classic quote, “If I have seen further, it is by standing on the shoulders of giants.”

(The writer is MD & CEO, Randstad India )

Title: Cop crushed to death by liquor-laden SUV in Bihar
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: A police constable was crushed to death by a liquor-laden SUV on national highway-28 near Salona under the Barauli police station area in Gopalganj district early on Tuesday morning. The driver of the SUV, who hailed from Haryana , also died as the vehicle hit a speeding container while he was trying to flee from the spot.

Police seized a motorcycle of deceased constable Manoranjan Kumar and the SUV from the spot and sent the bodies for postmortem. A liquor smuggler, who was also travelling in the SUV, suffered serious injuries in the incident. He is undergoing treatment at the Gopalganj sadar hospital where his condition is stated to be critical.

The incident occurred around 5.30am when the SUV moving towards Muzaffarpur from Gopalganj hit the constable’s motorcycle having official logo of the police department on suspicion that he was following the car. The constable, who received multiple injuries, died on the spot.

The driver of the SUV, Sahil, then hit a container coming from opposition direction in a bid to flee from the site of occurrence and received serious injuries in the process. He also died on the spot.

SHO of Barauli police station Ritesh Mishra said the constable was on way to Masarakh in Chhapra from Gopalganj on his motorbike after delivering official letters. A native of Barharia village under the Masarakh police station in Saran district, the deceased constable was posted in Nawada .

The driver of the SUV was a resident of Khanpur Kala in Haryana’s Sonipat district. The identity of the injured is yet to be ascertained. “Locals, who had gathered in large number after the accident, took away the bottles of liquor from the SUV,” the SHO said.

The body of the constable was handed over to the family after guard of honour at the police lines. Gopalganj SP Manoj Kumar Tiwari said the police have lodged an FIR against the driver of the SUV. “The consignment of liquor booked from Haryana was to be delivered to a bootlegger in Muzaffarpur district,” the SP added.

Title: Rainbasera service charge waived in Gaya
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

GAYA: Gaya district administration has waived off the Rs 15 service charge for availing ‘ rainbasera ’ or night shelter services for the poor and other shelter seekers in view of the extreme cold conditions prevailing in the district.

There are seven night shelters in the Gaya Municipal Corporation area with a capacity of 250 beds, which can be doubled in times of emergency by arranging beds on the floor also. District magistrate Abhishek Singh said that apart from waiving off the service charge, the district administration has also distributed around 1600 blankets among the needy. “The distribution has been made randomly to those found shivering in the streets,” Singh said.

He added, “Circle officers have been directed to arrange bonfire in their respective blocks. Altogether 64 bonfires have been arranged in the Gaya Municipal Corporation area. Bonfires have also been arranged at some important places like Gaya railway station and Rai Kashinath More. Bonfires have also been arranged at 15 points in Bodh Gaya Nagar Panchayat and Tekari Nagar Panchayat areas and 10 points under the Sherghati Nagar Panchayat area.”

The DM also said that all schools in the district upto Class XII have been closed till January 5, 2020, even though no report of any cold-related death has been received from any part of the district so far.

Meanwhile, marginal increase in mercury in the night and sunshine in the day brought the much-needed relief to the people. According to India Metereological Department (IMD), as against the minimum temperature of 2.4 degrees Celsius recorded on Monday morning, the minimum temperature recorded on Tuesday was 3.9 degrees Celsius.

Title: Bihar: Rs 69 crore for extension of R Block-Digha Road
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

R-Block-Digha road construction in progress at Patna (File Photo)

PATNA: The state cabinet on Tuesday approved Rs 69.55 crore for the extension of R Block-Digha Road. The extended road will be 1.3km long and connect R Block-Digha road to the Ganga Pathway. The R Block-Digha Road was earlier supposed to be constructed up to Bankipore-Danapur road only.

Briefing media after the cabinet meeting, state road construction department principal secretary Amrit Lal Meena said the extended road will be connected through an elevated flyover. This will be the fourth flyover on this road. He also said construction work on this part of the road will be completed by August 15 this year.

In another proposal of the road construction department, the cabinet gave administrative approval of Rs236.65 crore for strengthening, widening and constructing the road between Noorsarai and Silao as per the revised estimate. Meena said this road was supposed to be seven metres wide, but now its width will be 10 metres. Two bypass roads will also be constructed for better and faster connectivity between Patna and Rajgir.

The cabinet also gave its approval for taking advance of Rs19.40 crore from Bihar contingency fund for the upcoming human chain event scheduled for January 19. The human chain will be formed across the state from 11:30am to 12 noon in support of the Jal-Jivan-Hariyali campaign of the Nitish Kumar government, and to sensitize people against child marriage and dowry. It was an education department’s proposal.

The cabinet approved the dismissal of 16 doctors who were found missing from their duty at public health centres for a long time. Altogether 21 agendas got the cabinet nod on the last day of the year.

Meanwhile, the state government has decided to celebrate the birth anniversary of former Union finance minister Arun Jaitley as state function on December 28 every year. Though this was announced by chief minister Nitish Kumar a few days after Jaitley’s death in August this year, the cabinet approved it on Tuesday. On December 28, Nitish unveiled life-size statue of Jaitley at a park in Kankarbagh area of the state capital. Jaitley’s wife Sangeeta Jaitley and their children were present during the event.

Title: Loan default: CBI raid on Rayapati
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

VIJAYAWADA: The CBI on Tuesday conducted simultaneous searches on the offices and properties of former MP and TDP leader Rayapati Sambasiva Rao in Guntur and other places. The searches were conducted in connection with alleged disproportionate assets (DA) and also for defaulting on loans from various banks.

According to sources, the raids follow a complaint lodged by a consortium of banks led by Union Bank of India to CBI Banking Securities and Fraud Cell. In its complaint, the consortium alleged that construction firm Transstroy (India) Limited in which Sambasiva Rao allegedly had stakes, had defaulted in repayment of loans of Rs 300 crore. The raids began at around 6.30 am in Hyderabad, Visakhapatnam, Guntur and Vijayawada .

During the raids, sleuths reportedly found details of huge transactions which were diverted to Transstroy Singapore PTE Limited, which is a subsidiary of the company.

“A case has been registered against Transstroy for cheating and criminal misappropriation. Executive members involved in the company had siphoned off around Rs 260 crore which came as a bank loan,” a senior official said.

Sources said that investigation by a six-member team was going on till Tuesday night. The team is looking into all transactional details.

Officials also reportedly found that money was spent in giving costly gifts worth Rs 5 crore which includes a diamond-studded gold saree to the presiding deity of Tiruchanoor temple in Tirupati .

However, officials are yet to confirm if the bank loan which was meant for Transstroy’s business was misused in purchasing them. Other transactions worth Rs 5.28 crore were made from the company’s accounts in purchasing gold and silver articles which once again allegedly strays from the loan’s purpose.

Apart from Sambasiva Rao, company managing director Cherukuri Sridhar and independent non-executive additional director Suryadevara Srinivasa Babji among others were named as the accused. The company was classified as a non-performing asset by the consortium way back in 2013 after Canara Bank audited the firm.

Sambasiva Rao contested the Lok Sabha polls in April this year on a TDP ticket but lost to his YSRCP rival. He was a member of the Lok Sabha four times. He was also a member of the Rajya Sabha for a term. Sambasiva Rao began his political career as a Congress worker and later became an MP on a Congress ticket from Guntur. He left Congress and joined the TDP in protest against bifurcation of Andhra Pradesh in 2014.

Title: Blue chips rally, but smaller companies lag
Content:
(Representative image)

MUMBAI: The year 2019 will be remembered as a period when, although the two benchmark indices sensex and Nifty performed well and showed a low double-digit gain, not many retail investors made money. It will also be remembered as the year when both the sensex and Nifty rallied even as the country’s GDP growth rate went southward.Consider this: During 2019, sensex gained 14.4%, while the Nifty gained 12%, the broader BSE100 index was up 9.6% and BSE500 was up 7.8%. The gains in the sensex and the Nifty came despite a severe slide in the country’s economic growth rate, from 6.6% during July-September 2018 to 4.5% in July-September 2019.Data show that other than the promoters, institutions — foreign as well as domestic — hold large chunks of blue chips, while retail investors have large holdings in companies that are outside of the 50 companies that comprise the Nifty index. Since the sensex and the Nifty have outperformed the broader indices, it could be inferred that while institutional investors made money in 2019, the same can’t be said about retail investors, according to a dealer with a domestic brokerage.Data relating to market capitalisation also strengthens this argument. BSE’s market capitalisation rose from Rs 144.4 lakh crore to Rs 155.2 lakh crore — a jump of Rs 10.8 lakh crore. But in percentage terms, the rise was just 7.5% — almost half the rise in the sensex during the year. Mutual fund data also showed that largecap funds outperformed the mid and smallcap funds by a wide margin.However, interestingly, long-term debt funds outperformed even the largecap funds. Data also showed that during the year, returns from liquid funds were below their long-term average return.

Title: Majority of startups have less than 10 employees
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

(Representative image)

MUMBAI: Only 14% of startups in India hire 10 employees or more in the first six months of their operations. Even after the business matured, as many as 60% still hired 10 employees or less.

According to a survey of 1,246 startups conducted by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), only 3% of the startups hired more than 100 employees. Over 63% of the respondents also reported plans to hire at least 20 new employees in the next two to three years. These startups were mainly from software development, IT consulting/solution and health sectors, and were less than three years old.

The pilot survey on the startup sector was conducted by the RBI between November 2018 and April 2019. It was aimed at collecting information on select important characteristics of the startup sector. One of the key findings was that 75% of startups were concentrated in five states — Karnataka, Maharashtra, Telangana, Delhi and Tamil Nadu.

The annual turnover for more than a fourth of the respondents was up to Rs 10 lakh, whereas around 20% startups did not report any revenue generation. Less than a fifth of the respondents reported that their turnover exceeded Rs 1 crore. A third of the founders had an academic background in engineering. Most of the founders had professional experience and 7.3% of the founders were still students.

Startups in six sectors — agriculture, data & analytics, education, health, IT consulting/solution and manufacturing — accounted for nearly 50% of the survey respondents. Most of the startups had at least two co-founders.

Nearly 45% cent of the participating startups had at least one female founder. In all, 5.9% cent of the participating startups were founded by only females in comparison to 55.5% by only male founders. The remaining 38.6% of the participating startups had both male and female as co-founders.

Title: Hema panel report confirms ‘casting couch’ in Mollywood
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

ustice Hema commission submits the report to chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan in the capital on Tuesday. Commis... Read More

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Justice Hema commission , constituted to study the issues faced by women in film industry, has asked the state government to introduce a separate law to deal with issues in Malayalam film industry .

Confirming pervasiveness of ‘ casting couch ’ in the industry, commission has submitted a 300-page report to chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan on Tuesday. The commission also attached a set of 1,500-page documents, including screenshots, voice clips and pen drives, as evidences along with the report.

The committee, headed by retired judge of high court Justice K Hema and actor Sharada and former bureaucrat K B Valsala Kumari as members, was constituted in June 2017 based on the petition filed by Women in Cinema Collective (WCC) to the chief minister to study the problems faced by women in Malayalam film industry. WCC met the chief minister following the actor assault case in 2017.

Justice Hema told TOI that the commission has suggested enactment of law to deal with several unique problems faced by the industry. “A separate tribunal should be constituted to hear a wide range of human rights violations in the industry. We came across serious issues such as soliciting sexual favours from aspiring actors for work. Commission has examined various witnesses, both men and women, and taken their statements and evidences. However, we have not mentioned any names in the report in order to ensure that the participants won’t face any harm from the industry,” she said.

A statement from the office of the chief minister said that the report has confirmed the issue of casting couch in cinema. “Several persons had to endure sexual harassment to get work. Most of the victims do not file police complaints,” it said.

Title: At $6.3 billion, current account deficit dips to 0.9% of GDP
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

(File photo)

MUMBAI: The country’s current account deficit (CAD) narrowed to 0.9% of the gross domestic product (GDP) at $6.3 billion in the quarter ended September 2019 as imports slowed down due to lower demand. In the previous fiscal FY19, the CAD was 2.9% of GDP , or $19 billion, in the comparable quarter.

In the current fiscal’s preceding quarter ended June 2019, CAD was 2% of GDP or $14.2 billion. “The contraction in the CAD was primarily on account of a lower trade deficit at $38.1 billion as compared with $50 billion a year ago,” the RBI said in a statement.

India’s current account position is largely on a deficit because of the country’s dependence on oil imports. According to data released by the central bank, the net deficit due to oil imports shrunk to $19.3 billion from $23.5 billion.

The CAD is the difference between foreign exchange inflows and outflows. Private transfer receipts, mainly representing remittances by Indians employed overseas, rose to $21.9 billion, increasing by 5.2% from their level a year ago.

In the financial account, net foreign direct investment was $7.4 billion, almost the same level as in Q2 of 2018-19. Foreign portfolio investment recorded net inflows of $2.5 billion — as against an outflow of $1.6 billion in Q2 of FY19 — because of net purchases in the debt market. Net inflows on account of external commercial borrowings to India was $3.2 billion as compared with $2.0 billion in Q2 of 2018-19.

The balance of payment stood at $5.12 billion in the second quarter and $19.1 billion during the first half of this fiscal. The net inflow on account of external commercial borrowings to the country was $3.2 billion in the second quarter as compared with $2 billion in corresponding period of the previous financial year.

Title: Companies with Rs 50 crore turnover sans e-pay option to be fined
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

(Representative image)

MUMBAI: Businesses with turnover of Rs 50 crore and above that do not provide digital payment facilities to their customers will be fined Rs 5,000 per day from February 2019, according to a government notification.

In a circular issued on Tuesday, the Central Board of Direct Taxes ( CBDT ) said that with effect from January 1, 2020, businesses must provide the facilities for accepting payment through the prescribed electronic modes. The government and the RBI have already directed banks to waive charges for electronic payments online. The proposal requiring businesses with turnover of Rs 50 crore to provide digital payment platform was mooted by the finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman in the Budget in July 2019.

Subsequently, the Finance Act was amended to include section 271 DB in the Act, which provides for levy of penalty of Rs 5,000 per day in case of failure by the specified person to comply with the provisions of section 269SU.

“In order to allow sufficient time to the specified person to install and operationalise the facility for accepting payment through the prescribed electronic modes, the penalty under section 271 DB of the Act shall not be levied if the specified person installs and operationalises the facilities on or before January 31, 2020,” the circular said.

The government also notified its proposal to waive MDR on payments made through RuPay and Unified Payments Interface (UPI) and UPI QR code from January 1, 2020. Meanwhile the ministry of electronics and information technology said that it was discontinuing a scheme where it reimbursed MDR charges of value up to Rs 2,000 fro transactions made through debit cards, Bhim and Aadhaar pay and on payments up to Rs 1 lakh made to the government.

The department said that as the finance ministry circular has barred MDR charges on RuPay and UPI the MDR reimbursement schemes are being closed from December 31’ 2019.
