Title: 3-day Prakashotsava celebrations begin
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

PATNA: Sikh devotees in large numbers have gathered at the Kangan Ghat tent city for the three-day 353rd Prakashotsava celebrations which began on Tuesday to mark the birth anniversary of tenth and last Sikh Guru Gobind Singh.

From gates bedecked with flowers to pandals illuminated with lights and sounds of hymns and prayers at every nook and corner, the tent city has set a different atmosphere for the devotees.

Spread in an area of 30 acres, the tent city has ‘langar’ halls, bedrooms, VIP lounges, stages and all necessary facilities for the convenience of the devotees.

More than 10,000 pilgrims from across the country and abroad have reached the city for the celebrations. “At least 5,000 devotees have been accommodated at Kangan Ghat tent city and the others at various gurdwaras here. Around 13 government schools are also being used for the stay of pilgrims,” said a member of Takhat Sri Harmandir Sahib Prabhandhak Committee.

Divisional commissioner Sanjay Kumar Agarwal on Tuesday visited Kangan Ghat tent city and inspected the arrangements there. “More than 1,000 police officers from Patna and Vaishali have been deployed in and around the tent city for the safety of pilgrims. Besides, constant monitoring is being done through surveillance cameras,” Agarwal said, adding 27 ambulances have also been arranged for the pilgrims.

All gurdwaras in the city, including Takhat Sri Harmandir Patna Sahib Gurdwara, Gurdwara Sri Gai Ghat Sahib, Guru Ka Bagh Gurdwara and Bal Leela Gurdwara have been decked up with flowers and illuminated with lights.

The Takhat Sri Harmandir Patna Sahib Gurdwara, which is the birthplace of Guru Gobind Singh, witnessed large crowd of devotees throughout the day on Tuesday. “Guru Gobind Singh, the founder of the warrior Sikh community, Khalsa, had hugely contributed to Sikhism,” said M S Dhillon, secretary of Takhat Sri Harmandir Patna Sahib Gurdwara Prabhandhak Committee.

He added that thousands of devotees visited the gurdwara at 4am on Tuesday to participate in ‘badi prabhat pheri’. “More than 10,000 devotees participated in the procession. Apart from devotees, five gatkas performed martial arts. Horses, camels and elephants were the major attractions. The procession originated from Takhat Sri Harimandir Ji Patna Sahib Gurdwara at 4am and culminated there after passing through different areas of the city,” Dhillon said.

Title: House of Mrinal Sen to be sold
Content: It is said one dies twice in life. First, when the heartbeat stops. Then, sometime later, when one’s name is uttered for the last time. On his first death anniversary, when one entered the Padmapukur flat of Mrinal Sen that has been home to 15 years of intellectual brainstorming, it was amply clear that the master-director had well and truly cheated death the second time around even though he had long stopped breathing.This game of hide-and-seek with death actually started some time back when his Chicago-based son and daughter-in-law, Kunal and Nisha, took a unique decision to distribute his belongings and awards among anyone who cared to look after them. The couple does not have children and back in Chicago, they have already made a pact with a group of friends and signed on a living will that allows the “plug to be pulled” if they are in a vegetative state. Living light with a sense of detached attachment is perhaps a conscious choice on their part. “Both Nisha and I know that we are at a die-able age. We might live for another 20 years or so but it’s also a fact that anything can happen any time. Since we live abroad, we are aware that when we die, no one knows how our house will be cleared,” he said.It isn’t difficult to understand the choice when one listens to the couple speak. Sometime back, Left Front chairperson Biman Basu came over and took Sen’s hospital bed that he used at home. It was then given over to the People’s Relief Committee. Berhampore Film Society has taken his telephone and specs for preservation. Some 422 books were picked up by Uttarpara-based archivist Arindam Saha Sardar. A cupboard full of mementos was left ajar for anyone to pick them up while old family acquaintances and young cine-lovers queued up to collect what they will show their grandchildren as their most precious collection. Even the two cots in the master bedroom that were once used by Mrinal and wife Gita awaited a kind soul to pick them up. Three prospective buyers have already had talks about buying the flat but nothing has yet been signed on the dotted line.On Monday evening, Kunal and Nisha sat in the centre of the room where Sen would once sit to watch television while the latter’s acquaintances dropped by to pay their respect to the legend. According to Kunal, maintaining the house in his father’s absence had become a challenge. Once, they returned to find a broken window pane. On another occasion, leakage started from a portion of the damaged ceiling. The third occasion was the most irritating. The couple had just arrived in Kolkata and had quite a lot of soiled clothes. After putting them inside the washing machine, they went out to have food. Shock of their lives awaited them on their return when they found water from the washing machine had flooded the flat and was dripping down the staircase to the third floor! “Though terribly jetlagged, we sat till well past midnight cleaning up the mess by soaking towels in the water!” they recalled.Though the original home was never ostentatious, it wasn’t this minimal either. Only a few chairs remain in the sitting area. Few photographs hang on the wall. The book shelves in the study lie empty. His books have more or less been packed to be sent off to Uttarpara. A grey refrigerator stands tall in the dining area but the wooden table in the centre where the legendary director would occasionally sit in the mornings to glance through the newspaper is missing. The television, which in the last days of his life even screened Bollywood films (earlier on, it was a strict no-no), was still there. And beside it hung a huge sepia-toned photograph of Mrinal — something that Kunal was a little undecided about whom to gift.It was not an overnight decision to dispose off the flat that had been the director’s address for the last 15 years. “I always knew this would happen,” Kunal said. Of course, the flat could have been turned into a museum of sorts. But returning to a half-functional house-turned-museum is not a terribly exciting idea. Since Kunal and Nisha live abroad and chances of their personal supervision on a regular basis are rather slim, there was always the fear of returning to a flat with cobwebs and layers of dust accumulating on precious belongings. “We didn’t want that to happen,” he added, as old-time family acquaintances like Ina Puri and Samik Bandopadhyay dropped by.What made things a little simpler was that the icon had not really left behind too many precious belongings. Years back, while moving apartments, he had disposed most of his papers. Fortunately, the important awards were kept in the locker. “He never kept things in order. Letters would pile up on his desk and the day Ma would start screaming at him, he would just bind all of them with a rope and stack the lot under the bed. This process continued for years. When we had to move apartments, it was impossible for anyone to sort important ones,” Kunal recalled.So, a call went to the Kolkata Municipal Corporation and the then mayor, Subrata Mukherjee, had sent across a truck with two people. “They threw away almost everything, including the scripts. So, this house practically doesn’t have any of those old letters. While throwing away the stuff, someone told him to check a rather big packet that had stuff which made a ‘dhong-dhong’ sound. That packet contained some of his minor awards!”On his last visit to Kolkata, the couple had taken his Padmabhushan, the Silver Bear from Berlin, the French award (Commander of the Ordre des Arts et des Lettres) and an award bestowed on Gita Sen. This time around, they intend to take some others back. “For Chorus, the Russians had given an award shaped as a solid sphere. It was so heavy that when he was given that award, he had literally dropped it. This time, I want to carry that along with a few others,” Kunal said.On his earlier visit, film archivist Shivendra Singh Dungarpur had collected Mrinal’s kurta, pen and chair for his foundation. “On this recent visit, he took film stills and major awards. That includes the Dadasaheb Phalke , Filmfare and many National Awards. Initially, I am taking all the international awards and keeping them with myself. I plan to donate 80% of them right away to University of Chicago and Stanford University. I will keep the rest at home for sometime and subsequently give them away. Four hundred years later, even if someone wants to see them, I am certain that they will be preserved well by these two universities,” Kunal said.Some personal things still remain in the bedroom. His handwritten letters haven’t survived but other communications from the digital age have. “When I thought a communication could be important, I kept a printout of the email,” Kunal said. The exchanges are important but like all printouts, they lack the personal touch. Two “treatments” of films that he never made have survived. Besides, there is a diary of sorts that has details like laundry bills and travel dates. Nisha, meanwhile, has collected his passports and checked the stamps to keep record of where he went when. “I also took some of his books from his collection of 3,000 works. Apart from Arindam, there are others who have taken some 50 more,” he added. What about his starch-white kurtas and shawls? “Some had specifically asked for his shawls and we gave them away. The rest, which could be used, were given away to common people. Nandita (Das) had wanted a shawl and we have kept one for her,” he said. Anything for Shabana Azmi ? “She never asked for anything. It is hard for me to presume who will want anything and I do not want to burden anyone,” he pointed out.There are some letter exchanges that Kunal is personally annotating. “May be, something he had written on a chit of paper. I am currently annotating these. One third of it is done already. Once complete, I will distribute them too.”When dusk settled down, one of Mrinal’s favourite actors — Mamata Shankar — walked in. Nisha ushered her inside and gave her a beautiful white idol of Shiv and Parvati. “Ma used to worship this at home. I have kept it for you. Ma’s puja resulted out of a feeling somewhere in between fear and faith. But Bondhu (Kunal addresses his father that way) would always tease her about it. I am 65 and have always seen this at home,” Kunal said. A visibly moved Shankar added, “This is a huge thing for me. For me, it symbolises Mrinalda and boudi. Amar thakurer ashonei rakhbo…” Later in the evening, actor Dhritiman Chaterji dropped by as well to share memories.Giving away personal belongings isn’t easy. More so, if one has to relinquish the rights of inheritance and willingly turn personal possessions into public property. “These are personal threads. I know now my connection with my parents will be at a conceptual level. I tried to take a long perspective and see if some of the materials will be available hundreds of years from now for scholarly research. I don’t know if there will be any interest in him in even 50 years, but I’d rather the future decide that. I think what we are doing is probably what my parents would have liked us to do. Neither of them liked pomp and show nor any fuss around them,” said Kunal. But by donating these to one and all, Kunal has given strangers a chance to create personal memories of the master. The hospital bed that might be used by a patient who perhaps had no connection whatsoever with Mrinal and his movies, the Shiv Parvati idol that will get a pride of position in Shankar’s puja room, the mementos that will now sit pretty on some cine-lover’s drawing room will ensure that his name continues to resonate, cheating death forever.

Title: 2 brothers among 4 killed in accidents
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Karnal/Jind: Two brothers were killed after a tractor hit their motorcycle near Baldi bybass in Karnal on Monday evening. While one died on the spot, the other succumbed to his injuries in a hospital hours later.

The deceased have been identified as Vikas (23) and his younger brother Vishal (21), both residents of Kalri Khalsa village in Indri sub-division of Karnal district.

According to information, Vikas and Vishal, who worked in Karnal municipal corporation office, were returning to their village after work on the bike when a tractor coming from the opposite direction hit them on the national highway. Vishal died on the spot, while Vikas died during treatment at Kalpana Chawla Government Medical College and Hospital.

Model Town police post in-charge Satpal Singh said they have registered a case against the tractor driver, who fled from the spot after abandoning the vehicle, for causing death due to rash and negligent driving. “We have seized the tractor and the driver will be arrested soon. Bodies of both deceased have been handed over to the family after autopsy,” he said.

Meanwhile, a 60-year-old man was killed in a road accident in Jind district on Tuesday. Prakash Singh, a native of Aprahi Colony in Jind, was heading home on his bicycle in the evening, when he lost control and fell on the road near a hospital on Rohtak road. He was crushed under the wheels of a tractor-trailer coming from the opposite side.

In another accident, Ganga Shah was killed near Jhanj Kalan village after a car rammed into his scooter on Tuesday. Shah, who was a motor pump attendant in the Jind sugar mill, was heading for duty when the accident occured. Sadar police have booked the car driver for causing death due to negligence.

Title: Man arrested for killing his pregnant daughter
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Varanasi: Police on Tuesday arrested one person for killing his own 18-year-old daughter with the help of her lover on December 17 in Kotwali Dehat area of Mirzapur district. The accused identified as Rajaram Yadav confessed that he killed his pregnant daughter fearing dishonor in the society.

According to reports, the body of an unidentified girl was found in a well in Chindlikh Dubey village on December 18. The body was cremated by the police after postmortem on December 22. An FIR was registered in this regard under sections 302 (murder) and 201 (causing disappearance of evidence of offence) of IPC against unidentified persons.

During investigation, it came to light that the girl was the daughter of Rajaram Yadav, a resident of Jasovar village.

Acting on a tip off the police succeeded in nabbing him on Tuesday. Mirzapur SP said during interrogation, Yadav revealed that he killed his daughter with the help of her lover, Rakesh Sonkar of Chausa village and dumped the body in an abandoned well. According to him, the girl had an affair with Rakesh for some time. On knowing that the girl became pregnant, Yadav threatened Rakesh of lodging a case of rape and POCSO Act if he did not bring her back. When Rakesh came with the girl, Yadav again threatened him for lodging case if he did not help him killing the girl. Later, they strangulated the girl and mutilated her face with stones.

Police also recovered the stones used in crime. A manhunt has been launched to nab Rakesh.

Title: All is well between JD(U) and BJP: CM Nitish Kumar
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

CM Nitish Kumar

PATNA: CM Nitish Kumar on Tuesday tried to ward off speculations about a growing conflict with ally BJP and said, “Sab theek hai ( all is well ).”

Nitish’s remark came just an hour after his party’s senior leader and poll strategist Prashant Kishor made a frontal attack on senior BJP leader and deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi . “Modi became deputy CM by virtue of circumstances despite his party’s defeat in 2015 elections,” Kishor tweeted.

Journalists sought Nitish’s reaction on the growing differences between his party and BJP over Kishor’s recent assertion that JD(U) must be given larger number of seats in the coming state assembly election due this year because it is a bigger party (than the BJP) in Bihar and the state election would be contested on the face value of Nitish.

Trouble between the two NDA allies began on Sunday after Kishor told media persons that since the assembly election will be contested on the face of Nitish, hence the ratio of seat sharing between BJP and JD(U) cannot be 1:1. “The basis of seat-sharing talks between BJP and JD(U) should be 1:1.4 or may be 1:1.3,” he said.

Kishor has raised his voice against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act despite JD(U) backing the bill in Parliament and the proposed National Register of Citizens (NRC).

Though Nitish claims all is fine in the NDA, political pundits have started analysing the sudden developments, especially after Jharkhand election results. “The way PK is attacking the Centre on every consecutive day indicates that he is doing it out of some well-planned strategy,” said N K Choudhary, social scientist and former head of economics department at Patna University. “I believe PK is speaking Nitish’s words as the latter is trying to extract the outcome of possible political churning and finalize the seat- sharing with the BJP much to his interest as early as possible, as he did it before the 2019 general elections,” he said.

Nevertheless, reacting over Kishor’s argument on seat-sharing, Sushil Modi on Monday made a stinging remark while reminding him of “his business of collating political data and coining slogans”. Modi tweeted on Monday: “There is no problem in seat sharing. But those who have entered politics not driven by ideology but while engaged in the ‘business of collating political data and coining slogans’ are making utterances in violation of ‘gathbandhan dharma’ and benefiting the opposition’s alliance in the bargain. --- A person engaged in a profitmaking business first prepares his market for his service, he thinks about the interest of country in later stage (sic).”

Kishor’s statement has also been criticized within his party. “Two things are clear about the 2020 polls. First, election will be fought under the leadership of Nitish Babu. Second, seat sharing is not something that will be decided in full media glare,” JD(U) general secretary (Organisation) RCP Singh said on Monday at Manpur in Gaya district, while voicing disapproval of Kishor’s statement.

BJP state president Sanjay Jaiswal has also questioned Kishor. “The seat-sharing issue will be decided by the top leadership of both the parties. Is Kishor the party president of JD(U)? Who is he?” Jaiswal told reporters on Monday.

Title: Majority of startups have less than 10 employees
Content:
(Representative image)

MUMBAI: Only 14% of startups in India hire 10 employees or more in the first six months of their operations. Even after the business matured, as many as 60% still hired 10 employees or less.According to a survey of 1,246 startups conducted by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), only 3% of the startups hired more than 100 employees. Over 63% of the respondents also reported plans to hire at least 20 new employees in the next two to three years. These startups were mainly from software development, IT consulting/solution and health sectors, and were less than three years old.The pilot survey on the startup sector was conducted by the RBI between November 2018 and April 2019. It was aimed at collecting information on select important characteristics of the startup sector. One of the key findings was that 75% of startups were concentrated in five states — Karnataka, Maharashtra, Telangana, Delhi and Tamil Nadu.The annual turnover for more than a fourth of the respondents was up to Rs 10 lakh, whereas around 20% startups did not report any revenue generation. Less than a fifth of the respondents reported that their turnover exceeded Rs 1 crore. A third of the founders had an academic background in engineering. Most of the founders had professional experience and 7.3% of the founders were still students.Startups in six sectors — agriculture, data & analytics, education, health, IT consulting/solution and manufacturing — accounted for nearly 50% of the survey respondents. Most of the startups had at least two co-founders.Nearly 45% cent of the participating startups had at least one female founder. In all, 5.9% cent of the participating startups were founded by only females in comparison to 55.5% by only male founders. The remaining 38.6% of the participating startups had both male and female as co-founders.

Title: Man with ‘towel gun’ loots Rs 9 lakh from Patna bank
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: In a daring, daylight heist, bang in the middle of the state capital, a masked man walked into a public sector bank branch on the bustling Station Road near Patna junction, pointed a gun wrapped in a towel at the cashier, and coolly walked away with Rs 9.12 lakh in cash on Tuesday afternoon.

It took him just two minutes to loot the bank. And, as it turned out, he was perhaps not even carrying a gun. The robber had wrapped a thick towel around his right arm, which the shaken cashier assumed, to be a firearm.

City SP (central) Vinay Tiwary said, “The robber entered the bank at 3.04pm and exited at 3.06pm. Police reached the spot at 3.11pm.”

Patna SSP Garima Malik said that the investigators suspect the masked robber was pretending to carry a gun. “He was spotted putting cash in a bag with both his hands. But there is no evidence of him keeping aside any firearm anywhere in the CCTV footage before stuffing the money in the bag,” said Malik, adding, it appears the robber knew the branch well as he was moving around with familiarity.

Jitendra Kumar, an eye witness, told TOI that the criminal had wrapped a thick towel around his palm and wrist making it difficult to make out if he had a pistol hidden or not.

“Pointing it, he threatened all of us to move inside. His face was covered. There was a power cut when he entered the branch,” Kumar said.

There were at least 25 people, including 15 bank employees, inside the branch when the loot took place. No alarm was activated even after the loot. In addition, the branch has been functioning without any security personnel. With this loot on the last day of the year, the tally of bank loots across the state reached 14, which is the second highest since 2014 and 2015. Maximum 21 bank robbery incidents were reported in 2011.

SSP Malik said the role employees would be investigated as the cashier himself was spotted holding the bag in which the robber was putting in the cash.

Title: No let up in cold, man dies in Jalandhar
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Despite bone-chilling cold, revellers gather at Manali to celebrate New Year’s Eve

CHANDIGARH/SHIMLA: Intense cold continued in Punjab and Haryana on New Year’s Eve, with Narnaul recording the lowest temperature of 2.3 degrees Celsius — three degrees below the normal temperature. Union Territory Chandigarh, the joint capital of two states, recorded a minimum of 4.8 degree C, one notch below normal on Tuesday.

The cold was so severe that in Jalandhar, a man is suspected to have died because of it. He was found dead outside a shutdown factory in Sodhal Nagar area of Jalandhar on Monday. Police have kept his body in the mortuary as the man could not be identified.

According to the meteorological department, parts of Himachal Pradesh recorded freezing temperatures, with the state’s lowest temperature recorded in Keylong at minus 8.2 degrees Celsius. The met office has predicted snowfall and rain in the middle and higher hills of the state from December 31 to January 4. Snowfall is most likely to occur in higher hills of Lahaul-Spiti and Kinnaur districts on December 31 and January 1 whereas in the middle hills of Shimla, Kufri and Manali on January 2 and 3, the director of IMD’s Shimla meteorological centre, the met office said.

But irrespective of the cold, visitors thronged Himchali towns, particularly Manali and Shimla, to usher in their new year. This brought cheer among hoteliers but also traffic jams to the state.

The vehicles from other states, especially from Delhi, Haryana, Punjab, Chandigarh and Uttar Pradesh, made a beeline to Manali that choked roads of not just Kullu-Manali but the whole Kiratpur-Manali highway. The main problem that tourists faced was inadequate parking. Tourists had to drive many kilometers in search of a parking space. Himachal Pradesh police have tightened security arrangements to ensure smooth flow of vehicular traffic and to maintain law and order.

Weather was mainly dry over the state in the last 24 hours with minimum temperatures 1 to 2 degrees below normal.

The MeT office has predicted snowfall and rain in the middle and higher hills of the state from December 31 to January 4.

Shimla recorded 1.2 degrees Celsius and Kalpa in Kinnaur district registered a low of minus 3 degrees Celsius, Kufri, Manali, Solan and Dalhousie shivered at minus 1.8, minus 1.4, minus 0.6 and minus 0.4 degrees Celsius respectively.

Hisar shivered at 4.5 degrees Celsius, Ambala 4.6 degrees Celsius, Rohtak 4.8 degrees Celsius, Sirsa 4.9 degrees Celsius and Karnal at 5 degrees Celsius.

In Punjab, Amritsar, Ludhiana and Patiala braved chill at a low of 3.4, 4.1 and 4.6 degrees Celsius, respectively. Pathankot, Adampur, Bathinda and Halwara recorded their minimums at 3.5, 3.6, 4.2 and 4.6 degrees Celsius, respectively. Dense fog descended at several places, including Patiala, Pathankot and Gurdaspur, reducing visibility.

Title: Kangra forensic lab now ‘electronic evidence examiner’
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Dharamshala: The Union government has authorised the Regional Forensic Science Laboratory (RFSL), Northern Range, Dharamshala, to examine electronic devices, particularly mobiles and hard disks — making it the first in the region to do so. Now, reports of this lab will be admissible for trials across the country. The lab has also qualified the Korean quality parameters of document examinations.

A communication to this effect was sent by the South Korea national forensic institute to the forensic directorate of Himachal Pradesh on December 17. Korean forensic authorities had sent samples for examination to Dharamshala lab on September 9, for which reports were sent on September 30.

Forensics deputy director Dr Meenakshi Mahajan, when contacted, confirmed that the lab has matched the Korean quality parameters and added that the Union ministry of electronics and information technology has also notified it (lab) as an examiner of electronic evidence under Section 79A of the IT Act 2000.

“The lab is the first in the northern part of the country to get notified from the Union government. A notification regarding this has also been issued,” she said.

This lab, which became functional in 2008, caters to Kangra, Chamba and Una districts of Himachal Pradesh.

Title: Kerala: Tribesman’s body tied to pole & carried on shoulders, rights panel seeks report
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Tribesmen carry the body of Soman wrapped in a mat through the forest in Kunjippara.

KOCHI: Kerala State Human Rights Commission ( KSHRC ) has sought a report from the state government over the incident where the tribal people in eastern part of Ernakulam were forced to carry a man’s body around 3km on foot for postmortem in hospital due to the lack of proper roads to their settlement.

The commission registered a suo moto case based on the news reports about the incident. KSHRC chairman Justice Antony Dominic directed the state chief secretary and Ernakulam collector to file a report within three weeks. After receiving the report, the case will be considered during the sitting in Aluva.

The body of the tribesman, Soman (37), who allegedly committed suicide at his house in Kunjippara tribal hamlet in Kuttampuzha in Ernakulam last week, had to be carried on foot by his fellow tribesmen after the inquest by police. The tribesmen had to carry the body on their shoulders after wrapping it in a mat and tying it to a bamboo pole to take it to the nearest road.

District police chief (Ernakulam Rural) K Karthick said that the police reached the hamlet on foot after walking through the forests for kilometres.

“I have enquired about the incident. Electricity supply and road connectivity is yet to reach Kunjippara tribal settlement which is located deep in the forests in Kuttampuzha. Though the inquest was completed, there was no way to bring the body by jeep. Later it was carried on shoulders and taken across a river and shifted to a jeep which took it to the main road where the ambulance was waiting. The body was then taken in the ambulance to the Kothamangalam taluk hospital for autopsy,” he said.

The district collector was not available for the comment.

Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Despite bone-chilling cold, revellers gather at Manali to celebrate New Year’s Eve

According to the meteorological department, parts of Himachal Pradesh recorded freezing temperatures, with the state’s lowest temperature recorded in Keylong at minus 8.2 degrees Celsius. The met office has predicted snowfall and rain in the middle and higher hills of the state from December 31 to January 4. Snowfall is most likely to occur in higher hills of Lahaul-Spiti and Kinnaur districts on December 31 and January 1 whereas in the middle hills of Shimla, Kufri and Manali on January 2 and 3, the director of IMD’s Shimla meteorological centre, the met office said.

But irrespective of the cold, visitors thronged Himchali towns, particularly Manali and Shimla, to usher in their new year. This brought cheer among hoteliers but also traffic jams to the state.

The vehicles from other states, especially from Delhi, Haryana, Punjab, Chandigarh and Uttar Pradesh, made a beeline to Manali that choked roads of not just Kullu-Manali but the whole Kiratpur-Manali highway. The main problem that tourists faced was inadequate parking. Tourists had to drive many kilometers in search of a parking space. Himachal Pradesh police have tightened security arrangements to ensure smooth flow of vehicular traffic and to maintain law and order.

Weather was mainly dry over the state in the last 24 hours with minimum temperatures 1 to 2 degrees below normal.

The MeT office has predicted snowfall and rain in the middle and higher hills of the state from December 31 to January 4.

Shimla recorded 1.2 degrees Celsius and Kalpa in Kinnaur district registered a low of minus 3 degrees Celsius, Kufri, Manali, Solan and Dalhousie shivered at minus 1.8, minus 1.4, minus 0.6 and minus 0.4 degrees Celsius respectively.

Hisar shivered at 4.5 degrees Celsius, Ambala 4.6 degrees Celsius, Rohtak 4.8 degrees Celsius, Sirsa 4.9 degrees Celsius and Karnal at 5 degrees Celsius.

In Punjab, Amritsar, Ludhiana and Patiala braved chill at a low of 3.4, 4.1 and 4.6 degrees Celsius, respectively. Pathankot, Adampur, Bathinda and Halwara recorded their minimums at 3.5, 3.6, 4.2 and 4.6 degrees Celsius, respectively. Dense fog descended at several places, including Patiala, Pathankot and Gurdaspur, reducing visibility.

Title: Second rhino death due to infighting in Dudhwa this year
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Shahjahanpur: The carcass of a 6-year-old male Indian single-horned rhinoceros was recovered from South Sonaripur range of Dudhwa National Park on Tuesday morning. According to forest officials, there were multiple injuries on its body, probably caused by another male rhinoceros. This is the second rhino death in Dudhwa.

A panel of five veterinarians, including Dr Utkarsh Shukla from Lucknow Zoo, conducted the autopsy and confirmed that the rhino died due to infighting. They ruled out poaching as its horn was intact. Forest department officials who inspected the carcass said they saw foot marks of an adult rhino nearby. In February, a 15-year-old rhino was killed by a relatively younger bull in the national park due to infighting.

The Indian single-horned rhino is listed as ‘vulnerable’ in the IUCN Red List. Today, its population has dwindled to about 2,700 across India and Nepal. Indian rhino is also included in schedule-I of the Wildlife (Protection) Act, 1972

With the death of the rhino, Dudhwa now has 38 left in two enclosures – 34 in Kakraha compartment of Sonaripur range and four in Belraya range of DTR. Of these, 29 are cows and just five bulls are left. Besides, there are four calves in Sonaripur.

Field director Sanjay Pathak told TOI, “We used to call the deceased rhino the fourth son of Narayani and it was possibly killed by an adult rhino. We are yet to identify the pachyderm that killed it. It may be injured and in need of treatment.”

Rhinos were translocated from Assam to Dudhwa in 1984 and kept in a 27-sq km enclosure in Kakraha in Sonaripur range. In 2018, Dudhwa successfully launched it second rhino rehabilitation programme by shifting three females and one male rhino from Sonaripur to a 20-km enclosure in DTR’s Belraya range.

Most of the rhinos in Dudhwa are offsprings of Bankey, its oldest rhino who died at the age of 50 of natural causes in December 2016. A year later, three-year-old Sehdev was killed by three tigers. Earlier this year, 15-year-old Bhimsen died during infighting.

Title: Kashi warm as brightsun shines generously
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

cvv

Varanasi: Unlike the bone-crushing cold and foggy Monday at 2.3 degree Celcius, a sunny Tuesday brought respite to the residents of the city with the minimum temperature rising to 5 degree Celcius.

Both the minimum and maximum temperatures went up on Tuesday, and the sky remained clear throughout the day.

Met officials said a rise of 4 degrees in maximum temperature and 2.7 degrees in minimum temperature was recorded on Tuesday. The maximum temperature was 15 degree Celsius, and the minimum temperature was 5 degree Celsius.

Residents flocked to the ghats and parks to enjoy the sunny weather.

Several flights from Lal Bahadur Shastri International Airport were canceled on Monday due to dense fog that caused poor visibility.

Title: No let up in cold, man dies in Jalandhar
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Despite bone-chilling cold, revellers gather at Manali to celebrate New Year’s Eve

CHANDIGARH/SHIMLA: Intense cold continued in Punjab and Haryana on New Year’s Eve, with Narnaul recording the lowest temperature of 2.3 degrees Celsius — three degrees below the normal temperature. Union Territory Chandigarh, the joint capital of two states, recorded a minimum of 4.8 degree C, one notch below normal on Tuesday.

The cold was so severe that in Jalandhar, a man is suspected to have died because of it. He was found dead outside a shutdown factory in Sodhal Nagar area of Jalandhar on Monday. Police have kept his body in the mortuary as the man could not be identified.
