Title: Anil Kumar Khachi appointed chief secretary of Himachal Pradesh
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Anil Kumar Khachi

SHIMLA: The Himachal government has appointed Anil Kumar Khachi, the 1986-batch IAS officer, as the new chief secretary of the state. A notification has been issued in this regard.

Anil Khachi earlier held the charge of additional chief secretary (finance, planning, statics and 20-point programme). He will succeed Dr Shrikant Baldi who retired on Tuesday. The government also announced transfers and postings of some other senior IAS officers. Additional chief secretary (forest and language, art, culture) Ram Subhag Singh has been given additional charge of (MPP and power) besides the charge of chairman of Himachal Pradesh State Electricity Board Limited.

Additional chief secretary (health and family welfare) R D Dhiman has been given additional charge of tourism and civil aviation department.

Adviser (power) Prabodh Saxena has been given the charge of principal secretary (finance, planning, 20-point programme and economic and statistics). Principal secretary (education) Kamlesh Kumar Pant has been given additional charge of language, art, culture department.

On his return from central deputation, 1995-batch IAS officer Rajneesh has been posted as secretary (information and public relations, environment science technology). He will also hold the additional charge of chairman of HP State Pollution Control Board.

On his return from central deputation, 2002-batch IAS officer G K Srivastava has been posted as secretary (Ayurveda, training and foreign assignment). Secretary (finance) Akshay Sood has been given additional charge of housing department.

Director public finance and public enterprises-cum-special secretary (finance) Rajesh Sharma has been given additional charge of examiner, local audit department. Director, HP Institute of Public Administration, Chander Prakash Verma has been given additional charge of land records. Director (Ayurveda) D K Rattan has been given additional charge of settlement officer, Shimla division.

Title: Gorakhpur wakes up to coldest morning of this winter at 4C
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Gorakhpur: Tuesday morning was the coldest one of the season in Gorakhpur when the temperature dropped to 4 degree Celcius. The city also recorded 25 foggy days this December, highest in the last 42 years.

Weather expert Kailash Pandey said similar weather conditions would prevail over the next few days. Six cold days were recorded this December with the maximum temperature around 16 degree Celcius. Fog in Gorakhpur has broken the record of last 42 years with 25 foggy days this December. The second highest number of foggy days (23) in December were recorded in 2016.

Three people died in Basti district due to extreme cold. Niranjan, 38, resident of Kaptanganj, died early on Tuesday morning. Baburam (60) of Walterganj died on Monday around 1 am at the district hospital. Sitaram, also a resident of Walterganj, died in Varanasi on Monday night.

Title: Our generation is less judgemental and more tolerant
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

As a person born in the new millennium, I feel that what set us apart from the generation of our parents is we are less judgemental, more tolerant and better networked.

The perception that millennials are socially disconnected and aloof has been proved wrong multiple times, but still the society clings to the stereotyped image of us as being loners, who are always glued to mobile phones and social media.

Kerala had seen young millennials in action when they brought people together for relief operations during the floods. Now, they are hitting the streets to protest against Citizenship Amendment Act. We, as a generation, can unite people because we are more open minded.

While most of us are politically conscious, the issue is that there is no proper platform in national institutions like NIT to voice our opinion or raise objections against the decisions of authorities, if need arises. Even the government is trying to suppress student voices in institutions like JNU. I think that more people from the campuses should enter national politics as the age-gap between the current crop of national leaders and our generation is massive.

On career front, I think our generation is not driven by salary prospects alone while making career choices. Some of my colleagues have even left NIT after realizing that their interests lie elsewhere, like arts and literature. At the end of the day, we need to be happy and satisfied. We are ready to take risks to follow our passion.

I think that our lot are more goal-oriented and would like to align our family lives to our goals. The girls of my generation would take decisions about marriage only if they like it. Also, I think that traditional gender roles are changing rapidly in our generation as it is increasingly becoming normal for men to do household chores along with women.

I think 90% of the girls in our group don’t know cooking, but I know many boys who are good at it. Also, if two people get along well and share the same interests, then other factors like caste of religion are becoming less of a hindrance now, at least for dating.

(Diyea Robin K is pursuing her fourth semester in Electronics and Communication Engineering at National Institute of Technology, Calicut)

Title: Parent-teacher meetings & annual functions to be held in govt schools
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Bareilly: For the first time, the government-run primary and upper primary schools in Bareilly would hold parent-teacher meetings (PTM), where the parents would be apprised of their kid’s behavior, results and importance of maintaining attendance.

According to the officials, the PTM would be held on the second Mondays of January, April, July and October.

If there is a holiday on the second Monday, it would be organised on the next working day. The headteacher would inform the parents about PTM by writing in their children’s notebooks two days before. The officials have made it mandatory for the teachers to be present during PTM.

The officials have directed schools to use 10% funds of the composite grant to organize the annual function in February. A school receives annual composite grants ranging from Rs 20,000 to 1 lakh, depending upon the strength of students.

Basic shikha adhikari Tanuja Tripathi said, “We will organize first PTM in January in primary and upper primary schools of the district. We have issued directions to teachers in this regard. Annual functions in schools will be held in February.”

City education officer Devesh Rai said, “During PTMs, the attendance of the students and the importance of being regular in schools will be discussed with parents. Besides, teachers will inform the parents of their children’s results, behavior and other activities. We will create awareness among parents about school activities, including yoga, kitchen garden, and sports and other government campaigns like Poshan and deworming pills.”

For annual functions, it has been directed that the students should participate in cultural activities and short dramas to give a message on cleanliness, environment, conservation of water and no use of plastic.

During the event, the students who performed well in cultural activities, sports, music, story writing and painting would be felicitated.

Title: Dacoits strike at house in Bareilly, decamp with cash, jewellery
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

BAREILLY: A group of five dacoits stormed into a house and decamped with cash and jewellery after locking the family up in a room at gunpoint. The incident occurred on the outskirts of Bareilly city early on Tuesday.

The dacoits targeted the house of Ram Naresh situated in Shivganga colony of Izzatnagar area at 1 am when the family was sleeping.

Police said an FIR has been lodged against five unidentified accused and anti-dacoity and surveillance teams of crime branch have been deployed along with local police to resolve the case at the earliest.

The house owner, Ram Naresh, who works as an insurance company agent, said he and his family members were sleeping when five armed dacoits forcefully entered his house through roof and woke them up. They were asked to give up their cash and jewellery at gunpoint.

After sweeping all the expensive items, dacoits tied their hands and locked them in a room. They also took away their mobile phones to ensure that they couldn’t contact anyone. On Tuesday morning, neighbours rescued the family and police were informed.

Izzatnagar station house officer AK Verma said, “An FIR has been registered against unidentified robbers under IPC section 395 (dacoity) and we are trying to identify the gang involved in the crime. There must be someone who would have done reconnaissance for the dacoits and he could be the connecting link. Forensic team has collected the samples of finger prints and we will try to match them with our list of robbers active in Bareilly.”

Title: Delhi: AAP MLAs meet up with voters at mohalla sabhas
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Arvind Kejriwal

NEW DELHI: As the assembly election draws near , Aam Aadmi Party MLAs have intensified their micro-level canvassing . Organised at different places within the assembly constituencies, the ‘mohalla sabhas’ are being used by MLAs to closely connect with voters.

The AAP government’s report card, which lists major achievements of the government in the last five years, is distributed among the public during the meetings and discussions are held.

AAP came to power in 2015 winning 67 out of 70 assembly seats. It currently has 61 MLAs as the party lost the Rajouri Garden seat in a by-election to BJP and five MLAs were disqualified under anti-defection laws.

The MLAs of the party have been asked to focus on small meetings. Each MLA has to conduct 10 ‘mohalla sabhas’ before January 6 so that they are able to clearly explain to the public the major achievements of the government.

CM Arvind Kejriwal had recently launched the report card of his government describing its top 10 achievements. The report card is a major part of the party’s campaign for the upcoming assembly elections and is being taken to 35 lakh households in the city.

Meanwhile, Rajya Sabha MP Sanjay Singh on Tuesday welcomed a group of local functionaries from BJP, Congress and Lok Janshakti Party into the party fold and said that AAP will repeat the historic victory of 2015 in the upcoming polls. “People from across the political parties are joining AAP influenced by the government’s achievements. In the report card, we have shown how the honest governance of AAP has resulted in people of Delhi getting free electricity, water, education, health facilities and all the other basic amenities to live a life of dignity. Many are overwhelmed with such a governance model,” said Singh.

Title: Delhi: Congress forms 6 panels to oversee poll readiness
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Delhi unit chief Subhash Chopra

NEW DELHI: To oversee its readiness for upcoming assembly polls , Congress on Tuesday appointed six election-related panels. While Delhi unit chief Subhash Chopra has been named the chief of the 56-member election committee, Kirti Azad was nominated the head of the 165-member campaign committee.

A statement issued by the party said that Congress president Sonia Gandhi also approved appointment of 69-member manifesto committee, 164-member publicity committee, 65-member election management committee and 104-member media coordination committee.

Former Union minister Ajay Maken will head the manifesto committee and senior politician JP Agarwal has been put in charge of the publicity committee. While former Delhi minster Arvinder Singh Lovely has been named as chief of the election management committee, Mukesh Sharma will be head of the media coordination committee.

Senior party functionaries such as Kapil Sibal, Janardan Dwivedi and Karan Singh have been appointed as members in both the election and campaign committees.

Last week, Congress had set up a screening committee to shortlist candidates for the Delhi assembly election with Rajeev Satav as its head and Virender Singh Rathore and Challa Vamshi Chand Reddy as members.

Meanwhile, several Delhi Congress functionaries were detained on Tuesday evening at Connaught Place where they were sitting on a ‘saamuhik upwaas’ (fast) against the amended citizenship act, economic slowdown and unemployment. They were taken to Mandir Marg police station and continued to be there till the filing of this report.

Those detained by police included Delhi Congress chief Subhash Chopra, AICC general secretary in-charge PC Chacko, chief spokesperson Mukesh Sharma and some former Delhi MLAs and MPs.

Congress party functionaries were protesting to express their “angst” against the BJP-led Centre and AAP dispensation in Delhi. Minor clashes took place between Congress workers and police when the protesters were being removed.

Chopra said that Central government had failed on the economic front and both BJP and AAP betrayed the residents of unauthorised colonies and JJ Clusters.

Title: Somesh Kumar is chief secretary, will be in office till 2023
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

HYDERABAD: Somesh Kumar, a close confidant of chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao, was appointed as the chief secretary (CS) on Tuesday. The 1989 IAS batch officer has been working as special chief secretary of revenue department. The fifth chief secretary of the state, who took over from SK Joshi, will be in office till December 31, 2023.

Joshi, however, has been appointed as advisor to the irrigation department keeping in mind his experience and his role during the execution of projects such as Kaleshwaram.

The state government preferred Somesh over half a dozen other senior officers of special chief secretary rank, keeping his three-year long tenure into account. The names of special chief secretary Ajay Mishra, who has only seven months left, was also considered. While a few others initially in the race had only a little over one year of service left.

Hailing from Bihar, Somesh is a post-graduate in psychology from University of Delhi. Before joining the Civil Services, he worked as a psychologist in DRDO for about two years between 1987 and 1989 and was involved in testing of candidates applying to the armed forces.

After joining the Civil Services he worked as project officer of Integrated Tribal Development Agency, Paderu , Visakhapatnam; additional commissioner in the erstwhile Municipal Corporation of Hyderabad (MCH) between May 1995 and 1996; and was incharge of mega city project. He also worked as collector of Anantapur district in united AP for two years from 2000 to 2002.

Before the state’s bifurcation in 2014, he was posted as GHMC commissioner and he continued till Oct 2015. As commissioner of the Greater Hyderabad civic body, he introduced the popular Rs five meal, planned Strategic Road Development Project (SRDP) and increased property tax collections. It was during his tenure as commissioner that the row over deletion of lakhs of voters’ names from electoral list had erupted.

Title: Speed thrills but kills: Road accidents claimed 570 lives in 2019 in Allahabad
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Allahabad: Over 570 people lost their lives and 900 others were injured in 1,365 road accidents in the city in 2019.

Despite a series of road safety awareness campaigns and strict implementation of traffic rules and regulations, at least 33 people died and 56 injured in December alone.

According to data released by Allahabad range police recently, 63% of fatal and non-fatal road accidents recorded this year were attributed to rash driving and violation of speed limits.

Though traffic police on December 15 prescribed speed limit for heavy/commercial, four and two-wheeler vehicles for 56 identified roads but failed to bring down accidents.

Traffic police claimed to have penalised over 300 defaulters in last fortnight for violation of speed limit/rash driving.

DIG (Allahabad range) KP Singh said, “Fresh directives have been issued to traffic police authorities for strict implementation of road safety norms. Three special teams equipped with speed radars have also been deployed to identify speed limit violators.”

“Rash driving, wrong side driving, use of mobile phones and drunken driving also lead to road mishaps,” he said.

Highest number of road accident deaths were reported in June (71) followed by 68 in March, 59 in May, 56 in February, 47 in April, 44 in November, 43 in October, 42 in January, 38 in August, 35 in July, 33 in December and 30 in September. “Efforts are being made to minimize road accidents. Directives have been issued to traffic cops to tighten noose around speed limit violators and rash drivers,” the DIG said.

Title: Pilibhit SP declines request to quash FIR against Sikh devotes booked for violating section 144
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Pilibhit: Pilibhit superintendent of police (SP) Ashok Dixit on Tuesday said the FIR filed against 55 Sikh devotees, who violated section 144 of the CrPC by taking out a religious procession, won’t be dropped and asserted that they would have to go through the legal procedures.

The top cop’s response came after the president of Delhi Sikh Gurudwara Management Committee (DSGMC), Manjinder Singh Sirsa, requested the SP to withdraw the case immediately.

Police have named 5 identified and 50 unidentified in the FIR. All of them have been booked under section 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant) of the Indian Penal Code.

DSGMC chief Sirsa said the chief priest of Akal Takht, the highest religious authority of Sikhs, Jatthedar Harpreet Singh, was disappointed with the police for booking the devotees, and added that he had asked the top cop to withdraw the case.

“He (the chief priest) was disappointed with the Pilibhit police for booking Sikh devotees. We took out the Sankirtan (religious procession) in Delhi, on the same occasion, that was joined by over 3 lakh devotees and lasted for 16 hours, but there was no hindrance from the administration,” Sirsa said.

However, Dixit said he clearly stated to Sirsa that the booked devotees would not be harassed, but they would be subject to go through legal procedures.

“The matter should not be viewed by the Sikh leaders from the religious angle, but from the viewpoint of law, which is equally applicable to everyone without any discrimination”, the SP said.

Title: Aerial survey for rail project begins
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

KANNUR: The aerial survey to identify the alignment of the Thiruvananthapuram-Kasaragod semi high-speed railway ( SHSR ) project got under way on Tuesday, covering the northernmost 80km stretch from Kannur in the initial phase.

The aerial survey will be completed in seven days for the entire 532-km stretch up to Thiruvananthapuram, marking the first vital step before commencing the work of the project, named Silver Line, said an official release. This line will reduce the end-to-end travel time to four hours.

LiDAR (light detection and ranging) aerial remote sensing method is being used for the survey, conducted on a Partenavia P68 series aircraft that took off from Kannur International Airport (Kial).

A joint venture of the Kerala government and ministry of railways, the project had obtained the in-principle approval of the Centre on December 17, said the release.

The survey is being carried out by Hyderabad-based GeoKno India Pvt Ltd, which had also conducted LiDAR survey for the Mumbai-Ahmedabad bullet train project.

According to V Ajith Kumar, managing director, Kerala Rail Development Corporation Ltd, the implementing agency of the project, also called K-Rail, the survey will help identify the alignment very fast and start the construction. K-Rail is a joint venture by the state government and the railway ministry.

From Kasaragod to Tirur, the Silver Line will run parallel to the existing railway track. From Tirur to Thiruvananthapuram, the line will pass separately from the existing railway line since that stretch has a large number of curves that hamper speed.

It will have 10 stations and a proposal to build short-distance feeder links to connect to other stations too is also on the cards. Trains will have a maximum speed of 200 km/h. tnn

Title: Kochi cops brace for anti-CAA protest
Content:
Anti-CAA protesters take out a bike rally in Ernakulam on Tuesday.

KOCHI: With Marine Drive set to host a massive protest by Muslim organisations against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) on Wednesday evening, prepare for gridlocks in the city on New Year’ Day. With thousands expected to attend the meeting, police have issued a traffic advisory to avoid congestion on the roads.Cops have advised use of the Metro for commute within the city, as movement of traffic from Aroor, Tripunithura, West Kochi, Kakkanad, Aluva, Varapuzha and Vypeen to the city would be regulated from 3pm to 9pm.City police commissioner IG Vijay Sakhare has urged the cooperation of residents.No parking would be permitted on either side of Banerji Road, from High Court Junction to Edapally Bypass Junction. Parking is also barred on the stretch from St Martin’s Church, Palarivattom, to Palarivattom Bypass Junction, and from BTH Junction to High Court Junction, a press release said.Vehicles ferrying protesters have also been issued parking directions. Those coming from Aroor, Tripunithura, West Kochi, Kakkanad, Muvattupuzha and Perumbvoor should park their vehicles along Container Road after dropping off passengers near the SBI Bank at Palarivattom Bypass junction.Vehicles coming from Aluva should enter NH-17 at Edapally, drop passengers off there and then proceed to Container Road for parking. Vehicles from Paravur, Kodungallur and Varapuzha should enter NH-17 and drop passengers off near Lulu Mall and head to Container Road via Kalamassery and park along the sides. People coming from Vypeen should get off at Mulavukadu junction and their vehicles should head to Container Road for parking.The protest, organised by a coordination committee of Muslim organisations, is expected to announce a series of anti-CAA protests. Protesters are to reach the venue at Marine Drive in small rallies from JLN Stadium, Kaloor . The meeting is expected to begin at 5pm.Swaraj India leader and senior Supreme Court lawyer Prashant Bhushan and Jignesh Mevani, dalit activist and Gujarat MLA, would be chief guests at the event. It is scheduled to be inaugurated by Panakkad Sayed Hyderali Shihab Thangal, state president of the Indian Union Muslim League (IUML).Organisers have arranged nearly 3,000 volunteers to control the crowds. Participants have been asked to use small placards instead of flags and to strictly follow standard guidelines for holding a march during the protest.According to organisers, Samastha Kerala Jamiyyathul Ulama, Kerala Muslim Jamaat, Dakshina Kerala Jamiyyathul Ulama, Kerala Nadvathul Mujahideen, Jamaat-e-islami, knm markazuda’wa, Muslim League, KMEA, MES, MSS, Wisdom Islamic Organisation, Ernakulam District Jamaat Council, and Mahal Coordination Committee are among the organisations participating.A bike rally announcing the protest was held in Ernakulam on Tuesday. The rally of 1,001 bikers began from Gandhi Square, near the head post office at Aluva, and culminated at Rajendra Maidan in the evening.

Title: Action Replay 2019: Headway in cutting Delhi’s landfills to size
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

The city’s monumental waste management problem was recognised by both Supreme Court and parliamentary panels t... Read More

NEW DELHI: The city’s monumental waste management problem was recognised by both Supreme Court and parliamentary panels this year. There were few pluses and many missed goals for garbage management in 2019.

Among the gains was the initiation of dismantling Delhi’s three mountains of shame. A deadline of two years has been fixed for flattening the three landfills and setting up biodiversity parks in their place.

After decades of neglect and policy paralysis — which ended in Delhi’s landfill sites at Ghazipur, Bhalswa and Okhla approaching the height of Qutub Minar — trommelling and bio-remediation started to deconstruct the legacy garbage mix.

Taking suo motu cognisance of a TOI report in May, National Green Tribunal (NGT) dismissed the plans of the municipal corporations of capping the landfill sites and, instead, directed them to follow the “Indore model” in biomining for clearing up legacy waste. The report had mentioned how landfills were polluting underground aquifers and people living nearby were being forced to use water contaminated by leachate.

On NGT’s orders, the civic bodies pushed ahead with a Rs 250-crore biomining plan for 265 lakh tonnes of legacy waste to reduce the heights of the three landfills. About 20,000 metric tonnes of waste was segregated and neatly piled in rows at Bhalswa landfill near GT Karnal Road in the first two months. There is still the pressing question of where to dispose of the inert material, such as sand and mud.

A senior north corporation official overseeing the implementation of the plan said, “We will soon have 15 trommelling machines to sieve the garbage, but we are running out of space for storing inert soil. The abandoned pits in Bhatti Mines are the best option for it.”

The civic bodies have still failed to crack the source of Delhi’s waste problem — segregation of garbage at source. Despite issuing several notices in multiple colonies and giving a six-month deadline for developing nine model wards in the city, the plan has failed to catch up.

Experts from Centre for Science and Environment and NGOs have repeatedly underlined that with over 50% biodegradable waste there is a high potential to compost or generate biogas out of the segregated wet waste. An South Delhi Municipal Corporation official said a great amount of “political will” is required to enforce segregation of garbage at source. “We can’t issue challans due to backlash from councillors,” he added.

Title: Do it because you must, and feel great afterwards
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

I work as an assistant at LIC, which means that I am not at home at all times. The garbage collector does not visit my locality at a fixed time too, so it makes a lot of sense for me to treat household waste myself.

I segregate tea leaves, green leafy vegetables, egg shells etc and put them all in a compost bin . I add waste decomposing agents and cocopit to the mix. Within a month, the wet waste transforms into great quality manure, usable for my garden at my home in Vishwakarma Nagar.

The dry waste generated from my household, like plastics, bottles, medicine bottles etc is given to the recycler.

I started this practice a year ago, when I realized that we are unnecessarily burdening our planet with so much waste generation . On top of that, I find the activity fun to do. When the nutrient-rich manure is ready, the proud feeling is indescribable. I have a beautiful tej patta (bay leaf) plant blooming in my garden, because of that manure.

We don’t put leftover food in the compost mix, as it is necessary to maintain its pH balance. Our house help is also instructed to dispose of waste properly. I tell her what to throw and where to throw it on a daily basis, and she willingly complies.

Waste segregation also helps the garbage collectors. They are humans too; if we do our bit, their work is significantly reduced as well.

I wish that everyone starts doing this at their household level. It is our responsibility to reduce waste generated from our homes, so that it helps in reducing the burden on our planet. The pollution levels are skyrocketing and climate change is real. It is high time that we realize our responsibility towards our planet, and encourage others to be responsible too.

Title: TTD to offer one laddu free, save Rs 250 crore annually
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

TIRUPATI: The Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams (TTD), in what could be called a New Year gift, has decided to offer a free ‘ laddu ’ to all devotees who visit the sacred abode of Lord Venkateswara. The scheme is likely to be rolled out on the auspicious occasion of Vaikuntha Ekadashi, which falls on January 6.

Given religious sentiments attached by the devotees to the laddu prasadam, TTD produces and distributes three different kinds of laddus — big laddu, small laddu and prasadam laddu. Around 3,000 big laddus, weighing 700 grams each, are produced everyday, of which some are offered free to ticket-holders of certain Arjitha sevas, while the rest are sold for Rs 200 each to VIPs or those with recommendation letters. TTD incurs an expenditure of Rs 170 per big laddu.

The small laddu, weighing 175 grams each, is the most sought-after prasadam. About 3 lakh to 3.75 lakh such laddus are produced everyday, for which TTD incurs an expenditure of Rs 39 per laddu. TTD has been selling the small laddus, which is also known ‘Tirupati laddu’, under different categories and at different prices. Under the divya darshan system, it offers one free laddu, two laddus priced at Rs 10 each and any additional laddu (maximum two additional laddus per person) at Rs 25 each.

Sarva darshan devotees get two laddus at Rs 10 each and the additional ones at Rs 25 each. Similarly, special entry and VIP darshan ticket-holders get two laddus free and two additional ones at Rs 25 each. The small laddu is also sold for Rs 50 in the open counters.

The temple administration also prepares approximately 75,000 prasadam laddus weighing about 25 grams each which are offered free of cost inside the temple after devotees complete darshan.

Given the subsidies involved in the laddu sale process, TTD has been incurring an annual loss of around Rs 250 crore. The multiple categories in the sale process have also led to widespread black-marketing of the laddus. Taking these complexities into account and to reduce the losses due to subsidised sale of laddus, the temple administration has now decided to simplify the whole process and stop the multiple category system of laddu sale at differential prices.

So from January 6, one small laddu would be offered free of cost to every devotee who visits the temple. In addition, devotees can purchase any quantity of laddus they desire at Rs 50 each.

Title: Kolkata: 1,500 motorists booked in 24 hours, 20 for drinking
Content:
Police manage the crowd on Park Street

KOLKATA: The city partied in style, ringing in the New Year on Tuesday night. Only a few drink-driving cases surfaced, with 20 being registered from Monday till 8pm on Tuesday. Last year, the figure was 45 around the same time. Cops booked over 1,500 motorists till 8pm on Tuesday. Of this, 248 were booked for helmetless riding and 312 for honking.The revelry on Park Street, which was abuzz with visitors at restaurants since afternoon, peaked after sunset. As the lights came on, thousands descended upon the party hub amid unprecedented security. At least 41 pickets were set up under 13 DCPs.The city, however, saw a few stray incidents. At Avishikta crossing, a young man allegedly assaulted a traffic sergeant from the Purba Jadavpur traffic guard on Monday evening when he was asked to stop his car for checking. Cops said that the man was under medication and appeared disoriented. He was admitted to MR Bangur Hospital and the Survey Park police registered a case against him. Patuli police arrested a man for snatching a woman’s bag that contained valuable documents.Traffic cops, too, were on their toes to stop extortion bids. But traffic snarls could not be completely avoided in the morning in the Alipore Zoo-Rabindra Sadan zone. The Bhowanipore traffic guard coordinated with Alipore police to nab a man, Ranjit Kumar Mishra, for allegedly extorting parking fees from Alipore zoo visitors near the Presidency correctional home. Women cops, too, were making the rounds.Revellers thronged restaurants and multiplexes for lunch and to catch the latest blockbusters. “I bunked office and started celebrations with lunch at a restaurant in Acropolis Mall with my family and then went for a movie. In the evening, we went to Park Street and checked into a pub for a New Year’s party,” said Kinshuk Chatterjee, a techie from Jadavpur.“I wanted my daughter to feel the festive mood. For the cops on the streets, though, it means extra work. The traffic guards conducted anti-drink drives across 40 locations and found several offenders throughout the day. The cops, though, said they were expecting a spike after 1am on Wednesday. In comparison, the new party zones across EM Bypass, the Ruby connector, Sarat Bose Road and Southern Avenue, and those covered by Kasba, Tiljala and southeast traffic guards registered six drink driving cases on Tuesday.The crowd swelled in pubs around 8pm on Tuesday. A large police contingent stood guard to ward off troublemakers. With around 110 CCTV cameras, a drone, 13 quick response teams and the anti-eve teasing all-women Winners team manning Park Street, the area turned into a mini-fortress. Vehicles were stopped from entering Park Street later in the day, helping revellers have a gala time.

Title: In a first, seven night vision devices for Magh Mela vigil
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Allahabad: An elaborate surveillance and security system — involving 185 closed-circuit television (CCTV) cameras, seven night vision devices, three digitised lost-and-found camps, six wireless grids, 13 hi-tech fire stations and 12 fire watchtowers, among other things — promises to keep more than five crore devotees safe during Magh Mela 2020.

The 43-day annual fair will begin with Paush Purnima bathing ritual on January 10 and end with Mahashivratri dip on February 24.

Deputy IG (Allahabad range) KP Singh told TOI that the security blueprint also included deployment of over 3,500 police personnel, including 243 lady cops. “Compared to Magh Mela 2018, we are increasing police presence by 25% this time,” Singh said.

The fair will sprawl over 2,000 bigha and has been divided into three zones — Sangam, Jhunsi and Arail — and six sectors. Apart from 13 police stations and 38 outposts, a 5km-long deep-water barricading and 3km-long river line have been created for the safety and convenience of devotees who would be flocking from different parts of the country during the mega religious affair.

“For the first time in Magh Mela, we will be using night vision devices. As many as 185 CCTV cameras, including 14 pan-tilt-zoom (PTZ) and 52 fixed ones, have already been installed on the premises for strict vigi,” the DIG said.

Apart from the police force, four bomb disposal squads, 10 anti-sabotage teams, 20 companies of paramilitary personnel and a team from the Integrated Command & Control Centre will help the Magh Mela authorities man the sea of pilgrims.

Police deployment will include three additional SPs, 15 deputy SPs, 30 inspectors, two teams of ATS commandos, two companies of RAF, 50 jal police personnel, 16 mounted cops and one company each of National Disaster Response Force (NDRF) and State Disaster Response Force (SDRF).

While deep-water barricading has been done along ghats to stop devotees from venturing into deeper waters, the river lines will allow deployment of boats. The DIG said jal police will press 20 motor boats into service.

An estimated 45 lakh devotees are expected to take the holy dip on Paush Purnima and another 15 lakh on Mahashivratri. Around 2.5 crore devotees are also expected to bathe in the river on Mauni Amavasya on January 24.

Title: $1 lakh raised online to bring Hyderabad techie’s body back from the US
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Charitha Reddy

HYDERABAD: When a young woman IT professional from Hyderabad, Charitha Reddy, was killed in a road accident in Michigan, US, on December 27, her family appealed for online donations of $ 50,000 to help transport her body back and support her family. Charitha’s family members have left for the US to bring her body back. Her parents live in Neredmet in Secunderabad .

The appeal touched a chord with many. Within a couple of days, as much as $ 1,07,779 (approx. Rs 77 lakh) was raised with 3,400 people making contributions. Such was the outpouring of generosity that Charitha’s cousin Jayanthi Reddy, who was organising online donations on a GoFundMe page, decided to stop accepting donations.

On the page, Jayanthi gave details of the accident and asked everyone to donate generously so that the money could help support the family.

Charitha (25), who had been in the US for over four years working for a multinational company, died on December 27 when an intoxicated man drove his vehicle into her parked car.

When the accident took place, Charitha was sitting in the rear and was badly injured. She later died. Her parents said another girl, who was in the car, was operated for an injury on her jaw, but is believed to be out of danger.

In her appeal, Jayanthi had said, “The Muskegon Heights man who hit our car was intoxicated and it was the sole reason for this incident and we request you to be sober while driving.”

Title: Action Replay 2019: Public space shrinks as heritage plays second fiddle to revamp
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Every year, thousands of people gather at India Gate on the last day of the year to mark a new beginning.

NEW DELHI: Every year, thousands of people gather at India Gate on the last day of the year to mark a new beginning. They reach the iconic heritage site from all directions. This year, however, the same will not be possible, since designated entry points have “compromised” its openness.

The barricading around India Gate is testimony to the shrinking of public places, which defined Delhi in 2019. With boundary walls around the National War Memorial , tourists no longer get the uninhibited view of the heritage buildings associated with the capital — the Parliament and Secretariat . Experts have also raised concerns regarding the redevelopment of the area around Central Vista.

“India Gate’s open aspect allowed those arriving or passing by to connect to the larger city, and symbolically, to the country and all its people,” said Sujata Kohli, honorary president of Indian Society of Landscape Architects (ISOLA).

The year also opened up new spaces for public gatherings, with Sunder Nursery and Central Park proving major crowd pullers for people planning to spend their day outside. Central Park in Connaught Place has seen several public gatherings over the last few months, with recent one being when hundreds of people turning up at the site to protest against the Citizenship Amendment Act.

Sunder Nursery, which is flanked by Humayun’s Tomb in the south and Purana Qila in the north, also became a viable “alternative” for family gatherings. The entry, however, unlike India Gate, is ticketed.

Visitors can now also opt for a “heritage walk” through the lush garden between 10am and 4pm, according to the management at Sunder Nursery.

Another site that reappeared in the public imagination late in 2019 was Jantar Mantar, which had been “restricted” for public gatherings early in the year. But the monument made a comeback, becoming the centre for rallies and protests.

Title: 225 tourism facilities set to be plastic-free
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: As many as 225 tourism accommodation units in the state will become ‘ plastic free ’ from Wednesday as part of the ‘ Clean Kerala Initiative ’ project of Responsible Tourism Mission under the state tourism department. It is being implemented in association with Kerala Travel Mart (KTM) Society.

These accommodation units, including resorts, hotels, homestays and house boats have decided to exclude 19 plastic items like carry bags, tray, disposable cups, bottles, straw, plates, cups, cling film, thermocol, bowls, flags, sheets used for food parcelling, spoons, fruit and vegetable punnets, juice packets, PVC flex materials and food parcelling plastic containers, said an offical release issued here on Tuesday.

These accommodation units, including 30 resorts, 35 homestays, 30 house boats and 130 hotels across the state, have already handed over the self-declaration form to RT Mission.

All hotels, resorts and homestays and 20 house boats in Kumarakom have joined hands with RT Mission in this venture. Joining the initiative are 40 units in Kottayam, 15 in Ernakulam, 20 in Kasaragod, 32 in Idukki, 38 in Wayanad, 32 in Kozhikode, 15 in Alappuzha, five in Thrissur, 10 in Kollam, 12 in Thiruvananthapuram and six in Malappuram.

As part of the ‘Clean Kerala Initiative’ the RT Mission had organized a two-day workshop for tourism industry partners. The decision to make the tourism destinations of state as plastic-free and green certified was taken in the workshop.

Tourism minister Kadakampally Surendran said the aim was to make nine select destinations 100% plastic-free through the project. Kumarakom could be declared as the first plastic free destination of Kerala in 2020 itself, said tourism secretary Rani George.

According to tourism director P Bala Kiran, Kerala Tourism has already started RT classification for tourism enterprises for achieving the plastic-free goal.

Rupeshkumar K, the state RT Mission coordinator, said that to promote the alternative products for plastic bags, the mission was distributing 70,000 cloth bags to various tourism enterprises as a token and that many tourism enterprises have signed agreement with different units of RT Mission which produces various eco-friendly products.

“Altogether, 3,000 rooms in 225 accommodation units became plastic-free as part of this initiative. The project aims to make nine major tourism destinations in Kerala plastic-free by 2021,” he added.

Title: Dubious distinction: MP, Maha top the country in tiger deaths
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Nagpur: The country lost 110 tigers in the year just gone by. The year also saw death of 491 leopards, according to figures compiled by Wildlife Protection Society of India (WPSI). While poaching was big reason behind tiger mortality, road and rail accidents accounted for a big chunk of leopard deaths.

In case of tigers, there is a marginal rise in numbers compared to 2018 when 104 tiger deaths were recorded including 34 due to poaching. In 2019 too, 38 of the 110 deaths have been attributed to poaching. Like last year, Madhya Pradesh continues to lead the tally with 29 tiger deaths followed by Maharashtra with 22. In 2018 MP saw deaths of 23 tigers followed by 19 in Maharashtra.

However, the official database of National Tiger Conservation Authority (NTCA) differs with the figures. NTCA has recorded 92 tiger deaths in 2019 while it was 102 in 2018. Tito Joseph, programme coordinator of WPSI, which works for wildlife crime enforcement, says poaching and seizure of body parts of tigers had slightly increased since last year.

The difference in NTCA data may be due non-inclusion of figures derived from seizure of body parts. “We calculated the number of tigers depending on seizures, which may not necessarily belong to one individual only,” Joseph said.

For example, in Maharashtra the official figures record deaths of 18 tigers but it doesn’t include three tigers poached in Tumsar range under Bhandara division in July this year. The arrested accused have confessed they killed three tigers there. This may be the case elsewhere.

“There are certain corrections which will be communicated to the headquarters after verification from divisions concerned. Some mortalities were not communicated by the states to the NTCA,” NTCA officials said. “As far as Tumsar tigers were concerned, the number has been split in MP and Maharashtra as some body parts were seized in MP,” they said.

As per the latest tiger estimation by NTCA-WII, there are 2,967 tigers in India. In Maharashtra, the number increased from 190 in 2014 to 312 in 2018. With 526 tigers, MP is at the top. Deaths due to poaching remain a cause of concern in both states.

Of the 110 deaths in 2019, 38 were attributed to body parts seizure and poaching, 26 were found dead, 36 died in fight with other individuals, three due to road/rail accidents and six during rescue.

“On the one hand, it shows good detection rate and higher enforcement activity but on the other also shows increasing demand for tiger body parts. Improving intelligence-led enforcement, addressing impact of linear intrusions and conflict management can help keep viable populations of tigers,” Joseph said.

This year saw a marginal drop in number of leopard deaths. Though NTCA doesn’t have a database on leopard deaths, WPSI data shows in 2018, 500 leopards had died country-wide which included 169 due to poaching. There was no let-up in poaching of leopards in 2019 too as 127 of 491 deaths were attributed to this reason.

Maharashtra this year accounted for 97 leopard deaths. As many as 31 of these were in road and rail accidents. Last year, state saw 93 leopards dying including 22 in road and rail accidents.

“No general inference can be drawn from these figures. Every landscape has its own set of pressures and problems, but leopards are really getting hammered in road/rail accidents, which is worrisome. It is the result of not just increasing traffic volume but also increased speed due to four-laning and widening of roads,” said Nitin Desai, WPSI’s Central India director.

MP 23 29

Maha 19 22

K’taka 16 12

U’khand 8 12

UP 6 6

R’than 6 3

Kerala 5 3

Title: Kolkata: Eateries stay chock-a-block, singing bars extend hours
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Park Street restaurants stayed packed throughout the day, while visitors had to wait for at least 45 minutes t... Read More

KOLKATA: Crooning bars in central Kolkata will remain open beyond January 1 midnight. Following a rise in footfalls in the last week of 2019, most bars with live band have taken permission to stay open till 1am, while a few have taken the licence to serve drinks and play music till 2am.

Bands at these bars usually start wrapping up by 10.30pm. But enthused by the sudden rise in patrons since Christmas Eve, the bars applied for permission to remain open till 1am and 2am on December 31 and January 1. Bars, like Rocks on Waterloo Street and Bower on Mission Row, stuck notices outside their establishments, informing their guests about the new hours.

The late deadline also meant police would have to be more vigilant in the Esplanade-Chandni Chowk-Mission Row stretch, where most of the singing bars were located, given the history of skirmishes from there. “After a good run from December 24 and 31, we are expecting decent business on January 1 as well,” said a bar owner in Chandni Chowk. “ Getting permission for an extra hour or more involves a fee of Rs 15,000, and we also have to make budget for other overheads. So, only if a bar owner is kind of sure of getting good business will he apply for the permission to operate till late.”

Business at many of these bars in central Kolkata, located within a few meters of each other, witnessed a dip in earnings for most part of 2019 after police barred patrons from showering money on singers and conducted raids on some of the establishments for violating norms, which stipulated that the crooners could only sing and sway to the music but not break into a dance. Many bars with multiple floors were forced to shut owing to low footfalls as band leaders, who took the place on lease from owners and arrange singers and musicians, could no longer afford to pay.

A little away on Park Street, the party street of the city, revellers started visiting since 31st morning. All the restaurants had long queues outside and the average time of waiting touched 45 minutes during lunch hours. As the day progressed, the crowd swelled, turning the street into a sea of people. For restaurants, the crowds meant the till would not stop ringing. Mocambo and Peter Cat, which have seen a 20% surge in footfalls since Christmas Eve, decided to stay open till 1am on January 1 and 4. The original plan was to have a late deadline only on December 31. “The huge crowds encouraged us to seek a late closure on New Year’s Day and the first Saturday of the year. Going by the trend since Christmas, there will be a spill over of crowds to the New Year. Kolkatans have gone into celebratory mood,” said Siddharth Kothari of Mocambo and Peter Cat.

Title: 20-year-old youth shot at in Fatehpur
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Kanpur: A 20-year-old youth was shot at and critically injured in the Sujanpur area in Fatehpur district. The victim, identified as Amit Raidas, is a resident of the Kajrandera area in Kotwali police of the district.

Police said the assailant had fired at the youth from a point-blank range while he was asleep due to which he suffered critical wounds. Police suspect the murderous attack to be the fallout of some personal enmity. “We have recovered an empty cartridge and a cellphone from the spot. We think the youth was attacked owing to some old enmity. He has been admitted to Lala Lajpat Rai hospital in Kanpur," said inspector Umakant.

Title: Dy commander among 5 Maoists surrender
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Nagpur: Ajay Kulyami, former deputy commander of platoon no 3, is among five Maoists who have surrendered before the Gadchiroli district police this week. The surrendered Maoists had rewards around Rs27 lakh on their heads.

In 2019, 34 Maoists having rewards worth more than Rs1.80 crore on their heads have surrendered. The number of surrenders in Gadchiroli district since 2005 was 638 till now. Police arrested 22 Maoists in 2019.

SP Shailesh Balkawade, who addressed a press conference along with addl SPs Mohit Garg and Manish Kalwaniya, said the Maoist cadres are increasingly leaving the movement to return to the mainstream as is a much better perception now about the police department among the rebels than in the past.

Kulyami, who joined the rebel movement in 2007, had 19 offences of encounters against him and 12 murders. He was also involved five arsoning cases.

Rajo Tulavi, after joining the movement in 2008, had been serving in the platoon no 3 until she surrendered. She too was involved in at least eight encounter offences, two murders and equal number of arsons.

Sapna Wadde, who joined the movement in 2006 through Chatgaon dalam, served in platoon no 15 but decided to give up and return to the mainstream. She had a dozen of offences of encounters and four murders among other offences.

Gunni Madavi, another Maoist cadre who returned to the mainstream, joined the movement in 2007 and served in company no 10. She had two offences of encounters and other offences against her.

Gunni’s fellow Maoist Sunil Holi, who also served in company no 10 like her, who surrendered before police had 12 encounters, four murders and other offences against him.

Title: Will unsolved cases return to haunt pol parties this year?
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Vijayawada: From YS Vivekananda Reddy’s murder to data theft scandal, Andhra Pradesh witnessed at least three cases, which resulted in huge political battles, in 2019. With these cases remaining unsolved , political analysts feel that the issues could come back to haunt political parties later.

The first major political battle ensued after YS Vivekananda Reddy, a former MP and paternal uncle of the then opposition leader YS Jaganmohan Reddy was found murdered on April 15. The incident turned into one of the main election issues a special investigative team (SIT) was formed to probe the case.

Eventually, three persons, including Vivekananda’s personal assistant MV Krishna Reddy and two other associates — Yerram Gangi Reddy and Prakash, were arrested for allegedly tampering with the evidence. Not long after Srinivasa Reddy, a close relative of one of the prime suspects Parameshwara Reddy, was found dead. He had purportedly committed suicide.

The incident triggered a huge uproar in the state, which was witnessing intense political battles. While Jagan demanded that the case be transferred to CBI when he was in the opposition, he decided to continue with the SIT after becoming the chief minister. Recently on December 4, former chief minister N Chandrababu Naidu sought CBI intervention.

The second major political battle broke out, also during the election campaigning, when a whistle-blower claimed that the Andhra Pradesh government had allegedly leaked public data to a private firm called IT Grids. The Telangana state police raided the company as it was based in Hyderabad and found that the company had illegal access to voters’ Aadhaar, phone numbers, ration cards and other sensitive data. A tripartite political slugfest ensued as both ruling governments of Telangana and Andhra Pradesh blamed each other while Jagan criticised Naidu for the security breach. Till date, the case remains unsolved.

A controversy over deletion of voters’ names happened during the same time that was the third unsolved mystery. Several online applications were made for deletion of voters’ names through Form 7 that led to a war of words between the YSRC and TDP. Around eight lakh forms were examined and the EC found a little over 5,000 of them to be genuine. However, YSRC claimed to have helped people file around 7 lakh forms themselves.

Title: City nephrologist dishes out low-salt dhokla, fried rice, and appam for patients on dialysis
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Nagpur: Prevalence of kidney disorders has increased number of patients on dialysis in recent years. Those who undergo dialysis must forsake many delicacies that used to be a part of their diet earlier. But, a new concept of low-salt or no-salt snacks can bring this taste back in their lives.

Senior nephrologist and patron of Central India Nephrology Society, Dr Dhananjay Ookalkar, and his team have modified the recipes of some popular snacks like dhokla, fried rice, and appam and made them suitable for patients of kidney disorders and hypertension. They have used substitutes for salt and added protein-rich ingredients into these dishes.

“Dialysis has increased a lifespan of kidney patients but they face several issues regarding quality of life. Low salt or no salt food is rarely available in markets. Packaged foods also have hidden sodium contents. So, we decided to make our own low-salt options,” said Dr Ookalkar.

Those under dialysis or who have a history of chronic kidney disease (CKD) are strongly advised to avoid any food that contains over 250 mg of salt. All four dishes made in this project have only 100 mg of salt. Dialysis patients require more proteins than normal people. For this, protein-rich ingredients are added in the recipes.

Dr Ookalkar said that he wishes to popularize these snacks so that patients having kidney and hypertension can prepare them at homes. In the next phase, they will be adding many other breakfast items, especially for hypertension patients.

The dishes include rava appam, in which traditional appams are made using of rava, curd, crushed paneer and 1gm of salt with fresh vegetables. Dhokla made of crushed poha is another dish. Raw poha is grinded with curd to make dhokla plum. To make fried rice, 100gm raw rice is fried with different vegetables. The use of salt substitutes such as lemon juice, tomatoes, onions ensure taste even if salt content is low.

Dietitian Shraddha Rahate, who makes these food items, said that patients are loving them. “We have started serving these snacks to patients who are on dialysis. They find it refreshing,” she said. “Those who are on dialysis from more than three years start finding it difficult to follow strict diet restrictions. These tasty but healthy options are like boon for them. Apart from them, patients of hypertension can also have these to avoid further complications,” she added.

Title: 11 booked for forging document of Pondy grove where Bharathiyar had stayed
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

PUDUCHERRY: The CB-CID registered a case against 11 people, including the chairperson of Puducherry women’s commission and a tahsildar from Tamil Nadu, on charges of forging the document of a grove in Puducherry, where Tamil poet Bharathiyar stayed for about 10 years. They also received Rs 2.73 crore from the government when it acquired a portion of the land.

The grove, known as ‘ Kuyil Thoppu ’, is where the poet penned most of his poems during his stay in Puducherry. A case has been registered against retired public servant V C Gobinath, Puducherry women’s commission chairperson Rani Rajan Babu, her sons Ashok Thuyavan and Balaji Raja, TN tahsildar R Banumathy, P Gayathri Devi, R Prabath, S Rajalaskmi, S Rajasekaran, S Saraswathy and S Magudeswaran. All the accused, who had received shares of the compensation given by the government, are related to each other, police said.

The agency booked them under sections 120B (punishment of criminal conspiracy), 193 (punishment for giving false evidence in a judicial proceeding), 209 (dishonestly making false claim in court), 210 (fraudulently obtaining decree for sum not due) and 420 (cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property) of the Indian penal code.

The agency’s action came after a directive from Puducherry chief judicial magistrate on Monday. As per the complaint, the 11 people forged the documents of 4.34-hectare of land belonging to P Aravamudhu and two others represented by their power agent V Seenuvasamoorthy Reddiar and received a compensation of Rs 2.73 crore from the government after the government acquired 2.5 hectares of land.

The government acquired 1.46 hectare for constructing a memorial for late Congress stalwart Kamaraj, 0.61 hectare for expansion of the East Coast Road and 0.43 hectare for construction of interstate police wireless quarters.

The accused made a fake certificate dated January 30, 1935, claiming that the land was sold to them. They made a false claim for compensation based on the forged sale certificate before the court and received the compensation without the knowledge of the complainants.

The complainants, who came to know about the settlement, claimed there was no record with the government on the sale of the property. They lodged a complaint with the SP (CBCID), urging the agency to initiate action against the accused in September 2019. However, the agency, which initially began the investigation, did not proceed further and register a case.

The complainants then filed a petition before the Puducherry chief judicial magistrate, pleading for a direction to the agency to file a case, investigate into the matter and file a final report following which the agency filed a case against the accused on Monday.

Bharathiyar penned most of his poems including Kuyil Pattu at ‘Kuyil Thoppu’ in Puducherry after he sought asylum in the French territory to evade arrest from the British between 1908 and 1918. The Puducherry government, which earlier proposed to establish a memorial for Bharathiyar in the site, has failed to initiate any concrete efforts to implement the project.

Title: 29 students hurt in Himachal accident
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

The bus overturned on the Manali-Chandigarh highway, at Bilaspur in Himachal Pradesh on Tuesday. (Photo: ANI)

KOZHIKODE: As many as 31 persons, including 29 students and two teachers of MES Arts and Science College , Kalanthode near Chathamangalam, who were on a tour to Manali were injured in a road accident at Bilaspur in Himachal Pradesh on Tuesday morning.

The mishap occurred when the private tour bus overturned after the driver lost control following suspected break failure around 9.30am.

Shafi Pulpara, a teacher of the college who is part of the team, said that three students who had sustained fracture injuries in the hand have been shifted to PGI Hospital in Chandigarh.

The injuries of others are minor and they are being treated at the Bilaspur Zonal Hospital. The tour group of third year BCom students comprised a total of 51 persons. They had arrived in New Delhi by train on Monday and were proceeding by bus from Delhi to Manali when the accident took place. The parents of the three injured students are on their way to Chandigarh.

Shafi said that those who are fit to travel were planning to start their travel back home on Wednesday.

Title: VMC spends year harnessing tech for effective solid waste management, eliminating plastic
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Vijayawada: The Vijayawada Municipal Corporation ( VMC ) made significant progress on the solid-waste management front in 2019 by harnessing technological advancements.

The civic body introduced online waste management system allowing sanitation workers to use QR code scanners while collecting garbage bins from houses that could be, in turn, monitored in real time through the commissioner’s dashboard. Following the change, as many as 32 wards out of 59 have been declared as bin free. VMC also installed 45 smart bins at various locations that sends alerts to authorities as soon as they are full.

Besides, the VMC also established a composting plant with a capacity of 150 metric tonnes to process solid waste. The Construction and Demolition (C&D) waste plant has also become functional in 2019 that can process 200 metric tonnes of construction rubble every day.

The VMC has identified 43 locations for the construction of additional toilets under the Street Furniture Project to address the problem of open defecation and urination. The civic body won an award from Swacch Andhra Corporation for best toilet maintenance.

Apart from domestic garbage collection, the VMC has taken up another initiative to address the problem of bulk waste. The civic body empanelled an agency to collect and process bulk waste from hotels, restaurants and other commercial establishments. As many as 285 bulk waste generators have been identified in the city, said VMC commissioner Prasanna Vekatesh.

Meanwhile, the plastic-free drive taken up by the VMC gained momentum in the year. Apart from single-use plastic being banned, the civic body also initiated various measures to promote alternatives to plastic. Prasanna Venkatesh said the distribution of cloth, jute and paper bags have been yielding positive results. He observed that earlier three tonnes of plastic used to be generated in the city every day that has now come down to less than two tonnes. The VMC also signed an MoU with UltraTech cement to recycle the plastic.

On the administrative front, the VMC set up a social media complaint cell to address any civic issue within 24 hours. The commissioner said the initiative has got a huge response from citizens and it has redressed more than 90% of the complaints within stipulated time.

“For employees of VMC, the year 2019 will remain a memorable one as they started getting salaries through the 010 account on the first day of every month. Although there are issues that are yet to be resolved we are constantly working to resolve them,” said Prasanna Vekatesh.

Title: Dense fog, potholed city roads expose commuters to danger
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Bareilly: Damaged city roads and reduced visibility due to dense fog have been exposing commuters’ lives to danger, whereas fund-starved Public Works Department (PWD) officials say they feel helpless as repeated demands for funds for the repairing of the roads went unheard.

Commuting on damaged Choupla road, Pilibhit road, Police Lines road, Quila overbridge, Bisalpur road, among others, has become life-threatening. Besides, the condition of several roads connecting prominent city areas such as Mini Bypass-Quila road, Choupla, city station, Police Lines, Pilibhit road, etc, has deteriorated further in the absence of proper maintenance.

According to PWD officials, the department is fund-starved and does not have money to repair the roads on its own. “We have been waiting for the government to release the fund sought by us for the repair and the maintenance of the roads.”

Speaking to TOI, PWD, Bareilly division, executive engineer Harbansh Singh said, “We have been sending detailed reports on the condition of city roads that need repairing repeatedly. Besides the reports, videos and photos of the damaged city roads, including Sitapur road, Bisalpur road, Pilibhit road, Mini Bypass-Quila overbridge, etc, were also sent to the state government for the approval of funds to the tunes of Rs120 crore for their re[air and maintenance. Since we have not received the money yet, the condition of the roads remains unchanged.”

Daily commuter Saurabh Singh, a resident of Green Park locality, said, “Commuting is risky with flyover constructions underway at Choupla, Satellite and near Lal Phatak. The roads have been damaged due to the installation of heavy machines for the construction work. Since motorists have been using service lanes, the authorities must repair them for their convenience and ease off traffic congestions. It is very unsafe to travel in the evening as potholes become invisible due to heavy fog.”

PWD officials said they would repair the roads as soon as they receive the fund.

Meanwhile, traffic inspector JN Asthana told TOI, “With flyover construction underway in three prominent areas, it has become difficult to maintain smooth traffic movement, especially during peak hours. It is the duty of the department taking up the construction/repair work install signage boards cautioning commuters of the apparent danger at the construction sites. Besides, barricading should be done and field workers in reflective uniforms should be deputed to alert commuters near the construction sites.”

Title: AITUC wants mining corp, says no to auction of ore
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Panaji: The All India Trade Union Congress (AITUC) has opposed the auctioning of mining leases and demanded that the government form a state-owned Goa Minerals Development Corporation.

“All the mining workers who have lost jobs due to mining closure should be re-employed in the corporation with continuity of service. Pending formation of this corporation, all thosewho lost jobs must be paid a sum of Rs 25,000 per month as ‘retention allowance’,” general secretary Christopher Fonseca told reporters.

All trucks, barges, earth moving machineries, mining equipment and infrastructure must be systematically pooled and used to operate the mining leases under the corporation, Fonseca said, adding that it should be managed by a board of directors.

“The second complete closure of mining operations has devastated Goa’s economy. Tens of thousands of workers and mining dependants have lost their jobs and without any tangible source of income, are presently facing extreme hardships,” he said.

AITUC has also demanded 7th pay benefits to panchayat employees, KTC transportation to and from all the industrial estates, settling of overtime wages of river navigation department employees for the last 24 months, issues of KTC badli drivers and conductors, pending issues of panchayat employees, lifeguards and BSNL contract workers.

AITUC also demanded that unskilled workers be paid a minimum of Rs 700 per day, semi-skilled Rs 770 per day, skilled Rs 847 and highly skilled Rs 932.

Title: CCP to finalise contractor for pay-parking soon
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Panaji: The Corporation of the City of Panaji (CCP) is in the process of finalising the pay-parking contractor for the city. The highest of the two bidders has quoted Rs 57 lakhs per annum.

“The bids are currently under scrutiny,” an official from the civic body said.

The pay-parking scheme is being implemented on nine stretches in Panaji around-the-clock. CCP decided to have pay-parking for 24 hours, including Sundays and public holidays, instead of 12 hours as was earlier decided. This is because of the high volume of offshore casino vehicles that occupy and block parking spaces. Parking fee on two-wheelers will be also be imposed by CCP.

“The contractor will be responsible for marking the -parking slots and affixing boards. They will also use hand-held electronic ticketing machines to issue tickets,” the CCP official said.

“CCP will insist on a 50% bank guarantee so that the corporation is not at a loss should the contractor default on payments,” the official added.

Till now, a number of meetings have been convened between offshore casinos, the tourism department and traffic police to sort out traffic congestion and haphazard parking of casino vehicles. When asked about the assurance of vehicles being parked at the multi-storied parking complex at Patto, mayor Uday Madkaikar said the issue will be taken up right after pay-parking is implemented.

He also said that there are around 300 two-wheelers belonging to casino employees that are parked in the vicinity each day.

The bid for the tender had to be kept open for an additional 10 days after CCP received just one bidder.

In 2017, the corporation burnt its fingers when the company chosen for the pay-parking system failed to pay CCP Rs 24 crore, this even while it continued to collect parking fees from motorists. The system’s attempt to bring about traffic-discipline also ran aground.

According to the last contract, the contractor was required to pay CCP Rs 63 lakh per year and in turn, collect parking fees for two-wheelers and four-wheelers in the city’s core zone. The contractor was required to depute 60 workers to collect parking fees but it failed to do that, as well.

Title: Gorewada daily wagers oppose contract system
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Nagpur: Over 50-60 temporary forest labourers working at Gorewada Rescue Centre in the city have expressed dissent over bringing them under the authority of a private contractor who will take over from Wednesday.

Last month, leading service provider BVG India Limited bagged the contract to manage the workers who operate as daily wagers for works like chowkidars, firefighting, cleaning, animal care and feeding among host of other outdoor services.

Till now, these daily wagers were recruited by Forest Development Corporation of Maharashtra (FDCM) for three months and after a break of one month were taken back again. The same process is being followed for the last 5-6 years.

Through tendering process recently, the FDCM handed over their services to BVG group. Being experienced, all the labourers have been recruited on contract by the BVG.

The labourers were told by RS Kanojia, secretary of the Bharatiya Janata Kamgar Mahasangh (BJKM), not to join the contractor “as their services can be terminated any time for non-performance”.

Kanojia, in a press release, said, “The union is opposed to a private party as it will deprive workers of their basic rights, seniority, government benefits, health scheme, and leaves etc.”

FDCM officials argued that the new contract system is in interest of the workers. “They will be paid Rs9,200 instead of Rs8,200 earlier. As it is being daily wagers, they had no government benefits. Now they will be paid continuously for 11 months, the period of contract,” they said.

The officials said most of the workers have agreed to go on contract and have also submitted their documents to BVG. “However, a section of them are being misguided by the union leaders,” the FDCM officials said.

On Tuesday, the FDCM officials held talks with the workers to resolve the issue. However, the labourers said Kanojia would meet FDCM officials on Wednesday after which a final decision will be taken.

Title: Focus on quality edu must: Parents
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Hyderabad: Parents said unless quality of education is not given priority at the start of the academic year, conducting special classes for a couple of months before Secondary School Certificate (SSC) exam will not have an impact on students. They said importance must be given to making students understand the subject.“In these special classes, schools are only concentrating on teaching how to score pass marks. Had they focused on teaching subjects from the start of the academic year, these special classes wouldn’t have been required,” said Narasimha Y, a parent. tnn

Title: Biscuits, bananas to replace sprouts & pulihora in schools
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Starting January 2, 2020, class 10 students preparing for the Secondary School Certificate (SSC) examination in the city will be served biscuits or bananas as snacks instead of sprouts and tamarind rice.

The education department officials are planning to provide these items along with mid-day meals as the students have to be in schools from 8.30am to 5.30pm. “They will either get banana or biscuits. If more funds are allocated, chikki will also be provided,” said B Venkata Narasamma, district education officer, Hyderabad. She said that the money for providing snacks will come from the collector’s fund and donors. “If any donor approaches a school and wants to fund snacks for children, we will allow it as students will get more food,” she added, and said that they have been providing snacks for class 10 students for the past two years.

The officials said that they have decided to do away with sprouts and tamarind rice as many schools in the district have no kitchen facility. They said that it was becoming difficult to cook these items and serve to students on time.

The said items will reach the schools in the morning so that teachers and principals can choose a time and distribute it to students as per convenience.

Parents and activists welcomed the move.

Title: No obituary reference for Thomas Chandy in assembly
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The special session of the assembly, which was convened to pass a resolution against CAA, did not take up the obituary reference of Thomas Chandy who died on December 20.

The usual practice in the assembly is that when the session is convened obituary references of the MLAs or former MLAs who have died after the last session are taken up on the first day and the house adjourns for the day as a mark of respect. But, on Tuesday, when the special session was convened there was no obituary reference for Thomas Chandy who was a three-time MLA of the House and a former minister.

On Tuesday, Congress MLA K S Sabarinadhan registered his protest for not paying tributes to the senior MLA through a letter to the speaker. However, P Sreeramakrishnan told the House that the obituary reference was not taken up since it was a special one-day session convened for passing a crucial resolution, and would be taken up in the next session.

“It was most unfortunate that the House went into the official proceedings without any reference to the death of Thomas Chandy. This has not been the practice of the House,” Sabarinadhan said.

During the 14th state assembly, the House has lost four MLAs including Thomas Chandy. K K Ramachandran Nair who represented Chengannur constituency died in January 2018. P B Abdul Razaak who represented Manjeswaram constituency died in October 2018 and former finance minister K M Mani died in April 2019.

Title: ARTO thrashes auto driver, video viral
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Jhansi: A video that went viral in Mahoba on Monday shows the ARTO and his associates badly thrashing an elderly auto-rickshaw driver. The video also shows a cop intervening and trying to save the driver. By late night, both the parties lodged cases against each other.

As per reports, auto driver Rakesh Yadav was waiting near Bajariya police station in search of passengers when ARTO Mahoba, Ajay Yadav, along with his team arrived there and challaned Rakesh to which he objected. The discussion turned into a heated argument and some men in khaki accompanying the ARTO started thrashing the driver, who was also seen hurling abuses.

The entire scenario was filmed by some passerby on mobile who later made it viral. Hearing the news, a number of auto drivers reached the police station and started agitating against the ARTO, alleging him of extorting money and demanded action.

Late night both sides lodged cases against each other. An FIR was lodged against the ARTO, his driver and two constables under sections 323, 504, 427 of IPC and against the auto driver under sections 323, 504 IPC.

Giving this information, SP Mahoba Manilal Patidar said, “Police are investigating the matter and will take further action accordingly.”

Title: Civic polls: Congress to move HC against EC, TRS
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: The Telangana Congress has decided to approach the high court against the state election commission and TRS government for announcing the municipal poll schedule without finalising the reservation of wards for SCs, STs, BCs and women.

While making it clear that the party is not against the municipal polls, the Congress alleged that the delay in finalising quota for urban local body polls was a conspiracy by the TRS.

“Chief Minister K Chandrasekhar Rao does not want to give time to the opposition parties to finalise candidates to contest municipal elections. If reservation of 120 municipal chairpersons and 10 municipal corporation mayors is announced on January 4 or 5, followed by the reservation of 50% of the total 4,000 wards that go to the polls in urban local bodies, we would have to finalise the candidates and complete other formalities of issuing the B-forms in 24 to 48 hours as the nomination process begins on January 8,” Telangana Pradesh Congress Committee president and Nalgonda MP N Uttam Kumar Reddy told TOI.

On the other hand, the Congress has adopted ‘select and elect’ policy for finalisation of candidates.

The party leadership has decided to leave it to the local cadre to select candidates and take responsibility to ensure that they are elected by working for their victory in the urban local bodies which goes to polls on January 22 as per the schedule announced by the state election commission.

Title: Karvy goes for rejig; new CEO for financial services business
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Amitabh Chaturvedi (File photo)

HYDERABAD: Scam-hit Karvy Group on Tuesday said it has kicked off a restructuring exercise and has also initiated a major management reshuffle as part of efforts to improve overall governance and functioning.

The Hyderabad headquartered group said it is in the process of restructuring its overall business into two verticals — financial services and non-financial services — and has brought on board Amitabh Chaturvedi as Group CEO of its financial services business.

The rejig comes a little over a month after stock market regulator Sebi banned Karvy Group flagship Karvy Stock Broking Ltd (KSBL) for pledging securities of its clients, without their knowledge, to raise funds from banks and financial institutions in violation of the new Sebi rules that kicked in on October 1, 2019.

KSBL had pledged securities of around 95,000 clients to raise over Rs 2300 crore from various banks and financial institutions including ICICI Bank, HDFC Bank, Bajaj Finance, Aditya Birla Finance, Axis Bank, IndusInd Bank, among others.
