Sebi had, vide its circular dated June 20, 2019, asked all brokers to segregate clients’ funds and securities by September 30 in compliance with its order but KSBL failed to comply with the new norms.

Karvy Group chairman C Parthasarathy said in a statement on Tuesday that Chaturvedi has been appointed Group CEO of financial services with a mandate to completely overhaul the governance processes, ensure best practices and bring in greater fiduciary discipline to these businesses.

Chaturvedi, who has over 30 years of experience in the financial services space, has earlier been associated with organisations such as Dhanalakshmi Bank, Reliance AMC, ICICI and Essel Group.

The restructuring will see stock broking, wealth management, commodities trading and investment banking, among others, come under the ambit of financial services. On the other hand, non-financial services will comprise of data management services, data analytics, market research and allied businesses.

Karvy Group, which was set up in 1982, said changes in senior management are also being initiated and an experienced team would assist Chaturvedi in implementing the group's vision of having a strong presence in the financial services space.

Title: GPSC to fill 70posts by March
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Panaji: Youths aspiring to join the prestigious Goa civil services will get an opportunity in the New Year with the Goa public service commission (GPSC) deciding to fill around 70 posts of gazette officers.

The commission had advertised 39 posts for openings in various departments for which 772 candidates had submitted applications. Advertisement for the remaining 31 posts will be issued shortly.

Speaking to TOI, commission chairman Jose Manuel Noronha said that a computer-based recruitment test (CBRT) for 31 posts will be held on January 19 in three sessions.

Applications were invited for a post of senior psychiatrist, nine medical officers, a statistical officer, three child development project officers, 24 junior scale officers and an assistant professor in architecture. Noronha said that 39 posts, including those of junior scale officers, will be filled by March 2020 and a CBRT will be held for the third time for the assistant agriculture officer’s post.

Noronha advised aspirants to study old questions papers available on GPSC website in preparation. He said that going by past trends, around 4,000 candidates are expected to submit their applications for the 31 posts.

“If candidates study and work sincerely, cracking CBDT won’t be an uphill task,” he said, adding, “There is no role for training institutes to crack CBRT”. He said there is always a rush of applications for junior scale officers’ posts as they are open to graduates.

In all, 772 candidates had applied for the 31 posts that were advertised.

Applications were invited for a post of senior psychiatrist, nine medical officers, a statistical officer, three child development project officers, 24 junior scale officers and an assistant professor in architecture

Title: Numaish safety steps pass Telangana high court muster, to begin today
Content:
Numaish has put in place several safety measures to prevent a repeat of last year’s mishap

HYDERABAD: Expressing prima facie satisfaction over the safety measures taken by the state and the exhibition society, the Telangana high court on Tuesday gave the green signal to the authorities and the society to commence the 45 day long exhibition from January 1, 2020.However, it added a rider that the state legal services authority’s member secretary will physically inspect the exhibition, examine all the safety measures and would revert to the court with a report by Jan 6. We will review the issue again after receiving the report, said a bench of Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan and Justice A Abhishek Reddy while hearing a PIL filed by advocate Khaja Aijazuddin expressing concern over the safety of the lakhs of people visiting this exhibition during the 45 day Numaish .State’s special counsel Sarat Kumar briefed the bench about the elaborate arrangements made by the state and the society for the safe conduct of the event. Had it not been for the keen interest shown by the bench, things would not have been this safe, he said. The bench told him that the credit must go to the petitioner.Though the water board had expressed its inability to supply and keep ready huge quantum of water to meet the needs of fire department, the society and the authorities had used the 6 bore wells existing within the Exhibition grounds and drew water to an extent of 3 lakh litres and filled them in two sumps available within the society space. This will be useful and available to the fire department to fill their hydrants in case of any emergency, the state counsel explained. And we have kept ready 80 hydrants this year at the venue, Sarat said reminding the court that there were none last year. The bench too took the issue seriously and has been summoning the officials and records to ensure a safe Numaish this year unlike in 2019 Numaish where the exhibition was disrupted for a few days on account of a sudden fire at the exhibition.Aijazuddin brought to the notice of the court that as per the official plan there should be 1600 stalls but he officials had permitted 2900 stalls. The bench perused the records and said that it wants to ensure that the required space gap is properly maintained between the stalls, their rows and the nearby substation. Legal Services Authority would inspect those aspects in the next few days. The case has been posted for January 6

Title: At 3.1 degrees Celsius, Dehradun records coldest December morning in 8 years
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

The last time the temperature had dropped this low was on December 24, 2011

DEHRADUN: The city on Tuesday recorded its coldest day of December since 2011, with the minimum temperature touching 3.1 degrees Celsius (about three notches below normal), according to the Indian Meteorological Department (IMD).

The last time the temperature had dropped this low was on December 24, 2011, when the minimum temperature was 2.6 degrees Celsius. Notably, the temperature has settled below 4 degrees Celsius twice last week in the city.

Speaking to TOI, Bikram Singh, director, regional meteorological centre, said, “The minimum temperatures across the state are settling below normal and Dehradun is no exception. As per our records, Tuesday’s was the lowest minimum temperature in the month of December since 2011.”

In 2018, the minimum temperature in December was 5.2 degrees Celsius. It was 5.8 and 5.4 degrees Celsius in 2017 and 2016 respectively. In 2015, the temperature had plunged to 3.4 degrees Celsius on December 25.

Speaking about the dip in temperature, Rashi Rawat, a college student and a local resident, said, “It was indeed the coldest morning this winter. I was going for my morning tuition at 7:30am and was chilled to the bone. I hope things improve.”

In Mussoorie, the minimum temperature was recorded at 3.1 degrees Celsius. In Mukteshwar in Nainital district , it was 0.5 degrees Celsius. The cold seemed to have spared Pantnagar in US Nagar to some extent, where the minimum temperature was 5.7 degrees Celsius.

Meanwhile, the Met office has forecast a change in weather from January 1 onwards. The minimum temperatures will start rising and settle around normal in the beginning of the year, as the western disturbance will start impacting the weather conditions in Uttarakhand. High-altitude places are likely to receive snowfall, while isolated places in the plains are expected to be lashed by rain.

Very light to light snowfall is likely to occur at isolated places in Uttarkashi, Chamoli, Rudraprayag and districts of Kumaon region on January 1 as per the Met office. Places located at a height of 2,500 meters and above will be more affected, Met officials said.

Title: Hyderabad: Lorry hits auto; Class 7 student dies, six injured
Content:
The overturned auto at Habsiguda crossroad

HYDERABAD: A class VII student, who dreamt of pursuing an IIT course, was killed when a lorry hit the autorickshaw he was travelling in at Habsiguda crossroads on Tuesday.Avanth Kumar, 13, a student of Bhashyam High School in Habsiguda, died on the spot, while his elder brother, Vedanth, 14, who was also in the auto, escaped with minor injuries. The accident occurred at 7.40 am when the sand-laden lorry crashed into the auto which was on its way to the school. Under the impact of the crash, the auto overturned and Avanth, who was thrown out, came under the lorry wheels. There were seven students in the auto.“Five other students sustained minor injuries and were shifted to Aditya Hospital. They were later discharged. Auto driver Srinivasu also sustained minor injuries,” said Uppal inspector P Venkateshwarlu. Police said the lorry driver fled from the spot leaving the vehicle.“The accident happened due to negligence of the lorry driver. There was no mistake on the part of the auto driver, who has been driving the three-wheeler to the school for almost 15 years,” Santosh Kumar, father of Avanth, said.“Avanth was very intelligent. It was his dream to study in IIT-Bombay. We had chalked out everything accordingly for him. Now, he is gone,” Santosh, who is an RTC bus conductor at Chengicherla bus depot, said. The family resides in Kalyanpuri, Uppal.A Bhashyam school staffer said they provide school buses. “We operate two school buses, but some parents prefer using their own transport. Avanth was a class topper and very active in school,” he said.A case under sections 304-A (causing death by negligence), 337 (causing hurt by act endangering life or personal safety of others) and 279 (rash driving) was filed against the lorry driver.

Title: 1 dead, 16 hurt as Sabari pilgrims’ van rams truck
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

The vehicle hit a truck carrying wooden logs that was parked on the MC Road near Perumbavoor

KOCHI: A 44-year-old Sabarimala pilgrim died and 16 others, including four children, were injured when their van rammed the rear side of a truck carrying wooden logs that was parked on the MC Road near Perumbavoor in the early hours of Tuesday.

The deceased has been identified as Dharmalingam (44), a native of Gandhi Nagar, Tirupur, Tamil Nadu. The van was hired by the Ayyappa devotees from Tirupur and they were on their way to Sabarimala.

Police have started inspecting CCTV cameras in the area to confirm whether the van was speeding when the accident happened. Police said that those sustained severe injuries have been admitted to hospitals in Perumbavoor and Ernakulam.

“The incident took place near Karikode. Dharmalingam was rushed to hospital but he succumbed to his injuries. Five others have been admitted in a critical condition. The truck was parked on the state highway and we suspect that the van driver lost control, before hitting the rear side of the truck,” said a police officer.

Local residents came running hearing the noise and rescued the people who were stuck inside the vehicle. The deceased person had to be pulled out of the van by fire and rescue service officers. The accident happened at 3.45am. The front portion of the van was mangled in the collision.

Soon after the accident, another car hit the rear side of the van. The front portion of the car was also severely damaged in the collision. The passengers in the car suffered minor injuries and were discharged after receiving medical assistance from a nearby hospital, said a police officer. Police said the car passengers were also Ayyappa devotees who were coming from Coimbatore.

The body of the deceased was handed over to the kin after an autopsy.

Title: Man crushed as sugarcane-laden truck overturns
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Pilibhit: A 55-year-old marginal farmer, Natthu Lal, of Maseet village under Barkhera police station was crushed under a sugarcane-laden truck that overturned on Barkhera-Daulatpur road in the late evening hours on Monday.

The accident took place when Lal was on his way home from his field. The truck driver fled the spot, leaving his vehicle behind.

Upon getting information, Bisalpur circle officer Praveen Malik rushed to the spot and launched a rescue operation with the help of a crane.

Police sent the body for autopsy and impounded the truck. “An FIR against the unidentified driver was registered under sections 304A (causing death by negligence) and 279 (rash driving) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC),” said SHO Umesh Kumar Solanki.

Title: Net metering to continue for solar rooftop consumers
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Nagpur: In a major jolt to state discom MSEDCL, Maharashtra Electricity Regulatory Commission (MERC) has rejected its demand of making net billing compulsory for solar rooftop consumers.

According to the MERC (Grid Interactive Rooftop Renewable Energy Generating Systems Regulations) 2019, it is up to the consumer to decide whether he wants net metering or net billing.

The net billing system proposed by MSEDCL would have made solar rooftop unviable and had been opposed by all consumers including Maharashtra Solar Manufacturers Association (MASMA).

Some aspects of the new regulations are in favour of MSEDCL. The cost of net meter and renewable energy meter used to be borne by the discom so far. Now, it will be borne by the consumer. However, the reality is that MSEDCL had not supplied even a single net meter to consumers so far. The consumers had purchased the meter on their own and MSEDCL had not refunded the cost to any consumer. Therefore, this change won’t affect the consumers much in real terms.

Secondly, MERC has decided to levy a grid support charge on consumers having load of more than 10 KW. While the formula for calculating this charge is mentioned in the notification, MSEDCL will have to seek its levy in the next tariff petition. The charge will be known after MERC gives a ruling on MSEDCL’s petition.

There are many clauses that are in favour of the consumers. The maximum solar load permissible on a MSEDCL distribution transformer was up to 40% of the transformer capacity. Now it has been increased to 70% with a deviation of 5% on either side. MSEDCL can permit 100% after conducting a load study.

MSEDCL has been given a timeline for processing the applications of solar consumers. It will have to issue a letter of sanction within 15 days of receiving the application. The testing of net meter and its installation has to be done within next 10 days. Grid synchronization and signing of agreement will have to be accomplished in another ten days. The registration fee has been reduced for smaller consumers. Earlier, it was Rs500 up to 5kW and Rs1,000 thereafter. Now, it is Rs500 up to 20kW and Rs100 for every 20kW or part of. High tension (HT) consumers will have to pay Rs5,000 flat.

Other clauses of the regulations are: All meters to have advanced metering infrastructure (AMI) facility with RS485 for higher communication port and check meter for solar generation is compulsory above 20kW and it is to be installed by MSEDCL.

Title: Kanpur bids adieu to 2019 with coldest December night, freezes at 0 Celsius
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

take a chill pill: Locals brave chill to greet New Year. Light rainfall expected on Thursday

Kanpur: Already in the grip of extreme cold conditions, Kanpur bid adieu to 2019 by recording the coldest December night in 48 years as mercury plummeted to zero degrees Celsius on Tuesday.

According to weathermen, night temperature in Kanpur has never dipped to zero degrees Celsius in December since 1971. There are chances of light rains on January 2 and 4, they added.

In January 2013, minimum temperature dropped even below zero degrees twice while in January 2003, night temperature touched zero degree mark six times. The same year, minimum temperature dipped below zero degree Celsius twice. The all-time lowest minimum temperature in Kanpur was recorded at -1.1 degrees Celsius on January 8, 2013.

On January 9, 2013, night temperature was recorded at -0.4 degrees Celsius. However, the winter of 2003 was the coldest as night temperature touched zero degree mark for record six times (January 12, 14, 15, 20, 21 and 23). On January 13 and 22 the same year, minimum temperature had touched -1 degree Celsius. This made January 2003 the coldest month since 1971 when Met department of CSA University started maintaining records. Also in 2003, the day temperature plummeted to lowest since 1971. On January 21, 2003, the day temperature was only 8.2 degrees Celsius. Again on January 12 the same year, day temperature was recorded at 8.8 degrees Celsius. On January 11 in 2001, minimum temperature was 0.5 degree Celsius and 0.6 degree Celsius the next day. On December 26, 1973, Kanpur recorded minimum temperature of 2 degrees Celsius. In 2002, lowest minimum temperature in January and February was 2 degrees Celsius. On December 29, 2012, night temperature had plummeted to 2 degrees Celsius but did not fall further.

Year 2014 was comparatively warmer but on December 21, 2015, minimum temperature fell to just 0.8 degree Celsius.

On December 20 and 22 the same year, minimum temperature was 1 degree Celsius.

Year 2019 saw the lowest day temperature of 9.4 degrees Celsius on December 30.

Title: ICICI Bank to challenge Telangana HC stay on DRT order against Karvy Stock Broking
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Hyderabad: ICICI Bank on Tuesday said it is in the process of challenging the Telangana High Court order staying the Debt Recovery Tribunal-II Hyderabad order of December 9, 2019, in a plea that it had filed against Karvy Stock Broking Ltd (KSBL) and others.

ICICI Bank, which lent over Rs 625 crore to Karvy, said the tribunal had ordered Karvy to deposit sufficient security for its dues within 15 days, failing which its properties would be attached and had restrained Karvy from transferring, encumbering or creating any third party interest on the pledged properties. The bank also said the tribunal had ordered the appointment of Advocate Commissioner to take possession of all the properties and served notices on the defendants with regard to the travel restraint and asset disclosure that it had sought against Karvy and all the defendants.

The high court had, in its order dated December 24, 2019, said: “Prima facie the order dated 9-12-2019 in IA No 5811 of 2019 in OA No 833 of 2019 of the 1st respondent being an ex parte order is prejudicial to the petitioner. Therefore, there shall be interim suspension as prayed for.”

ICICI Bank, however, said the high court has neither stayed the DRT proceedings as a whole, nor stayed the tribunal’s orders in entirety and has only stayed the operation of the Advocate Commissioner. “The DRT orders requiring the defendants to deposit sufficient security and imposing a non-disposal injunction on the properties have been upheld by the high court and continue to be binding on the defendants. ICICI Bank is in the process of challenging the high court’s order in relation to the appointment of the Advocate Commissioner,” ICICI Bank said in a release. TNN

Title: President Ram Nath Kovind's wish to visit Sabarimala sends officials in a tizzy
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

President Ram Nath Kovind

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: President Ram Nath Kovind has expressed interest for a darshan at Sabarimala when he reaches Kochi on Sunday. The office of the Rashtrapathi Bhavan has enquired about the facilities including chopper services available to reach Sabarimala.

“The government has asked the Travancore Devaswom Board whether it can arrange a helipad at Sannidhanam. There is no possibility for setting up a new helipad now. But we have communicated that there is a huge water tank which can be converted into a helipad at Pandithavalam,” said N Vasu, president of Travancore Devaswom Board.

However, he was not sure whether the Rashtrapathi Bhavan will be satisfied with this proposal. “The President’s security team will have to give the clearance first. It is not possible to set up an alternative helipad. We will have to first get the forest department’s clearance for it and that has many formalities,” said Vasu.

A senior police official said that the President is visiting Kochi on Sunday en route to Lakshadweep. “It will not be possible for the President to trek the hill shrine due to security reasons. Hence we have not received any confirmation whether he will be visiting the Sabarimala,” said the police official.

The state government has communicated about the facilities it can provide at Sabarimala to the Rashtrapathi Bhavan. “We are yet to get an official confirmation of his darshan at Sabarimala,” said an official from the devaswom minister’s office.

Title: Ambil Odha restoration work likely to start in a month
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

TIMES VIEW

The restoration of Ambil Odha should not be confined to removal of silt, garbage and debris, installing iron mesh and building a retaining wall. The main reason for its flooding last year was numerous encroachments along it. Slums, shops and even cowsheds have come up along its banks. They obstructed and shrunk the waterway, causing the flooding. A firm stand about removing these encroachments is an absolute must if we want to prevent a repeat of September 25, 2019.

====

Pune: The civic body is likely to start the Ambil Odha redevelopment project in a month from four locations near Pune-Satara road.

The Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) has issued 16 tenders for different works, including removal of silt and debris from the nullah. Each tender involves works amounting to about Rs22 lakh.

Susmita Shirke, the head of the PMC’s drainage department, said, “The tender process will be completed in a month, after which the ground work will start. This is the beginning of the restoration project in the flood-affected areas.”

The PMC decided to repair and restore Ambil Odha after the September 25 deluge that claimed many lives. The restoration and repair works aim to improve its water carrying capacity and enhance the safety of residents living along the nullah. The project cost is estimated to be Rs300 crore. According to the PMC officials, different works would be carried out across the city with the help of local ward offices.

Shirke said iron mesh would be fitted on the borders of the bridges across the nullah to prevent citizens from throwing garbage in it.

According to the PMC’s plan, the project includes construction of a 5km retaining wall along the nullah. Residential areas adjacent to the nullah would be protected by it.

Heavy showers had inundated Tangewala society near Aranyeshwar during the September 25 deluge. The parking areas of Treasure Park society were flooded, damaging over 600 vehicles. The residents of Gururaj society, too, had suffered damage. Areas dotting Sinhagad and Satara Road, Sahakarnagar, Bibvewadi, Ambegaon, Katraj and Kondhwa were also affected by the deluge. A cleanliness drive would be carried out in all these areas.

A group of citizens had inspected the areas affected by the deluge and had given their suggestions for the nullah restoration work.

Title: House passes resolution for Anglo-Indian quota
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The assembly on Tuesday passed a resolution requesting the central government to take immediate action to ensure a continued nominated representation of Anglo-Indians in the Lok Sabha and the state assemblies, which expires on January 26.

After unanimously ratifying the amendment bill for extending reservation for SC/ST communities in Parliament and state assemblies for another 10 years through a statutory resolution, the government resolution moved by chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan urged the Centre to initiate measures to introduce a similar amendment bill to protect the rights of Anglo-Indian community.

Taking part in the discussion, opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala said this amounted to an open attack against minorities and asked the Centre to rectify its mistake. “The Union law minister said in Parliament that there were only 296 Anglo-Indians in the country, while their actual population is around 3.47 lakh,” he pointed out.

Meanwhile, presenting the resolution to ratify the amendment bill for extending SC/ST representation till January 26, 2030, the CM said the reservation was crucial for eradicating the centuries-old caste system and discriminations.

“The SC/ST reservation in government jobs besides in the Indian legislature is vital for ensuring socio-economic justice for the community,” he said.

Title: Badshahi Ashurkhana beautification hits political bump, halted
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Workers called it quits on Tuesday. They filled up the pits dug up for planting saplings and left

HYDERABAD: Renovation and beautification works of the historic Badshahi Ashurkhana in Old City was stopped abruptly on Tuesday due to political interference. Badshahi Ashurkhana is the second oldest building in Hyderabad and officials took up conservation works on the instructions of the high court.

While the department of heritage is looking after renovation works, the GHMC has taken up beautification of the area outside the Ashurkhana entrance. Civic body workers had dug up pits to plant saplings and create two landscaped gardens on either side of the main gate.

But suddenly on Tuesday, the workers filled up the pits and left, said Mir Abbas Ali Moosvi, Mutavalli (custodian) of the Badshahi Ashurkhana. He alleged that a local politician had prevailed upon civic officials to stop the beautification work so that the area could be re-allotted to hawkers, who were evicted during an anti-encroachment drive. The encroachments around the structure were removed following intervention of the HC about a decade ago.

“Since then, the area on either side of the main gate has been lying idle, and there are efforts to encroach upon them. We requested the GHMC to take up beautification works to prevent encroachments. But even as the work was half way through, it was abandoned. A local politician had ensured that the work is stopped,” Moosvi told TOI.

Badshahi Ashurkhana is the second oldest structure in Hyderabad south of Musi river. It was constructed in 1594AD, three years after Charminar by Qutub Shahi king Mohammad Quli Qutub Shah. It is a protected monument but due to centuries of neglect it fell on bad days. While the main building was waterproofed to prevent soaking of rain water, Naqqar Khana, Aabdana, and ancillary structures lay in ruins. There have been no efforts to restore them.

According to INTACH city convener, P Anuradha Reddy, soon after the shifting of the capital from Golconda to Hyderabad, the Qutub Shahis built Charminar. It was followed by Badshahi Ashurkhana and Darul Shifa, the first multi-storied government hospital in these parts of the world. The Ashurkhana was the centre of attraction and prime structure during the Qutub Shahi period. The rulers would lit it up during Moharram.

Abbas Ali Moosvi said the enamel work inside the building is still fresh. It is a masterpiece of Persian enamel work. “Unfortunately, there is none to look after the building, though Agha Khan trust takes care of certain things. It needs regular flow of funds for upkeep. Though the Ashurkhana was built in 1594AD, the enamel work was carried out in 1611AD.

Ali Asgar Bilgrami, who served as director of Hyderabad archaeology department in 1920s, had named Ashurkhana as older than Imam Baras of Hooghly and Lucknow. While ancillary units are in ruins, the main building is in secondary stage of dilapidation. It houses 14 diamond-studded alams.

Title: Pune Metro trials to start soon, two stations to be ready by February
Content:
The Sant Tukaramnagar station is taking shape rapidly

PUNE: With a three-coach rake in place, the stage is set for the trial runs of the Pune Metro rail project.The testing is expected to be completed by March and, by the second half of this year, Metro services are likely to start in the two priority stretches in Pune and Pimpri Chinchwad.At present, the rake has been placed at the Sant Tukaramnagar station on the PCMC-Swargate line. Various agencies of the Indian Railways are in the process of testing various parameters — including safety — and infrastructure on the six-kilometre stretch between the Sant Tukaramnagar and Phugewadi stations.In a couple of days, Maharashtra Metro Rail Corporation Limited (MahaMetro) will hold trial runs of the Metro rake. A second three-car rake is expected to arrive in Pune in the next three days. It too will be installed on the Sant Tukaramnagar-Phugewadi stretch. A MahaMetro official said the civil work of both these stations would be completed by the middle of February.MahaMetro managing director Brijesh Dixit said full Metro services could start in some stretches of the Vanaz-Ramwadi and PCMC-Swargate corridors. “We will not be able to set an exact date of commencement of commercial operations, but are very hopeful that the trials would be completed by March at the earliest. The testing is a long process, as we have to fulfil various parameters. Following the completion of the trial runs and the construction of the stations, Metro services will be available for the public,” Dixit said on Tuesday.An essential part of the testing phase is the certification by the Research Design and Standards Organization and the Commissioner of Metro Rail Safety — both bodies will check if the work was done in accordance with the drawings and plans.Dixit said MahaMetro plans to start trials of Metro rakes on the Vanaz-Garware College priority stretch in the next two months. Two stations — Anandnagar and Garware College — will be completed on the stretch on priority. “The work had been slowed down due to non-availability of land, However, most issues have now been sorted out,” Dixit said.

Title: Blaze at bunk: Car, 2 fuel dispensers gutted in fire
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

HYDERABAD: A car and two petrol dispensing machines were burnt to a crisp in a fire accident at a Shaikpet petrol pump on Tuesday. The fire department has confirmed that no one was hurt in the mishap . The fire control room received an alert at around 2.06 pm from Indian Oil petrol pump at Shaikpet.

A pump staffer noticed that fuel was leaking from the tank of a Skoda Superb (2010 model) while it was being filled. He stopped pumping in fuel and the driver of the car, Basheer Ahmed from Hakeempet, got out to check what was wrong. “All of a sudden, a fire broke out from beneath the car. Within seconds, flames engulfed the entire car and two fuel dispensing cabins in the petrol pump. The driver and all workers at the pump ran out on seeing the flames,” said station fire officer Chandra Shekhar .

A fire tender and a mist bullet were put in place. “The car and the fuel dispensing cabins were completely damaged. Though it took us less than 10 minutes to douse the fire, it had already caused significant damage,” the officer added. The mishap damaged property estimated to be worth Rs 10 lakh.

Title: Action replay 2019: Data points to marginal gains, gas chamber Delhi’s still unliveable
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

New Delhi: The city’s perennial air pollution problem showed no signs of going away, with another grim reminder coming just after Diwali.

While Delhi witnessed its cleanest September in nine years, pollution levels started spiking at the end of October and the Air Quality Index touched 494 on November 3, the highest since November 2016. The spike occurred post-Diwali, with stubble burning and firecracker emissions creating a deadly cocktail of toxins in the air.

A blame game began soon after with Delhi government saying stubble burning in neighbouring states was the main problem. Though Punjab and Haryana distributed Happy Seeders and fined farmers, little changed. Punjab actually showed an increase in the number of farm fires.

Till November 25, Punjab recorded 52,942 stubble burning cases compared with 51,751 in 2018. Haryana and Uttar Pradesh both showed a sharp decline in farm fires. Indian Council of Agricultural Research data showed a decline of 52% in the total farm fires in the three states in October-November this year compared with 2016. In 2016, the states had reported 1.27 lakh incidents of stubble burning. It declined to 88,948 in 2017, 75,532 in 2018 and 61,332 in 2019 with Punjab being the biggest culprit all these years.

Like every year, government bodies, corporations and agencies were most active in October and November. Delhi, Punjab and Haryana facing the wrath of Supreme Court, which said it was better to kill people in one go than to let them live and suffer in gas chambers. SC also rapped Delhi government over delay in tackling pollution and said that the odd-even scheme, which was implemented from November 4-15, seemed to have little impact. The apex court also suggested new solutions and technologies. Asked to try out hydrogen-based fuels, commonly used in Japan, to experimenting with smog towers and anti-smog guns, Delhi government has started working on an anti-smog tower pilot project, which could be ready in three months.

Long-term data showed the situation was gradually improving. Delhi government cited CPCB’s data saying there had been a reduction in the average annual PM2.5 this year. The average PM concentration came down from 154 micrograms per cubic metre (µg/m3) in 2012-2014 to 115 µg/m3 in 2016-2018, CPCB data showed. CSE said another 65% reduction was required for Delhi to meet the standards.

Title: Night food courts closed on New Year’s Eve in Guntur
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Vijayawada: In a bid to regulate crowd at night food courts, Guntur urban cops ordered their closure on the New Year's Eve on Tuesday.

The district is currently mired in protests regarding the trifurcation of the state capital.

The officials said that with or without the protests, the past few New Year celebrations since the inception of night food courts left the region in disarray. Hence, they issued notices to the vendors to keep night services closed in the city.

In Vijayawada, the night food courts were allowed but officials made the establishments close soon after midnight. Meanwhile, the officials have kept vigil for drunk driving during the New Year celebrations.

Vijayawada traffic police sources said that they would be organising a special drive against drunk driving from 9 pm till post-midnight across MG Road, Benz Circle, Eluru Road, One-Town and other areas where New Year celebrations were taking place. tnn

Title: Kerala: ‘Assemblies have no power on CAA’
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Union minister Ravi Shankar Prasad during the inaugural session of ‘Jana Jagrata Samelanam’ in Thiruvananthapu... Read More

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: After the state assembly passed a resolution against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA), Union law and telecom minister Ravi Shankar Prasad said on Tuesday that only Parliament has exclusive powers to pass any laws in this regard.

“It is only the Parliament, which has got the powers to make any law with regard to citizenship; not any other assembly, including the Kerala assembly,” he said, quoting Article 246 from the Constitution. “I would urge the chief minister to kindly seek better legal advice,” he said. Prasad was in the state as part of the campaign to clear the air on CAA. Condemning the unruly incidents that took place in the History Congress at Kannur University, he said it has become clear that those who talk of curbing dissent were themselves slipping into repressive mode.

“I condemn what happened with the governor of the state,” he said, adding that so-called eminent people were seen pushing the governor. “These are the people who are not willing to hear the counterview even from the governor…Irfan Habib is a Leftist, and is entitled to his views, but he must listen to the counterviews also,” Prasad said.

On the CAA, Prasad said it was perfectly constitutional and legal. “I am saying this as a party worker as well as the law minister of India. The CAA is not related to any Indian, Muslim included. It is only related to persecuted communities in Afghanistan, Pakistan and Bangladesh who are being singled out for persecution because of their faith. All these three countries are declared Islamic republics,” Prasad said.

He said it was not the first time that the country is giving citizenship to people from other countries. “When President Idi Amin of Uganda turned out thousands of Hindus from Uganda, Indira Gandhi gave them refuge. When the Sri Lankan Tamil crisis was going on, lakhs of Tamil Sri Lankans were given citizenship in India. Former PM Manmohan Singh has publicly demanded that they be given citizenship. So did Rajasthan CM Ashok Gehlot and former Assam CM Tarun Gogoi,” he said.

He said the population register was the register of usual Indian residents and the data were used for development and for framing policy for both the Centre as well as state governments. With regards to the National Register of Citizens, he said PM Modi has clearly stated that no decision has been taken regarding it.

Title: Aurobindo Pharma Foundation may take over 108 ambulance service
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Soon, the 108 ambulance services might be handled by Aurobindo Pharma Foundation, said highly placed sources from within the Telangana health department. It is learnt that the foundation’s proposal, floated after the department called for tenders from corporate companies to take over 108, has been tabled before the chief minister, and is the final stages of being cleared.

The ambulances are currently taken care of by GVK Emergency Management and Research Institute (EMRI). The plan to outsource the operations is aimed at increasing coverage of districts and villages by 108 ambulances. At present, there are 358 ambulances of which around 25 are kept in reserve, while the remaining are plying on roads. With the upgrade, the number of ambulances is also expected to be increased so as to cover over 500 zones across the state, each with an ambulance at its disposal.

Further, sources said, the foundation has proposed to bring about automation in dispatch of ambulances, automatic call distribution, GPS integration and computer-telephone interface among other measures. Aurobindo’s proposal also talks about cutting short the time taken to reach an accident spot by introducing GPS identification of the accident scene, which is currently missing. While first responder teams will be set up in all villages in the future, satellite trauma centres will be set up along national highways, as per the plan. “An integrated emergency management application will GIS functionality that can meet current and future requirements of emergency management. The application can be integrated with other disaster management facilities available in the state, like police and fires services. Also all vehicles will be fitted with customised GPS/ automatic vehicle location tracking equipment for tracking the exact location and movement of vehicles in real time,” read the proposal.

It has assured high level of employee satisfaction and ensure that no protests and strikes happen, said insiders.

Title: Man gets 1 year jail for forging documents
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A special court on Tuesday sentenced a man to one year’s jail and fined him Rs 10,000 for forging documents to the protector of emigrants (POE), Hyderabad. CBI Investigation has revealed that Mohammed Abdul Razzak, proprietor of Razzak Enterprises, in Madina, Near Jubilee Post Office, had in 2010 forged documents to the POE, and fraudulently induced with false documents for issuance of emigration certificates to one S Komatireddy Kanakaiah.

In another case, an in-charge tax inspector and a bill collector, GHMC Secunderabad , were sentenced to undergo two-year imprisonment and a fine of Rs 1,000 by a special court. The duo, Baindla Narayana Swamy, office superintendent and in-charge tax inspector in Baudhanagar circle XVIII, and Dammu Surya Kantham, bill collector in circle XVIII, had demanded Rs 5,000 bribe.

Title: Step-father submits fake birth certificate, booked
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Pune: A 35-year-old businessman was booked on Monday on the charges of submitting forged birth certificate of his step-son during the passport verification process at the Sahakarnagar police station.

The man, his wife and their minor son had applied for passports, following which they were asked to submit relevant documents for police verification. Their interview was scheduled for September 19, 2019.

“They duo had submitted all the relevant documents, including their son’s birth certificate. However, when asked about the minor’s date and place of birth during the interview round at the police station, the couple gave separate answers. This made the verifying officer suspicious and the man was booked,” assistant inspector of Sahakarnagar police Suhas Patil told TOI.

He said, “We suspect their son’s birth certificate — issued by the medical authorities of Rajasthan government — to be forged. Our team would soon visit Rajasthan to verify the authenticity of the document.”

Patil said the man and his wife has been staying in the city for over six years. The 35-year-old runs a glass business on Satara Road.

“Prima facie probe revealed that the man is the step-father of the minor boy. It is suspected that the woman forged her son’s birth certificate in Rajasthan. We are yet to figure out the reason for the forgery,” another police officer said.

“We have booked the man for submitting the fake documents and misleading the police s during passport verification process,” he added.

Title: Kochi Metro’s ridership went up by 32% in 2019
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Kochi Metro’s ridership has witnessed an increase of 41 lakh passengers in 2019, which is a 32% increase when ... Read More

KOCHI: The Kochi Metro ’s ridership has witnessed an increase of 41 lakh passengers in 2019 , which is a 32% increase when compared to 2018.

In 2019, more than 1,65,99,020 passengers travelled in the Metro. Whereas, in 2018, a total of 1,24,95,884 passengers used the Metro services.

On September 4, 2019, the Metro services was extended till Thykoodam. The ridership drastically increased after this. The ridership was 88,83,184 from January 1 to September 3. From September 4 to December 30, the ridership was 77,14,836.

Average ridership per day now is 65,000. During weekends it touches 68,000. In October, the Kochi Metro Rail Ltd (KMRL) increased the speed of trains along the Maharaja’s College-Thykoodam stretch. Till then the trains were running at 25kmph along the stretch. The decision was made after Commissioner of Metro Rail Safety accorded sanction for KMRL. The maximum achievable speed of a Metro train is 80 kmph and at stations the speed limit is 50kmph. “2019 was a huge year for Kochi Metro. We are extremely happy that more Kochiites are opting to travel by Metro,” said KMRL MD Alkesh Kumar Sharma.

“In 2020, we look forward to the central government’s sanction for the second phase, inauguration of Pettah stretch, launch of India’s first Water Metro and plan for the extension of Metro to Tripunithura,” he added. While the Pettah stretch will be inaugurated by March 2020, the Water Metro is set to be completed by November 2020.

Title: Seeking important ministeries, Thorat & Chavan to meet CM
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Nagpur: Even as portfolios are yet to be allocated to the newly sworn-in group of 36 ministers, reports are emerging that the Congress high command in Delhi is sour over getting ‘lower-rung’ ministries as compared to its Maha Vikas Aghadi (MVA) partners Shiv Sena and NCP. It’s learnt that this is the reason why portfolios have not been announced a day after the swearing-in ceremony.

According to senior functionaries, Maharashtra Pradesh Congress Committee (MPCC) president Balasaheb Thorat and former chief minister Ashok Chavan would be meeting CM Uddhav Thackeray on Wednesday to convey and discuss the high command’s message.

“Since our party feels that it was provided with ministries of less importance, Thorat and Chavan would request Thackeray to exchange a few. Even party MLAs felt that they have not been given proper representation in the cabinet expansion,” a senior leader from Vidarbha told TOI.

The Congress legislators were also disappointed that former CM Prithviraj Chavan was not a minister. “Allotment of ministries with lesser significance may be a reason to drop Chavan’s name, as no major portfolio was left after revenue and PWD was shared by Thorat and Raut, respectively. There were indications that NCP had opposed Chavan’s name as investigations into the Punjab and Maharashtra Co-operative Bank (PMC) and multi-crore irrigation scams where the Pawars are named were initiated by him,” they said.

As per the common minimum programme (CMP) fixed by the three coalition partners before government’s formation, the Sena with 56 seats would get 16 ministries, NCP with 54 seats would have 14, while Congress which was relegated to fourth place after assembly polls with 44 seats, was allotted 12 portfolios.

Title: Oppn urges govt to implead in case against new law
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The opposition, while taking part in the discussions in the assembly for passing a resolution against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) on Tuesday, urged the state government to implead in the case before the Supreme Court against the implementation of the Act.

Asserting that the CAA cannot be ignored as an isolated move but only in connection with the NPR (National Population Register) and NRC (National Register of Citizens), opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala said he has already filed a case in the apex court against the Act and asked the state to join as a plaintiff in the case.

“The state also should stay away from initiating any procedures to facilitate the census, in which the newly added questions have made people apprehensive,” he said, reiterating his earlier demand for sending an all-party delegation to meet the President and ask for a repeal of the legislation.

He also said that the nation was facing the biggest challenge post-Independence. “The BJP government is trying to divide the nation on communal lines. The Centre did not follow international conventions while making amendment to the Citizenship Act, and now several countries have cancelled their diplomatic visits. It has also affected the foreign tourists’ inflow,” he said.

Joining the discussions, IUML legislative party leader M K Muneer said no one can question the patriotism of people who have fought for India’s freedom and contributed immensely in its progress, and that people like him will not produce any documents to prove their lineage.

“It’s not an issue of Muslims. Tomorrow, they will target dalits, Christians, the third gender, and even several castes and communities in Hindu religion. The RSS agenda is to implement the fascist theories of its ideologue M S Golwalkar,” he said. Muneer also called upon the state government to show restraint while handling protesters ‘as this is a second freedom struggle’.

Among those from the UDF who raised their concerns against the CAA were V D Satheesan, Mons Joseph, Shafi Parambil and Anoop Jacob, while participants from the LDF in the discussions included James Mathew, C Divakaran, K V Abdul Khader, Mathew T Thomas and M Swaraj, among others.

Title: Drive to clear footpaths to kick off from today
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Nagpur: Unfazed by attack and threats, mayor Sandip Joshi on Tuesday announced commencement of three-month long intensive drive to free footpaths and roads from encroachments. Hefty penalty will also be levied on the encroachers with the commencement of new calender year.

Joshi also announced stringent action against various types of nuisances by increasing the strength of the nuisance detection squad (NDS) which will also work in second shift from 4pm to 12 midnight. The NDS will seize and levy fines on those selling plastic kite, nylon manja and those using plastic in preparing bouquets.

Considering suggestions and complaints received from people related to facility of public toilets, Joshi said public toilets at 87 petrol pumps will be opened for public from January 1. A total of 75 new public toilets will be constructed before December 31 and two abandoned city buses will be converted into T-mobile cafeteria and women special toilet. The NDS will also expedite action on urination and defecation in open,” he said.

Joshi said the action against encroachments on footpaths and roads will be taken as per the new policy submitted by a committee-headed by Dayashankar Tiwari. “Standing committee, followed by general body, will approve the policy soon. Municipal commissioner Abhijit Bangar has already implemented it using his powers. The policy aims to make footpaths and roads walkable and induce fear among encroachers, hawkers. Works of Rs7 crore are planned to ensure hassle-free footpaths,” he said.

“Till now, the NMC used to recover less fine and return back materials seized during the drive. Now onwards, hefty penalty will be levied for the first time which will be doubled in the second instance. Shopkeepers will not be given their materials back. The hawkers will be given materials back for the first two times but not from the third time onwards,” sources said.

Bangar said the demolition of encroachments done by shopkeepers on footpath will start from January 1. “Earlier, a team from the NMC headquarters with the help of a few staffers from zone used to remove encroachments only in a particular area in a day. Now, we have prepared zone-wise enforcement teams which will ensure action across the city. We will select some pockets where the drive will be conducted in a repeated manner. During this drive, the process to appoint enforcement team in all the ten zones will be appointed on a permanent basis. Apart from police, five personnel of NDS will accompany the enforcement team in ten zones,” he said.

Joshi added the policy to seize open plots comprising garbage and filth will be approved soon. “Till now, the NMC used to levy fine on such open plots. We found some provisions to seize such plots. The NMC will erect a board on open plot giving a warning after which the plot will be seized. We will begin the action from a plot situated on Inner Ring Road near Khamla Square,” he said.

Joshi also said the strength of NDS has been increased to 203. “Till now, NDS was functioning with 87 personnel. It has levied a penalty of Rs2.75 crore for various types of nuisances in one year. The NDS was working only during day time. Now, 153 personnel will work in morning shift and remaining 50 in second shift from 4pm to 12 midnight. NDS will also take action under Single Use Plastic Eradication Scheme,” he said.

On Tuesday, NDS seized 25 plastic kites and recovered fine of Rs500 in Mangalwari zone. Joshi and Bangar have proposed to develop Smart Kiosks which are basically dedicated food zones. Action on hawkers will be taken after developing these zones. The first zone will be developed along VIP road behind Children Traffic Park.

Title: CM Pinarayi Vijayan hails Loka Kerala Sabha as a practical forum
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Pinarayi Vijayan

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The second session of the Loka Kerala Sabha is being convened with the satisfaction that it has been transformed to a forum which discusses and finds a solution to all issues of expats and utilises their potential in the best possible way, chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan said.

In his article on the eve of the second edition of the Loka Kerala Sabha to be held in the capital from Wednesday, the chief minister said that the state government does not view it as a formal or a decorative forum, but a practical forum that will implement what has been said.

“The best example is the decision to form a secretariat in the first edition. Also, seven standing committees were formed and all their recommendations were compiled and implemented. This shows the commitment of the state government towards non-resident Keralites,” he said.

The chief minister said that the investment company Overseas Keralites Investment and Holding Ltd was formed to ensure that the remittances from NRKs which is almost equivalent to 30% of the GDP of the state does not get scattered. The company was formed by collecting 74% of the investment capital from NRKs and the rest being invested by the state government. He also said that government could also set up a special cell for NRK women, an NRK facilitation centre, a pre-departure orientation centre, high-power committee for skill development, etc, within this timeframe.

The chief minister said that with Loka Kerala Sabha, all issues commonly faced by NRKs can be addressed, whereas earlier, individual cases were being dealt with separately. He said that one of the main issues faced by NRKs is the uncontrolled airfare to Gulf countries. The state government could ensure more services in the Gulf sector through the intervention of the ministry of civil aviation. He said that a forum like Loka Kerala Sabha is inevitable in ensuring that the contributions and potential of the NRK community is utilsied for the development of the state.

Title: Trade union to join Jan 8 central strike
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

AITUC members and all unions will join the countrywide strike call of the national convention of workers on January 8 to oppose the anti- people policies of the central and state governments. General secretary Christopher Fonseca said that around 1.5 lakh workers are expected to join the protest to demand resuming of sustainable mining where full benefits will go to stakeholders and people of the state, among other demands. tnn

Title: Delhi fog fades, flight services improve at Lohegaon
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Pune: Flight services from the city airport were slightly better on Tuesday than a day before with the weather condition in the national capital showing signs of improvement.

Around 10 flights reaching and leaving the city were delayed between 6am and 6pm on Tuesday. In contrast, over 20 flights were delayed on Monday. No flight was cancelled on Tuesday as against Monday’s six cancellations.

“Flight movements remained largely normal (on Tuesday). The number of delays was less and the durations were moderate. The Delhi airport authorities tweeted in the morning that all their flight operations were normal,” an official at the Lohegaon airport said.

“Flights to destinations such as Hyderabad, Ozar, Bengaluru, Goa and Ahmedabad were delayed. But the situation was not as chaotic as Monday’s,” the official said.

The situation improved following a change in the condition in the North. “Clear weather, no fog. All flight operations are normal at the Delhi airport,” the Twitter handle of the Delhi airport posted on Tuesday.

Advisories for the flyers, however, poured in from many airlines about destinations other than Delhi. SpiceJet stated, “Due to bad weather at Kanpur and Varanasi, all departures/arrivals and their consequential flights might get affected.” Vistara mentioned that flights to and from Varanasi could be affected because of the bad weather.

Flyers had a harrowing time at the Pune airport on Monday evening. An Pune-New Delhi Air Asia flight (I5732) was supposed to take off at 6:30pm, but finally left the city after 11:30pm. A Vistara flight for Delhi took off from Pune after 1.30am on Tuesday as against its scheduled departure at 8:20pm.

Similarly, An Air India flight for Delhi, which was supposed to take off at 6:50pm, left Pune at 11:25pm.

Title: State fixes age for nursery, Class I admissions
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Pune: The state government has fixed the age criteria for admission during 2020-2021 academic year in all schools. The cut-off date has been set as September 30, 2020. Students completing three years on this date will be admitted to nursery and those completing six years on or before the cut-off date can take admission to standard I.

The education department released the guidelines as many private schools have already started conducting admissions using different cut-off dates. Cut-off dates vary from school-to-school.

As per the Right to Education (RTE) Act, a child should have attained six years to be admitted in standard I and three years for nursery. Many schools have begun their admissions, especially, the CBSE affiliated schools, as their academic sessions begins in April.

Education department director Dattatray Jagtap has notified that the schools should follow a uniform cut-off date of September 30.

Jagtap said, “This is an annual practice and the state government based on the RTE Act has always been setting up the cut-off date usually announced in December and set for September 30.”

According to the education department, the age criteria for junior and senior kindergarten will also vary. A school principal said, “The education department should issue such guidelines much in advance. We have almost finished with the admissions and the notification cannot come so late and we cannot conduct the entire process all over again.”

The cut-off date is usually tricky for principals as there is pressure from the management to consider some exceptions for admission because the child may lose out by few days, another principal said.

Applicable To All Boards

* Age six is the minimum for admission to standard I in the state

* The cut-off date for calculating age be September 30, 2020

* The minimum age for admission to nursery or playgroup will be three years

* By the time these children reach standard I, they were at least six years old, as is required under the Right to Education Act

* Schools with nursery or playgroup as the entry level will have to admit students who have completed three years as on September 30, 2020

Age -- Class

3 years -- Nursery

4 years -- L Kg

5 years -- Sr Kg

6 years -- Standard I

Title: 15 loan sharks booked for threatening labourer
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Palanpur: Dhasura police in Aravalli district on Monday booked 15 people for extorting and threatening a labourer, forcing him to go into hiding , leaving behind his wife and two children.

According to police, Kalabhai Khant had taken loan on interest from two finance companies and six others at high rates.

The finance companies and the moneylenders had been demanding more than the capital and interest combined from Khant. Their men used to visit Khant’s house frequently and threaten him for payment.

The money lenders also took away from Khant’s buffalo, two cows, gold earring and other household items. They were demanded settlement of dues at the earliest or threatened to beat him up.

Under pressure, Khant went into hiding leaving his wife and two children a week ago. Khant also left a note explaining his why he had to go into hiding.

The Dhansura police have booked 15 people under IPC 384, 506(2) and 114, said sub-inspector N M Solanki. However, no arrests have been made so far, he added.

Title: Uploading of land grant orders on website gets delayed
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Pune: Two almost back-to-back elections in 2019 — one for the Lok Sabha and the other for the state Assembly — have delayed uploading of land grant orders under rehabilitation projects on the website of the district collectorate.

Over 25,800 beneficiaries in the district were supposed to be granted land of nearly 2,300 hectares for over 25 projects. The process was made online for maintaining transparency, tracking the orders and the individuals’ details and eliminating any confusion between department officials.

However, Only 60 land grant orders have been uploaded on the collectorate’s website (on pune.nic.in/documents/other) as part of the pilot project implemented in Pune district.

The orders issued from January 2019 were supposed to be uploaded under the pilot project, for which Rs5 lakh was sanctioned from the district development funds for special projects.

Pune district rehabilitation officer (DRO) B Waghmare said the pending documents would be uploaded on the website soon. “The task is difficult, but not impossible. We can commence it this year. The pending orders can be scanned and subsequently uploaded,” he said.

Senior officials in the rehabilitation department conceded about the delay in uploading the orders online in the election year. “The alleged Shirur land scam should be the trigger for the state government to go for this project,” an official said.

Title: Molestation charge on BJP man dropped
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Hyderabad: A molestation case against the son of a former legislator was dropped after the woman withdrew the complaint.

“We are not aware why she withdrew the complaint,” said Madhapur inspector Venkat Reddy. A case against Ashish Goud, son of former MLA T Nandeshwar Goud, was registered on the charges of outraging the modesty of the woman. The woman, a former contestant in BiggBoss accused Ashish and his friends of misbehaving with her at a hotel. Following the incident, Ashish was removed from Bharatiya Janata Yuva Morcha. tnn

Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Hyderabad: Managing director of Sports Authority of Telangana (SAT), A Dinakar, retired on Tuesday. B Manohar, managing director (FAC), Tourism Development Corporation, has been given full additional charge for the post of vice-chairman and MD, SAT . Title: ‘GST, bankruptcy code to help Indian economy’
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Arun M Kumar, currently the chairman and CEO of KPMG-India , had served as assistant secretary of commerce for global markets and the director general of the US and foreign commercial service under Obama administration. In an interview with TOI, Kumar shared his view that the Indian economy will be benefited by various reforms like GST and bankruptcy code . He also said that India could benefit from the ongoing US-China trade war . Excerpts from the interview:

How do you see 2020 and the decade ahead?

Progress is rarely a straight line. 2019 was a year in which many upward trends took a pause. Uncertainties around the world, including the US-China trade situation and Brexit made economic headwinds, and India was affected as well. Even so, India continued to attract investment and the growth of entrepreneurship remained unabated. Such interregnums can have their benefits, if companies and countries use them to become more competitive. India’s GDP grew by a factor of 2.2 over the last decade. Looking out over the next decade, especially given the aspiration and energy of India’s young people, India should emerge as one of the top three economic powers in the world.

Will India be benefited by the ongoing US-China trade war?

There is an opportunity for trade diversion. In some areas, it is already happening with mobile phones being made here. There is definitely a big opportunity to take on some of the manufacturing happening in China – one in the context of the US-China trade war, and the other is based on the changing economics of China. There is an opportunity for India and other countries like Vietnam and Bangladesh to take on the manufacturing of various products. India has to prepare carefully in multiple ways and the government has identified several areas. We ourselves have prepared some studies like which are the kind of products and companies that will be interested in reconfiguring their supply chain to go through India.

Modi government had been bringing in many reforms that have serious effects on businesses and industries. How do you see their impact?

There are two important reforms. One is GST. It is very important that goods can move across the country faster. It was a Constitutional innovation to get the states and the Centre to work together to agree on standard rates across the country. Yes, there were some hiccups and some will continue. The second one is the bankruptcy code. It is important and timely because right now, you are dealing with a lot of non-performing assets.

Is the Indian economy really strong enough for all these reforms?

In the long-term, you have to have these changes. Otherwise, you can’t have a dynamic and competitive economy. GST is a good example. One of the areas where India lags behind China is logistics costs. Your labour costs might be low, but if your logistics costs are high, you can’t be competitive. So, GST is one and the infrastructure spending is the other one. Better roads and bridges increase competitiveness. We need more productivity and exports, and all the benefits of high competitiveness lead to high income.

Which are the sectors that are going to have two-digit growth?

In Kerala, it is tourism. Kerala is a good example, but the whole country has got so many (tourist) attractions. It is like infrastructure becomes important and the good progress made regarding airports. I think transportation and infrastructure really boost tourism. And, tourism is job-creating. Nationwide, there are many service sectors (that should have a high growth rate), and although we have a slump in automotive, it will come back up again. The country is going to have more cars, as the energy and aspiration of the middle class and those entering the middle class are quite incredible.

Title: Thrissur corp too passes CAA resolution
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Thrissur: Thrissur Corporation council on Tuesday passed a resolution against the CAA amidst stiff resistance from BJP councillors, who tore off the copies of the resolution and walked out.

The resolution was moved by CPM leader and former deputy mayor Varghese Kanamkulathi and the leader of opposition Mukundan of the Congress supported it.

However, the BJP councillors started shouting slogans alleging that the resolution was against the Constitution. According to them, the corporation council had no right to pass a resolution against an Act which has come into force after both the houses of Parliament approved it and the President gave assent.

The LDF and UDF councillors however said the corporation council was well within its rights to express the opinions of the councillors on an Act which went against the basic secular ethos of the Indian Constitution.

The resolution was unanimously approved by the council after the BJP members staged a boycott. Mayor Ajitha Vijayan presided over the function.

Title: Orders for recovery of mining losses in new year: Mines department
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Notices had been issued to 42 leases holders to file their final reply in the matter

PANAJI: The directorate of mines and geology (DGM) has said that orders for recovery of money from illegal mining , based on the audit report submitted by the team of chartered accounts, will be passed in the new year.

Mines director Ashutosh Apte told TOI that the department is studying the data in order to pass recovery orders. “The orders will be issued in the new year,” Apte said.

Notices had been issued to 42 leases holders to file their final reply in the matter. In October, the department had started the final hearing, based on the audit report, to recover money lost to illegal mining.

Earlier, the department had evaluated the replies filed by holders of 118 mining leases to the audit report submitted by the team of chartered accountants.

In 2015, the state government had appointed 15 chartered accountants to undertake a comprehensive audit of lease holders and traders of mineral ore in Goa during the last five years, when exports touched peak figures.

The accountants had submitted an audit report of 118 mining leases to the mines department . Subsequently, the department analysed the report to ascertain the exact loss to the state owing to illegal mining.

Based on the analysis, showcause notices were issued to the mining companies. Later, the mining companies submitted their replies and hearings were conducted.

However, the charter accountants are yet to begin the audit of 260 iron ore traders. Around 464 traders are registered with the mines department, out of which over 260 traders were involved in the mining business from 2007 till September 2012, the officer said.

The chartered accountants were asked to examine the exact quantity of ore extracted, exported, amount of royalty paid, export duty, ore (if any) sourced from other state, etc.

The Shah Commission report on illegal mining, which had exposed a series of irregularities in the state’s mining activities, had pegged the loss of revenue to the government from the mining scam at Rs 35,000 crore.

Former chief minister Manohar Parrikar had assured the Goa assembly in July 2012 that a team of chartered accountants would be engaged to conduct an audit of all ore export-related activities during the past five years.

Title: Kerala: Single-use plastic ban comes as a boon to Mahila Mandir
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Residents of Mahila Mandir make paper bags.

KOCHI: Chambakkara-based Mahila Mandir, a shelter home for destitute women, is all set to make maximum out of the single-use plastic ban announced by the state government. The residents of the shelter home are gearing up to provide alternative for plastic carry bags.

There are 18 residents at the Mahila Mandir and they run a paper bag unit. As of now, they make up to 700 paper bags per day at the unit. “Now, we are getting many enquiries for cloth bags. So, we are planning to switch to cloth bag manufacturing,” said Mahila Mandir superintendent Beena F R. Many firms, including Kerala Khadi and Village Industries, have placed orders for paper bags. “We are unable to manufacture such a huge quantity of paper bags. So, we are giving training to Kudumbashree workers on manufacturing of paper bags and cloth bags,” she said.

They supply paper bags to the firms like Beverages Corporation. “It is from textile firms that we get maximum orders. We expect that we will be able to outsource the excess work to Kudumbashree workers,” an employee with Mahila Mandir said.

It was almost three years ago that a paper bag manufacturing unit was started at the Mahila Mandir, functioning under social justice department. “The initial cost was Rs 7 lakh. Later on, the unit started getting orders. But, there was slump post flood. But, it was soon overcome. With the ban on single-use plastic coming into effect on Wednesday, the prospects of the firm are getting brighter,” said V P Chandran, councillor representing Chambakkara division. “Such endeavours can be helpful in ushering positive changes in the society,” he said.

Most of the residents are destitute while some of them come to the Mandir for a short stay. “It is those like the victims of domestic violence who avail short stay. Moreover, there are some residents who are sent by the courts as they are unable to go back to their homes due to peculiar circumstances,” said a source.

Title: Citizens’ groups oppose IBC amendment ordinance, claim their voices went unheard
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Pune: Citizens’ groups across the country expressed their displeasure over the ordinance for the amendment of the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, recently approved by the Union cabinet, claiming that their say was not taken into consideration.

Calling it a largely pro-builder amendment, they claimed that the clause stating that homebuyers willing to take the developer to an insolvency court would have to ensure that a minimum of 100 homebuyers or 10% of the total homebuyers filed for bankruptcy against the developer seemed practically impossible at a given time.

“The specific number seems highly impossible for a citizen wanting to raise a complaint against the developer. A citizen should have had the right to file his/her complaint at individual-level,” said Abhay Upadhayay, the president of Forum for People’s Collective Efforts.

The forum had written to the Prime Minister to stop any proposed amendments in the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code (IBC), diluting the rights of flat owners. It received mass support on social media but its say was not considered, claimed the members of the group.

The ordinance was passed without taking the view of the consumers or homebuyers, they stated.

“The government should have at least called us for a discussion so that we could put forth the practical difficulties,” stressed the consumers across India.

Under the IBC, a single creditor (operational/financial) having a due of Rs1 lakh or more could drag a corporate entity to the NCLT. Against this backdrop, how a single homebuyer could be barred whose financial stake would be many times more than this amount, questioned consumers.

“It is absurd to demand that the accused should not be dragged to a court of law till his victims find others and joins hands to become eligible to approach a court of law. It is akin to saying that no one should approach a police station against a person guilty of murder till kin of other victims of the murderer joined hands,” said a consumer peeved with the move.

The proposed amendment was to provide protection to buyers from criminal proceedings against previous promoters of a bankrupt firm. But there were several loopholes in it, the buyers pointed out.

Under the amendments, the liability of a corporate debtor for an offence committed prior to the commencement of the corporate insolvency resolution would cease and it would be the same if there was a change in the management of the corporate debtor.

The government in the ordinance stated that the amendment was expected to remove ambiguities in the IBC and ensure smooth implementation of the code. The amendment paved the way for the initiation of insolvency proceedings against the real estate entity only if a group of creditors approved it.

Title: Governor, CM extend New Year wishes
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Panaji: The New Year is the opportunity to learn from the prior year, bring about positive changes in one’s life and achieve desired goals, governor Satya Pal Malik said while extended his wishes to the people of Goa. He asked people to resolve to live in harmony.

Chief minister Pramond Sawant in his greetings urged all Goan’s to “rededicate themselves and put in renewed efforts to achieve socio-economic development and take Goa ahead in all areas of human endeavours”.

Title: Chief Secretary reviews preparations for 38th National Games
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Dehradun: Uttarakhand Chief Secretary Utpal Kumar Singh, on Tuesday, chaired a meeting to review the ongoing preparations for the 38th National Games scheduled to be held in Uttarakhand in 2021.

The Chief Secretary directed state’s sports secretary to take continuous guidance from the national sports federations and Indian Olympic Association (IOA) in the ongoing construction of sports infrastructure in Uttarakhand.

He also said that the proposal of works, which are awaiting approval, should be sent to the government after taking permission from technical advisory committee (TAC) at the earliest. He also called for continuous monitoring to maintain quality and time-bound progress in construction works.

Chief Secretary Singh also directed the 18 committees, set up for discharging different functions at National Games, to prepare a detailed work plan for the sports extravaganza. These committees are — technical committee, affiliation committee, game village committee, communication and technology committee, infrastructure committee, ceremony committee, cultural and medal committee, accommodation committee, among others.

During the meeting, sports secretary Brijesh Kumar Sant informed that 34 games have been shortlisted by the Indian Olympic Association for the event. However in the meeting, it was agreed to send a proposal to Indian Olympic Association for not including cycling, horse riding, golf, modern pentathlon, and sailing in the list of sports disciplines for the 38th National Games.

Title: Travelling film fest in Kochi on January 2 & 3
Content:
Representative image

for the love of cinema: Films will be screened at Bharata Mata College Auditorium, Thrikkakara, from 10am to 5.30pm

KOCHI: A travelling film festival on gender diversity ‘SamaBhav’ (meaning equanimity) is coming to Kochi on Thursday. The event is hosted by Men Against Violence and Abuse ( MAVA ), based in Mumbai, in collaboration with Bharata Mata College and P K Rosy Film Society of Women in Cinema Collective.The theme of the festival is ‘gender, masculinity, sexuality and diversity’. The two-day festival is open to college students, young filmmakers, film enthusiasts and representatives of social organizations across Kochi. Films will be screened at Bharata Mata College Auditorium, Thrikkakara, from 10am to 5.30pm on Thursday and Friday. Entry to the festival is free.The SamaBhav Film Festival, one of a kind in India, is part of a travelling festival, in its third year, that kicked off on November 25 – the International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women. It travelled to Mumbai, Indore, Varanasi, Noida, Sonipat, Udaipur, Imphal, Guwahati, Patna and four districts of Maharashtra – Raigad, Pimpri, Nagpur and Wardha.“The travelling film festival would engage youths through healthy conversations with experts on contemporary gender issues and intersectionality, related to all three recognized genders (male, female and transgender), and advocate for a healthy, pluralistic, gender-just society, the organizers said. The festival aims to provide a safe, non-threatening platform to ventilate differences and celebrate diversity in gender.The film festival, being held in 16 locations from November 2019 to March 2020, is featuring 16 national and international short films, documentaries and feature films. These films cover a wide range of topics like gender-based discrimination, violence against women, homophobia, transphobia, breaking the gender binaries and toxic masculinity.National award winning films Bulbul Can Sing and Kharvas, Untying The Knot (Bangladesh, Canada), Turup, Please Mind The Gap, Ruchibhedam, Gi, Kaaye Kaaye Sexual, Bachelor Girls, Mahalachumi, and U Ushacha are among the notable films that would be screened.Gender rights activists Harish Sadani, Sheetal Shyam, Dhanya, Aleyamma and Archana Padmini will initiate debates on various topics.For registration, contact 9870307748 or mail to samabhavfilmfest@gmail.com.

Title: 25-year-old cop ends life at home, reason not known
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Ashish Dave’s body being taken for postmortem examination from his house in Marutinagar police quarters on Tue... Read More

RAJKOT: A young police constable posted in Thorala police station committed suicide by hanging at his house in the official government quarters in Marutinagar after Monday midnight.

The reason for the extreme step was not known immediately.
