Ashish Dave, 25, who was also a promising hockey player, was found hanging from the ceiling fan in his house. Dave, who is posted in Thorala’s detection staff, had used a dupatta and chair to hang himself. At around 1:30pm, his wife Anjali, who was sleeping in their bedroom woke up hearing the noise of falling chair. She saw that Dave was not there and went to the other room to check. Much to her horror, she saw him hanging and started screaming for help.

Neighbours rushed there and called the 108 emergency ambulance, but Dave was already dead by then.

Senior police officials said Dave had not left any suicide note and they are trying to find out the reason behind the drastic step.

Sources said that Dave had taken leave for two days saying that his wife was unwell. On Monday evening too, some of his colleagues had casually called him up and asked him his New Year plans. He denied having any plans and told them also that Anjali was unwell. People close to him also said that Dave was behaving normally till he went on leave and did not show any signs of being disturbed. He did not face any financial problems or serious illness too, police department sources said.

Thorala police station sources said that Anjali had two miscarriages in the couple’s six years of marriage. Anjali was also a hockey player and the two had met during some match six years ago. After a brief courtship, they got married.

Till recently, Dave stayed with his elder brother Hiren and mother at the latter’s house in Railnagar. He shifted to Marutinagar police quarters recently with Anjali.

Title: CRly enhances safety, goes for hi-tech surveillance at stations
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Nagpur: RailTel Corporation of India Limited has installed Internet protocol (IP)-based video surveillance system (VSS) at Wardha railway station.

Wardha is a ‘A’ class station under Nagpur division of Central Railway . The project has been implemented utilizing the ‘Nirbhaya’ fund for ensuring better safety for women.

IP-based close circuit television (CCTV) cameras have been installed on the railway station premises for keeping a tab on all the activities 24X7.

Railway officials said the VSS system installed here comprises 38 full high definition cameras. Out of these, 26 are bullet type of which 4 are of 4k resolution used at the entry and exit points of the station. Other cameras are of dome type for platforms, FOBs etc. A PTZ (pan tilt and zoom) type camera has also been installed in the parking area.

In addition, CCTV cameras have also been commissioned at Ahmednagar, Amravati, Khandwa, Berhampur stations of Central Railway. CCTV camera live feeds are displayed on multiple screens at the Railway Protection Force (RPF) control room for monitoring.

“Soon, all CCTV cameras provided at these railway station premises will be networked on the optical fibre cable and the video feed of the CCTV cameras will be brought to a centralized CCTV control room from where the video feeds will be viewed on multiple LCD monitors by RPF personnel, enhancing the security and safety of the passengers tremendously,” they said.

Apart from this, at Wardha, a state-of-the-art Wi-Fi facility with 16 access points has been provided by RailTel. The Railway Board has entrusted RailTel with the work of providing IP-based VSS with video analytics and facial recognition system at all railway stations.

RailTel will provide VSS at A1, A, B, C, D & E category stations and coaches of premium trains and suburban EMU coaches. Talking about this new system, Sanjeev Mittal, general manager of Central Railway, said, “Today we have added one very important passenger amenity for the security of our passengers, especially women and children. The new CCTV surveillance will help us provide more proactive security. This facility will be extended to other stations very soon.”

Talking about the project, Puneet Chawla, managing director, RailTel, said, “We have started work of providing VSS at all stations. In the first phase, we are working on 200 stations out of which 80 stations have already been completed.”

Important videos can be stored for a longer duration in the new system. The VSS is expected to ensure better security of passengers at stations and the property as well.

Title: Dileep in court for removal of name from accused list
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Kochi: In yet another development in the actor rape case , accused actor Dileep on Tuesday approached additional special sessions court in Ernakulam with a discharge petition seeking to remove his name from the accused list in the case.

The accused also submitted a list of queries regarding the authenticity of the visuals of the victim which can be verified with the help of Central Forensic Science Lab (CFSL) as directed by Supreme Court in the case.

The court was considering the case as part of a preliminary hearing before framing charges against the accused persons. The counsel for Dileep filed a discharge petition when the case came up for consideration in the evening.

Even as the court was going through Dileep’s petition, the court decided to adopt an in-camera procedure to further hear on the petition. The court decided to continue hearing the discharge petition on Wednesday evening.

Title: Cleanliness drive held in Mussoorie to bid adieu to 2019
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Nearly 50 volunteers participated in the campaign

MUSSOORIE: A cleanliness drive was organised near city’s Municipal Garden to bid adieu to 2019 and to welcome 2020. Nearly 50 volunteers from several organisations participated in this campaign which was aimed at spreading awareness regarding the need to reduce non-biodegradable wastes and maintain cleanliness.

A number of college and school students also participated in this drive which was organised under the aegis of “I am Mussoorie” foundation.

“It is sad to see that shopkeepers dispose huge quantity of plastic waste down the hill slopes. There is an urgent need to ensure better waste disposal in the town,” remarked Neha Joshi, founder of I am Mussoorie foundation. She also pointed out that the business community of the town must be made aware of proper waste management practices..

According to Arvind Shukla, project leader of Hilldari (a social project promoted by Nestle India under its CSR programme), a total of 268 kg of single-use plastic was collected during the drive. “The waste would be segregated before being sent for recycling,” Shukla told TOI.

Title: Gujarat: 109 buffaloes die after eating contaminated fodder
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

The dead buffaloes in a cattle shed on Radhanpur Road in Mehsana

PALANPUR: More than 100 buffaloes, including adult males, females and calves, died allegedly after eating contaminated fodder , at a panjrapole (cattle shelter) on Radhanpur Road in Mehsana town on Tuesday.

The cattle shed manager Prakash Shah said that he was informed in the afternoon by his staff members that number of bovine had started falling to the ground after eating fodder.

“I informed the veterinary officer about the situation and also lodged a police complaint with B division police station. By Tuesday evening the death toll touched 109,” said Shah, adding that there were total 833 bovine in the cattle shed.

Talking to TOI, deputy district veterinary officer Dr Bharat Desai said, “Our teams are working at war footing to control the mortality,”

Dr Vipul Mewada, who is heading the veterinary team said, “The deaths have occurred after the animals ate green grass and fodder that was supplied from different places. Exact cause of death will be known only after postmortem.”

Mehsana district collector H K Patel said that the animals probably died after consuming maize leaves that was suppled along with the fodder. “We have been able to saved about 350 bovine so far. The concerned department has collected blood and other samples from the dead animals and sent it for examination,” he added.

Title: Assonora plant springs leaks, to be shut for a day
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Panaji: Goa’s water requirement is steadily increasing and Bardez taluka is one area where demand is rapidly rising. This had put stress on the Assonora water treatment plant, which treats 105MLD to 110MLD water daily for the taluka and parts of Bicholim, leading to it developing leaks in many places.

However, carrying out repairs is difficult as it would mean giving the plant prolonged rest for the duration of the maintenance work which would in turn mean Bardez and parts of Bicholim will have to go without drinking water supply.

The PWD has identified some major areas of leakages which will be repaired on priority to resolve at least part of the problem for now. For this restricted water will be supplied to Bardez and parts of Bicholim on January 4 and 5 to facilitate repair works.

“There are some leakages in the plant and water is getting wasted. There are some places which need urgent repairs. Such points have been identified and the material has already been arranged so that no time is wasted in carrying out the repair works. The plant will be shut down for a day and work can be completed within this short time,” an official said.

The Assonora plant currently receives water from the Amthane reservoir where water is pumped in from the Sal for treatment.

Title: Small hands on deck: Yacht club puts wind in sails of budding talents
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

HYDERABAD: The polluted waters of Hussainsagar may not support marine life any more but they are surely giving wings to the dreams of many young, underprivileged sailors and infusing new life into their dreams of achieving ‘Dignity Through Sports’. The Yacht Club of Hyderabad (YCH) has taken under its wings many boys and girls from low-income groups. These kids virtually didn’t have much of a life as their parents couldn’t even think of giving them a decent education. YCH has put the wind under their sails and some of these kids are now sailing on in life. Preethi Kongari, Majji Lalitha, Mehboobie Tungara, Jaikiran Bolli, Vijay Kumar, Gowtham Kankatla and Durga Prasad are among a host of them who have found a new purpose in life.

The success stories of these kids bring a smile to Suheim Sheikh, who had the courage to dream of a day when Hussainsagar would be teeming with sailors of all classes. The YCH sailors have won dozens of national and international medals. Ten YCH boys have also been absorbed into the sailing schools of the armed forces.

“If you look at all sportspersons who have made it big, it’s because they had access to the sport. Desire, drive and determination are needed but the most important factor for success is access. That was lacking for sailors in the city,” Suheim said. He considers himself lucky to have access to sailing. “My father was a member of the sailing club and so I had the privilege to sail. I loved the sport and was involved in it for nearly 20 years before dropping it to earn a living,” said Suheim, who is an IIT Madras graduate and ran a software company.

He, however, couldn’t remain in that world as his calling was different. He quit and got back to sailing. “When I came back, I saw that many couldn’t have access to the waters and hence the pool of sailors was very less in the city,” said Suheim, who got inspired to help children from poor backgrounds to take up sailing.

It took him nearly three years to get going. The main problem was the lack of access to the lake. “I approached the municipal commissioner and presented the idea to him. He liked it and said I could start the club at Sanjeevaiah Park .”

The YCH was founded on June 5, 2019 – World Environment Day . It began with three little boats and four sailors. Now, they have a fleet of 140 boats and over 100 sailors.

YCH is a not-for-profit body and apart from coaching sailors they have also been able to cater to the educational and nutritional needs of these kids. “As they come from families that cannot afford three meals a day, we took it upon ourselves to cater to their diet too,” Suheim said.

Over the last few years, Suheim has shifted his focus to girl sailors. “A couple of years ago when I had taken some of our boys for an event in Pune, one of my friends asked me why there were no girl sailors. Since then I have realised that empowering the girl child is very important.”

YCH and Nandi Foundation started Project Naavika and the results have been astounding. Preethi became the first girl ever to win the Monsoon Regatta this year. Seven of these girls go to the same training facility that PV Sindhu goes to. Thanks to Praveen Raju, the YCH girls have access to the gym at Suchitra Academy.

Suheim has had to fund the YCH from his own resources but doesn’t regret. “A man doesn’t need much to live. I am lucky to have the resources to take care of my needs. My wife, too, has been very supportive,” he said.

After investing his life into the project for the last 10 years, what has he gained? “Satisfaction. Seeing changes in the lives of these kids gives me immense satisfaction,” said Suheim, who has been awarded the Admiral Kohli Trophy by the Yachting Association of India in October this year for promoting the sport.

Title: Temple cleansing ritual at Tirumala
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Tirupati: The temple cleansing ritual, Koil Alwar Tirumanjanam, was held as a prelude to the annual Vaikunta Ekadasi festival at Tirumala on Tuesday.

The Koil Alwar Tirumanjanam is held four times a year at the Tiruchanoor temple—on the Tuesday preceding Ugadi, on Vaikunta Ekadasi, on annual Brahmotsavams and on Ani Vara Asthanam.

With the annual Vaikunta Ekadasi festival to be held at Tirumala on January 6, the ritual was carried out as prescribed in the ‘Vaikhanasa agama’ texts.

The idol of the presiding deity inside the sanctum sanctorum as well as other processional deities were given a waterproof cover. Later, a herbal paste of sandalwood powder, refined camphor, turmeric and other herbal ingredients were applied to the walls and pillars inside the sanctum and at the sub-shrines inside the main temple complex. TNN

Title: CB files chargesheet against Suresh Gopi
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The crime branch team probing the tax evasion case against actor and BJP MP Suresh Gopi , who allegedly registered his two luxury cars in the Union Territory of Puducherry , has completed the probe and filed a chargesheet before the Thiruvananthapuram chief judicial magistrate court.

The CB stated in its chargesheet that Gopi had registered his two Audi cars priced at Rs 60 lakh and Rs 80 lakh each in Puducherry by producing fake documents. He showed his residency as Karthika Apartment at Ellaippillai Chavady in Puducherry. He claimed to be a tenant in the apartment and managed to get a notary attest his rental agreement. He also secured an LIC policy in his name in this address. Though the actor tried to influence the apartment owner after the case was registered, the owner gave his statement against the MP when the investigation team questioned him.

He told the investigators that he did not know the actor. The notary too told the investigation team that his signature and rubber stamp on the agreement were forged. Through this fraud, the actor-turned politician evaded paying tax of Rs 3.60 lakh and Rs 16 lakh for each car, the probe team said.

The CB had registered the case against Gopi while probing the backgrounds of 272 luxury cars that were plying on Kerala roads with PY registration. They registered 16 cases in this regard. Besides Suresh Gopi, actor Fahadh Fazil was also found to be using vehicles with Puducherry registration. Fazil later paid the actual tax.

Title: Jamnagar cop booked in DA case
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: A suspended head constable , who was arrested in a graft case last month , was on Tuesday booked for having disproportionate assets against his known sources of income by the Rajkot division of anti-corruption bureau (ACB).

The ACB booked Chandravijaysinh Zala for having disproportionate assets of Rs 7.74lakh against his known source of income after they raided his home in Khodiyar Nagarcolony of Jamnagar city.

Investigation officer, M M Sarvaiya of Devbhoomi Dwarka ACB, said that Zala was arrested for taking Rs 7,000 bribe as hush-up money not to harass an accused in lock-up when he was posted with the B Division police station in Jamnagar. After his arrest, the ACB sleuths raided Zala’s house and found Rs 7.74 lakh in cash.

Zala was given time to explain the source of cash. When he could not, the ACB lodged FIR of disproportionate assets against Zala at the Jamnagar city police station.

Title: Mishap claims life of AP student in Philippines
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Vijayawada: A veterinary student from AP died in a road mishap at San Carlos city in the Philippines on Tuesday. The deceased was identified as Ponnapalli Jagadeesh of Nandigama town, Krishna district.

According to sources, the incident happened in the morning when Jagadeesh was on his way home from Virgen Milagrosa University and Foundation where he is studying.

A speeding bus hit him from behind killing him on the spot. Locals alerted the cops who reached and examined the scene. They then informed Jagadeesh’s parents.

Sources said Jagadeesh was pursuing a veterinary course and was hoping to emerge as a breadwinner for the family as they are from a poor farming background.

Local Telugu community with the help of Indian Embassy are working out the modalities to bring his body to India. Currently, officials have completed the post-mortem and booked the bus driver for the offence.

Title: Open gym to come up near Cauvery bridge
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

At an estimated cost of Rs 22 lakh, six simple gym equipment including tai chi wheels and double-cross walker ... Read More

TRICHY: Utilising the vacant space adjacent to Mambalasalai road near the Cauvery bridge in Srirangam , the corporation has launched civil work on an open-air gymnasium to encourage residents indulge in physical activity.

The corporation said that the vacant space adjacent to Mambalasalai road, sandwiched between the abandoned and new Cauvery bridge was encroached by hawkers. As the land with native trees belong to the state highways department, Trichy Corporation recently obtained permission to clear the space and utilise the area for developing an open-air gym.

The civil work on the 4,000 square feet space was launched last week. “The vacant space was encroached and littered with waste. Though the proposal was mooted in the middle of 2019, there was a delay in obtaining permission from the highways department,” an official with Trichy Corporation said.

Preliminary work such as filling and levelling the ground besides erecting compound wall is being carried out.

At an estimated cost of Rs 22 lakh, six simple gym equipment including tai chi wheels and double-cross walker that can be operated with little effort even by senior citizens shall be placed in the gym space.

“We will completely fence the area adjacent to Mambalasalai with steel bars to ensure the safety of gym users. Entrance for the open-air gym will be positioned on the old Cauvery bridge side,” the civic body official added. Utilising the existing green cover, 10 granite stone benches will be installed. The gym is likely to be made available for public use by the end of this month.

Title: Goa: Two trucks, bus in accident at Barcem
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

MARGAO: In an accident involving two fish-laden insulator trucks and a bus led to traffic blockade on both sides at Barcem, Tuesday morning.

Police sources said the two trucks were proceeding towards Mangalore from Margao, while the bus was headed to Margao from Karnataka.

The trucks were moving one behind the other when the one behind hit the truck ahead. As a result, the bus coming in the opposite direction lost control as it ran over the pavement. TNN

Title: When art has politics at heart
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

By Gowri Ramanarayan

CHENNAI: The 92-year-old violin maestro T N Krishnan performing a glorious concert on Christmas morning at the packed Madras Music Academy was by itself perhaps the most memorable moment of this music season. But just as you marvelled at the sweep of imagination and sighed over "Sankarabharanam", his strings broke into "Jingle Bells", wishing everyone a merry Christmas and a happy New Year. That is how, in these times of strife, a master musician reminded us of the values guaranteed by our Constitution.

The Christmas spirit pervaded the intimate ‘arangam’ space as well, where Bharatanatyam artist Geeta Chandran celebrated the birth of Christ with a lullaby to baby Krishna, and a Kabir poem about finding the garden of beauty within each of us. Not merely poignant ‘abhinaya’, but a message of peace.

Tradition, heritage, marabu, parampara — we know they are inextricable from the classical music and dance flooding Chennai sabhas in December. But it would be good to remember that this tradition, unmistakably identified with the Hindu faith, is not with blind hatred toward other beliefs. Nor does it remain static.

In the past, classicism did not mean imperviousness to socio-political currents. Several Old Madras musicians had risked imprisonment for sedition with "nationalist" songs against the British Raj, wore khadi, supported social reform, promoted Gandhian values and chanted "Ishwar Allah tero naam". M S Subbulakshmi continued to maintain this spirit as she intoned "Bismillah ir-rahman ir-raheem" with the same devotion she expressed in her "Vishnu Sahasranamam". D K Pattammal’s signature anthem spoke of peace and unity as Gandhi’s vision.

Though music and dance in free India have been more about structure and presentational methods to accommodate changing audience tastes, shifts in politics and society do affect performance. Certain age-old songs have been dropped or edited to match the mood of the times. A few performers have started avoiding compositions now seen as degrading women. Composer Gopalakrishna Bharati’s poignant songs extol the nobility of the outcaste Nandan, but a young Ashwath Narayanan or a Ramakrishnan Murthy follows the more recent practice of substituting neutral, universal terms like deenan (helpless) or ezhai (destitute) for the original words. A rare example was the replacing of "andanar" (brahmin) with "maanudar" (human being) in a Tamil hymn.

In dance recitals and dance dramas based on mythological grids, many old approaches seem ideologically out of date. The Surpanakha episode in the Ramayana can no longer be treated as a comic interlude as was done in the past. However, audiences can sometimes create new meanings with their ironic re-interpretations, as seen when ‘Kurmavartaram’ was staged at the Bharata Kalakshetra auditorium. Choreographed by Rukmini Devi, this classic depicts the story of how the gods lure the demons to join them in the struggle to extract the elixir which guarantees immortality. Disguised as a bewitching woman, Lord Vishnu tricks the demons out of their promised share.

The viewers were certainly moved by the devotional elements in this story of Vishnu’s avatar, and applauded the dynamic artists with gusto. But, paradoxically, they also saw the performance as a contemporary political allegory of exploitation, empathising with the demon victims than with the gods. In the same theatre, a spectacular "Panchali Sapatham" centre-staged the game of dice where the Pandavas lose everything to the Kauravas, including their queen. To the poet Subramania Bharati this was a chilling parable of India enslaved by the British. But to the viewers of today the episode became a gut-wrenching metaphor of their nation, and indeed the world, preyed by greed, megalomania and hatred.

The classical arts deploy metaphors and images, not slogans. Chennai’s Margazhi Utsavam indicates how some artists strive to employ those subtle tools to trigger an awareness of contemporary social problems and ethical dilemmas, to turn performance into a process of healing. They know that audiences are looking for art that lives and breathes in its time, not museumised spectacles. Aptly, Srinidhi Chidambaram’s Bharatanatyam recital ended with a ‘mangalam’ finale asking why faiths abandon love for oppression, and why hearts cannot co-exist in harmony as flowers do.

(The writer is a playwright and theatre director)

Title: Tourists flock Rishikesh, Haridwar to celebrate New Year’s Eve
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Many hotels and restaurants in the holy town have arranged for New Year parties

HARIDWAR: Large number of tourists thronged Rishikesh and surrounding areas on Tuesday to celebrate the New Year ’s Eve. According to hotel and resort owners, tourists (mostly from Delhi-NCR, Punjab, and Haryana) have made advance bookings for December 31. Some resorts have arranged for special events for the tourists.

Ram Pal Singh Bhandari, owner of Ripply Adventures Camp in Rishikesh, told TOI, “We have made special camping arrangements for New Year’s Eve. Most of the camping sites have been booked and tourists from Delhi-NCR, Punjab, Uttar Pradesh, and other parts of the India have already reached. The tourists have been advised to adhere to the rules.”

Dinesh Bhatt, president of Rafting Samiti in Rishikesh, said that tourists have reached in large numbers to camp in Rishikesh, Tapovan, and Lakhsman Jhula area. Rafting is popular among them. Almost every organiser has organised a New Year’s Eve party for tourists.

Similarly, Haridwar is also witnessing a huge tourist rush. Many hotels and restaurants in the holy town have arranged for New Year parties. Forest guards of Rajaji Tiger Reserve and Haridwar Forest Division have also been put on high alert to ensure smooth New Year celebrations.

“We took a bath at Har ki Pauri in the morning. Then, we left for Rishikesh to celebrate the New Year. However, some of our friends will be welcoming the New Year in Haridwar,” Akash Kumar, a tourist from Delhi, told TOI.

Title: Food poisoning leaves 1 dead, 22 in hospital
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

KANNUR: An inmate died and 22 others have been hospitalized following food poisoning at a destitute home near Oduvally in the interiors of Thaliparamba in the district on Tuesday.

According to officials, the deceased has been identified as Gundu Rao from Andhra, who had been staying at Divya Karunya Ashram , Chundakkunnu, near Oduvally. This is a rehabilitation centre for psychiatric patients, wandering beggars and disabled people.

The inmates suffered food poisoning apparently after they consumed ghee rice, chicken curry and salad, supplied for lunch as part of an old students’ meet of higher secondary school in Naduvil on December 29. Though the food was part of the noon meal, they showed symptoms when they consumed it in the evening too. There are 24 inmates, and one inmate who did not consume this food had nosymptoms.

All the 22 infected people have been admitted to Govt Medical College, Pariyaram, while the body of the deceased has been kept in mortuary, as the family could not be traced.

A joint team from the health and food safety departments visited the place and collected samples for examination.

DMO K Narayana Nayak said they would send the samples for testing to know the cause of poisoning. “In the preliminary enquiry, we found that when they consumed the food in the afternoon they did not have any problem but when they consumed it in the night as well, they suffered the symptoms,” he said.

Police said a case of unnatural death has been registered.

Title: UP video shows civilians throwing stones at anti-CAA protesters from police side
Content:
A man can be seen taking out a CCTV camera.

AGRA: Days after a senior police official of Agra range claimed that no bullet was fired during the anti-CAA protest in Firozabad on December 20, at least four videos have emerged in which police are not only shown purportedly firing at the protesting mob, but also helped by unidentified civilians, who are seen throwing stones from their side. In another video, a mob is seen setting to fire a shop in the presence of police force.The authenticity of the videos could be not confirmed.Six people were killed with bullet injuries in the anti-CAA protest on December 20. Inspector General (Agra range) Satish Ganesh, however, had claimed that that not a single bullet was fired by police during the violence. On Tuesday, when TOI shared the four videos with the IG for his reaction, he said: “I will ask Firozabad SP to look into them.”In the first video accessed by TOI, a group of 15-20 civilians along with cops are seen barging inside a wooden shop (Raja ki Lakdi ki Taal) owned by one Raja Khan. The men throw stones, vandalised shop and later set ablaze woods kept inside the shop. It's located on Shikohabad Adda Road at Vakeelpura Mandi, close to Nalband Chouraha under Rasoolpur police jurisdiction. Firozabad police claims that this is the place where violence started on December 20.In the second video, the same group of civilians are found throwing stones towards Phoolwali gully dominated by Muslims while police stand behind civilians. Moments later, cops are seen firing from their assault rifles.Speaking with TOI, Azad Khan (42), the elder brother of Raja Khan, said, “I along with my nephew Faraz Khan (19) alias Deepu, and other employees Gulshan Sharma (19) and Mohammad Israr were selling woods, when we saw heavy police force and group of civilians running towards Nalband Chouraha from Rasoolpur thana. Sensing something unusual and threatful, I immediately asked all my customers to return home.” Azad suffered multiple injuries after been assaulted by civilians and cops inside his wooden shop.“We immediately shut our shop's door. My staff and a few other customers hid themselves behind stack of woods, while my nephew and I were in our office watching the group of civilians and policemen through our seven CCTVs cameras. We saw civilians vandalising two-wheelers and other vehicles parked outside the shop while policemen remained unmoved. Later, two policemen came toward our shop and broke our shop's door, helping unruly civilians to barge inside. Both police and group of civilians threw stones at our shop, destroyed our CCTV cameras, took away CCTV DVR from our office which had footage of vandalism," claimed Azad.The mob set our woods on fire while police kept looking at them. They dragged me, my nephew and staff out of the shop and brutally assaulted us. I begged police to let me douse the fire, but they didn’t allow. I somehow escaped and jumped off the shop’s rear wall to save myself, while my nephew Faraz, employee Gulshan Sharma and a customer identified as Adil were taken to police station,” he added.While Gulshan has been released, Adil is in jail and has been issued property seizure notice by Firozabad district administration. His father, Saeed, told TOI: “Adil was returning after offering Friday’s prayers when he had to take refuge in a wooden shop along with some other men since there was violence on streets. He was on the phone with me when some people dragged him out. I heard him shout for help. His phone has been switched off since."Azad told TOI that Gulshan was released by police on December 21 morning after his parents showed his identification card to police. "We had nothing to do with violence and were engaged in our usual business. My nephew Faraz was born on Diwali day, therefore we kept Deepu as his nickname and is now known by his Hindu name instead of Faraz.”Talking to TOI, Gulshan Sharma said, “We were selling woods to customers, when police and violent mob barged inside the shop and brutally attacked us. They took me and others to police station and only after confirming my identity, police released me. My jaw was broken in the assault in which my employers' property was badly damaged."Gulshan Sharma had joined shop just a month back on the recommendation of a local police officer who had good terms with Azad Khan. In violence, Gulshan’s motorbike was vandalised by mob and policemen.In Video: CAA violence: Videos shot by locals show civilians pelting stone, setting ablaze Muslim-owned property before cops in UP's Firozabad

Title: BDU-affiliated college students forced to take exam on holiday
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: The state might have declared holiday for colleges until Wednesday, but students in colleges affiliated to Bharathidasan University had to appear for their semester examination on Tuesday after their test dates unusually clashed with that of holidays.

Students had to attend examinations on December 23, 24, and 26 even though higher education secretary Mangat Ram Sharma issuing direction to university/colleges to remain closed on these days. He made the announcement on December 20, asking institutions to compensate the holidays by opening on Saturdays and other holidays.

The university had scheduled examination on these days much earlier to the announcement made by the higher education secretary and university chose to go ahead with semester examinations on these days. A faculty from city college said that the university should have postponed semester examinations considering hardship to students. “Especially for outstation students as hostels were closed in many colleges and students had to come only to write examinations,” said the faculty.

Higher education secretary, in his letter, had not mentioned anywhere that examinations should not be conducted on these dates. Instruction was to declare holiday on these four days,” said controller of examination (COE) BDU K Duraiarasan.“We had rescheduled semester examinations originally scheduled for December 27 and 30 as local body polls were to happen on these days and outstation students had to go to their hometowns. Postponing examination on these days would have affected working days on the upcoming semester especially when the working days are less, he said.

Title: Cheetah squads to hit roads today
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The all new Cheetah Patrol Squad of the city traffic police and the new traffic sector system introduced to ease the traffic regulation duties of the police and thereby reduce the traffic woes of the city motorists will officially start functioning from Wednesday, the New Year day.

Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan will flag off the new systems during the occasion of the inauguration of the new building of Thampanoor police station in the city.

The city police first initiated works to revise the traffic sectors in the city in a way ensuring presence of more police personnel on roads for traffic regulation.

A traffic sector is like an area under a local police station with an officer in the rank of a sub-inspector in charge of it. Earlier, the city had 11 sectors, five under north traffic subdivision and six under south traffic subdivision. Under the new system, the number of sectors was raised to 30, with 14 under north sub-division and 16 under south sub-division. This was done by reducing the size of the sectors that existed before.

A month ago, the idea of Cheetah Patrol Squad was also mooted in a meeting convened by state police chief Loknath Behera in which the city residents had the opportunity to submit their complaints and suggestions regarding city traffic directly to the DGP.

There will be 10 Cheetah patrolling teams in the city and each team will be provided with a four-wheeler for patrolling purposes. Each Cheetah Patrol Squad will consist of a sub-inspector, a driver and a civil police officer.

The sub-inspector of the Cheetah Patrolling Squad will act as a ‘station house officer on wheels’, who will have the authority to receive complaints, register cases, regulate traffic, attend to accident victims and even initiate steps to recover vehicles that are parked in an obstructive way.

There will be 10 Cheetah Patrol Squads in total, five each under the north and south traffic sub-divisions. These squads will be attached to various local police stations in the city. However, with the stations as the base of their operations, each Cheetah Patrol Squad will be led by a sub-inspector who will also have three or four traffic sectors under their control, based on proximity.

Cheetah patrolling units will be always be vigilant and responsive to perform any operations given to them either through wireless set or mobile phone. They will immediately reach the spot where any traffic-related issue happens and will take necessary actions accordingly.

They will hand over the offender (accused) to the concerned police station under the jurisdictional limit, with a written report of the offence committed by the accused and will also take immediate steps to transfer the victims to the nearby hospital.

Title: New VC takes charge in TNNLU
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Trichy: V S Elizabeth has been appointed as the new vice-chancellor of Tamil Nadu National Law University.

Professor from National Law School of India University, Bengaluru she took over from Kamala Sankaran after completing her five-year term as vice-chancellor.

Faculty of NSLIU from 1991, after teaching History in a few colleges in Bengaluru, she was holding the position of placement officer and coordinator of the centre for child and the law in NSLIU since 2015. tnn

Title: G’chiroli cops moot amnesty plan for youths who joined Maoist camps
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Nagpur: Gadchiroli police have decided to initiate no legal proceedings against the youths for joining the Maoists as their recruits despite their names being mentioned as supporters in records.

The decision has been taken based on the assumption that the youths may have joined the camps fearing consequences of refusing the rebels.

Around 12 youths from Nelgonda and its adjoining hamlets had joined the Maoists’ training camp at Abhujamadh, a stronghold of the rebels stretching across the Maharashtra-Chhattisgarh borders, which was subsequently stormed by C-60 commandos on November 30, 2019. Two persons, who police claimed were rebels, were neutralized at the camp site where arrangements of physical exercises and arms training were found.

It’s learnt that around eight supporters out of 12 have returned home after the camp site was busted by the elite commando group of the Gadchiroli police. Despite knowing their names and the fact about their presence at the camp, police have decided not to invoke any penal provisions against them.

Sources said the decision to show leniency will continue for supporters and members of the militia unless their active involvement in the sabotage comes to fore.

SP Shailesh Balkawade said no action would be initiated against the 12 youths who had gone to participate in the training camp. “Eight have come back but we will write to the families of the rest of the four youths. No action would be initiated against them provided they return promptly without being involved more in the movement,” he said.

“We have dealt humanely with the persons who have returned so far and waiting for the others to come back. In fact, we will go a step ahead and try to find out whether they can be helped with some employment,” said the SP.

Balkawade said the district police have decided to overlook help offered to the Maoists by the villagers, like giving food and other supplies. “We can understand that the villagers deliver food and ration supplies to the Maoists fearing consequences of refusal. Police will not spare those supplying logistical support to the Maoists to trigger blasts and other such activities,” he said.

Citing an example, Balkawade said police had not initiated any action on bulk of the residents of Lavheri village of Kurkheda taluka, who knew about the Jambhulkheda blast or supported in executing the act leading to death of 15 jawans of Quick Response Team (QRT) and one civilian driver on May 1, 2019.

“Police had arrested only six persons who then had actively helped the Maoists to carry out the blast,” he said.

Balkawade claimed that police are now fast gaining grounds among the masses of the Gadchiroli replacing Maoist influence at most of the places in the district where the rebels earlier enjoyed deeper support.

Title: More green cover, but state still forest deficit
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Jaipur: Rajasthan, which ranks 15 in terms of recorded forest area (RFA) in the country, is a forest deficient state according to India State of Forest Report (ISFR) 2019.

Although the state’s forest cover has seen marginal increase of 57.51 sq-km as compared to 2017, the moderate forest cover area and open forest cover area have declined in the last two years.

Acccording to the report, while very dense forest (VDF) area remained unchanged from 2017 with 78sq-km, the moderately dense forest (MDF) reduced from 4340 sq-km in 2017 to 4309 in 2019. Also, the open forest area which was 12,154 sq-km two years ago, now stands at 11,708 sq-km.

IFSR mentioned that reasons for this increase were plantation and conservation activities as well as improvement in interpretation. The report reads, “In the last two years, the state raised a total of 42,633 ha of plantation. Also, the state has examples of some of the best afforestation practices along the Indira Gandhi Canal. Under the Joint Forest Management, there are 6,377 village forest management committees and eco-development committees operational in the state.”

In Rajasthan, RFA is 32,737 sq-km out of which 12,475 sq-km is reserved forest, 18,217 sq-km is protected forest and 2,045 sq-km is unclassed forests. The state has five national parks, 25 wildlife sanctuaries and 11 conservation reserves which constitute the Protected Area network of the state covering 2.92% of its geographical area. There are three Project Tiger (Ranthambhore, Sariska and Mukundra Hills) and two Ramsar (Keoladeo Ghana sanctuary and Sambhar lake) sites.

The report also highlighted an alarming fact that despite increase in forest cover, tree cover of the state had decreased by 154 sq-km as compared to the previous assessment reported in ISFR 2017. Tree cover in Rajasthan is estimated as 8112 sq-km as mentioned in the report. The report also pointed out in Rajasthan, between January 1, 2015 to February 5, 2019, a total of 2,834 hectares of forest land was diverted for non-forestry purposes under the Forest Conservation Act, 1980 (MoEF & CC, 2019).

Title: Fire breaks out in secretariat building
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

DEHRADUN: A fire broke out in the room of the personal secretary of Additional Secretary (Law) at the secretariat building here on Tuesday. According to the fire department officials, the fire was presumably caused due to a short circuit which destroyed the stabiliser and central processing unit of the computer, some papers, and curtains in the room.

The fire brigade reached the spot in around half-an-hour after the secretariat staff found smoke coming out of Sanjay Kumar’s room. Kumar is the personal secretary of Sayan Singh Negi, Additional Secretary (Law). Fortunately, no human injury was reported in the incident.

“The flame was quickly doused by fire extinguishers. The staff also managed to save important files but the blaze caught the computer’s CPU,” said Diwakar Kumar, who works in fire brigade control room. He added that the exact cause of fire would be ascertained following proper investigation.

Earlier in February, 2019, a fire had broken out on the fourth floor of the state secretariat building where the chief minister’s office is situated.

Title: Man found charred to death
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Agra: A 35-year-old Dalit man, missing since Monday evening, was found charred to death in an abandoned perfume factory under mysterious circumstances in a remote village of Etah.

Identified as Sher Singh alias Sahdev, the victim went missing on Monday after 6:30pm. Resident of Jhinwar village under Nidhauli Kala police jurisdiction, victim was the youngest among five siblings.

“He left home without saying anything,” Sahdev’s sister, Bhuri, said. “Once victim's elder brother, Moharpal, who works in Delhi, gives us a written complaint, we will lodge an FIR. Victim’s body has been sent for autopsy to ascertain the cause of his death,” station house officer of Nidhauli Kala, Subhas Katheria said.

Title: Hiked OPD, treatment charges to become effective at govt hosps from today
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Dehradun: Uttarakhand government’s mandate of increasing the OPD and other treatment prices at various government hospitals will be implemented across the state from Wednesday (January 1, 2020).

Dr BC Ramola, chief medical superintendent of Coronation Hospital, told TOI that OPD (Outpatient Department) registration will now cost Rs 25 and the indoor fees for various wards will be hiked up to 10%. “A hike in treatment charges at government hospitals, community health centres (CHCs), and primary health centres (PHCs), has been made after a gap of nine years,” added Dr Ramola.

The IPD (In-patient Department) rates in government hospitals will now be Rs 45 per day as against Rs 40 per day earlier. A regular private ward will now cost Rs 200 per day and an AC room will cost Rs 600 per day.

To recall, the state government had hiked the OPD and treatment rates at government hospitals by up to 40% in August last year. Later, the government rolled back the hike after protests by Opposition parties and locals.

Title: 1 arrested for illegal sand mining near Kollidam river
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: A raid conducted by a village administrative officer (VAO) and a village assistant led to the arrest of a man indulging in illegal sand mining in Kollidam River near Srirangam in Trichy on Monday. The police also seized a sand-laden truck.

The Srirangam police arrested the truck driver, S Srinivasan, 40 from Thiruvanaikovil in Trichy. His helper Selvam from Tagore street in Srirangam and the truck owner Karunanidhi from Tagore street in Srirangam were yet to be arrested.

Acting on a tip-off, VAO of Vellithirumutham Bharathidasan and village assistant Ravi visited the eastern side of new bridge across Kollidam River around 9 am yesterday. The officers found two persons loading sand, mined from the river bank, into a lorry . On seeing them, Selvam escaped from the spot while the officials managed to get hold of Srinivasan.

Title: Goa: Implementation of new MV Act after cabinet meet
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: The implementation of the Motor Vehicles (Amendment) Act, 2019, which was scheduled for January, will be discussed at the upcoming cabinet meet, following which the legislation will be enforced.

“The state government has decided that the matter will go to the cabinet. The law department wanted it to be discussed as it is a major policy decision. The matter will go for discussion and a decision will be taken at the cabinet meet scheduled to be held in January,” transport director Rajan Satardekar, said.

He added that the act is likely to be implemented by the end of the month.

The new legislation came into force across the country from September 1 onwards. However, after some state governments raised concerns regarding some of the hiked fines, they were permitted to impose lower penalties for certain traffic violations. Taking a cue, the Goa government also decided to reduce the penalties for some offences and the enforcement of the new MV (Amendment) Act was consequently postponed to January.

“There is no scope for us to reduce fines for violations like drunk driving or driving without a licence. Fines for other offences like helmetless riding, wrong parking etc can be reduced,” transport minister Mauvin Godinho has said.

He had earlier also announced that the government would first repair pothole-ridden roads in Goa before implementing the act and charging steep fines.

Satardekar said the issue of reduction of fines for certain traffic violations will be decided by the cabinet this month, too.

Title: Railway police urge people to use helpline number in case of emergency
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: Warning passengers of offenders in trains, Trichy division railway police superintendent T Senthilkumar urged the people to use helpline 1,512 in the event of emergencies, here on Tuesday.

“Though the helpline is functioning for the past two years, it is the time to remind the people of using it fully for their safety on board the trains. This helpline can be used to report on teasing of women, movement of suspicious people. The response will be quick that the government railway police will be on spot for their help,” Senthilkumar said here on Tuesday.

As many as 700 police personnel have been deployed across the 28 stations in division covering 18 districts from Villpuram to Kanyakumari to ensure the safety of the passengers on the eve of New Year. “With 120 trains crossing Trichy every day ferrying over two lakh passengers, government railway police, railway protection force and other staff carry out open line patrol, platform patrol and onboard train patrol,” he said.

The intensified security has been put in place in the railway stations in pilgrim centres such as Rameswaram, Palani, Velankanni, Vellore , Thanjavur , Kumbakonam and few other places.

SP Senthilkumar listed out the cases cracked in 2019. GRP arrested 53 bag-lifters and recovered 150 sovereigns of gold ornaments stolen from the railway passengers. In the cell phone theft case, GRP arrested 94 accused and seized 254 out of 335 mobile phones this year.

GRP rescued 827 children from railway stations in Trichy railway division. “The rescued children included missing children and runaway children. Of the rescued children, 809 children were handed over to their parents. The parents of the rest of them are yet to be traced. So, they are kept in the care and protection home,” he said.

On the deaths on the track, SP blamed the careless trespassing of people on the railway track several times. “While suicide on the railway tracks are also a cause of concern, many cases of deaths on the track occurred as the passengers trespass the track listening songs on the headphone and also for relieving themselves. It should be avoided,” he said.

Title: Man rapes mute woman, 65, in Roorkee
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

Title: Spark from welding work could have triggered fire
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

File photo of the fire

RAJKOT: The fire that broke out in the bulk methanol storage tank near Kandla Port in Kutch district on Monday afternoon was still raging on Tuesday. Sources said that spark from welding like work on the tank could have triggered the explosion and the resultant fire that killed four men.

Kutch district collector Praveena D K told TOI: “We are awaiting the for final report but according to preliminary assessment some welding work was being done on the upper surface of the tank which could have triggered the fire.” Usually, the maintenance work is done after the tank is emptied but it was not regular kind of maintenance work.

The bulk chemical tanks near the methanol tank were emptied as a precautionary measure. Fire officials said that the blaze was under control but will be completely doused only by Wednesday morning. Eight fire tenders were still engaged in dousing the fire.

The four killed in the fire were identified as Sanjay Vagh, Sanjay Sahu, Darshan Rai and Omprakash Regar. Their bodies were charred beyond recognition.

The bulk storage tanks belong to IMC group and contained about 200 metric tonne of methanol when the fire broke out on Monday.

Title: Delhi: BJP may name its candidate for CM post soon
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Delhi BJP chief Manoj Tiwari

NEW DELHI: Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) may soon announce its chief minister’s candidate for the upcoming assembly election in Delhi. Sources said the party had initially decided to name its chief minister candidate in Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s rally but delayed the announcement .

The internal surveys conducted by the saffron party have suggested that the electorate may like to know who the chief minister of Delhi would be if BJP is elected to power.

A senior BJP functionary said that top leadership appeared positive to the suggestion and the possible announcement may be made by BJP national president Amit Shah during the booth-level workers’ meet on Sunday. “The elections, however, will be fought under the leadership of Delhi BJP chief Manoj Tiwari.”

“The office-bearers of the local party unit and the members of the core group for the assembly polls have been indicated in recent meetings that a decision on CM candidate may be taken soon,” said a core committee member of Delhi BJP.

BJP has fought all previous assembly polls in the national capital with a CM face. The ruling AAP has been regularly challenging the saffron party to name the candidate who would be taking on chief minister Arvind Kejriwal in the upcoming assembly election.

A section of BJP functionaries had earlier suggested the central leadership that the elections may be fought in the name of PM Modi to prevent any dissent, said sources. “We have seen in previous elections how naming a chief ministerial candidate did not go down too well with some Delhi leaders. A section believed that any such decision may have an adverse impact on the party’s prospects,” said a senior party functionary.

Another party functionary said the decision to name the chief ministerial candidate was strengthened following the recent defeat in Jharkhand.

Title: Gujarat: Stray bulls kill two in separate accidents
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: Two persons were killed in separate road accidents involving stray bulls in Jamnagar and Rajkot districts, police said on Tuesday.

The first accident took place near Sheikhpat village of Jamnagar late on Monday night when Arvind Solanki (28) was travelling in an autorickshaw with his relative Jasuben Solanki. All of a sudden a bull strayed onto the path of the vehicle and collided with it. Due to the impact, Arvind got thrown out of the vehicle and was hit by a car coming from behind. Arvind was rushed to nearby hospital where he died during treatment. Police has registered a case of accidental death.

In the second case, 45-year-old Baldev Sonagara succumbed to his injuries on Monday after he had collided with a bull while returning home on his motorcycle on Kuvadva Road on December 29. He had received severe head injuries in the accident.

Title: Forest inspector suspended over bribe clip
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

DEHRADUN: The divisional forest officer (DFO) of Terai (East) suspended a forest inspector (FI) on Tuesday after a purported audio clip of the forester allegedly seeking bribe from a man believed to be from the sand mining mafia went viral on social media. Both the forest department and Haldwani police have initiated an inquiry into the matter.

Terai (East) DFO Nitishmani Tripathi said that the action against the forester, Kailash Chandra Kapil was taken based on a purported audio clip in which he is allegedly seeking money for allowing sand mining in Kumaon. “We contacted the forest inspector who told us that someone is conspiring against him and it’s not his voice. He also told us that he had lodged a police complaint in the matter. However, prima facie, it’s his voice and I have suspended him with immediate effect,” Tripathi added.

According to sources in the forest department, the accused, in the initial investigation, maintained that he received an extortion call from an unknown number and the caller threatened to circulate a fake audio if he failed to pay money. However, during preliminary inquiry, several colleagues of the accused confirmed that the voice was that of Kapil.

Tripathi said, “We have started an inquiry in the matter and a separate investigation is also being done by district police. Suitable action will be taken against him if he is found guilty. His suspension has been done to send out a message that corruption will cost officials their job.”

Title: RCCI wants better rail connectivity, facilities
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Rajkot: The Rajkot Chamber of Commerce and Industry (RCCI) has demanded better rail connectivity with north India and Mumbai. At a meeting of Zonal Railway Users Consultative Committee (ZRUCC) in Mumbai, the representatives of RCCI said better connectivity with northern states would boost business in the long run.

Vice president of the RCCI, Parth Ganatra said “We suggested that a folable tray or trolley be provided to female passengers travelling alone in a train with a child less than five years old. This is in line with facilities provided in developed countries.”

The RCCI also demanded stoppage for Duronto train at at Borivali station in Mumbai as most of the Gujaratis reside in Borivali and Kandivali areas. They have also raised demand for thrice a week train between Rajkot and Haridwar instead of one current one. The industry body demanded escalator facility at Rajkot railway station.

Title: Women’s security, police welfare top priorities in 2020: CP
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Nagpur: Biding adieu to 2019, city police commissioner BK Upadhyay on Tuesday said women’s security will be one of the top two priorities in the New Year. The other key focus area would be police welfare.

After seeing off the hotly contested general and state elections in 2019 without any hiccups, Upadhyay ended the year with a popular decision of starting home-drop scheme for women in the backdrop of the Hyderabad rape and murder case.

As per the scheme, women would get help to reach home in police vehicles in case they are stranded without any transportation at any place between 9pm and 5am.

Upadhyay is set to be felicitated along with Jt CP Ravindra Kadam and Nagpur police by an NGO on January 3 for successfully commencing the plan and his other women-oriented policing measures.

Statistically, Upadhyay and his team had a better 2019 than the year before. In 2018, there were 166 cases of rape, while the number came marginally down to 161 till December end. There number of molestation cases in 2019 (338) was also less as compared to the previous year (378) till December 30. All the offences have been detected.

Apart from the home-drop scheme, Upadhyay is contemplating to strengthen the existing ‘Damini squad’ which helps women in distress, especially in public places. The top cop nurtured a liberal policy towards registering complaints lodged by women by issuing instructions to the police stations that such cases should not be soft-peddled.

“(In 2020) We will open a school for police families at the headquarters. Initially, the school would be for students between Std I and IV. Later, we have an expansion plan in the pipeline,” he said.

In the past, for CP Satya Pal Singh, now an MP, had started a school but it had to be rolled back due to want of permission.

In 2019, Upadhyay said his focus area was ‘organized crime’. Around 13 gangs were slapped with charges under the Maharashtra Control of Organized Crime Act (MCOCA) while 44 goons were put behind bars charged with Maharashtra Prevention of Dangerous Activities (MPDA) Act.

Though murder cases have gone up by six in 2019 in comparison to 2018, police records showed that 39 of them were due to domestic dispute and not involving goons. Robbery cases have come down by 40 while burglaries were 54 less in 2019 than the year before. There were lesser cases of dacoities in 2019 (15) than in 2018 (25). Also, motor vehicle thefts cases have come down by 54.

After arresting gangster Santosh Ambekar , Upadhyay and Kadam’s collaborative efforts witnessed registration of 12 offences against him including invoking the fifth MCOCA against him within two months.

The firing on city’s first citizen, mayor Sandip Joshi, during the winter assembly session might have been a setback for Upadhyay, but the top cop sounded confident about cracking the case soon. “Whatever is the motive and whoever may be behind the incident, we will place the facts before the citizens soon. We have not taken the question on police’s ability lightly,” he added.

Title: This New Year, learn from failures & respect time: Kamal Nath
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

MP chief minister Kamal Nath , while extending ‘New Year' to the citizens of Madhya Pradesh, urged them to learn from failures of the past and respect time. In his latest blog, Nath said failures were nothing but the outcome of efforts made half-heartedly and people who cultivated friendship with time, reached their desired destinations and comfortably achieved their targeted goals.

"Let us welcome the dawn of 2020 with countless hopes, enthusiasm and positive energies . The year 2019 has gone down the memory lanes. Always be ready to learn from failures and note that failures are nothing but the outcome of efforts made halfheartedly. Always think that success is relative. Despite sincere efforts, it may be elusive. So, always be in pursuit of excellence. I just recall a couplet from classical Urdu poetry in which great poet Hali says- "Hai Justaju Ki Khoob Se Hai Khoobtar Kahan? Ab Thaharti Hai Dekhiye Jaa Kar Nazar Kahan?" said Nath.

Emphasising on learning from the failures, he said, “Don't be scared of failures and never be charmed by successes as they are not permanent. We fail only when we fail to keep pace with the changing Time, which is merciless. It never stops for anyone regardless of their socio-economic status or geographical identities. This is the only precious thing, which everybody has but a few have the requisite wisdom to utilise it." "I recall the title of a famous painting of extremely talented Russian Jewish painter Marc Chagall which reads that ‘Time Is A River Without Bank'. So, if we want Time to flow in the desired direction, we have to embank the River of Time and this is the challenge all of us have to take up. No one can help us in this pursuit," said Nath.

Nath also suggested to respect time and said, "There are certain things, which we can't purchase despite all our wealth like love, affection, knowledge, trust, sleep, smile, health, friendship and of course the powerful time.

We perish every moment if we waste it. In the New Year, take a resolve to be sensitive about the use of time. Respect every moment and keep learning to manage the time."

Title: Agra: Forest cover shrinks in eco-sensitive Taj Trapezium Zone
Content:
In Agra district, the forest cover has reduced by 9.38 sq km over the last two years

AGRA: The India State of Forest Report 2019 has revealed that over the last two years, forest cover has shrunk in the eco-sensitive Taj Trapezium Zone (TTZ).The TTZ is a 10,400 sq km trapezium-shaped area covering five districts of Agra, Firozabad, Mathura, Hathras and Etah in UP and Bharatpur district of Rajasthan. The zone comprises over 40 protected monuments, including three World Heritage sites -- Taj Mahal, Agra Fort and Fatehpur Sikri.As compared to the 2017 Forest Survey of India (FSI) report, the forest cover in the six districts has reduced from 3.47% to 3.43% of geographical area in 2019. In 2017, the forest cover in TTZ was 664 km which has shrunk to 657.71 in 2019.In Agra district , the forest cover has reduced by 9.38 sq km over the last two years.The report comes four years after the Supreme Court had rapped the UP government for making false claims on planting planting of saplings in the TTZ to protect the Taj Mahal from pollution after a two-member panel had submitted a report, saying that the state government’s claim of having planted 15,000 saplings around the World Heritage site was false.The apex court had ordered the state government to plant over 2.58 lakh saplings in 790 hectares.Reacting to the report, divisional commissioner Anil Kumar, who is also the chairman of TTZ, said, “We are working on increasing the green cover in the TTZ area. Lakhs of saplings have been planted in each of the districts over the past two years. They will develop into trees in next few years, significantly increasing the forest cover. After studying the FSI report, suitable action will be taken in a time-bound manner.”According to the FSI report, in Mathura district, forest cover has shrunk to 1.71 km and by 4.82 km in Etah district. In Hathras, no change has been recorded in the forest cover. However, the forest cover has increased by 9.60 km in Firozabad district and by 1.27 km in Bharatpur district.District forest officer Manish Mittal said, “We are studying the report. There seems to be some change in the methodology in evaluating the forest cover. The reasons behind the decline in forest cover will be identified soon. This year, 28 lakh saplings have been planted in the district. Last year, around 18 lakh trees were planted. Agra district is going to see a major increase in forest cover over the next 4-5 years.”Senior lawyer and secretary of city-based social organization, Agra Development Foundation (ADF), KC Jain said, “It is upsetting that forest cover has reduced in the area declared as eco-sensitive zone by the apex court. A special committee of experts from the FSI, Dehradun, National Botanical Research Institute in Lucknow and Dayalbagh Educational Institute in Agra should be constituted to suggest ways to increase the forest cover in the TTZ.”

Title: Unrest hits foreign tourist footfall in Rajasthan
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Foreign tourists enjoy their day in Jaipur city (File photo)

JAIPUR: The ongoing unrest over CAA and NRC has taken a hit on number of foreign tourists visiting Rajasthan in winter.

Tourist destinations like Pushkar, Udaipur , Jodhpur and Jaipur have seen fewer foreigners than previous years in the last two week of December. The hospitality sector started receiving cancellations and seen a dip in bookings by foreign nationals after advisories issued by some countries in the wake of rape cases and abrogation of Article 370.

It further aggravated after the CAA protest started. Jaisalmer, however, seemed to be an exception which has seen a good turnout of foreigners.

Piyush Sharma, a marketing manager at a four-star hotel in Jaipur, said Rajasthan may have not seen any major violent protests or demonstration, but was still facing the brunt. “Arrival of foreign tourists depends on political and social stability along with law and order situation of host country,” said Sharma. The latest entrant in world tourist map Sawai Madhopur is also feeling the heat due to dwindling number of foreign tourists.

Title: Museum-Zoo team declared winners
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Museum-Zoo department has bagged the first prize in the flower show competition held at the Kanakakkunnu Palace as a part of Vasantholsavam 2019.

The team led by G R Rajagopal exhibited 1,700 plant species in the nine-day flower exhibition, which in turn brought the first prize back to the Museum-Zoo team after 17 long years.

“We exhibited 1,700 different plant species, which is a new record. All teams which participated in this competition faced adverse climatic conditions. We found it hard to ensure that the flowers bloomed as we received very less amount of sunlight. But it was the determination, perseverance and hard-work of our employees, including the daily-wage staff, which helped us win this competition,” said S Abu, director of department of museums and zoos.

The Museum-Zoo team contested in 57 categories out of 70 and bagged 23 first prizes, 13 second prizes and 9 third prizes. They edged ahead of the Kerala secretariat team by four points, thereby winning the overall category with 421 points.

“The meticulous planning and professional approach of our team members made this victory possible. Last year, when we finished second, we honoured our team members by presenting them with plaques at a special celebratory function. This year we will be conducting a bigger celebratory function to honour each and every member of our team for making this possible,” said Abu. He also added that the Museum- Zoo team will be participating in next year’s competition by exhibiting more than two thousand plants.

Title: Activists send fresh set of proposals to remove encroachments on NH-16
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Visakhapatnam: A section of social activists in the city have sent a fresh set of proposals to the National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) and the Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation (GVMC) to remove illegal encroachments on both sides of the stretch of National Highway (NH)-16 passing through the city.

Activists claim that if the government’s proposal to make Vizag city the executive capital of the state materialises, the number of vehicles on city roads will increase manifold, worsening the commute on the NH-16 .

“Even the present condition of the NH16 is very bad. Traffic hardly moves during peak hours. At some of the crossings, the wait at traffic signals seems to be timeless,” said Tenneti Narasimham, a social activist who has long advocated to remove encroachments on the stretch.

In June 2019, TOI had reported that the average speed of vehicles on the NH-16 was around 25 km/hour to 30 km/hour.

“The only way to sort out this issue is to increase the breadth of the highway and build service roads all along the stretch that passes through the city. We are now planning to take up the issue with the chief minister,” added Narasimham.

In June NHAI, Visakhapatnam prepared a report that stated there were no less than 227 encroachments on a mere 6-km-stretch from Zoo Park to Maddilapalem crossing.

The report stated that around 208 encroachments are permanent in nature and include popular bars, restaurants, bakeries, automobiles and garment shops.

“In our reports we have included the names of the owners of the stores, whether these stores are permanent or temporary in nature and in what capacity they have encroached upon the highway. The GVMC is the authority to take legal steps against these encroachers,” said an NHAI official.

GVMC officials claimed that driving away encroachers overnight is difficult given the permanent nature of the encroachments. Several encroachers have been operating business for years.

“It is very difficult to drive them away. We have to wait for the government’s position on this and will act if Visakhapatnam is announced the executive capital,” said a senior GVMC official.

Title: Several IAS & IPS officers promoted on New Year’s eve
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Jaipur: On the eve of New Year, the state government promoted eight IAS officers and IFS GV Reddy, who has been given additional charge of head of forest force in addition to his charge of principal chief conservation of forest and chairman of bio diversity board.

The state also promoted five IGs, one DIG and five SPs/DCPs.

Sanjay Malhotra and Dr R Venkateshwaran, principal secretary revenue and administrative reforms, respectively, have been made additional chief secretaries in their respective departments.

Four secretaries have been promoted to principal secretaries. Ajitabh Sharma, secretary to the chief minister, Alok Gupta, secretary Devasthan, Dinesh Kumar, secretary mines and petroleum, and Rajesh Kumar, secretary and commissioner, have been promoted to the posts of principal secretary.

Pradeep Kumar Borad, commissioner college education, and Mahesh Chandra Sharma, joint secretary GAD, are the other two officers promoted to the to the next grade.

Jose Mohan, who was deputy inspector general of Bikaner Range, has been made inspector general (IG) of the same range. He will continue to perform the duties of DIG till further orders.

IGs who have been promoted to Additional Director General of Police (ADG) include Prashakha Mathur, Biju George Joseph, Sushmit Bishwas, Dinesh M N , and Smita Shrivastav.

SPs and DCPs who have promoted to DIGs are Anshuman Bhowmiyan, Rahul Prakash, Haider Ali Zaidi, Hemant Kumar Sharma and Anil Kumar Tank. The orders also included change in the pay grade level of over 20 police officials.

Title: Fog and cold wave: Schools to remain closed till Jan 2
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Agra: Following dense fog and cold wave condition, the district administration on Tuesday ordered school up to class 12th to remain closed till January 2. The order issued by additional district magistrate Prabhakant Awasthi mentioned that strict action will be taken against school authorities in case the order is violated.

Dr Bhimrao Ambedkar University also declared no classes till January 1. However, the semester exam will take place as per schedule and university offices will operate.

On Tuesday, both maximum and minimum temperature remained below the normal level. The maximum temperature was recorded 13.9 degrees Celsius which was nine degrees Celsius below the normal level. The minimum temperature was recorded 4.9 degrees Celsius two degrees less than normal.

Over a dozen trains, including Gatimann Express and Shatabdi Express, ran behind schedule on Tuesday. According to the meteorological department, there is possibility of rainfall in the first week of January.

Title: Payment of gratuity is a matter of right: Gujarat HC
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: The Gujarat high court upholding the order of single judge ordering Upleta municipality in Rajkot district to pay gratuity amount to the petitioner who retired in 2012 when he was under suspension. A division bench led by Justice S R Brahmbhatt ruled that any curtailment in his gratuity has to be done on the basis of applicable law.

Arjan Vadhia joined as a store keeper and retired as a tax inspector in Upleta municipal. He had to fight an eight-year-long legal battle after his retirement on March 31, 2012 after he was placed under suspension during retirement and the municipality had withheld his gratuity amount of Rs 4.24 lakh citing municipality recruitment rules as well as conditions of service of employees rules-1989.

Arjan approached the controlling authority in Rajkot in October 2013 which ordered the municipality to pay the full amount with 10 percent interest. The municipality then approached the appellate authority challenging the order which reduced the amount of gratuity to Rs 2.97 lakh on the grounds that the petitioner was under suspension in the last few months of his service and that he was paid subsistence allowance.

Vadhiya challenged this order before the HC where single judge bench ordered in his favor and quashed the order of appellate authority. The municipality challenged the single judge before a division bench of high court.

Upholding the order, HC noted that “The payment of gratuity , as said by the Supreme court, is a matter of right and any curtailment thereof needs to be on the basis of applicable law.”

Petitioner’s advocate Mehul Mehta said, “The division bench also ruled that the subsistence allowance can’t be said as wage and rejected considering the allowance amount to calculate Arjan’s gratuity.”

Title: Delhi: Uniform fee for new power connections
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: Getting a power connection in the city’s non-electrified areas will be cheaper with Delhi Electricity Regulatory Commission (DERC) notifying uniform service line development charges throughout Delhi.

DERC has made the service line development (SLD) charges same in both non-electrified and electrified areas, a Delhi government release stated on Tuesday. The difference of SLD charges collected between September 1, 2017 and December 30, 2019 will be adjusted in the ensuing electricity bills, the release added.

According to a power department official, the charges for a new connection at the non-electrified areas was higher compared to the electrified areas. “Now it’s Rs 3,000 for up to a 5kW connection everywhere,” he said, adding that only a few areas in Delhi, especially in the outer areas, might be without power.

As per the government release, DERC has got two new members. They are Ashok Kumar Singhal, a former additional chief adviser cost, and head of Indian Cost Account Service in the Union finance ministry’s expenditure department, and Akhilesh Kumar Ambasht, a former Indian Forest Services officer. Both posts were vacant.

DERC is responsible for determining the tariff for electricity and regulation of the power sector in Delhi.

Title: Panel wants united fight against CAA
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

NFIW general secretary Annie Raja in the city on Tuesday

JAIPUR: The National Federation of India Women (NFIW) has urged all civil society groups to stand together against CAA and NRC protests.

Reacting on the split between Yogendra Yadav, who is leading 100 civil society groups, and the CPI affiliated bodies, NFIW general secretary Annie Raja said those who were against the draconian laws must stand united. “It’s time for all those individuals and groups who are taking a stand against the NRC and CAA to unitedly fight against the evil designs of the government. We should bury our differences and stand together,” said Raja in Jaipur on Tuesday. The bodies affiliated with the CPI has raised objections over Yadav’s statement for including some groups they consider as non-liberals.

The women activists had gathered in Jaipur for the 21st NIWF national meet ‘Asserting Constitutional Values Towards Gender Equality, Communal Harmony and Non-Violence.”

Raje termed the non-stop women protest at Shaheen Bagh in Delhi a watershed moment which will script a new movement in India.

“Hundreds of women braving chilly conditions are protesting 24/7 from the past 10-12 days against the CAA,” said Raja. Nisha Siddu of NIWF talked about the anti-women stand of the Modi government since 2014. “Our women have suffered the most during the demonetisation. It has rendered them without work or taken away all the limited opportunities they had. Even in the new education policy, the strict exam system will obstruct women from taking up higher education,” said Siddu.

Title: Trichy: Stone inscription of 17th century discovered
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

A 17th century stone inscription and a sculpture has been discovered near Trichy

TRICHY: A sculpture and stone inscription dating back to CE 17th century have been discovered near Trichy, shedding light on construction of a weir during the rule of a local feudatory.

P Loganathan, an enthusiast in history, spotted the inscription near a dried-up pond at Velur in the Kilthottiyappatti - Thennalur road near Viralimalai .
