Terming it a significant discovery, R Kalaikkovan, director, Dr M Rajamanikkanar Centre for Historical Research, Trichy, said that a sculpture for first time is found with a notification of the construction of a weir in Trichy district along with a sculpture depicting a male announcing the same.

The 16-line record is in Tamil script and gives the date as Tamil month Ani 22, 1698 CE. It registers the construction of the weir during the rule of the local feudatory Chinnakar Mada Srinayakkarayyan when Manisarayappillai of Thiruvanaikkavan was the head man of the village (Maniyam).

A pond with well-raised bunds has stone and stucco mixed walls of 2.40 metres height on its south embracing the weir with three projecting stones on each side to denote the water level. R Akila, assistant professor, department of history, Arignar Anna Government Arts College, Musiri, and M Nalini, head, department of history, Seethalakshimi Ramasamy College, Trichy, visited the site on receiving information and examined the inscription. “The granite sculpture that stands on the platform is inserted in such a way that the wall be in the centre with a caved edge to facilitate surplus water to flow through,” said Akila. M Nalini said that a land donation record of Muthukkar Mada Srinayakkarayyan, who is mentioned in the new find, was discovered some time back in Chettiurunippatti of Alundur

Title: 75-year-old man dies after voting
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

TIRUPUR: A 75-year-old man died of cardiac arrest outside the polling booth after casting his vote in the second phase of local body elections near Kundadam in the district on Monday.

The deceased was identified as C Dhandapani of Nochipalayam near Maruthur. Dhandapani, a farmer, went with his son Chellamuthu to cast their votes in Maruthur panchayat union primary school, a police officer said.

When they came out of the polling booth after voting , Dhandapani swooned down. Dhandapani did not respond when his son and other voters tried to wake him up by splashing water on his face.

A policeman who was on duty near the polling booth alerted ‘108’ ambulance. After examining, the ambulance crew confirmed that Dhandapani was dead. Police did not register any case as it was a natural death.

Title: Didn’t know I had talked to PM until he mentioned it in Mann Ki Baat: Parveen Fatima
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Parveen Fatima of Kargil in Ladakh is a supervisor-cumcoordinator in a private apparel manufacturing unit at N... Read More

TIRUPUR: Parveen Fatima of Kargil in Ladakh had no idea that she had spoken to Prime Minister Narendra Modi when she got a call on her mobile enquiring about her career progress after she was trained and placed in a job under Himayat, a scheme implemented by the Union rural development ministry.

Fatima, who works as a supervisor-cum-coordinator in a private apparel manufacturing unit at Nochipalayam in Tirupur, said she came to know it was the PM who called only when Modi mentioned the conversation in the Mann Ki Baat programme on All India Radio.

“I was in my native place when I received a call on my mobile phone. The person at the other end queried about my job and encouraged me to continue it. The call lasted only under a minute. Later, the authorities at the Kargil Himayat Center, where I took the training on apparel tailoring and basics, informed me that the PM was pleased with my progress,” the 24-year-old woman told TOI.

“I was overwhelmed and my family and relatives were very happy. Even the local press poured in and interviewed me.”

Fatima was among 90 women from Kargil - aged between 18 and 28 - who were placed in one of the apparel units of SCM Garments Private Limited under the Himayat scheme, an exclusive scheme for the then unified Jammu and Kashmir launched eight years ago.

The private company has allocated a section of tailoring machines exclusively for the Ladakhi women. The company has provided them accommodation, and brought a cook from Ladakh to prepare food for them in the hostel as the women had requested it. Even transportation is separate for the women, to travel between their hostel and the unit.

“Usually, our families are reluctant to allow women to go out of Ladakh. Even though the women completed the training for tailoring under the Himayat programme, our parents were hesitating to allow us to work outside Ladakh. They allowed us to come to Tirupur only after the Himayat Center authorities arranged a meeting and convinced them about our safety,” Fatima said.

In a short stint of six months, SCM Garments promoted Fatima as supervisor-cum-coordinator for the stitching section of those Ladakh women. “It feels great that I grabbed the skills quickly from trainers in the company, and I was selected to lead our women,” she added.

She had wanted to choose a career in fashion designing as she had grown watching traditional embroidery in Jammu and Kashmir. “When I revealed my dream, a well-wisher advised me to take training under the Himayat scheme to know about the basics of apparel making. Moreover, I wanted to travel to other places in the country and to get good exposure. So, I chose to work in Tirupur,” Fatima said.

Fatima has three siblings. Her father Sabeer Hussain, a daily wager, struggled to get work, especially during the winter season. “My income is the major source for running our family,” she said.

A manager of the apparel unit said, “The stitching section run by the Ladakh women is having almost 50% lesser efficiency in production than the section handled by local people. But our aim is to motivate them to compete with the skilled employees.”

M Arul Saravanan, chief marketing officer of SCM garments, told TOI, “We were the first company in Tirupur to recruit people trained under the Himayat scheme in Ladakh. We have been actively recruiting trained tailors under the Deen Dayal Upadhyaya Grameen Kaushalya Yojana (DDU-GKY) scheme, under which the Himayat comes, across the country. We plan to recruit 500 more trained people from Ladakh and J&K.”

Title: 12 days on, UP cops sit on court order, fail to take cancer patient to hospital
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Ahmad Nabi

AGRA: Even after 12 days, Firozabad jail administration has not been able to take stage-2 cancer patient Ahmad Nabi, who suffered multiple fractures in alleged police action during the December 20 anti-CAA stir violence, to district hospital due to lack of personnel for police escort.

On December 24, a special court judge had ordered the district administration to provide all possible medical assistance to Nabi who suffered multiple fractures during the alleged police action.

Firozabad jailor Lal Pratap Singh said, “We had written to Firozabad Police Line reserve inspector (RI) for personnel to escort Nabi, but he failed to provide any. Nabi had to undergo surgery for his fractures, though our jail medical staff had provided him temporary plaster. He is currently in medical ward of jail.”

Speaking with TOI, RI Ram Singh of Firozabad Police Line said, “On Wednesday, we will provide escort for Nabi.”

Meanwhile, a district hospital doctor said, “Nabi was supposed to be admitted here on Tuesday for a medical check-up before the operation for his fractures, which was scheduled for Wednesday, but police failed to bring him here. Earlier on Saturday, he was brought to the hospital but was not admitted by the cops.”

Dr R K Pandey, chief medical superintendent of district hospital, had told TOI, that “due to dispute between jail staff and police escort, Nabi was not admitted in hospital”.

Sources claimed that police were ordered to take Nabi to the out-patient department (OPD) but they were not briefed about his admission for surgery.

“The jail staff asked police escort to admit Nabi in the hospital, but they said no,” said Vakeel Nabi, younger brother of Ahmad Nabi who was present at the district hospital when Ahmad Nabi was being taken into the doctor’s chamber.

“My brother’s both legs are fractured and he has also suffered severe injury in his left arm during police action on December 20. Ahmad was returning home when he was picked by police and assaulted,” alleged Vakeel Nabi.

Ahmad Nabi runs a crockery store in Hajipura area of Rasoolpur police jurisdiction where violence had occurred on December 20.

Title: A colourful guest at city zoo this New Year
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: This New Year, the city zoo has got a slithery, colourful exhibit. Banded krait , a slow moving, long, venomous snake, which is not found in Kerala was brought to city zoo on Tuesday.

The snake was captured by Vava Suresh at Malayinkeezhu, which was later handed over to department of forests. On Tuesday the zoo authorities housed the krait in a special enclosure.

“The zoo had housed kraits before. It is a very beautiful snake and adults can attain length up to 59 inches. What we have here is an adult. As soon as we got the snake into the enclosure, it coiled inside the bamboo tree sweeping the dry leaves in the shape of a nest,” said S Abu, director, museum and zoo.

Banded krait is usually found in states like Bengal, Odisha, Assam and Arunachal Pradesh. Rescue of the snake in the district has puzzled authorities as it is not migratory by nature. The officials said that it may have been reared or been smuggled furtively. The zoo already has a rich display of reptiles like reticulated python , green anaconda and king cobra.

Banded krait has a high contrast yellow and black colour and it feeds on rats and smaller snakes.

Title: Chennai: It’s a struggle to reach metro from Central
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

The metro rail station has five entry/exit points with more than eight elevators linking the platform and stre... Read More

CHENNAI: Hundreds of people who get off trains at MGR Central railway station daily find it difficult to access metro trains as the station does not have signage to guide people to the subways leading to the underground Central metro station.

Though Central metro is the city’s largest intermodal hub linking long distance, suburban trains and buses, Southern Railway and Chennai metro rail are yet to arrive at a consensus on setting up signage on the railway premises though discussions have been on for six months.

The metro rail station has five entry/exit points with more than eight elevators linking the platform and street levels, escalators and staircases at all access points.

But since its inauguration, there have been complaints from commuters that they have been not able to find or reach the station from the surrounding areas, including MGR Central, as there are no signages to guide them. Those arriving in the city for the first time experience it more intensely as they are not even aware of the metro facility despite the entry points to the station built at walking distance from the railway station.

Though Southern Railway and CMRL signed an agreement to install signage on railway premises, differing views on board size, number of boards and logo display have stalled the move. Railways say metro rail didn’t consult it on the number of boards, location in the station and size of the boards before giving contract. A metro rail official said southern railway authorities are demanding advertising charges to install signage. “We put up a kiosk in central station paying railways 1,000 a day to direct passengers to the metro facility. But it did not work out, as central has many entry/exit points which passengers use,” the official said. A senior railway official said, “Metro rail wants to put up 4ftX2ft boards on all platforms only with their logo. The boards will be big and may hinder the view of passengers. The design and size of the boards were decided suo motu though they are to be installed on our premises. We are ready to offer 4-5 vantage points to install the boards or we can install the boards as per their specifications. Steps will be taken to resolve the issue soon.”

S Ranganathan, who recently reached MGR Central around 4.30am from Coimbatore, was fleeced by auto drivers, as he was not aware of metro timings. “I was told there is a metro station nearby to reach Shenoy Nagar. I had to ask the auto drivers for directions, as there were no signages or information boards anywhere near the MGR Central. I ended up paying 250 to reach my destination,” he said.

Title: Major roads in Vilankurichi in shambles, residents suffer
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Most of the interior roads in Vilankurichi, which is surrounded by residential areas like Cheranma Nagar, Gand... Read More

COIMBATORE: M Kaveri , who works as a domestic maid , dreads pedalling down the damaged Sree Vignesh Nagar Road at Vilankurichi . “I have seen many people fall down and injure themselves,” the 53-year-old woman told TOI.

Residents of Sree Vignesh Nagar say it has been a decade since the road was laid. “While the road has not been relaid even once, the corporation dug it up recently to lay drinking water pipelines,” said V Balasubramaniam, secretary of the Sri Vignesh Nagar Welfare Association.

“After that, it has become unmotorable,” said D Rajeshwari, a resident. “When it rains, I take every step cautiously, because I have seen children and women slip and fall while walking and while using two-wheelers.”

Most of the interior roads in Vilankurichi, which is surrounded by residential areas like Cheranma Nagar, Gandhima Nagar, Murugan Nagar and Sree Vignesh Nagar, are in urgent need of repair.

Gandhi Road, which connects Vilankurichi and Saravanampatti is also riddled with potholes. “I don’t even allow my children, aged three and six, ride tricycles on the road. Pits in front of our house is so deep that even two-wheelers get stuck in it,” said M Selvi.

A 40 feet wide road has narrowed down to 20 feet due to dense overgrowth extending from two vacant plots on to the road.

The residents wrote to the chief minister’s cell and the corporation commissioner, requesting them to relay the roads. They event got a traffic sub-inspector, former ward councilor and corporation engineers to inspect the area recently.

The ward assistant engineer said that the roads were not relaid as drinking water pipelines were yet to be laid and connected to the houses. “The situation is the same at the neighbouring areas, including Cheranma Nagar. We are laying the road at Kumudham Nagar as the pipeline work is over there. Once this area is handed back to us after the work, we will relay the road here also,” he said.

Title: Illegal bldgs in Agency under radar
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The district administration, led by sub-collector of Paderu Dr S Venkateswar has taken up a drive against illegal constructions encroaching upon the Agency area.

A total of 45 illegal constructions in Chintapalli have reportedly been demolished. The process of identifying other illegal structures is going on.

The drive has been taken upon in response to petitions from locals and tribal leaders. Tribal leaders have been complaining that people from the plains have been coming and settling down in Agency areas for business since the space became a tourist hotspot.

Speaking to TOI, tribal activist G Rama Gopal said, “This has been a problem for long. Many people from the plains have come and settled down in the Agency area and in the process have built a number of illegal structures.” According to Gopal, such structures exist in Araku, Paderu, Tajangi, Peddabayalu, Hukumpeta, Lotugeddajunction, Borra Junction and Chintapalli.

DK Balaji, project officer of ITDA, Paderu confirmed that the drive is on. He said that structures are being identified at the moment. “Many of these structures violate the 1of 70 Act which stipulates that transfer of land from tribals to non-tribals cannot happen without the prior permission of the state government.”

Balaji further said that tribal leaders have been complaining that many non-tribals are setting up shops here illegally owing to the burgeoning business opportunities. Sources in the revenue department said that all buildings that have come up in violation of Agency laws are being identified.

Title: 1 million download Kavalan app in Tamil Nadu
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: The number of Kavalan mobile app downloaded on to smartphones in Tamil Nadu has reached 1 million , say police, adding that they had made some changes and removed certain features that were thought to be intruding on the privacy of users.After the rape and murder of a veterinary doctor at Cyberabad near Hyderabad in late November, Tamil Nadu director general of police J K Tripathy called on people to install the Kavalan app to help police respond to SOS calls.According to police, at least 9.4 lakh android phone users in the state have downloaded the app, while about 60,000 iPhone users have installed it on their phones. As per the data provided by police, Chennai tops with about 1.60 lakh users of the app, followed by Coimbatore district, including the city, with 45,000, Kancheepuram with 40,000 and Tiruvallur 35,000.“After many complained to us about the safety of their personal profile and other issues, we made certain changes in the app,” said a senior police officer. The photo option in the profile column has been removed, while options in personal details like personal mail ID and official mail ID have been taken off, he said. In the date of birth column, the option to select the dates concerned has been replaced with that of keying in the details.On Tuesday, on the occasion of New Year’s eve, Chennai police commissioner A K Viswanathan launched a fresh campaign to encourage residents to install the app, releasing balloons with messages of the app into the sky at Gandhi statue on the Marina beach. The commissioner also cut a cake and distributed it to personnel on duty at the spot, a practice initiated by former commissioner Letika Saran and followed by her successors.The police also tied a Kavalan app band on the wrists of children visiting the beach with elders and parents for the New Year-eve celebrations. They have advised people, especially women, to press the panic button on the app immediately on seeing anyone trying to misbehave with women or create nuisance in public places and at hotels and clubs.The city police, who have vigorously campaigned at all places of public gathering for installing the app, including urging protesters gathered at Chepauk recently, have also suggested that men install the app on their phones to get police help instantly in an emergency.Such campaigning, apart from awareness programmes at many women colleges in the city, have helped swell the total number of subscribers of the app, a senior officer said.

Title: Anti-CAA protests: Five ex-AMU students to be booked under Goonda Act
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Agra: Two weeks after violence erupted in the Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) campus which left over 70 people injured, the Aligarh police has decided to book five former students, including two erstwhile students’ union office bearers, under the Uttar Pradesh Control of Goonda Act for allegedly instigating the mob.

Confirming the matter, SSP Akash Kulhary told TOI on Tuesday that they have identified the five ex-students through the CCTV footage of December 15, which was provided by the AMU authorities. He said all the five have a criminal history and “are a threat to peace” in the district.

“I have written a letter to the district magistrate CB Singh to take action against them under the Goonda Act, and they can be externed from the district for six months,” Kulhary said.

The former students have been identified as Huzaifa Amir, former secretary of the students’ union, Hamza Sufiyan, former vice president of the students union, Nadeem Ansari, Aamir, Mintoe, and Sarjil Usmani,

Among these, Hamza Sufiyan and Huzaifa Amir had been rusticated by the university administration for five years for creating ruckus at the vice chancellor’s office and for allegedly misbehaving with the varsity employees in July 2019.

So far, three FIRs have been filed against the protestors, including students of the AMU, in the December 15 violence that took place on the campus.

Two FIRs were filed by the district police, which arrested 26 identified protesters, including seven AMU students. They were booked along with other 1,200 to 1,300 unidentified people.

They were booked under IPC sections 307 (attempt to murder), 147 (rioting), 332 (voluntarily causing hurt to deter public servant from his duty), 336 (act endangering life or personal safety of others), 504 (intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of the peace), and 506 (criminal intimidation) and section 7 of the Criminal Law Amendment Act (CLA).

Another FIR was registered against 1,000 unidentified protesters under IPC sections 147 (riot), 153 (provocation with intent to cause riots), 332 (voluntarily causing hurt to deter public servant from his duty), 353 (assault or criminal force to deter public servant from discharge of his duty), 336, 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant) and section 3, 7 the Prevention Of Damage Of Public Property Act on the complaint filed by the Rapid Action Force.

Title: Coimbatore police get high rating for quick response to emergency calls
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: The state police master control room (SPMCR) in Chennai has given the Coimbatore city police a rating of 4.6 out of 5 for its quick response and action taken time after receiving emergency calls .

Patrol teams of the city police have reached spots within a maximum of 3-4 minutes from the time of receiving emergency calls from control rooms, police commissioner Sumit Sharan said.

Speaking to reporters in the city on Tuesday, Sumit Sharan said, “After receiving alert from the control room in Chennai, our cops would take a maximum of 3-4 minutes to reach the spot and it is a very good quick response time in the city. We are also planning to introduce 12 more patrolling vehicles for quick response.”

The state police master control room (SPMCR) has been functioning in Chennai. It receives calls from those who dial 100 from anywhere in the state.

From SPMCR, the call recordings would be forwarded to the respective control room of the police commissionerate or the district police office, who in turn would alert the patrol teams.

“After reaching the spot, the patrol team would contact the city police modern control room by walkie talkie and the quick response time would also be noted immediately,” Sumit Sharan said.

The city police have 44 two-wheeler patrolling teams and 24 four-wheeler patrolling teams.

“All the four-wheeler patrolling vehicles are fitted with GPS. We can monitor the vehicle movements from the city police modern control room. After receiving alert from the SPMCR, police personnel from the modern control room would locate the vehicle movements by GPS and will alert the nearby patrolling team,” he added.

To strengthen patrolling, police officers have sought six more two-wheelers and six more jeeps from their higher-ups.

“The SPMCR has given a rating to each police commissionerate or district police based on the quick response time and actions. The Coimbatore city police has been given 4.6 out of 5 last week,” Sumit Sharan said.

He said the city police have registered 6,46,737 cases for traffic violations and collected fine amount of Rs 13.44 crore since January 2019.

The fatal accident rate has also been reduced with 132 people losing their lives in 2019 when compared to 162 people in the previous year.

Title: City fails to make mark in swachh drive’s 2 quarters
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Jaipur: Jaipur city has ranked 25th in the first quarter and 31st in the second quarter in Swachh Sarvekshan League 2020, the results of which were declared on Tuesday.

At the state level, Jaipur stood first in the first quarter and second in the second quarter. According to Jaipur Municipal Corporation (JMC), the results show Jaipur scored 80% marks in all parameters.

Nodal officer of Swachhta Survekshan 2020 at JMC, Harshit Verma, said they were happy with the results and expect that this would have a positive impact on the final rankings.

“We have been working tirelessly on the city’s cleanliness and finally it is showing results. This year Swachhta Survekshan 2020 is divided into three quarters,” said Harshit. In first quarter, Jodhpur ranked 33rd and Kota stood 41st. In the second quarter, Jodhpur topped the list in the state while Jaipur bagged the second position. Kota was third.

First quarter was from April to June, second quarter July to September and third quarter was from October to December. The final results are expected to come in March 2020.

The Central team visited the cities of Rajasthan on different dates in the three quarters. Last week, JMC officials revealed that Swachhta Survekshan Team visited Jaipur secretly and inspected the sanitation condition. No one in the JMC got to know about their arrival. Officials said that the central team always arrive without informing anyone and even team members are informed a few hours before their arrival.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Auto driver arrested for kidnap, murder
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: A 32-year-old autorickshaw driver has been arrested for the kidnap of a woman and murder of a man in Tiruvallur . The driver kidnapped the woman when she boarded his vehicle on the night of December 26 and knocked down Yagesh, who tried to rescue the woman at Mappedu.

Police said the accused, Kesavan of Pinjivakkam near Kadambathur, was nabbed from a hideout at Surutapalli in Chittoor district of Andhra Pradesh on Monday. The woman had boarded the autorickshaw at Mappedu to reach Narasingapuram in Chembarambakkam. There were two men in the share autorickshaw and they turned out to be the driver’s friends. When the woman noticed the autorickshaw heading in a wrong direction, she cried out for help. Five men on the road side at Kondanjeri near Kadambathur heard her cries and chased the vehicle on four motorbikes. The woman jumped off the autorickshaw. While three of the men chasing the autorickshaw stopped to help the woman, Yagesh and Franklin continued to chase the vehicle. Yagesh overtook the vehicle and tried to stop it, when Kesavan, who was driving the autorickshaw, rammed the two-wheeler and sped away. Yagesh sustained injuries and, on December 29, died at Rajiv Gandhi Government Hospital.

Police said Kesavan knew the woman, who worked in a beauty parlour. Seeing her on the road on December 26, he planned to kidnap her with the help of two friends who got into the autorickshaw,” said a police officer. Police said Kesavan was trying to take her to his house when Yagesh and his friends heard the woman’s’ cries. “They are first-time offenders,” the police officer said. “They have been booked for culpable homicide not amounting to murder, kidnap and assault.” Kesavan was arrested and remanded in judicial custody. Police are searching for his two accomplices.

Title: Offices bear barren look on yr’s last day
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Jaipur: The usual buzz was missing at the secretariat on Tuesday as very few government employees could be seen at government offices. While most of the employees were on an extended holiday since Monday, availing their remaining casual leave or LTC, the public too stayed away due to chilling cold, amidst absence of chief minister and governor from the state capital.

The chief minister and governor were in Jaisalmer. While the CM was on a tour of the locust-affected areas of western Rajasthan, the governor is on a visit to Jaislamer. An officer on condition of anonymity said, except very urgent works, government is on a slow mode as a large section of employees are on leave. Since schools are closed for Christmas vacation, it is time for employees to avail LTC and go for a tour with their families to escape from the chilling cold in North India. TNN

Title: Chennai: Rowdy breaks hand while trying to escape police
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: Police have arrested two people, including a rowdy , for their role in the attack on an autorickshaw driver and stealing his vehicle at Surapattu near Ambattur .

The vehicle was reported stolen early on Monday. When police tried to nab the suspects, the rowdy tried to escape and broke a hand while scaling a wall in Ambattur.

Police said Murali, 35, of Kallikuppam near Ambattur, owns an autorickshaw. On Monday morning, he was headed towards Puzhal when two men intercepted his vehicle near Surapattu. They attacked and snatched Rs 2,000 from him. Later, they pushed him on the road and escaped with his vehicle.

When an injured Murali cried for help, some passersby rescued him and alerted police. Murali underwent treatment at Government Stanley Hospital and later lodged a complaint at the Ambattur police station.

Based on his complaint, Ambattur inspector Chidambara Murugesan tracked the suspects with the help of CCTV camera footage. Police identified the duo as anti-social Dinesh alias ‘Kudumi’ Dinesh, 32, and his aide Kumar, 29.

Based on a specific tip, a police team raided a hideout in Ambattur in the wee hours on Tuesday and nabbed Kumar. When Dinesh tried to escape sensing that police had cornered them, the team chased him. When he tried to climb a wall to escape, he fell and broke a hand.

Based on their confession, police recovered the stolen autorickshaw, which they had hidden under a tarpaulin sheet in the neighbourhood to be sold later.

The Ambattur police admitted Dinesh at Stanley hospital, where he underwent treatment before he was produced before a magistrate court in Ambattur. The magistrate ordered that the duo be remanded in Puzhal prison for 15 days.

Title: Muzaffarnagar admin receives 48 more claims seeking recovery of damages
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Muzaffarnagar: The Muzaffarnagar district administration on Tuesday received additional 48 claims for recovery of damages done to vehicles and property, including Rs 13,000 claim from the nagar palika for damage of roads, during the anti- Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) on December 20.

On December 28, the administration received 23 claims for recovery of damages during the protests.

The administration has now sought a list of ‘rioters’ so that notices can be issued to them to pay for these claims.

“All these claims have come from the public and government, including nagar palika of Muzaffarnagar. We have asked the police to provide a list of offenders so that notices can be sent to them,” additional district magistrate (ADM) Amit Singh said.

Executive officer of the Muzaffarnagar nagar palika, Vinay Kumar, said," Among the roads that were damaged during the violent protest include a divided on Kachchi Sadak. We have filed a case against them and approached the ADM court to claim Rs 13,000 as damages.”

Notably, police Incharges of Civil-lines police station and Nagar-Kotwali were asked to provide details of offenders who had vandalized the vehicles and other properties during the violence last week after Friday prayers.

So far, 43 cases have been registered and 73 people have been sent to jail in connection with the anti-CAA protests in the district.

Also, a special investigation team has started an investigation into the cases.

Title: Ring Road is among city’s high-density traffic areas
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Surat: About 170 to 200 passenger car units (PCU) per km per hour per lane density during peak morning and evening hours have made the Ring Road one of the high-density traffic areas of Surat. Built 40 years ago, this 6km long six-lane city’s main arterial road provides majority of commuters coming from the walled city an alternative route for speedy travel to Surat railway station.

However, growth of new residential areas in Athwa and beyond and rise in vehicular population from three lakh vehicles in 1980s to 31 lakhs by 2019 have led to maximum usage of the Ring Road.

Dr Shriniwas Arkatkar, associate professor in transport department of Sardar Vallabhbhai National Institute of Technology (SVNIT), told TOI, “There are three major problems with Ring Road. It witnesses different types of vehicular activities during different periods of the day. Symbolizing corridor centric development, people have no avenue to turn towards, which leads to heavy traffic density during specific time during the day.”

He said the Ring Road has become the most preferred route for people driving 10 lakh vehicles on daily basis. A team of professors from SVNIT has suggested a few solutions which include use of the road by distinct categories of people during different times.

Dr Arkatkar said, “Surat will have to make use of intelligent traffic management system. City must have Wi-Fi sensors across the space and should start levying congestion charges to deter people from using the road when not required. Most important thing is to find an alternative route.”

Ring Road users

About 10 lakh people use the Ring Road at least once a day. Among its users are four lakh textile traders living in Athwa, two lakh people engaged in different professions and another lakh who have to travel to railway station, GSRTC station and beyond for some casual work in other parts of the city. In Surat, of these 10 lakh people hardly 70,000 use public transport. Most like to travel in their own vehicles.

Title: Bone-chilling cold wavecontinues to sweep state
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Bhubaneswar: There was no respite from cold wave in the state for the third successive day on Monday.

Sonepur recorded the day’s lowest 5.4 degree Celsius, affecting normal lives, said an IMD source. In 15 more places in the state, the mercury dipped below 10 degree Celsius. The state capital recorded 10. 4 degree Celsius. Parts of Angul district also experienced severe cold.

The IMD’s latest forecast said there will be relief from the cold wave in near future. A fresh bulletin said minimum temperature in the state would witness a gradual rise by two to three degree Celsius in next two days. This will be primarily occur due to influence of western disturbances. There are chances of light to moderate rain in new year.

“Light to moderate rain or thundershower is very likely to occur in all over the state during three days in new year,” said director of IMD centre, Bhubaneswar, H R Biswas. On January 1, the forecast said, light to moderate rain or thundershower is very likely to occur at isolated places in seven districts — Nuapada, Bargarh, Jharsuguda, Sundargarh, Sambalpur, Deogarh and Keonjhar. The forecast said on January 2 and 3, rain may occur at many places in northern and coastal districts and in a few places in south.

After cold wave, the rain forecast may spoil new year plans of many people. The rain forecast has brought worry to farmers in the state as well as the crops are ready to harvest.

“We plan to postpone our picnic plan on new year day due to this rain forecast,” said Pratap Sahu, a college student of the city. A farmer on the outskirts of the city said he is very much worried due to the rain forecast. He said it is impossible to harvest the crops within a day or two. The recent light rain in some parts of the state also affected standing crops of some farmers in coastal pockets.

Title: In a first, Rajasthan government serves freehot milk to New Year revellers
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

A stall serving hot milk to people near Rajasthan University on Tuesday

JAIPUR: Not only medicines, the health department is distributing milk free in the state. On the eve of New Year, stalls were set up by health department officials across the state with glasses filled with hot milk.

It is for the first time that the health department has taken the initiative to set up stalls to offer free milk on New Year eve.

The orders were issued by the National Health Mission (NHM) mission director Naresh Kumar Thakral to all chief medical health officers on December 30. “Nav varsh ki karein shuruat—daru nahin doodh ke saath (begin new year not with liquor but with milk) was the slogan of the health department.

The programmes were organised with the help of donors and NGOs and at many places health department set up stalls on their own.

Health authorities looked busy arranging milk for the event. In Pali district, the health department failed to get support of donors due to paucity of time. Despite that, health officials managed to gather people at Suraj Pole where they took pledge to step into the New Year with milk and not with liquor.

However in Churu, health department provided milk at an event organised at Indramani Park. In Jodhpur , the event was organised on Old University campus in which hundreds of youths were served hot milk.

“The state government is taking measures to make the state addiction free. In this regard, the state government recently imposed a ban on the sale of e-cigarettes and hookah bars,” said health minister Raghu Sharma.

In Jaipur, the event was organised in front of Rajasthan University’s main gate and at Sawai Man Singh Hospital.

“We need support of the people to make the state addiction free, which is why, we asked people to step into new year with milk not liquor,” said Sharma.

Chief medical health officer (Jodhpur) Dr Balwant Manda said, “The milk stall we set up at Old University campus evoked good response. People in large numbers were served hot milk. We started at around 6.30pm and it continued till late night.”

Title: Two students arrested for peddling ganja in Chennai
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: Police have busted a ganja racket arresting six people , including two college students , in Chitlapakkam. Police seized about 3 kg of ganja from their house.

The arrested were identified as C Yashwant Raja, 25, of Kodambakkam, K Satish Kumar, 22, of Andaman Islands, G Srikanth, 22, of Maharashtra, V Arvind Krishna, 26, of Thoothukudi, V Vignesh, 22, of Puducherry, and C Gautham, 22, of Cuddalore. Police said Vignesh and Gautham are studying fourth year engineering in a college in the suburbs.

Police received a tip about the suspicious movement of youngsters, especially college students, at a house in Chitlapakkam and mounted surveillance in the area. They sent a decoy to buy ganja sachets from them and after the decoy confirmed they sold ganja, a police team swooped in on the house. They seized the contraband and nabbed the suspects. During interrogation, the accused said they received the narcotics from Andhra Pradesh. They said they used to wait near a toll plaza on Grand North Trunk Road on the outskirts from where they brought the drugs hiding them in laptop bags and sold them to customers. The arrested people were remanded in judicial custody after being produced before a magistrate court.

Title: NRC: Faked DOB now a big worry for Saudi returnees
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Many people from Hyderabad had migrated to Saudi Arabia in search of work by forging their age on documents. It was a popular trend in the 1980s-90s. But, those who have returned to India now could land themselves in trouble.

They might be in possession of documents reflecting different ages, different names and different dates of birth and may have to knock the doors of courts to get them corrected in the wake of the implementation of CAA, NRC and NPR hanging over their heads.

The required age to migrate to Saudi Arabia is 22 years. The problem is largely prevalent among the city’s minority community, many of whom are now approaching lawyers for a ‘honourable’ way-out. “Not just age, their worries are compounded by the mismatch in the dates of birth and their names,” a lawyer revealed.

Legal experts pointed out that it becomes difficult for those having too many contradictions in date of birth certificates. “If they fail to produce relevant documents, they could be in for a long haul to get the certificates rectified. Approaching courts can be a tedious process,” a legal expert said.

The then Vajpayee government had allowed people from India to migrate to Saudi Arabia if they are going there in search of work. Many youngsters, who were not 22 but were desperate to land a job for themselves, managed to procure passports with help of agents and by mentioning their age as 22.

“Those days, enforcement of rules was not that strict. Taking advantage of this, agents would manufacture fake certificates, submit them at the passport office and get their clients passports,” MA Shakeel, an advocate, explained.

Another problem the Gulf-returnees could face is change in their wives’ names. “At the time of marriage, the bride name could have been entered differently in the passport, while the name in her school certificate could be something else. This lacuna will create problems for them,” another said.

Title: Book EDM fest organisers for murder: Congress
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: Congress on Tuesday demanded that an FIR be registered against the organisers of EDM festival Sunburn Klassique for the “murder of three men at the event”.

In a letter submitted to the inspector general of police Japsal Singh on Tuesday, Congress said the FIR will send a positive signal to all.

"A delay in investigation may give the culprits time to conceal and suppress crucial evidence. The law must be allowed to take the right course," the party stated.

The party has blamed the government's lethargy for the deaths of these youth, and demanded that EDM festivals be banned in the state on the grounds of the death of the tourists. "Such incidents ruin Goa’s image before the world, and ultimately deter quality tourists from visiting our state. All such things will lead our tourism industry towards doom ," said state general secretary of NSUI and youth congress, Janardhan Bhandari, and youth president Varad Mardolkar, in their letter.

They also said the festival should be banned on the grounds that organisers don't follow the rules and regulations that govern such events— like beginning construction and erection work before final permissions are granted, and for inconveniencing local people by causing traffic congestion on the Calangute- Assagao-Anjuna-Baga Siolim stretch.

The EDM events held during the festive season where there is already a heavy inflow of domestic and foreign tourists, creates major traffic snarls along the narrow village roads.

Title: Pawan Kalyan: Farmers wouldn’t have given land had Jagan opposed Amaravati earlier
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Jana Sena chief Pawan Kalyan at a protest at Krishnayapalem in Guntur district on Tuesday

VIJAYAWADA: Protests in capital region entered the 14th day on Tuesday with Jana Sena chief Pawan Kalyan touring the villages and extending his support to agitating farmers. Tensions prevailed at Krishnayapalem after cops stopped him from going towards Mandadam. Defying police restrictions Kalyan moved past wire fences and walked through fields to reach Mandadam as Jana Sena workers along with farmers pushed through the police security ring.

Earlier, Kalyan kicked off his tour at Yerrabalem where he met women on relay hunger strike. Speaking at the protest venue, he took on the state government over the three capital proposal. He accused the chief minister of going back on his words after accepting Amaravati as capital when he was in opposition.

He also took on the ministers for mocking the farmers as ‘paid artists’ and terming Amaravati a desert. He said had Jaganmohan Reddy opposed the proposal of making Amaravati the capital, farmers would not have given their lands.

He urged the farmers not to stop their fight for Amaravati and assured them of support. The Jana Sena chief also said he would take up the issue with the Union government.

He criticised the police for trying to obstruct his tour. He said police bosses who have given orders to their subordinates must remember that political parties are not permanent but the govenrment and people are, and they should abide by the rules.

Meanwhile, dharnas, hunger strikes and rasta rokos continued in other parts of Amaravati. Former irrigation minister and TDP functionary Devineni Umamaheswara Rao sat on a day-long hunger strike in support of the farmers. TDP chief N Chandrababu Naidu has given a call to party workers to stay away from New Year celebrations in support of the protests. Naidu announced that he would visit the capital region on January 1 to spend the day with agitating farmers.

Title: Introspection must for intersections
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Surat: Huge and ill-conceived traffic islands on city roads are one of the factors behind traffic congestion. Surat whose estimated population is around 50 lakhs, boasts of 4,000km road network with 31 lakh vehicles jostling for space. Officials of transport department of Sardar Vallabhbhai National Institute of Technology (SVNIT), who are conducting a survey of more than 70 intersections to identify traffic issues, have identified Sahara Darwaja, Hira Baug, Athwagate and Anuvrat Dwar among 11 top junctions with traffic density of around one lakh PCUs per day.

“We have places where there is a blind approach at intersection like the one at Anuvrat Dwar. Six roads cross each other here and minor accidents are a daily occurrence,” said Rajesh Patel, a resident of Vesu.

Dr Gaurang Joshi, a member of faculty of transport department, SVNIT, said, “The purpose of an intersection is that it is a transfer point for one to move to another road. The approach should be easily accessible to any vehicle rider. It should not be more than 10 per cent of passenger car unit (PCU) density of approaching roads.”

“In Surat city, majority of intersections have been built without any futuristic angle. Now an exercise is being carried out with future population projections keeping geometric, traffic and architectural designs in mind,” said Rajesh Pandya, deputy commissioner, Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC).

“We have an urgent need to convert uncontrolled intersections into signalized intersections. We are making required arrangements for this in our project. We will also have to get real-time traffic management system data and use it regularly to exercise control over our intersections,” said Dr Shriniwas Arkatkar, associate professor, SVNIT.

Title: Age of ‘child’ should be increased from 16 to 18 yrs: Child rights body
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Panaji: The Commission for Protection of Child Rights has proposed that the age of a child, under the Goa Children’s Act 2003, which is up to 16 years, be raised to 18 to bring it on par with the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (Pocso) Act and other acts.

The commission’s chairperson, Sushma Chodankar, has stated that this will help fast-track cases where children are victims.

“Cases where the victim is up to 16 years go to the Goa children’s court while those in the age group of 16-18 years are sent to the sessions courts designated at POCSO courts. This sometimes creates confusion and delays in cases,” Chodankar said.

In its final draft amendment of the Goa Children’s Act 2003, submitted to the government on Thursday, the commission also highlighted a host of other changes. These include the need for a second children’s court in South Goa to handle the large number of cases and bring speedy justice to victims as well as save them the inconvenience from travelling from one end of the state to the other.

Instead of the secretary of the department of women and child, the commission has proposed that, depending on the type of offence, secretaries of the respective departments — education, health, labour and others — be held accountable under the act.

The commission also wants all private lodging and boarding homes and orphanages to be mandatorily registered with the directorate of women and child development, while childcare institutions specifically for children in need of care and protection be required to register themselves, under the Juvenile Justice Act, with the directorate.

Much confusion arose recently about private boarding homes housing children on the request of their parents, registering themselves, and ultimately, the court had to intervene.

After going through the suggestions, comments and rationale from various stakeholders, the commission observed that it is important to mainly focus on the implementation of the act, rather than just carrying out the amendment, as despite the act coming into force in 2003, and rules in 2004, it hasn’t been fully implemented yet.

“At present there are several central acts which cover the issues of children and they should be considered while carrying out amendments to the Goa Children’s Act 2003 & Rules, 2004 as the central act prevails over state legislations,”said Chodankar said.

Title: People make a dash for Aadhaar, PO can’t handle
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Citizens queue up at Trimulgherry head post office to enrol for new Aadhar cards on Tuesday

SECUNDERABAD: With people rushing to get their documentation in order, in light of the controversy surrounding Citizenship Amendment Act, tempers flared at Trimulgherry head post office in Lal Bazaar on Tuesday. About 50 people were seen waiting in a queue to enrol themselves for new Aadhaar cards. Some had been waiting from 6.30am. With staff at the post office giving out only 20 tokens, many of them became furious after being denied the chance to submit their application.

“People were waiting in line for hours. When they were told to come back later, many got desperate,” said Robin Zaccheus, an activist who witnessed the scene. Tweeting about it, he said, “Look at the pain people are going through standing in rain.”

“They wrote my name on a piece of paper around 6.30am. When I returned at 10am, the chit with my name was missing,” said one woman, not wanting to be named. She said that she would return another day to complete the process.

A notice near the post office states that timings for weekdays are from 9am to 3pm for non-financial issues.

However, people said there was no point of the timings being set considering that they had placed an arbitrary token system. “I was standing in line since 8am, but could not get a token. The chits were over before time,” said Sneha Lahmu , a resident of Yapral.

Post office officials simply said they were short-staffed. Replying, from their official handle @IndiaPostOffice asked for the name of the post office name and pincode to address the issue.

Title: Chennai: CBI registers 6 cases of fraud against ex-official of PNB
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: Central Bureau of Investigation ( CBI ), Chennai, has registered six cases against Shane Sylvester Rozario, a former assistant general manager of Punjab National Bank ’s Mylapore branch, for causing a loss of around Rs 45 crore to the bank as loans given to various companies were allegedly diverted for other purposes causing losses. The FIRs were filed on December 27, 2019.

In the first case, M Vishwanathan, proprietor of GR Projects in Chromepet, and Rozario allegedly cheated PNB by causing a loss of Rs 10.12 crore as the loan of Rs 10 crore was classified as non-performing asset (NPA) and a fraud account in April 2019. Bank officials, in their complaint, said the borrower diverted the funds for other purposes.

In the second case, Lalitha Rani, proprietor of M/s Sathvika in Kodambakkam and Rozario allegedly cheated PNB of Rs 9.37 crore by similarly diverting loans received, for other purposes.

Her account was classified as fraud account in May 2019.

In the third case, Fancy Nachimuthu Durai, proprietor of M/s Cliff India Corporation in T Nagar and Rozario allegedly cheated PNB by causing a loss of Rs 11.09 crore by diverting funds obtained through loans from the bank for other purposes.

In another case, Moonmars Housing Pvt Ltd in Chennai and Rozario allegedly cheated PNB by causing a loss of Rs 5.82 crore diverting funds obtained through loan from the bank.

In the fifth case, VKN Lakshmi Agro Foods Pvt Ltd and Rozario caused a loss of Rs 10.65 crore to the bank by diversion of funds obtained through loans for a different purpose.

In the sixth case, M Najmudeen, proprietor of Akino Electronics in Chennai, and Rozario caused a loss of Rs 8.95 crore by siphoning off funds given by the bank for business purposes. His account was labelled a fraud account in April and declared a NPA.

Title: Teachers’ exam: Girls stay put on water tank, government refuses to budge
Content:
Rajasthan University (File photo)

TimesView At a time when the country is reeling under unemployment and the youth searching for jobs, the demand by a section of candidates to postpone the RPSC exam for teachers is not just a betrayal of lakhs of other candidates who are preparing for the same but downright arbitrary. Many come from economically weaker sections and will suffer financially from the disruption of exams. Politicians who have come in support of protesting candidates too should have thought about the future of those who are preparing for the test. If the exams are postponed, it will result in financial loss to the government which has completed preparations. Any change in the schedule will disrupt RPSC’s calendar of exams and the government should resist all pressure and desist from any such move.

JAIPUR: Two girl students, who had climbed up an overhead water tank near the Aravali hostel on Rajasthan University campus on Monday demanding postponement of first grade teachers’ exam, have refused to come down despite efforts by the administration. The issue has been going on for the last one month. Exam is scheduled for January 3, 2020, and government has made it clear that it will be held on time.Both the girls spent the coldest night of the winter on the water tank in an attempt to force the government accept their demand.Mahendra Meena, a candidate who is supporting the agitation, said the government was not looking at the plight of aspirants. “In October, the RPSC declared that the exam will be held in the summer of 2020, but after a week, forms were published and on November 4, 2019, date of the exam was announced,” said Mahendra.CM Ashok Gehlot announced that for protesting candidates, another exam for the first grade will be conducted in September 2020 for 3,000 posts. Education minister Govind Singh Dotasra said there was teachers’ shortage which makes recruitments a must.

Title: Surat slips from two to 18 in cleanliness survey
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Touted to be one of the cleanest cities of Gujarat, Surat had secured a second all-India rank in the survey fo... Read More

SURAT: The world’s fastest growing city has slipped 18 places in the the latest Swachhata Sarvekshan results of which were announced by the union ministry for housing and urban affairs for the first and second quarter of the current financial year on Tuesday.

Touted to be one of the cleanest cities of Gujarat , Surat had secured a second all-India rank in the survey for the previous quarter.

Banchhanidhi Pani, municipal commissioner, however said that the first two quarters carried only 22% weightage of the total marks. “In the first quarter, we had excellent citizens feedback which was not so good in the next quarter. A team of IPSOS agency will visit the city in the second week of January for inspection, when we expect that the ranking will improve.”

Dr Ashish Naik, deputy commissioner of health added, ““In the third quarter, the official team will make personal visit to the city and take citizen feedback for validation. We expect to reach the top again like the first quarter in the next survey.”

Meanwhile, three cities- Rajkot, Vadodara and Ahmedabad - have been ranked in the top 10 cities in the survey. Rajkot has surprised many by bagging the second position while Ahmedabad was ranked sixth.

Ahmedabad improved its position by one notch as compared to first quarter. However, Vadodara which was not in the top 20 list of the cities with over 10 lakh population suddenly jumped to the fourth position overtaking Ahmedabad and Surat city which was ranked third in first quarter fell to the 20th position.

Porbandar town, which was so far included in the list of cities does not find place in the top 20 with over one lakh population.

Title: Meat sellers stop sale for a while, customers inconvenienced
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Kolhapur: Meat shop operators stopped selling mutton for a brief while on December 31 morning.

The operators were upset as several Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) and Food and Drugs Administration (FDA) officials came to their shops and asked them to get the animal slaughtered at the KMC’s slaughterhouse in Bapat Camp.

The shop operators claimed that they were made to wait for hours to get their animals — sheep and goat — slaughtered. Therefore, they decided to slaughter the animals at the back of their own shops. However, according to rules, it is mandatory to get the animals’ health checked by a KMC veterinary officer and animals must be slaughtered only at the KMC’s slaughterhouse.

The meat operators kept the shops closed for some times and this caused immense inconvenience to citizens looking to buy mutton.

Local citizens said the KMC and FDA should not impose strict rules on any day of celebration. They said since the demand for meat goes up on such days, the restrictions should be eased so that everyone gets to buy mutton.

Vijay Patil, the chief veterinary officer of KMC, said, “Around 280 goats and sheep were cut since morning at our slaughterhouse. We have appealed to the citizens to get the meat only from animals certified by us. The meat operators oppose this rule, but we have to follow it. Over the past few days, the slaughterhouse has remained open. Upon FDA action, the meat shop operators got their animals verified. Though there is a demand to ease the restrictions, we cannot compromise on citizens’ health.”

Mutton-lovers in the city also complained that due to the increase in demand, the mutton shop operators were selling mutton at higher prices. They claimed that mutton was sold in the city for Rs 560 (or more) per kg. The district administration-appointed panel of 25 members had fixed the mutton price at Rs 480 per kg. The meat shop operators’ association claimed that none of its member had sold the mutton above the fixed price.

Title: TRS regime’s double standard exposed: JAC
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Hyderabad: Soon after the high court gave the go-ahead for the Million March, activists opposing CAA, NRC and NPR have accused TRS government of applying double standard while giving permission to rallies.

Women activists of a JAC said the government gave permission to BJP and AIMIM to conduct pro- and anti-CAA rallies but is not willing to extend the same gesture to them. “It clearly exposes the government’s intentions. BJP and MIM are allowed to hold rallies. We fail to understand why permission is denied to us to organise an anti-CAA rally,” an activist said.

The JAC wanted to hold a protest meet at Tank Bund but the government is yet to give permission. TNN

Title: In 2019, Goa Police bag larger drug hauls, more arrests than 2018
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: Goa police have arrested more persons and seized more drugs in 2019, when compared to the previous year.In 2019, Goa police seized 5kg more drugs than last year, and arrested 239 persons as against 237 last year. The total value of the drugs seized in 2019 is over Rs 5.9 crore, including Goa’s largest-ever drug haul—the Rs 3 crore seizure of an assortment of narcotics from a Nigerian national effected by police in October. In comparison, the total value of drugs seized in 2018 was around Rs 2.96 crore.Speaking to TOI, superintendent of police for Goa’s anti-narcotic cell (ANC) Shobit Saxena said that their focus was to book big cases with the intention to break the backbone of the drug supply to Goa. “Almost all cases booked this year involved commercial quantities,” he said.So far this year, Goa police have booked 239 drug cases across the state, out of which 27 cases were booked by the ANC, 15 cases by the crime branch, two cases by Konkan Railway police, 90 cases by North Goa police and 82 cases by South Goa police.Police statistics showed that out of the 239 people arrested, 73 were Goans, 107 non-Goans and 59 foreigners.Police said that they have arrested 16 Russians, two Kenyans, one Italian, 36 Nigerians, one Nepali, one Austrian, one each of Portuguese and Ghanese nationality.The different types of drugs seized were ecstasy, MDMA, charas, LSD stamos marijuana, cocaine , ephedrine, methamphetamine, heroin, ecstasy powder, cannabis plants and amphetamine.Synthetic drugs are mostly imported by foreigners and used during parties. “Synthetic drugs are sold in Goa during the peak tourist season, when large numbers of foreigners visit,” a senior police officer said.After analysing the data, the ANC found that most of the foreigners arrested in narcotics cases arrived in Goa through the international airport at Dabolim, he added.During the investigation of narcotics cases, police interrogate the persons arrested to find out the names of dealers, distributers, suppliers and manufacturers of drugs. “All accused involved in these cases are arrested under appropriate sections of the NDPS Act, and thoroughly interrogated,” he added.

Title: Ex-cop held for bribe demand
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: A 52-year-old former constable was arrested for allegedly threatening shopkeepers to pay him bribe , at Kodungaiyur on Monday. The former policeman was identified as A Selvarajan of Kodungaiyur.

A tea shop employee alerted police after Selvarajan posed as a policeman and threatened him to part with Rs 500 at the shop on Thathamuthaiyappan Street in Mannadi. Investigation revealed that Selvarajan was recruited for the Armed Reserve unit in 1986 and posted at Crime Records until 1994. Selvarajan went on leave in 1994 and didn’t report back for work. “He’s jobless and into realty business as a broker,” said a police officer.

Selvarajan incurred huge losses in the business, allegedly forcing him seek bribes posing as a policeman, said the officer. Police said that once a policeman doesn’t report for work after a certain period of time, he will be dismissed and all allowances will be cut.

Title: Nearly 500 caught drunk in Valsad
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

The arrested persons in Pardi police station on Tuesday

SURAT: Police in Valsad arrested around 500 persons under prohibition charges in different police stations of the district on Tuesday.

They were caught during police checking on the road, mainly in Pardi and Vapi police stations areas, which are the entry points to state from the Union Territory of Daman.

Valsad police stepped up checking on roads and highways since Tuesday morning and by 9pm around 500 persons were already arrested in different police stations.

In Pardi police station around 150 persons were either caught drunk or in possession of liquor, while in Vapi town and Vapi GIDC police station around 60 were caught in each of the police stations.

Talking to TOI, Valsad superintendent of police, Sunil Joshi, said, “We are checking on roads to enforce prohibition laws and to prevent accidents. Police are getting medical examinations done on the arrested people. Strict checking will continue for a couple of days.”

Police did random checking of persons on two- and four-wheelers. Cops used breath analyzer or even physical inspection and whoever was found drunk was sent for medical examination. They were later arrested. By evening majority of the lockups in police stations of Valsad district were chock-a-block with prohibition case accused. Police had to accommodate the accused in the lobby and other sections of the police stations. They also had a tough time in keeping watch on those who were not inside the lockups.

Title: Cops deployed in full force to ensure safe NY revelry: IGP
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Panaji: Goa police on Tuesday deployed Anti-Terrorist Squad (ATS) on strategic locations to respond quickly to possible contigencies, in view of the New Year celebrations across the state. Lakhs of tourists visit Goa during the last few days of December, to ring in the new year.

Inspector general of police (IGP) Jaspal Singh directed the district superintendents of police (SPs) to ensure that all security and law and order arrangements are made. Singh directed the SP-traffic to ensure that there is no obstructive parking on arterial roads causing traffic bottlenecks.

The IGP further directed SP-special branch to deploy teams for collecting and transmitting information, in the face of any law and order situation that may occur during the revelry. Singh has instructed all deputy superintendents of police (DySP), police inspectors and traffic inspectors to be constantly available on their mobile phones.

“No official mobile numbers should be diverted to personnel phones,” Singh warned. He instructed the deputy inspector generals of police (DIGs) and SPs to visit different areas and inspect the availability and the alertness of the deployed personnel .

The IGP said that in case of any contingencies, police should respond immediately, and control room staff must remain alert.

In order to ensure smooth movement of traffic and accident-free celebrations, elaborate traffic arrangements have been made by the traffic police at all the major towns of Goa, especially along the coastal belt, police said

Title: MSME tech centre to be set up at Sulur
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Coimbatore: The district administration has identified about 20 acres at Sulur here to set up the micro, small and medium enterprises (MSMEs) technology centre in the district. The centre is expected to help the entrepreneurs in and around the district to help improve their standards to meet international competition.

The union ministry of MSME had sanctioned Rs 200 crore to set up the centre in the district under the scheme ‘establishment of new technology centres’.

“The selected land is fulfilling the specifications, including a non-residential area and with adequate transportation facilities, that are required to set up the centre. A team of MSME officials from New Delhi is expected to inspect the land within a week or two. Once they approve the site, the project would move to the next stage, which is floating tenders to construct the centre,” said R Vijayakumar, assistant director in-charge of MSME Development Institute, Coimbatore.

Vijayakumar said they have been planning to procure latest equipment in all sections including textile and automobiles after holding talks with the representatives of each association.

Pointing out that several MSMEs could not afford to purchase high-cost equipment, Vijayakumar said such equipment would be procured and made available for the industries to use. This will help entrepreneurs to meet international competition and infuse confidence to budding MSMEs.

Besides aiding about 50,000 MSMEs in the district, the centre would be useful for MSMEs functioning in nearby districts too. We are also planning to train students, and the district being an educational hub, it would be useful to a lot of students, he said.

A similar centre was sanctioned in Kochi about one-and-half years before and construction is underway. Last year, Chennai was sanctioned such a centre.

Title: Madras HC orders notice to state on gifts to government employees
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: The Madras high court has ordered notice to the state government on a PIL seeking direction to initiate stringent measures to curtail the illegal practice of receiving and giving gifts by government employees .

Admitting the plea moved by A Sampath, a retired state government employee, a vacation bench of Justice S Vaidyanathan and Justice P T Asha directed the authorities to respond to the plea in two weeks.

According to the petitioner, the state government had to strictly comply with Rule 3 of Tamil Nadu Government Service and Conduct Rules, which relate to avoidance of gifts and rewards in expectation of favour or anything in return.

Referring to a HC division bench order, the petitioner submitted that the DGP issued a circular dated July 12 to ensure strict implementation of the rule in compliance with the court order.

However, despite such a circular, gifts have been illegally accepted by the government employees, particularly during festival seasons, he said.

Therefore, the petitioner said, he made a representation to the authorities on October 3 requesting them to issue circulars to all the departments and to take appropriate action against those who indulge in such activities.

The authorities replied to the communication stating that the rule has been strictly implemented and that there is no need for issuing a separate government order for the same, he said.

Title: Telangana: Students of top varsities launch anti-CAA crusade
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Students of Maulana Azad National Urdu University (Manuu), English and Foreign Languages University (Eflu), Tata Institute of Social Sciences (TISS) along with various other organisations launched the Hyderabad chapter of ‘Young India against CAA-NRC-NPR’ campaign on Tuesday.

As part of the campaign, students will stage a protest against Citizens Amendment Act ( CAA ) in front of Arts College, Osmania University on Wednesday.

“There will be a huge public gathering at the Arts College on Wednesday. We will be reading out preamble of the Constitution and will take a pledge to not show submit documents to prove our citizenship,” said Faizan Sarwar, national joint secretary of All India Students Association.

Students said that as there is no opposition against the BJP-led government at the Centre, the onus is on them to force the government to revoke its decision to implement the National Population Register ( NPR ), National Register of Citizens ( NRC ), and CAA.

"We will be dedicating the first day of the New Year to defending our constitution,” said Bhagyashri from TISS, adding that students of over 100 varsities across the country will take a pledge against CAA, NRC and NPR.

Members of about 20 organization, which came together to form the Hyderabad chapter of Young India against CAA-NRC-NPR, said that they will also take part in the protest by Young India on January 8 and will ensure that all varsities are closed on that day in solidarity to protests against CAA.

They have gave an ultimatum to the central government to shelve their plans of implementing NPR, NRC, and CAA by January 26, 2020.

Title: Reverse tendering, reverse decisions marked state’s political script in 2019
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Vijayawada: 2019 has proved to be a year of reverse tenders for the government in engineering works. It also proved to be the year of reversing the decisions of the previous government that is causing tremors in the state.

While the government claims that it had saved close to Rs 2,000 crore in reverse tendering in 15 works, including the prestigious Polavaram Project, the reverse decision on the capital has turned politics in the state too hot in this year-ending winter season.

The government started the reverse tendering process alleging that the previous TDP government indulged in huge corruption in irrigation projects and other contracts. It started with the Polavaram Project where the government claimed to have saved Rs 782.80 crore in head works and power plant work of the project.

Starting from the irrigation projects, the government went for reverse tendering in every work starting from housing for the poor and weaker sections in the state to the purchase of stationery in government offices.

The YSRC government claimed that it had saved Rs 65.47 crore in purchase of computers and printers. Even in the purchase of mobiles for the secretariat staff and the mobile SIM cards for the village secretariat staff, the government had saved Rs 33.77 crore and Rs 83.80 crore respectively.

While there is a sort of positive feeling among people on saving money from the contracts, there is some disturbance and discontentment on the move to have three capitals for the state, which is seen as a reverse of the previous government’s decision.

Farmers in Amaravati are holding protests and the political parties are taking advantage of the situation. However, people in Rayalaseema are celebrating the government’s plan to locate the high court in Kurnool and those in Uttarandhra are celebrating the proposal for an executive capital.

The year thus ends with a note of protest in Amaravati and celebrations in the rest of the state.

Title: 15-day-old infant sustains severe burns in Alwar hospital
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Police and the child’s relatives at the hospital in Alwar on Tuesday

ALWAR/JAIPUR: A 15-day-old baby girl suffered serious burns on her face after a paediatric ward in a hospital caught fire because of a short circuit.

The girl was in an incubator and following the short circuit there was leakage in the oxygen supply pipe connected to the mask which was on her mouth due to which her face suffered 80% burns. A committee has been formed to look into the negligence on the part of the hospital.

The infant was admitted to Geetanand Children Hospital in Alwar a ago back and was said to be recovering when the incident happened on Tuesday morning. She was referred to Jaipur for further treatment. She is currently battling for life.

Her father Rahul Gaur told TOI, “We got my daughter admitted a week back as she was suffering from breathing problems. However, after treatment she recovering and we saw her on Monday at 10pm when she was absolutely fine. Around 5am on Tuesday, we got a call from the hospital asking us to rush there as there had been some kind of emergency. This is sheer negligence on the part of the hospital staff who slept off during the night when they should have been taking care of my baby. They would not let us enter the ward and were responsible for taking care of all the children admitted there but they failed in their duty.”

Apart from the infant, there were 14 other children in the ward at the time of the incident though they all were rescued on time.

Meanwhile, the hospital officials claimed that they were taking necessary measures to ensure that such accidents don’t happen in future. Hospital’s chief medical health officer Sunil Chauhan said, “The child’s face was burnt and she will need plastic surgery. We have called electricians to inspect the ward and make the necessary changes so that this kind of incident is not repeated in future.”

A team of state’s health department also reached Alwar and will conduct an inquiry into the matter, the report for which is to be submitted in 24 hours.

Title: Rajasthan: Two juveniles detained for killing 11-year-old boy
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

File picture of police carrying out investigation in the matter

JAIPUR: Police detained two juveniles for the murder of an 11-year-old boy whose body was found buried at Lohagarh Stadium in Bharatpur on December 28, three days after he went missing.

According to police, the two accused played at the same stadium with the victim and killed him with the intention to demand Rs 2 lakh ransom from the parents.

The deceased, identified as Prayanshu Jatav, was reported missing on December 25 when he did not come back after playing at the stadium.

Police teams started a search and finally his body was found.

He was strangulated and buried near a toilet inside the stadium. The child’s family claimed that Prayanshu would go to the stadium daily to play.

On December 25, when he did not come back, his family started looking for him. When they could not find him, they lodged a missing person complaint.

Bharatpur SP Haider Ali Zaidi said, “Two minor boys, who also played at the stadium, were the ones who murdered him. They strangulated him and buried his body at the stadium itself. We questioned the other children who were also present at the stadium on the day of the incident. A few of them told us that they had left for home before Prayanshu, who stayed back with the accused minors. We started looking at their activities closely from the recovered CCTV footage and detained them. They confessed to killing the boy with the intention to take Rs 2 lakh ransom from his parents.”

The victim’s cricket bat and ball were also recovered from the accused and police are investigating the case.

Last month, the body of 10-year-old Luv Jaiswal was found in Dholpur couple of days after his abduction. Few hours after the body was found near a hospital, the police detained the boy’s former tuition teacher. Police claimed that the accused called the child’s parents for a ransom of Rs 3 crore, but murdered him before that.

Title: Mayor, civic chief shun pvt vehicles, travel by KMT buses
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Kolhapur: Observing ‘ no vehicle day ,’ mayor Surmanjiri Latkar travelled to the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) building in a Kolhapur Municipal Transport (KMT) bus on Tuesday while civic chief Mallinath Kalshetti rode a bicycle from his residence to office.

Besides Latkar and Kalshetti, several corporators shunned their private and officials vehicles and opted for public transport. Some officials who reside close to their offices chose to walk.

Latkar, along with some local corporators, boarded a KMT bus to Shivaji Chowk in the morning. She was greeted by passengers who lauded her initiative. After alighting from the bus, Latkar walked to the municipal corporation building where the mayor’s office is located.

Among others who travelled by bus were standing committee chairman Sharangdhar Deshmukh and transport committee chairman Abhijit Chavan. They boarded a bus from Saneguruji Vasahat to Shivaji Chowk.

“We have unanimously decided to observe ‘no-vehicle day’ on the last day of every month. This was our first no-vehicle day. On this day, we will avoid using our official and private vehicles. I, along with some of the corporators, travelled in a bus. With so much traffic and pollution, it is important for everyone to undertake and support such initiatives. Our initiative serves both the purposes — reduces private vehicles on roads and reduces air pollution. We had appealed to the citizens to take part in this initiative. Respecting our appeal, many citizens shunned their private vehicles and travelled either by the buses or rickshaws,” said Latkar.

With more people using public transport such as KMT buses, they have contributed their bit to the revenue generation of the ailing public transport.
