It took around 30 minutes for the civic chief to reach the municipal corporation building from his residence in Tarabai Park. “My fellow officers travelled by KMT buses. Some of them joined me with their bicycles. The intended purpose will be addressed by this initiative and will also help improve our health, especially of those who travel by bicycle as it is a good exercise,” said Kalshetti.

The visible effect of the initiative was seen in the Vitthal Ramji Shinde Chowk which is usually overcrowded with the vehicles of corporators, officials and visitors. The said area looked deserted even on a working day.

Title: Aadhaar card racket busted in Umargam
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

The accused in police custody

SURAT: Police busted a racket with the arrest of two persons who were using fake details and documents along with thumb impressions of unsuspecting people to issue Aadhaar Card in Umargam of Valsad district on Tuesday. The accused persons were making use of an authorized computer and kit together with the thumb impressions of people taken on a rubber like material to issue dubious Aadhaar Card to them.

Vinesh alias Bunty Dhansukh Bhandari, a resident of Umargam, and Karanjeet Singh, a resident of Vapi but native of Patna in Bihar, were produced by the police in a court at Nargol. The court remanded them in police custody till January 6.

Police have recovered two laptops, a fingerprint scanner, GPS devices and cash worth Rs2.64 lakh from the accused. Acting on a specific information, the police raided Bhandari’s office in Hari Residency on Umargam Gandhiwadi GIDC Road and nabbed him. Singh was nabbed from there when he came to deliver a laptop to Bhandari. A laptop was later recovered by the police from Singh’s office in Daman where he was involved in a similar activity, police said.

Police declared Sarthak Borad, Guddu Rai and Viral Pansuriya, who live in different parts of the state, along with Anantram Patel, a resident of Indore in Madhya Pradesh, as wanted.

The accused first made fake PAN card and election identity card using the photo of their customer with fake details. “They made these identity cards by simply taking the colour prints on plastic cards. These fake cards were submitted to get Aadhaar Card,” Valsad superintendent of police Sunil Joshi told TOI.

Police found that the accused used rubber thumb impression stamps. They developed thumb impressions using an adhesive on the stamp, police said, adding that they have recovered two such stamps.

The seized kit includes laptops, a fingerprint scanner and a GPS device which used to be frequently replaced. The laptops had Aadhaar Card application installed in it. In a month, the kit was replaced at least four times, the accused have informed police.

“This is alarming that one can get original Aadhaar Card made using fake details and documents. This looks like a part of a large racket because it is not possible to get the kit without the involvement of authorized persons,” Joshi added.

Title: Maharashtra: Onion prices dip 34 per cent in two days as supply increases
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: The average wholesale onion price has dropped by 34%, from Rs 6,900 per quintal on Friday to Rs 4,500 per quintal on Tuesday, due to a rise in supply at the Lasalgaon APMC.

The market saw huge fluctuations in the onion prices throughout the month of December. The average wholesale price was around Rs 7,000 per quintal in the first week of December, but dropped to Rs 4,700 per quintal on December 9.

The average wholesale price shot up again in following days and recorded an all-time high of Rs 8,625 per quintal on December 16 due to shortage of supply against demand. The average price then dropped by around 40% to Rs 5,200 per quintal on December 23. However, the average wholesale onion price again shot up to Rs 6,901 per quintal on December 27.

“The supply of onions was around 10-12,000 per quintals a day around a fortnight back, but fresh kharif onion arrival crossed the 20,000-quintal mark a day at Lasalgaon for the past two-three days. This led to a drop in the wholesale prices,” said APMC officials.

“Incessant rain between July and October damaged around 75% of the kharif onion plantation in major onion pockets of Maharashtra , including Nashik , which is one of the major onion growing area.

The harvest of onions on the remaining 25% of the acreage has begun now, but the yield has reduced a lot. Moreover, there has been adequate plantation of kharif onions, the harvest of which has now begin but in a low quantity.

The harvest of late kharif onions will pick up in a week or two, which result in higher supply and lower prices. The average wholesale onion price is expected to drop again by another Rs 1,000 per quintal to Rs 3,500 per quintal in the period.

Title: Killer leopard on loose, teachers approach basic education dept for closure of schools
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Bijnor: With a killer leopardess on the loose in Bijnor and as many as 800 primary and upper primary schools in the district without boundary walls, lives of 24,000 children studying in these institutions are at risk. Several teachers approached the basic shiksha adhikari’s office on Tuesday expressing apprehension that they could be sitting ducks for the big cat that has killed five persons in the district in a month.

While the schools are closed for the students until January 2, the teachers continue to come to complete paperwork.

The leopardess has left forest officials flummoxed by refusing to enter cages and traps set by them in the past few weeks.

Five persons, including a woman and a kid, were killed in leopard attacks in the district last month while several sustained injuries.

The big cat had first killed a woman in Nawada village under Nagina Dehat police station on November 27. Since then, four other deaths have occurred.

It is yet to be ascertained if a single leopardess killed all these persons or there are others too.

According to forest officials, the leopardess has not attacked villagers in the past few days. It seems it is getting enough prey here along the Malan river.

Meanwhile, district coordinator of Sarv Shiksha Abhiyan, Salim Beg, said insecurity and fear have grown among teachers in the district. Education department has issued advisory to all teachers, kids and their parents.

“We has urged parents to pick and drop their children. In addition, teachers have been asked not to allow kids to venture out the school building while studying. Teachers should also be alert while travelling to the schools. The construction project of boundary walls around schools is in pile line. We have submitted proposal to the district panchayat raj dept,” Beg said.

There are 2,556 primary and upper primary schools in Bijnor district. Out of these, 400 schools are located in remote areas in Kotwali Dehat, Najibabad and Afzalgarh blocks. According to the the basic education department data, 450 schools do not have boundary walls around institutions. Besides, construction work of boundaries around 350 schools is incomplete posing threat not only to kids but teachers also. Many of these schools are close to sugarcane fields which is often an ideal hideout for leopards looking for preys in human habitation.

Bijnor divisional forest officer M Semmaran said the forest officials are studying the big cat’s pugmarks to locate it. “We have set up cages and installed camera traps to trace its location. It is still camping in Mohandiya village area. I hope it will be caught soon,” he said.

Title: Plea seeks age cap for OBC recruitment
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Madras High Court

CHENNAI: An advocate has approached the Madras high court seeking to prescribe upper age limit for candidates from other backward communities in direct recruitment to 32 posts of district judges .

When the plea came up for hearing on Monday, a vacation bench of Justices S Vaidyanathan and P T Asha directed the government counsel to get instructions from the authorities concerned and adjourned the plea to January 6.

According to U Kasipandiyan, the petitioner, the state government had on January 13 issued a notification to fill 31 district judge posts. The upper age limit for candidates from other backward communities was fixed as 48 years. For unreserved categories, the age limit was fixed as 45.

However, as not even a single candidate, who appeared for the written exam, managed to clear it, the recruitment process was deferred. Subsequently, on December 12 the state issued a fresh notification for direct recruitment for 32 posts of entry-level district judges. In the fresh notification, no upper age limit was fixed for candidates from other backward communities. As no upper age limit was fixed, 45 years fixed for unreserved categories will apply to other backward communities too.

Title: 12thedition of ‘Coimbatore Vizha’ from January 3
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

New additions to the festival this time are the ‘The Royal Boat Show’ and ‘Samarpan – Tribal Fest 2020’

COIMBATORE: The twelfth edition of Coimbatore Vizha is here , and with new additions. The festival which celebrates the city’s spirit and diversity, has been eagerly expected by cityfolk every year. The twelfth edition of the Vizha, to be held from January 3 to January 12 , 2020 , would feature 162 events by 100 organisations across more than 100 venues in the city, said organisers .

New additions to the festival this time are the ‘The Royal Boat Show’ and ‘Samarpan – Tribal Fest 2020’. The boat show would be held by personnel from Indian Navy (INS Agrani) and Royal Madras Yacht Club would hold a boat show on Kurichi Kulam in the city. The event would be held on January 4 and 5. On January 11 and 12, a tribal fest would be held at Brookefields where handicrafts of tribal people would be showcased.

Organisers said they wanted to have a gamut of events from heritage walks to food festival so that everyone would have something to engage in. “Inclusivity is what we are looking for. The festival is designed in such a way that there would be events to suit everybody,” an organizer said.

Events such Taste of Coimbatore, a food festival, and Art Street which had been introduced in the previous editions of the festival would also be held this time. While the food fest would be held on January 10 and 11 at Codissia Ground, Art Street would be held at Scheme Road, Race Course, on January 11 and 12.

Apart from these, at 3.30pm on January 5, ‘Coimbatore Vizha Parade’ would be held at Race Course, where more than 15 organisations and institutions would hold a cultural parade highlighting people of various cultures in the city. Also, nature trails, heritage walks, sports events and cultural performances would be held across the 10 days of the festival. For more details, visit www.coimbatorevizha.com

Title: Corporation to constitute biodiversity management committee soon
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

COIMBATORE: The city corporation is getting ready to constitute a biodiversity management committee (BMC) that will work on to preserve biodiversity.

The state government had recently directed the civic body to constitute the committee comprising six corporation officials and six officials from departments such as forest and education. The corporation commissioner will head the committee.

“We are in the process of finalizing the members and once the members are selected, a report would be sent to the state government,” a corporation official said. The committee will function under the Tamil Nadu biodiversity board.

As per the Biological Diversity Act, 2002 , “Every local body should constitute a committee within its areas for the purpose of promoting conservation, sustainable use and documentation of biological diversity including preservation of habitats, conservation of land races, folk varieties and cultivars, domesticated stocks and breeds of animals and microorganisms and chronicling of knowledge related to biological diversity.”

The committee will remain active for three years, the official said. “The members will meet to discuss the issues that affect biodiversity and find solutions to rectify it. They will also work on to map natural resources. The committee can also rope in experts or special invitees to discuss about the issues,” he added.

Title: Draw lessons from Ambedkar’s life and works, says scholar
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Professor Anand Ranganathan speaks at Chitnavis Centre, on Saturday

Nagpur: History means an account of events, but it also has the potential to become a weapon which can be relevantly used in a particular setting, said professor Anand Ranganathan , writer, blogger and columnist, on Saturday.

He was speaking on ‘India 2020- Dr BR Ambedkar’s vision of liberty, equality and fraternity’, organized by Manthan at Chitnavis Centre.

Talking about the lessons one can draw from Ambedkar’s life and his works, Ranganathan said, “As a nation, we choose to follow the road traversed by Gandhi and Nehru when we should be following Ambedkar’s footsteps. It’s not that we don’t understand Ambedkar and his ideologies, we just fear him as he was a man with authoritative stance on various subjects.”

Ranganathan, a recipient of prestigious Nehru Centenary Scholarship, stated that to understand the phenomenon that is Ambedkar, one needs to understand the man himself which includes his childhood. He then took the audience on a journey of Ambedkar’s childhood and his experience with untouchability.

He said “Ambedkar was the first untouchable to receive a scholarship at Columbia university. ‘First untouchable’ — an epithet used without knowing what evil lay within it, an epithet laced with unfathomable shame. The year was 1913 and he was liberated from the shackles put on him by his motherland, of caste prejudice and untouchability.”

He said Ambedkar later expressed how those years wiped the concept of untouchability from his consciousness.

“Being neutral is different from being objective. Being neutral is actually to take sides. When talking of human cruelty, one cannot, at the same time, talk of human genius, one cannot let anger subside, and the veins must not lose their bulge,” he said.

“Crimes against Dalits will not stop just because we have laws to punish the perpetrators. The solution is to seek inspiration from a man of black and white, Ambedkar himself and his works,” said Ranganathan.

Title: Minor respite from cold, Sikar logs 1°C
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Jaipur: After a prolonged spell of cold wave, mercury took an upward swing across the state on Tuesday, when majority of the places witnessed a rise in their minimum temperatures of 1.0°C, Met reports said.

People in Sikar witnessed bone-chilling cold in this season so far as a minimum temperature below 0°C was recorded in Sikar a few times in this season. Attributing the climatic change to the active western disturbances and upper air cyclonic circulation, the Jaipur Met office said that mild showers, lightning and hailstorm will occur at many places in the northern and eastern parts of the state in the next 24 hours.

After a continued dip in mercury, people in Jaipur experienced minor respite as a minimum temperature of 2.7°C was recorded in the city. In this season so far, Jaipur had witnessed a minimum temperature of 1.4°C and 1.0°C respectively on Sunday and Monday. However, the afternoon continued to witness nippy winds as a maximum temperature of 16.9°C, almost 6 degrees below the normal notch was recorded.

Looking at the dip in the mercury, Jaipur district collector Joga Ram on Monday issued orders that Classes I to VIII will remain closed in all the government and private schools of the city till further orders. For Classes IX to XII, schools will function after 9am. Similar orders were issued by Jaisalmer and Ajmer collectors.

Excessive fog and mist in the morning also affected rail and road traffic. At least 12 early-morning Jaipur-bound trains got delayed while the traffic on the highways connecting Jaipur to Agra, Jaipur to Ajmer and Jaipur to Delhi, was chaotic due to poor visibility. However, at the Jaipur airport which is CAT-III enabled, flight movement was smooth.

Many districts including Sikar, Jaipur, Ajmer, Alwar, Pilani, Jaisalmer, Phalodi, Bikaner, Churu and Sriganganagar witnessed their minimum temperatures below 4.0°C. In its forecast, Jaipur Met office said that a few places will witness showers and hailstorm while many places would witness fog and mist in the morning.

Title: SHRC asks TN government to pay Rs 85,000 to duo for police assault, threats
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: The State Human Rights Commission (SHRC) has directed the Tamil Nadu government to pay Rs 60,000 to a farmer who was abused and assaulted by the Tirunelveli district police personnel, for not producing original vehicle documents during a check.

According to the petition by Paulson, he had produced photocopies of the registration certificate (RC), which police didn’t accept and abused and assaulted him. The commission has also recommended disciplinary action against the police personnel.

Paulson was returning home after work on his two-wheeler in June 2013, when he was intercepted by special sub-inspector Samuthiram.

The special sub-inspector had asked for the RC and driving licence, following which Paulson provided the photocopy of the RC and said the licence was at home and he could fetch it from there. At this, sub-inspector Manojkumar began abusing and slapped him, while two other police personnel too assaulted him, Paulson said.

In response, the police personnel said Paulson was riding without a number plate and when asked to produce the documents, he used unparliamentary language against police and pulled the clothes of one of them. The complainant was arrested for this and produced before the magistrate.

After examining the submissions, the commission noted that there was human rights violation on the part of police and held that the complainant was eligible for compensation .

In another petition before the commission, S Raj Padmanabhan of Old Pallavaram in Chennai alleged threats and biased action by the Madipakkam police against him and his aides while settling a family dispute.

In July 2017, the complainant’s father-in-law had gone to a relative’s house to discuss the partition of a property and was assaulted.

Raj Padmanabhan said in his petition that the Madipakkam police registered a criminal case against him, by allegedly siding with the opposite party.

Police denied the allegations and stated the complainant and his aides had issued death threats to another person after which the case was registered. Police also denied demanding bribe to settle the case.

After examining the submissions, the rights commission held there was human rights violation and directed the state government to pay Rs 25,000 to the complainant.

Title: Congress seeks apology from Rajasthan BJP chief
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: The Congress on Tuesday sought an apology from Rajasthan BJP president Satish Poonia for dubbing chief minister Ashok Gehlot as a person suffering from “short-term memory loss” and “depression”.

Pradesh Congress Committee’s vice-president Archana Sharma said Poonia's remarks were condemnable and “reflected the negative mindset of his party”. “There can be ideological differences in parties and criticism can be based on that but making such personal comments cannot be tolerated. It appears that Poonia himself is insecure about his position. Therefore, he stooped so low in making the statement,” Sharma said. Sharma also hailed the performance of the state government in the past one year and claimed that the BJP was finding it difficult to digest that.

PTI

Title: Meerut zone registered dip in crimes in 2019, say police
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representational Image

MEERUT: As 2019 comes to an end, a quick glance at the crime statistics of Meerut zone – one of the most restive areas of West UP – shows that there has been a dip in crimes.

The data has been compiled by the police authorities. The maximum dip has been reported in crime against women -- kidnapping of women registered a 36.22% decrease while cases of harassment declined by 30.84%.

Meerut zone constitutes nine districts -- Muzaffarnagar, Saharanpur, Shamli, Baghpat, Bulandshahr, Gautam Budh Nagar, Ghaziabad, Hapur and Meerut.

Prashant Kumar, ADG, Meerut zone, said, “The reason behind a dip in crime rate in Meerut zone is that the police have been given a free hand to deal with criminals. There is no political interference of any kind by the current government. There is no recommendation of any sort to let off anyone and hence, the accused have to face consequences. Apart from this, team work of the police have given positive results.”

In women-related crimes, cases have registered a dip in kidnapping (36.22%), harassment (30.84%), murder (16.11%), sexual assault (10.76%), rape (10.28%), dowry death (2.07%) and chain snatching (0.5%). The other crimes which registered a dip include arson (14.33%), robbery (13.04%), murder (6.50%), loot (4.03%), kidnapping (3.78%), vehicle theft (3.36%) and thefts (1.59%), according to statistics provided by UP Police.

Meanwhile, 945 police encounters took place in which 20 people died and 1,624 were arrested – out of whom 674 were injured. As many as 156 police personnel were also injured in the encounters.

Asked about the criticism that UP police often faces due to the “free hand” given to them – be it police encounters or anti-CAA protests, Kumar, said, “In cases where police see unruly crowd or arson, we cannot stand there as mere spectators. We are legally authorized to resort to a lathicharge or take action as is necessary at that time. So many encounters have taken place and they have been cleared by the NHRC. These steps are necessary to maintain law and order situation here.”

Title: Nashik: 425 water connections snapped over dues
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: The Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) has snapped 425 connections of water tax defaulters in the last week of December.

The authority has decided on stern action against the pending tax dues, which has now totalled to Rs 5 crore in the past fortnight.

The civic body has set a water tax collection target of Rs 64 crore for the current fiscal year. So far, they have collected tax amounting to Rs 38 crore which is 26 crore short of the target. “We have intensified our drive against water tax defaulters. We have already started snapping connections of tax defaulters,” said an NMC official.

The municipal commissioner Mallinath Kalshetti has directed all the six divisional offices to snap at least 10 water connections of defaulters on a daily basis in each division, added an official. “Around a fortnight back, we had also conducted a drive and snapped 208 water connections of the defaulters. Of which, 70 defaulters have cleared their dues and we have re-connected their water connections,” said an official.

Out of total 425 water connections snapped, 102 were from Satpur division, 95 from Cidco, 82 from Nashik West, 59 in Panchavati, 47 in Nashik Road and 40 in Nashik East division.

In the month of August and September, a total of 2,700 water connections were snapped and their water was resumed after the dues were paid.

Due to the state assembly elections in October, the NMC could not take any action as most of the staff was busy in elections. They have now focused their attention on the recovery of taxes.

The city has 1.96 lakh water connections which include 1.88 lakh residential, 4,000 commercial and remaining 4,000 non-commercial water connections.

To further achieve their target the NMC has introduced an amnesty scheme for property tax defaulters, which has a February 10 deadline. Citizens can take advantage of the scheme and pay the taxes with minimal interest.

Earlier, NMC had put a condition to tax defaulters of clearing water tax dues first to take benefits of an amnesty scheme for property taxes. But due to cold response in the first 15 days, the civic body decided to withdraw this condition.

Title: Gurugram: Woman found dead in guesthouse, 2 detained
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

GURUGRAM: A 30-year-old woman was found dead under mysterious circumstances in a Sector 47 guesthouse on Monday, a day after she had checked into the facility with two youths. While the cause of her death hasn’t been ascertained yet, an FIR has been filed for murder and the youths have been detained for questioning.

Sunaina, a resident of Bhiwani, had booked two rooms — one for herself and the other for the men. The youths left the guesthouse in the early hours of Monday. A few hours later, she was found dead in her room.

Police said Sunaina got married to Ram Charan (41), also a Bhiwani resident, around 10 years ago. They have a nine-year-old son. Ram Charan works at a shop in Bhiwani, while Sunaina was working at a car showroom in Bhiwani. Six months ago, she moved to the Gurugram branch of the same agency and started living in a paying guest accommodation, leaving her son behind with her husband in Bhiwani.

Preliminary investigation revealed that Sunaina booked two rooms in the guesthouse through a mobile app on Sunday. They checked into the facility at 11.30pm. Around 4am the next day, the two youths checked out.

Police said they received a call from the guesthouse staff around 8am informing them that Sunaina wasn’t opening the door despite repeated knocks. A team soon reached the spot. The door of the room was unlocked and Sunaina was found dead. Police said the body was found facedown on the floor with the legs on the bed. Sunaina was identified with the help of the identity proof she had submitted at the time of check-in.

Police informed her mother of the death, who in turn informed Ram Charan. “I got a call from my mother-in-law saying that my wife was dead. We reached Gurugram late on Monday night. I suspect that Sunaina was murdered by the two men,” Ram Charan said.

The two youths were detained on Tuesday morning and are being interrogated on their alleged involvement in the murder, police said. On the basis of a complaint filed by Ram Charan, an FIR was filed under Section 302 (murder) of the IPC at Sadar police station later in the day. Her body was handed over to the family after an autopsy.

According to the autopsy report, the cause of death isn’t clear, SHO Basant Kumar said. “There was no injury on the body. Viscera samples have been sent to a forensic lab for further tests. We will be able to know the cause of death after the lab sends its report. Meanwhile, we’ve lodged a case and are interrogating the two youths,” the SHO added.

Title: No MoD notification yet, SCB poll aspirants campaign at full throttle
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Former SCB ward member J Pratap interacts with residents of Ward-I

SECUNDERABAD: While the Union ministry of defence (MoD) is yet to issue the official notification for elections in civilian wards of cantonments across the country, campaigning for the Secunderabad Cantonment Board (SCB) is already underway. Aspirants and former board members have begun their ‘padyatras’ to interact with and woo voters across wards in the country’s largest cantonment. Resolving issues pertaining to water, sanitation and roads are the key points in the campaign agendas of aspirants.

On December 19, officials of the cantonment board had completed the process of reservation of wards for women candidates. As per the official announcement, ward numbers II, V and VI have been reserved for women. Wards I, III, IV and VII have been reserved for general category while ward VII is reserved for candidates of scheduled caste (SC).

Aspirants began their campaigning as soon as the board had announced the reservations for the respective wards. Those hoping to win seats on the board include former SCB ward members, representatives of civic groups, founders of NGOs, local youth leaders and family members of current ward members. For instance, in Ward-I, former SCB vice-president Jampana Pratap has decided to contest and has started his campaign with Jakkula Maheshwar Reddy, who is currently representing the ward, also keen to contest for a second time.

“I have kept in touch with voters of the ward even before the reservation process. I am confident of my chances of winning the ward this time,” J Pratap told TOI. Meanwhile, current ward member Maheswhar Reddy is also confident of his chances. According to him, development work under his tenure should secure him another term.

“The election notification is expected by third week of January,” said an SCB official on condition of anonymity. There is still no clarity from the MoD on whether the SCP polls will be conducted through ballot papers or electronic voting machines. “We are ready for whatever the MoD decides,” the official said.

Title: Telangana: Protest at Eflu over hostel shutdown
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Students ’ union of English and Foreign Languages University ( EFLU ), on Tuesday, staged a dharna on campus against the university’s decision to shut down hostels till January 17.

Students said that shutting down hostels and rescheduling the academic calendar citing renovation as a reason was unacceptable. They also went on to describe the move by the authorities as “incompetent”. They claimed that students have already started reaching the campus and were being stopped from getting into the premises citing a circular that was released on Monday. “The university was supposed to reopen on January 6. However, now it will reopen only on January 20. University officials should rethink their decision, as this will completely disturb the academic schedule,” said a student of the varsity. “Looks like the varsity has extended the vacation only to stop anti-CAA protests on campus.”

In a press statement issued late on Tuesday evening, EFLU authorities stated that renovation works undertaken by the university were not an abrupt issue. “The UGC granted approval to utilise the XII Plan funds and had set a date of March 31, 2020, to utilise the funds. Several civil works have been identified under 26 heads related to sanitation, plumbing, renovation, arresting seepages, and erecting new structures on campus,” stated the statement.

It further added that as the work has to be undertaken in the hostels with heavy machinery and tools, which may cause inconvenience and disturbance to the students, the decision to extend the winter vacation was taken. “These civil works also include renovation of water-supplying facilities, toilets and other basic amenities. So, occupying the hostels will lead to discomfort and inconvenience for the students,” read the statement.

Title: Stop telling ‘lies’ in New Year: Congress to CM KCR
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

K Chandrasekhar Rao

HYDERABAD: Congress MLAs — D Sridhar Babu and D Anasuya alias Sitakka — on Tuesday said chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao should stop telling lies to people in the New Year and come out with a white paper on the finance, irrigation, agriculture and other sectors.

Addressing a press conference here, the MLAs said there is no word from the government on the implementation of Rs 1 lakh crop loan waiver though it had completed a year in office. They alleged that KCR ’s flagship Rythu Bandhu scheme has become a sop confined to election-bound areas.

“Except in Huzurnagar which went to bypolls, Rythu Bandhu has not been extended to farmers in several parts of the state. Farmers are also not getting remunerative price for their produce,” Sitakka and Sridhar said.

Sitakka said that KCR should have spoken truth at least after offering prayers in Rajarajeshwara temple in Vemulawada. “Welfare schemes are being implemented only in poll-bound constituencies. The government shold procure every grain of paddy produced by the farmers,” she said.

Meanwhile, senior Congress MLC T Jeevan Reddy slammed the police lathicharge on the oustees of Mid Manair project. The project-affected people were protesting during KCR’s inspection of Mid Manair on Monday. “Did we achieve statehood for the welfare of the people or for KCR’s benefit,” Jeevan Reddy said and added KCR misled the people on water availability from mid-manair for irrigation purposes.

Title: Rajasthan: 5 lakh aspirants for 5,000 posts of teachers
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

AJMER: Rajasthan Public Service Commission (RPSC) will hold a recruitment exam for school teachers January 3 to 13 in which about 5 lakh candidates will participate for 5,000 posts in different subjects.

Title: Telangana: With help from Centre, dying Kapra lake set for a new life
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

The plan for revival comes a few months after NGO Wetlands International gave Kapra a grade ‘D’ on their healt... Read More

SECUNDERABAD: Plans are afoot to turn Kapra lake in the city into a haven for birds. The development comes as a part of the Centre ’s plan to revive 100 wetlands across the country. A source working with the ministry of environment and climate change said that among the water bodies identified in the state for revival are Kapra in the city and Pakhal in Warangal. “Stakeholders in every state have been informed to send proposals regarding their plan to revive these wetlands,” he said.

In Telangana, the state forest department will work with other agencies as part of the revival effort. “We submitted our proposal and were asked to make some modifications,” said Medchal district forest officer, Ashok Kumar. Kumar has called for a meeting of all stakeholders including residents.

“We will be coordinating with the Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation and irrigation department which have been working on the lake,” Kumar said. Once the discussions take place, Kumar said the process to restore the lake and protect avian species will begin. The project will take at least four years, said sources with knowledge of the project both at the Centre and state level.

Residents for their part welcomed the news. “Among the issues to be discussed are the plantation drive that will take place as well as how to maintain the water quality,” said Jason Wilson, a resident of Sainikpuri. Another local, Deepa Shailendra said: “The lake’s ecosystem supports a variety of birds. Not just this, many people living around the lake are proactive and will be vigilant enough to help any conservation effort.”

The plan for Kapra’s revival comes a few months after NGO Wetlands International created a health map for lakes across the country and gave Kapra a grade ‘D’, one notch above the worst grade on the scorecard. The wetlands were judged on criteria including water quality, inlet and outlet choking, presence of invasive species, water birds, as well as on whether there is an approved map, notification, management plan in place and wetland conversion.

Title: BJP women’s panel targets Rajasthan government for kids’ deaths at Kota hospital
Content:
A member of BJP’s parliamentary panel interacts with the parent of a kid undergoing treatment at the Kota hosp... Read More

TimesView The recent deaths of 91 infants at the J K Lon Hospital in Kota allegedly due to lack of basic medical facilities is a pointer to the deteriorating healthcare system in the state. After TOI broke the story, the state government had constituted a team of doctors from the SMS Medical College to look into the reasons for such high child mortality. TOI had also written about many basic medical equipment lying unused and the absence of maintenance. Though the team has now submitted its report to the secretary, medical education, for reasons best known to authorities, it has not been made public. The government, which swears by transparency, should make it public and take effective steps to prevent such incidents in the future.

KOTA: BJP’s parliamentary panel comprising Jaskaur Meena, Locket Chatterjee and Kanta Kardam on Tuesday visited Kota ’s J K Lon Hospital where at least 91 kids died in December.The panel expressed displeasure at the alleged mismanagement in the hospital and slammed chief minister Ashok Gehlot for going to Ranchi to take part in the swearing-in ceremony of Hemant Soren in Ranchi but not visiting the Kota hospital .The Congress workers lodged protest against the visit of the panel by forming a human chain outside the hospital and accused the BJP of politicising the sensitive issue of kids’ deaths.The three-member team interacted with the parents and attendants of kids undergoing treatment in the hospital. Chatterjee claimed that the kids died due to infection and added that heaps of filth were lying in the hospital while pigs strayed on the premises.Expressing concern over the lack of infrastructure, the panel said two to three kids were lying in a single bed and the nursing staff was also insufficient. The behavior of the guard with the attendants at the hospital was not good, Chatterjee claimed.Later speaking to reporters, the members of the panel slammed the Gehlot government and accused the CM of insensitivity at the kids’ death.“While the kids are dying in the hospital. Chief minister Ashok Gehlot went to Jharkhand to celebrate formation of Congress government there. The mothers of deceased kids are still shedding tears but the CM is not here to wipe their tears,” Chatterjee said.‘If such an incident had occurred in the Gandhi family, there would have been a national grief across the country,” Chatterjee said.None of the Congress workers reached in the hospital so far, but BJP MLAs in Kota have extended monetary assistance of Rs 50 lakh, she further said.“Gehlotji and Rahulji must come here instead of going to Ranchi, Lucknow and Delhi delivering speeches,” Chatterjee said.On asking about higher number of kids’ death during BJP’s rule in the state in the last five years , Chatterjee said, “It is not a competition between the Congress and the BJP. Death of kids is not all about numbers,” Chatterjee said.

Title: Vadavalli residents demand borewell water connection
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: The residents of Devi Nagar in Vadavalli have petitioned corporation commissioner, requesting him to install a borewell pipeline in the area before the summer season.

They will be forced to depend on local borewells or buy water sold by tankers as drinking water will be supplied only once in 12 days, they said.

During peak summer, when the corporation reduces the frequency of drinking water supply across the city, residents end up using borewell water for all purposes. “Last year, frequency of drinking water supply was reduced to once every 12 days,” said activist N Chandran. “That time, people without borewells struggled to get water for daily uses like cleaning,” he said.

Women in the area said they had a difficult time due to lack of borewell pipeline. “Last year, for an entire month, we received water hardly thrice and in small quantities. We were forced to buy drinking water. We used it for washing and cooking. For the rest, we had to buy water,” said Kavitha, a resident. “We had to carry water collected from the borewell water pipe at the end of Radhe Avenue in plastic pots every day.”

“The corporation had recently dug up the road to lay drainage pipelines. They could have laid a borewell pipeline alongside,” said T Gopi, another resident.

Title: What should authorities do to control the population of strays?
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

As residents of Yapral complained about a rise in the number of stray dog population, TOI asked readers how the civic body could help solve the issue What should authorities do to control the population of strays ?

Containing the population of strays is a tedious task that cannot be easily handled by authorities alone. First and foremost, dogs should be sterilised periodically round the year in every area. The government should display numbers as helplines so that people can register complaints and act upon them swiftly. A few of the stray dogs who may be aggressive due to a variety of reasons could prove to be harmful to humans. Such dogs should be shifted to an isolated place out of the city where they can be taken care of in an appropriate manner. Dogs in every area are loyal to the people who feed them regularly and who caresses them often. Such people should help the authorities to get them sterilised and inform the authorities of the same - Deepesh Surana

The issue of stray dogs has been there in twin cities for over 40 years now. But improper handling of this issue has made it a serious problem. In any street or locality, the presence stray dogs will do more good than harm. They attack only strangers or when provoked by children and youth. However, if there are incidents of unprovoked attacks, then authorities can tackle the issue in by ascertaining of all the strays in city and classifying them locality wise and colony wise. Authorities must seek the help of animal husbandry officials, dog trainers, veterinary doctors. Pick the dogs up and move them to a far flung places on the outskirts of the city. Let professional folk train them and help these dogs lead a healthy life. These good dogs can be used by the police, CBI and other investigative agencies, and also for watch and ward in various VIP houses and quarters. All other dogs should be sterilized to start with and expert opinions should be sought on how to proceed further. Involve experts and trainers to come out with an apt solution to ensure they do not become a menace. All dogs which are not healthy need treatment. The authorities have to take it up and do it on priority - Ramesh Vemuganti

As the number of stray dogs in the city is multiplying by the day it is important that authorities do something to keep the number in check before it becomes a serious issue. In several areas aggressive dogs have attacked pedestrians, vehicles, and children. Dogs are often caught, and immunised and left in the same place from where they have brought. Instead of this, the government and the GHMC should employ a separate team that ensures that each street has a maximum of two healthy dogs - Nandikanti Sai Kumar

Stray dogs have become a menace to the citizens of the twin cities. This issue is not just limited to Secunderabad . There are specific locations where these stray dogs are posing a problem to residents and commuters and these areas need to be worked on first. Many complaints have been lodged about this menace but GHMC has not been able to take any action in this regard. GHMC is aware of the vulnerable points where these stray dogs are creating a problem. As a veterinarian, I suggest that these stray dogs should be sterilized on war footing to control their population.Secondly, vaccinating these dogs should be taken up immediately and these dogs need to be tagged so as to identify the vaccinated ones. Thirdly, pet lovers can adopt these stray dogs as they are very much immune to certain diseases and can survive small illnesses. Violent and rabid dogs if found, should be put to sleep by the veterinary hospitals after proper inspection ,in the interest of the health of locals - Dr GV Kumar

Authorities need to take a hard stance on the issue. We need to educate people because stray dogs bite children, spread garbage all over the place and create nuisance at night by fighting among themselves. Those feeding stray dogs must be discouraged from doing so. This leads to a large number of dogs moving to one particular street in the hope of finding food. Authorities need to take stringent action to avoid irreversible damage to citizens - Ravi Kumar

Authorities should take the following measures to contain the population of stray dogs in Secunderabad. Sterilisation should be taken up on war footing. Relocation of stray dogs should be done in the outskirts. The dogs must be treated for any health issues that they may have. Residents must be discouraged from feeding these dogs unnecessarily as they tend to crowd the lanes at night looking for food - Nagarjuna Srinivasa Rao

Title: Rajasthan: Four held for impersonating army officers
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

ALWAR: Alwar police arrested four men for impersonating army intelligence officers and creating ruckus at the NEB police station on Tuesday. The accused entered the police station and ordered the cops with one even taking the SHO’s chair.

The arrested men were identified as Vivek Singh, Bhupendra Singh, Ravindra Das and Somesh Singh.

“The four men entered the police station and claimed that they were in Alwar for official work. They asked us to book a hotel room for them. We got suspicious as they did not look like army officers and were in an intoxicated state,” said a police officer.

The accused had travelled from Haryana to Jaipur and could not provide any army identification proof. They tried to run away when being asked to prove their identities. We also recovered a Delhi registered car from them.

This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

AJMER: Rajasthan Public Service Commission (RPSC) will hold a recruitment exam for school teachers January 3 to 13 in which about 5 lakh candidates will participate for 5,000 posts in different subjects.

RPSC has already issued admit cards for the exam on its website. The exams will be in three groups — general knowledge paper from 9am to 10.30am, optional paper from 9am, to noon and then again from 2pm to 5pm. The exams will be held in all divisional headquarters.

Title: ISI, foreign powers responsible for ‘violent’ anti-CAA protests, says BJP MP
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Rajya Sabha member Sudhanshu Trivedi

MEERUT: Bharatiya Janata Party's (BJP) Rajya Sabha member Sudhanshu Trivedi on Tuesday said Pakistan ’s intelligence agency, ISI , and other “foreign powers” were responsible for the violent anti-Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) protests across the country.

Addressing a press conference as part of ‘jan jagran abhiyaan’ (public awareness drive) for the CAA at a hotel here in Meerut, Trivedi said, “The violence in the name of anti-CAA protests is a well-thought and strategic move by the ISI and other foreign powers. Otherwise, how is it possible that around 30,000 people participated in the protest at Jamia, which has only 4,000 students? When no Maulana or Ulema protested against the Act, then how did the violence spread so far and wide? The people who are trying to flare up the matter are those who have no political existence.”

He added, “The protesters who are covering their faces and throwing stones at police officers are not students, but professional criminals. Why would students of Jamia Milia Islamia and Aligarh Muslim University protest for Assam’s culture? The word ‘Muslim’ is not even there in the CAA, even then why is the Muslim community being incited?”

Claiming that the idea of CAA is the brainchild of the Congress, Trivedi, said, “Former Prime Minister Manmohan Singh in Rajya Sabha had advocated for giving citizenship to non-Muslims of Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan. On November 25, 1947, the Congress Working Committee had talked about giving refuge to those persecuted in Pakistan on the basis of religion. On September 20, 1947, even Mahatma Gandhi had mentioned this. Then why is the Congress protesting against it?”

Talking about the proposed National Register of Citizens (NRC), Trivedi said, “No final draft of NRC has been prepared. Work is being done. Presently, the focus is on those people who did not find their name in the NRC in Assam.”

Commenting on the viral video where Meerut SP (City) Akhilesh Narayan Singh was heard shouting at the protesters to go to Pakistan, Trivedi, said, “A clarification has been sought from the administration. However, the same Congress members who go to Pakistan and talk about destabilising Modi government are not worthy of any answer. In the UN, Pakistan had given reference of Rahul Gandhi’s comment.”

However, Union minister Satyapal Singh, who was also in Meerut to spread awareness about the CAA, said the Meerut police should have desisted from making such remarks.

“I saw the video of Meerut SP (city), and I believe it is the best if police ensures maintaining law and order instead of giving any remarks.”

Title: Surat: Who killed Dishit Jariwala ? Wife, two others set to walk free
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Velsee and Dishit Jariwala in happier times

SURAT: In a huge setback to the police in the sensational Dishit Jariwala murder case, all three accused including his wife were acquitted by a local court on Tuesday, over three-and-a-half-years after the brutal crime.

The court gave them benefit of doubt in absence of strong evidence to prove the murder charges. Moreover, majority of the witnesses turned hostile during the trial.

Dishit’s wife Velsee(25), her friend Suketu alias Sunny Modi (32) and Suketu’s driver Dhirendra Chauhan (37) are set to walk free after acquittal.

“Prosecution could not prove the charges. There were no corroborative evidences,” Bhadresh Dalal, public prosecutor, told TOI. “Witnesses like police personnel and doctors who did the postmortem stayed firm on their statement, but most of the other witnesses turned hostile which affected the case,” Dalal added.

The court had examined 73 witnesses, but there was no eyewitness in the murder. The main witness, an auto rickshaw driver who brought Suketu and Dhirendra to the spot of crime had also turned hostile. Police could not even prove that it was not a murder for loot, said Kirit Panwala, defence lawyer.

“The sequence of chain of events in the court. CCTV footages of Suketu and Dhirendra approaching the house were of no help and the motive of the crime could not also not be proved in court,”

It was alleged in the FIR that Suketu and Velsee were in love and they plotted and executed Dishit’s murder so that they could live together.

Initially, Velsee was the complainant in the case, but after her role was found from the CCTV footages and spot investigation, police became the complainant.

“We will plan future course of action after examining the judgement. We are yet to receive the written order,” said Vidhi Chaudhary, deputy commissioner of police, zone III.

Title: Snake rescued from counting centre
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Tirupur: A rat snake slithered into the vote counting centre of the Tirupur panchayat union set up in the Jaivabai Corporation Higher Secondary School in the city on Tuesday.

Police personnel, who were guarding the centre, managed to capture the five-foot-long snake and handed it over to the staff of the Tirupur forest range.

The non-venomous snake will be released near a water body, forest department sources said.

As many as 13 panchayats under the Tirupur panchayat union underwent the local body elections in the first phase on Friday. Ballot boxes are kept in the Jaivabai school as the counting will be held on Thursday. TNN

Title: A year of agriculture, more in store for farmers
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: Minister of agriculture Kurasala Kanna Babu termed the year 2019 as the year of farmers’ welfare. Speaking to media persons in Kakinada , the minister said that chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy had set an example to others by implementing over 80 per cent of the election promises in mere six months.

He referred to the YSR Rythu Bharosa scheme and said it was a blessing in disguise to the farmers in terms of financial assistance. The government also started interest-free loans, free insurance for farmers, free bore well, quality seeds, agriculture laboratories and free power supply to farmlands. The 2020 would start with the government paying the last instalment of the Rythu Bharosa to the farmers on January 2, he said.

The government is also planning to start agriculture workshops in three phases across the state from February 2020. The first phase would have 3,330 centers in February, he said and the number would go up to 11,500 by the end of April, the minister said.

The minister also referred to the Agriculture Mission established under the chairmanship of the chief minister creating Rs 330 crore market intervention fund to support the farmers.

The minister said that the government was gearing up to constitute market yard committees across the state giving due representation to all sections. These committees would help the farmers in finding remunerative price to their produce in the market, the minister said.

The agriculture assistants appointed in the village secretariats would closely help farmers in all spheres in the coming years, the minister said. The officials in the agriculture ministry were asked to work in the field with farmers guiding in the crop management, soil management and other market intervention.

He took a dig at the TDP government for not fulfilling even a single promise made to the farmers in the 2014 Assembly elections. He discounted the allegations of injustice by the government to Amaravati farmers and advised farmers not to fall in the trap of the politically-motivated leaders.

Title: State to give 100% subsidy on chemicals to kill locusts
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Jaipur: The state agriculture department has announced 100% subsidy on chemicals used to kill locusts in western Rajasthan districts.

The move comes after CM Ashok Gehlot held a review meeting last week. The department has now initiated a survey of agricultural areas to assess crop loss due to locust menace.

“The chemicals are free for farmers to counter the spread of locust from their fields and region. Earlier, the subsidy was 50%. Considering the prolonged period of locust menace, the decision has been taken to provide relief to farmers,” said Om Prakash, commissioner, agriculture department. The subsidy will be given to farmers in western districts like Barmer, Bikaner, Jaisalmer, Western Jodhpur, Sirohi and Pali.

The first attack by locust was recorded on May 23 and threat continues till date. This is for the first time that threat of locust, which generally remains from May to October, has extended till date.

The evaluation of crops loss has not been assessed by the government. However, the department says that total damage of both Rabi and Kharif crops, which is cultivated between 30000 and 40000 hectares, has been effected. “In terms of financial loss, the department is surveying the fields as crops vary from one place to another – wheat, quinoa, mustard, barley etc. The total affected area is 3.25 lakh hectares while net cropped area is just 10%-15%.

Gehlot during a review meeting had asked officials to utilise all resources and sought help from the Centre. The state agriculture in tandem with the Centre’s Locust Warning Organisation based in Jodhpur

.

Title: Wild tusker steps on electric fence, gets electrocuted
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Vellore: A male elephant was electrocuted after stepping on an electric fence allegedly erected by poachers to hunt wild animals on revenue land at DB Palayam near Gudiyatham . The spot was near the Paradarami reserve forest on the Tamil Nadu-Andhra Pradesh border on Tuesday.

Forest department officials said the 30-year-old wild tusker was electrocuted while returning to the forest after barging into private land located between the reserve forest and the government revenue land in DB Palayam.

C Mahendran, Gudiyatham forest range officer, said, “To hunt animals like wild boars and deer, poachers in the area fix electric traps. They sell the meat illegally.”

On Tuesday, farmers who were taking their livestock for grazing, were surprised to notice the carcass of the elephant on the revenue land and alerted the Paradarami police station. Following information by police, forest officials from both Tamil Nadu and Andhra Pradesh reached DB Palayam and conducted postmortem examination of the pachyderm in the presence of Vellore collector A Shanmuga Sundaram and district forest officer Bhargav Teja. Speaking to TOI, Shanmuga Sundaram said that following recent incidents of wild elephants from the reserve forest in Andhra Pradesh straying into villages in Vellore district, the administration had stepped up measures to construct elephant trenches.

Stringent action will be taken against the poachers involved in hunting of wild animals, the collector said.

Title: Farmers stage dharna over locust attacks
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Jaisalmer: BJP and Kisan Jagriti Manch staged a day-long dharna outside the collectorate over the government’s alleged apathy towards containing locust attacks and damage to crops. They alleged that locust teams of governments have totally failed in controlling the insects.

For the last six months, locust teams are camping in Jaisalmer and just doing the formalities. There was apprehension of Ravi crops getting damaged, but the department did not show any activeness. Former MLA Sang Singh Bhati said the state government was playing politics over locust control. tnn

Title: Drug situation going out of control, CM Pramod Sawant must act: Michael Lobo
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Michael Lobo

PANAJI: Science and technology minister Michael Lobo has said the drug menace in the state seems to be “going out of hand” and chief minister Pramod Sawant must immediately set up a dedicated team to check its spread.

“This is a serious issue and steps need to be taken to contain it. The chief minister should take stock of the situation,” Lobo, who is a BJP MLA from the tourist beach belt of Calangute , told TOI.

He said though the coastal belt was always known for its drug problems, “currently, it looks like the situation is going out of hand”.

Lobo said though the situation was grave, it was not uncontrollable. “To control it, we will need to have a dedicated team with the chief minister monitoring its progress on a regular basis,” he said.

Pointing to the 2017 decision of Manohar Parrikar , after he became the chief minister, of setting up a special squad of senior police officials reporting directly to him, Lobo said he would be meeting Sawant soon to discuss this issue.

“I will request the chief minister to revive this special team which Parrikar had set up to control drug trade. Or else, even local people will meet the same fate as that of the three tourists,” he warned.

During the three-day electronic dance music (EDM) festival that ended on Sunday, two tourists from Andhra Pradesh and one from Telengana died under suspicious circumstances.

Though police have said the cause of their deaths are “reserved”, senior BJP functionaries and opposition have attacked the Sawant-led government for its inability to control drug menace.

The cause of death of three young men, Lobo said, could have been due to consumption of “spurious drugs”.

Police have said all three deaths have one thing in common — “cerebral and pulmonary edema”.

Doctors said those who overdose on drugs run a higher risk of cerebral and pulmonary edema.

“Mostly, persons who abuse substances or suffer a head injury on being hit by a heavy object suffer from cerebral edema,” a government doctor had said. But he said there were “absolutely no injuries” on the bodies of the three youths.

In August, TOI in a series of reports had exposed the dark alleys of Goa’s drug trade and Sawant, who had initially shrugged it off, was finally forced to admit the menace after his own MLAs agreed with the reports about easy availability of drugs in the state.

Lobo also slammed Goa police for failing to check drug menace in the state and said the anti-narcotics cell (ANC) was “not doing the job properly”.

“They aren’t going after the drug dealers. Mostly, it is the peddlers who are arrested,” he said.

“Tell me, how many big raids have been conducted by ANC... we have a narcotics control bureau (NCB) office here. How many raids has it conducted?” Lobo said.

Title: 1 lakh kids remain critical after birth, says health minister
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Jaipur: Health minister Raghu Sharma on Tuesday every year 18 lakh infants take birth in the state and out of those 1 lakh remain critical due to anaemic mother, premature delivery and underweight.

“People should remain aware about health of their infants. They need to take immediate decision for getting clinical support, if the infant is unwell to save his life,” he said, adding that it is painful if an infant dies.

Sharma said if anyone was found guilty of negligence in the report of investigating team in the deaths of children in JK Lon Hospital in Kota, strict action would be taken against him.

Sharma criticised the previous BJP government for not installing centralised oxygen system in every hospital, including Kota’s JK Lon.

He, however, claimed that infant mortality rate (IMR) in the state had taken a significant dip. It was 7.62 per cent during BJP’s tenure in 2014, which has now been reduced to 5.55 per cent in 2019.

“They (BJP) themselves did not do anything. The IMR during their term was much higher, whereas we have reduced IMR and Maternal Mortality Ratio. We are bringing in more facilities in hospitals across the state. The government has focused majorly on the health sector,” he said.

Sharma said the state government's aim was to open medical colleges in all the 33 districts and the government was working very systematically in this sector.

Title: PSI, aide caught taking bribe
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

PSI Brijesh Gadhvi

SURAT: A police sub-inspector ( PSI ) and his aide were nabbed by anti-corruption bureau (ACB) while accepting a bribe of Rs90,000 from a person in an area under Salabatpura police station on Tuesday. The accused had demanded Rs one lakh from a zari manufacturer to help him avoid police action in a case of cheating lodged by his friend and the latter had paid an instalment of Rs10,000 already.

ACB arrested Brijesh Gadhvi, PSI, and Rutvik Patel, an estate broker. Patel accepted the bribe outside Rustampura police chowki and later went inside the chowki with the money. The complainant was also called by the accused cop inside the chowki after the money was paid. Soon, a team of ACB nabbed the accused red-handed as per the trap laid for him by R K Solanki, ACB PI, (Surat rural) under the supervision of N P Gohil, assistant director, ACB Surat.

The complainant used to purchase raw material from a supplier in Valsad. Rupesh (name changed), a friend of the complainant, expressed wish to buy the same raw material after which the complainant put Rupesh in touch with the supplier. Rupesh purchased the raw material but disappeared without making payment to the supplier, who lodged a complaint against him at Salabatpura police station.

“The PSI called the zari manufacturer and threatened to book him. He demanded Rs1 lakh for not taking action against him. Of the total money demanded, Rs10,000 was already accepted by him. He had called the complainant to receive the remaining Rs90,000 of the bribe,” said an ACB official.

Title: Christian Medical College performs life-saving surgery free of cost
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Vellore: A team of medical experts at Christian Medical College ( CMC ) in Vellore has performed a life-saving surgery ( thoracic aortic aneurysm ) on a 58-year-old impoverished daily wager free of cost .

The surgery, which costs up to Rs 6 lakh, was performed at the CMC through funds raised by the hospital development department.

Thoracic aortic aneurysm is an abnormal bulge in the wall of a major blood vessel (aorta) that carries blood from the heart.

Addressing a press meet at the hospital, Prabhu Premkumar, professor of vascular surgery, said, “Singh, a daily wage labourer from Walajapet in Ranipet district was on December 20 admitted to the CMC emergency ward with complaints of vomiting blood. Singh, who was at once shifted to the department of gastroenterology for a CT scan, was diagnosed with the thoracic aortic aneursym and was immediately referred to the vascular surgery department.”

“As Singh was the sole breadwinner from a poor background and could not afford the treatment expenses and given the urgency of the condition, the hospital administration arranged a stent free of cost and successfully performed the operation on December 21.”

Singh is undergoing treatment free of cost and is on the road to recovery, Premkumar said.

Speaking to TOI, Durai Jasper, public relations officer of CMC, said, “The development department of the hospital facilitates treatment for poor patients from the local community who are in need of emergency life-saving treatment using funds raised through the department.”

Title: HC directive to promote SI citing delay in completing dept inquiry
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Madurai: Citing inordinate delay in concluding departmental proceedings against a sub-inspector, the Madras high court directed the department to promote him to inspector of police as the there has been an inordinate delay in completing departmental inquiry against him. The court directed the authorities concerned to promote the petitioner, D Jeyaseelan Koilraj Mathew, who is working as SI at the CID security branch in Chennai, to inspector of police within eight weeks.

Justice M S Ramesh observed that in 2016 the court had quashed disciplinary proceedings against one of the co-delinquent, V S Illangovan.

The judge noted that the order has also been confirmed in the appeal by this court in 2019.

“It is not in dispute that the charges levelled against Illangovan is similar to that of the petitioner arises out of the same occurrence. While the court had concluded the disciplinary proceeding against a co-delinquent on the ground of inordinate delay, this court is unable to take a different view in the case of the petitioner,” observed the judge. The judge cited that although the disciplinary proceeding initiated against the petitioner in 2007 is yet to conclude, it would not be appropriate to subject the petitioner to departmental proceedings after all these years.

Disciplinary proceeding was initiated against the petitioner as he had misused his official capacity and brutally attacked three people.

Disciplinary proceeding was initiated against four other co-delinquents in connection with the incident and a criminal case was also registered in 2014. Although the petitioner was entitled to be included in the promotion panel in 2012, the same was rejected on the ground that criminal proceeding was pending against him.

The criminal case against the petitioner was quashed in 2018. After the criminal case was quashed, the petitioner sought for promotion and the same was turned down though proceedings dated February 25, stating that he was not eligible for promotion as departmental proceeding is pending against him.

The judge observed that it was the submission of the additional government pleader that they have filed a review petition challenging the order passed in the appeal in 2019.

The judge noted that it is needless to point out that if the authorities concerned obtain a favourable order in the review petition, it is open to them to workout their remedies in accordance with law. Hence, the judge set aside the order dated February 25.

Title: Kasba residents on high alert a day after liquor shop robbery
Content:
The Shantipally area where residents have started increasing security at their houses

KOLKATA: The robbery at a liquor shop located on the EM Bypass Rashbehari Connector at Shantipally’s Sarat Park in Kasba has not only surprised the cops for the sheer audacity of the accused, it has also left locals panicked. Witness to several petty crimes when the area came in to prominence almost a decade ago (one of the first areas of Kasba to get developed), residents of Shantipally said the past half-decade had mostly been incident-free. The fresh incident, coming a couple of days before the New Year, has left many wondering if they need to increase security at their shops and flats.“We have been staying here for two decades. We could not even hear a sound on Monday morning. But when I woke up in the morning, there were police all around. I stay with my wife alone. Though I own nothing that can attract a criminal , every crime reported right next to my home makes me nervous. I am planning to increase security of my house by installing CCTV cameras,” said 71-year-old Amitabha Chowdhury who stays on the flat located right next to the shop.Mitali Sarkar, a resident of the same flat where the shop is located, said: “The whole night, they keep unloading liquor crates. Around 4am, I heard a loud noise and got up thinking they were stocking up for the New Year. I came to the balcony to check. But the noise then stopped and I decided to go back to bed. I woke up when cops rang my calling bell and wanted to know about the owner.”“I cannot believe that someone can break the shutter, one inch of glass and a burglar alarm to commit the robbery. Barely metres away, a restaurant operates late in to the night and there is 24-hour security at the hotel located right opposite the road. This incident thus raises question on our prevalent security system. But then this has been a peaceful neighbourhood and the cops had almost managed to nab them before they fled. I am certain this will remain an one-off incident,” said Sarkar.Sanjay Varma, a local businessman staying at the BA block located right behind the shop, said that the narrow alley that opens up to the Bypass (right beside the shop) often gets unwanted visitors at night. “On occasions, rogue bikers come and drink here and throw away the bottles. But this happens only on festive occasions. Otherwise, the area is peaceful. Being a businessman residing here, I am a bit worried. I have already ensured that the CCTV outside my residence is working,” said Varma.Police said they were investigating the case with the belief that the gang had at least one local resident who acted as their eyes and ears. “The detective department and Kasba police have leads on the Rs 2.7 lakh robbery. We will crack this case soon,” said an investigating officer at Lalbazar. The owner of the shop has refused to comment.

Title: 1.5L individuals get one-day permits to raise a NY toast
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Nashik: The state excise department has issued one-day drinking permits to about 1.5 lakh individuals on the eve of New Year celebrations. The department has given drinking permits for a day to 22 hotels in the city as well.

As per state excise norms, it is mandatory for individuals, hotels or groups to acquire permits for consuming liquor during the New Year celebrations.

The state excise department has issues various drinking permits, which include permissions to consume alcohol for a day, a year and even lifetime drinking permits. The fee for one-day drinking permit is Rs 5, while a yearly permit costs Rs 100. The life-time permit, meanwhile, costs Rs 1,000 per head. One-day drinking permits for New Year celebrations for a group — in case of a non-commercial event — is Rs 7,000, while it is Rs 20,000 for hotels.

“The demand for one-day permits for New Year celebrations among individuals and hotels has been very good. We had provided online facilities for the individual permits. We also provided facilities to offer drinking permits on the spot at three locations in the city,” an official from the state excise department said.

The excise department has given relaxation in timing for sale and consumption of liquor on the eve of New Year for revellers.

Beer and wine shops were given the go-ahead to remain open till 1 am, while the deadline was 5am for beer bars and permit rooms.

“We have a resort at our winery here. We have organised a New Year party for tourists who stay at our guest house. Over 150 tourists from across the country and abroad have come for the celebrations this year,” said Pradeep Pachpatil, the chairman and managing director of Some Vineyards.

“This is for the second consecutive time that I have come to Nashik to celebrate New Year at the winery. I like the winery and the climate in Nashik is also pleasant, especially in the last week of December” said S Banerjee, a tourist from Bengaluru.
