Later, each entry is logged into the system,” an officer explained. Whatever be the issue, police now want to ensure that these issues are looked at compassionately.

Title: Revellers flood city streets for 2020 bash!
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Revellers swirled to the tunes dished out by DJs and partied hard, braving the 11.6°C chill

AHMEDABAD: Stretches of CG Road and SG Road turned into party zones as thousands descended on them to ring in 2020 at the stroke of midnight. Sindhu Bhavan Road and Vastrapur also drew huge crowds at restaurants and open plots. Revellers swirled to the tunes dished out by DJs and partied hard, braving the 11.6°C chill.

Mindful of the recent spate of crimes against women, the city police took no chances and deployed extra resources, including women personnel, at key locations across the city. P L Mal, DCP zone I, said that 250 police personnel along with five companies of the State Reserve Police had been deployed on CG Road. “Police also mingled with the crowds in plain clothes and kept an eye on the crowd with the CCTV network,” he said.

On SG Road, K N Damor, DCP zone VII, was at hand to ensure that no untoward incident occured. “The city has about 50 SHE teams who kept patrolling major stretches, scanning them for eve-teasers and speed demons,” said a senior city police official.

Smita Patel, who had come to CG Road with her group of friends, said that the New Year outing has been an annual ritual since her college days. “We generally dine at a restaurant and then take a stroll along the length of the road just to feel the energy, which is so contagious!” she said. “Fortunately, I have not faced any unpleasant incident.”

Till 11pm, the city police recorded 20-odd cases of drunken driving. Sources said that police had 600 breath analyzers with them. While parties went on till late, major venues wrapped up after 1.30am, said sources.

Title: 2,222 trees to face the axe to facilitate Metro’s smooth run
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

The felling of trees for the Metro project began near AIIMS in Saket Nagar

BHOPAL: The upcoming Metro project seems to be playing havoc with the city’s green cover as the civic body has given its nod to the construction company to chop 2,222 trees in the city, which is already losing its greenery at a fast pace in the recent times. The felling of trees for the rail project began on Monday near AIIMS, Saket Nagar. The magnitude of the problem can be well gauged from the research undertaken by a noted environmentalist Subhash Pandey that clearly states that 5 lakh trees have been chopped in the state capital in the last decade, leading to massive deterioration in quality of air.

Though Pandey refused to reveal the number of trees that are likely to be felled for the Metro project, engineer-in-chief of the project Jitendra Dubey said, “We have been granted permission to chop trees by the municipal corporation. The forest department of the Capital Project Administration (CPA) will plant four saplings for every tree that is cut, so the greenery of the city will not be affected. As the pillars for the Metro rail need to be constructed, felling of trees is unavoidable.”

According to sources, the BMC has given the construction company permission to cut down 2,222 trees in the city -- 1,199 from Karond square to AIIMS and 993 from Bhadbhada to Ratnagiri . With the CPA planting four trees for each tree that is cut, a total of 8,828 trees are to be planted in different areas of the city.

The construction company has paid Rs 1.28 crore to CPA for plantation and the forest wing of the CPA has already started the work. “So far, the construction company has chopped 1,555 trees in the city. This is the figure that they provided to us during the ground verification. In place of these trees, we are planting 4,796 saplings in different areas. The plantation work has already begun at Alia Polytechnic College, Ratibad, Tarasewania crematorium and near DAV college. We have already planted 5000 saplings,” said Sanjay Shrivastav, CPA chief conservator of forests.

Subhash Pandey, however, pointed out a major flaw in the plan saying that saplings will not compensate for the amount of oxygen a 10-year old tree gives and the carbon dioxide it absorbs, besides being home to a number of birds and insects. “We all know how the plantation is done. Big trees are cut and small saplings are planted, but no one bothers to take care of them to see them grow into trees. Even if the saplings grow, they will still take 10 to 50 years to compensate for the loss of the one big tree that was mercilessly chopped down”, said Pandey.

Commenting on the present state of the city, Pandey said, “I think scientists will have to make some new invention that will allow people to survive without oxygen. In the last decade, 5 lakh trees have been cut down and there is nothing that the departments concerned are doing about it. The pollution control board should take cognizance of the saplings planted in the last few years by various organizations, CPA and politicians. No one bothers to actually do anything and people also just become happy reading the news that saplings have been planted, without even bothering to see the real condition.”

CCF Shrivastav, however, said that the survival rate of saplings planted by them is nearly 90 to 100 percent and the chopping down of trees will be compensated in a few years. “We have planted local species like karanj, saptaparni, gulmohor and sissoo saplings that will easily grow in the climate of Bhopal. We have made fences around the saplings so that they may be protected and are also watering them regularly. The saplings will survive and increase the green belt of Madhya Pradesh”, Shrivastav said.

Title: Virus in air sends kids to ICUs with respiratory infections
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: The nip in the air and the holiday season is making it the best playtime for children, but it is also landing many children in bed for respiratory and viral infections. Many adults, too, are opting to work from home with hot soups, rasam and power naps as viruses spread in winter.

Doctors see long queues outside their clinics and high occupancy of beds in their children’s wards. The chill in December months harbours viruses, unlike the warmth during the rest of the year. “Almost every patient walking into the hospital complains of cough, cold, or wheezing triggered by viruses,” said paediatrician Dr S Balasubramanian, medical director, Kanchi Kamakoti Childs Trust Hospital. “It not only lasts long, but also sends some children to ICUs following complications of pneumonia,” he said.

Doctor don’t often verify the strain unless patients develop complications. Many children moved into ICUs tested positive for respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), which causes infections of the lungs and the respiratory tract. “It is more common in children, particularly premature babies, infants and those with a weak immune system,” he said. While most of the children recover in a few days with medication, a few need ventilator support.

Signs and symptoms of RSV appear about four to six days after exposure to the virus. In adults and older children, the symptoms mimic common cold — congested or runny nose, dry cough, low-grade fever, sore throat and mild headache. “I was feeling tired and just wanted to stay in bed,” said S Kavya, a law student, infected by the virus.

Kavya was lucky. In some people, the infection spreads to lower respiratory tract, causing pneumonia or bronchiolitis — inflammation of the small airway passages entering the lungs. “It leaves them with fever, severe cough, wheezing with other secondary infections that may require antibiotics,” said Dr P Kuganandam of SIMS Hospital.

While there are no vaccines in the market against most viruses, public health experts say washing hands frequently, limiting contact with people who have fevers or cold and properly discarding used tissues can help prevent spread of infections. Smoking can aggravate symptoms.

Title: Delhi: Chances of rain on Day 1 of 2020 recede, relief from biting cold
Content:
A day after recording the coldest winter day in 118 years, Delhi had some respite from the biting cold on Tues... Read More

NEW DELHI: A day after recording the coldest winter day in 118 years, Delhi had some respite from the biting cold on Tuesday. Both the minimum and the maximum temperature went up by a few degrees, owing to strong easterly winds .India Meteorological Department (IMD) officials said that with wind speeds increasing to around 15 km/hr, dense fog formation was prevented on Tuesday, allowing sunlight to come through in the afternoon.Easterly winds will continue to influence Delhi in the next 24 hours due to an active western disturbance, which will lead to a further increase in temperature on January 1. However, chances of rain and hailstorm impacting the capital have gone down, they added.“While we had initially forecast a spell of light rain on January 1, this now appears unlikely. On January 2, while Uttar Pradesh may see some hail activity, only isolated parts in Delhi will now record hail,” said Kuldeep Srivastava, scientist at the regional meteorological centre.Delhi’s minimum temperature, which had fallen down to 2.9 degrees Celsius on Monday, increased to 4.8 degrees due to the easterly winds. The maximum which was the lowest in 118 years at 9.4 degrees also increased to 14.7 degrees Celsius on Tuesday. This made it the 18th consecutive ‘cold-day’ Delhi has been recording since December 14, Met officials said.“Severe cold day or cold day conditions prevailing over Delhi-NCR since December 14 left behind a record of 13 consecutive days which were recorded in December of 1997,” said Srivastava.IMD classifies it as a “cold day” when the maximum temperature is four or more degrees below normal.Srivastava said the mean maximum temperature (MMT) for December 2019 has been 18.8 degrees Celsius, making it the second coldest December since 1901.Lodhi Road recorded Delhi’s lowest minimum temperature on Tuesday at 3.7 degrees Celsius, while Mungeshpur recorded the lowest maximum at 11.6 degrees Celsius. Forecast for Wednesday shows Delhi’s maximum and minimum could rise even further, touching 17 and 6 degrees Celsius respectively.On Monday, Delhi’s maximum temperature which stood at 9.4 degrees Celsius was the lowest ever winter temperature recorded since IMD started keeping records in 1901.

Title: No inputs from Gujarat for National Infrastructure Pipeline
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Nirmala Sitharaman

GANDHINAGAR: The report of the task force on the National Infrastructure Pipeline (2019-2025), released by Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman, for the projected $1.4 trillion (Rs.102 lakh crore) spending on infrastructure does not have projections of investment in infrastructure in Gujarat , as the state government did not care to provide inputs to the task force.

The report states, “Large states yet to provide adequate data (on investment in infrastructure) are Gujarat, West Bengal, Rajasthan and Bihar. Projected peak in annual phasing of investment spend in FY20-21, however, could spill over to FY23-25. Conceptual stage projects include expressways, freight corridors, river inter-linking and renewable energy .”

The report also projected that by 2030, Gujarat’s urbanization level will cross the 50% mark. “By 2030, it is estimated that 5 states – Tamil Nadu, Gujarat, Maharashtra, Karnataka and Punjab – will have >50% urbanisation. Also, the number of metropolitan cities in India is estimated to increase from 46 according to the 2011 census to 68 in 2030. Plugging the deficiency in infrastructure will smoothen the process of urbanization by promoting ease of living and facilitating economic activity. It will thus help in realizing the full potential of the growing urban economy and raise its contribution to GDP,” the report noted.

To achieve this objective, a task force was constituted to draw up the National Infrastructure Pipeline (NIP) for each years from FY 2019-20 to FY 2024-25, with the approval of the finance minister.

Nitin Patel, deputy chief minister and the state government spokesperson, was contacted several times to ask why Gujarat stayed away from sharing data with the government of India on investment in infrastructure in the state, but he did not respond.

Title: Renowned editor, CM’s bro-in-law Mehta dies
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Bhubaneswar: Renowned publisher, chairman and editor-in-chief of Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group Sonny Mehta died in New York on Monday. Mehta, brother-in-law of chief minister Naveen Patnaik and husband of well-known author Gita Mehta, was 77.

The news broke after Naveen took to Twitter on Tuesday morning to express his condolences. “I am deeply grieved by the passing away of my brother in law Sonny Mehta (Husband of my sister Gita Mehta). He was one of the world’s best editors and an extremely civilized person. May his soul rest in peace,” he tweeted. The bereaved chief minister also asked his supporters and well-wishers not to visit his residence to greet him on New Year on Wednesday, said an official communication from the chief minister’s office.

Son of a diplomat, Mehta headed the Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group for more than three decades after joining in 1987. The publishing giant completed its 100 years in 2015.

After completing his schooling at Sanawar School and partially in England, Mehta had graduated from the prestigious Cambridge University. Known as one of the finest editors of the world, Mehta had won many accolades in India, UK and USA. He was named the 2015 Publishers Weekly Person of the Year, said a source in the CMO.

Both Sonny and Gita visited Naveen Niwas, the residence of the chief minister here, in March.

Writers, publishers and leaders mourned Mehta’s death. Prime Minister Narendra Modi also mourned the death of the well-known publisher.

“Sonny Mehta would be fondly remembered by countless avid readers across the world. He endeared himself to many, thanks to his erudite and knowledgable personality. Saddened by his demise. Condolences to Gita Ji, you, your family and his admirers. Om Shanti,” Modi tweeted. In the evening, the Prime Minister also spoke to Naveen over telephone to express his condolence, said CMO sources.

BJP national vice-president Baijayant Panda also took to Twitter to express his condolences over Mehta’s demise. “Deeply saddened at the passing of Ajay Singh Sonny Mehta, world famous publisher & wonderful human being. Condolences to his son, wife Gita, herself an accomplished author, brothers-in-law Prem & @Naveen_Odisha Patnaik, & families. May his soul rest in peace, Om Shanti,” Baijayant wrote on the micro-blogging site.

In his condolence message on Twitter, renowned historian Ramachandra Guha said, “Deeply distressed to hear of the passing of Sonny Mehta. A truly great editor and a wonderfully warm and compassionate human being.”

Title: Odisha: Attempt to sell SUV to cop blows lid off vehicle theft racket
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

BHUBANESWAR: Attempt by a man to sell a stolen SUV to a police officer has landed him behind bars and blown the lid off an inter-state vehicle theft racket in Bhubaneswar.

Special squad of the commissionerate police here on Tuesday arrested Chinmay Sahu, 30, and Gopal Mohanty, 34, for allegedly cheating Sanjay Kumar Sandha, the sub-inspector of Khandagiri police station, while trying to sell him the stolen SUV at a lower price. During investigation, the special squad recovered eight stolen luxury vehicles.

This was perhaps the first time the commissionerate police seized eight stolen luxury vehicles on a single day. Police sources said accused Chinmay Sahu was an MCA degree holder whereas Gopal Mohanty had completed his MBA from a private college in Bhubaneswar. Sahu was staying in a rented house near Sainik School and Mohanty in Nayapalli.

Deputy commissioner of police Anup Kumar Sahoo said seven of the seized vehicles carried West Bengal registration plates while one had an Assam number plate. “We have come to know about another associate of the two accused in Kolkata. They seem to be part of a big gang that has illegal operations (vehicle thefts) in different states. We are in touch with West Bengal police to know details of the gang members in Kolkata,” Sahoo said.

Sandha, the sub-inspector, had lodged a complaint with Laxmisagar police here on December 29 alleging that Sahu approached and urged him to buy an used SUV bearing an Assam registration number at Rs 14 lakh.

In his complaint, Sandha said he paid Rs 8 lakh advance to Sahu and assured to pay the rest only after getting the requisite documents of the vehicles, including NOC from Assam transport authorities. Sandha alleged that Sahu cheated him.

He neither gave the car nor refunded the money, Sandha added.

“Our investigation led to unearthing of a vehicle theft racket. All stolen vehicles carried genuine number plates of other vehicles. We strongly suspect the vehicles were stolen from West Bengal. The chassis numbers of the vehicles were tampered with. We are trying to locate the original owners of the vehicles,” Sahoo said.

Title: SAD, SGPC seek action against Punjab cabinet minister Sukhjinder Singh Randhawa
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Sukhjinder Singh Randhawa

AMRITSAR/LUDHIANA: Shiromani Gurdwara Parbandhak Committee (SGPC) members and Shiromani Akali Dal have sought action against Punjab cabinet minister Sukhjinder Singh Randhawa for his alleged objectionable remarks against the founder of Sikhism, Guru Nanak Dev.

An SGPC delegation has urged acting jathedar of Akal Takht Giani Harpreet Singh, urging him to take action as per Panthic tradition against Punjab cabinet minister Sukhjinder Singh Randhawa. The SGPC delegation also lodged a complaint against the cabinet minister with Amritsar police seeking a case against him under Section 295-A (hurting the sentiments of a community) of the IPC.

SGPC senior vice-president Rajinder Singh Mehta on Tuesday said the delegation handed over a memorandum addressed to the jathedar, seeking action against Randhawa as per Panthic traditions. Mehta said Randhawa had allegedly committed a sacrilege against Guru Nanak Dev. “Everything he spoke is well clear in the viral video,” he said. The SGPC delegation also demanded immediate removal of Randhawa from the cabinet.

SAD senior vice-president Mahesh Inder Singh Grewal said, “A case under Section 295 of the IPC should be registered against Randhawa and the state government should immediately dismiss him from the cabinet. The Congress should apologise to the Sikh sangant for the act.”

Grewal said, “A case was registered within no time when the Christian community complained of sacrilege in Ajnala. And here a senior minister in the Congress government is being protected even though there is enough evidence to register a case. The statement of Randhawa that it is a “ doctored video” can be and should be verified.”

He said, “It’s most unfortunate that the Congress government has miserably failed in protecting the sentiments of the Sikh faith.”

Title: How music can unite us this year
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Ahmedabad will begin the New Year with inaugural hymns rendered by the stalwarts of India’s classical music. Saptak, the country’s longest music conference — spanning 13 days — begins on January 1. TOI speaks to three musicians who will perform at the event.

The themes for their recitals read like programme notes for a cultural phenomenon unique to India: harmony of not only notes but of spiritual energies and of everyday lives of the common people.

“Like flowers, air, water, fire, fragrance, and colours, music doesn’t belong to any religion,” sarod god Ustad Amjad Ali Khan told TOI. “Music and sound connect the world. Language creates barriers. Even today, in the 21st century, we are killing each other because of religion. But swar hi ishwar hai, har raga mein ek atma hai (the musical note is God, every raga contains soul).”

The ustad, who performs at the final baithak on January 3, went on to say: “My family and I feel we belong to all religions of India and the world.”

The Mohan Veena divinity, Pandit Vishwa Mohan Bhatt, presented the same flourish of hope. “The seven musical notes are common across the world,” Pandit Bhatt told TOI. “Otherwise, there are so many differences — of religions, cultures, and languages. But music can bring peace and love to the world.” Pandit Bhatt’s recital is scheduled on January 12.

“Music knows no religion, language, or boundaries,” Viraj Amar told TOI. She is an Ahmedabad vocalist and a disciple of Banaras Gharana titans Pandits Rajan and Sajan Mishra. “Music knows only love and peace; and the intrinsic need of all living beings is ultimately love,” she said. Her recital is on January 3 at the first baithak.

Title: Woman attacks mom at Salt Lake home
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: A woman allegedly hit her mother on her head with a hammer after a disagreement between the two on Tuesday morning. The mother-daughter duo had returned to their Salt Lake home from Bengaluru last week. Her father, a former engineer, was not at home when the incident took place.

Officers of Bidhanagar South police station went to the spot after neighbours informed them and shifted the injured woman, in her mid-60s, to a hospital and detained the daughter. According to the cops, the accused was grappling with a few psychological issues. “The family had shifted to Bengaluru a few years ago where the daughter works. They returned to their home last week,” said an officer.

Security guards and neighbours informed the cops that they heard the mother and daughter quarrelling on Monday night as well as on Tuesday morning. “When we reached the spot we found the mother lying in a pool of blood and the daughter sitting beside her with a hammer. She admitted that she had attacked her mother,” said the officer, adding that the father had left home a couple of days ago after a quarrel with the daughter. “Her mother had suffered injury on her head. Her condition is critical,” said the officer.

Title: Rs 900 crore bogus billing scam: SGST department arrests kingpin
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: In connection with the Rs 900-crore fake billing scam , the enforcement wing of the state goods and services tax ( SGST ) department arrested Paresh Nathalal Chauhan on Monday evening. Chauhan, an Ahmedabad businessman, was found to be operating 72 shell companies, 36 of which were registered under the value added tax (VAT) regime and the remaining were registered under the goods and services tax (GST) regime.Chauhan was produced before a local court in Ahmedabad on Tuesday and the department sought his remand for 14 days. According to SGST department officials, Chauhan had created bogus bills worth Rs 900 crore which were used to evade taxes to the tune of Rs 100 crore. Bogus bills worth Rs 427.28 crore were made under the GST regime with which Rs 60.73 crore in taxes were evaded.The department had been probing the case since October 2019 and Chauhan had been absconding till then.“Since one person can’t be operating 72 companies, we expect the involvement of more people. The investigation is still under way,” said C M Trivedi, additional commissioner, SGST department. “When the firms operated by Chauhan were investigated, several incriminating documents, pen drives, and hard disks were found.”Trivedi said that investigating officers suspect that the fake bills were circulated to companies within and outside Gujarat.After the new tax regime was rolled out, fake billing scams have been on the rise. According to SGST department officials, bogus billing scams to the tune of Rs 10,900 crore have been reported in 2019. In these cases, the state exchequer lost Rs 1,600 crore in taxes.

Title: Punjab: Brace for another rise in power tariff in April
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

PATIALA: After a 30 paise per unit hike in power tariff, the electricity consumers in Punjab are staring at another rise in electricity rates within next three months. The Punjab State Power Corporation Limited (PSPCL) has filed a petition with the state power regulator seeking a 14% increase in tariff for the next fiscal to balance the revenue and expenditure. The recent rise in the price was on the account of PSPCL shelling out Rs 1,490 crore to pay private power companies as coal washing charges.

In the annual revenue requirement (ARR) petition before the Punjab State Electricity Regulatory Commission (PSERC), the discom has submitted that there was a need to generate Rs 37,250 crore in the next financial year. It would leave a gap of Rs 4,545 crore in its balance sheet and as the power corporation has no other means gather funds, it wants the cost of power to go up by 14%.

PSERC has asked the power corporation to furnish some additional details after which it would be holding a public hearing before announcing the next hike in April. There is also a carry forward of Rs 7,728 crore from the previous years and the accumulated deficit as on March 31, 2020, would be around Rs 11,179.66 crore. The corporation has bifurcated this amount over the next two years to avoid a massive hike in power tariffs.

Last year, PSPCL had sought an 8% to 14% hike on various categories of consumers. However, the regulator had allowed only 2.14% hike, after which the energy charges for various categories of domestic consumers increased by 8 paise a unit and now stands between Rs 4.99 and Rs 7.11 per unit (depending on usages and load). For non-residential power supply, the cost had increased by 5 paise per unit, and the cost of power for the industries was increased by 8-10 paise per unit.

As the regulator has allowed a 30 paise hike for domestic connections and 29 p a unit for industrial connections, which would be charged during the next 12 months beginning January 1, the next hike could swell the power cost by more than half a rupee per unit. As per the AAR, the average cost of power now is Rs 6.62 per unit and PSPCL has sought to raise it this figure Rs 7.26 per unit for next fiscal.

PSPCL has tried to balance out the increase by proposing a 15% reduction in the energy charges for the domestic category for the first 100 units, besides requesting the regulator not to cross-subsidise the agricultural power supply.

To improve its financial health, the power corporation has also requested the regulator to issue 75% amount of the power subsidies in the first half of the year, and the remaining 25% in the last six months. At present, the government is supposed to pay the power subsidies in 12 equal instalments to the PSPCL.

Title: Delhi: Highway robbers meet their match
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

The patrol trucks can be spotted from a distance around GT Karnal Road, Madhuban Chowk, Britannia Chowk and Mu... Read More

NEW DELHI: Delhi Police has decided to go for dedicated highway patrol teams at night with armoured mini-trucks to crack down on robbers . The northwest district police is the first to start with five patrolling teams.

Tata 407 vans, which were earlier used by Delhi Police mainly to transport barricades and move personnel, have been modified with a hatch-mounted firing port and a specially designed armour to protect personnel from bullets or stones thrown by criminals during a chase. Nine personnel, who are part of each unit, are equipped with long-range weapons such as AK-47s, INSAS rifles and MP5 guns.

“We realised that the vehicles were underutilised and decided to give them a makeover. The vehicles were painted and fitted with reflective strips and a siren. The roof has been cut open on two sides to allow officers to stand for a bird’s-eye view of the area they are patrolling. Each of our five subdivisions has one such vehicle now,” said Vijayanta Arya, DCP (northwest).

The vans, which have been patrolling the areas for the past two weeks, can be spotted from a distance around GT Karnal Road, Madhuban Chowk, Britannia Chowk, Mukarba Chowk and other roads leading to the highways even during fog because of their luminous paint. The officers, who wear reflective jackets, are also equipped with riot gears and ropes to handle any law and order situation.

A drop in the number of calls regarding heinous crimes during the night has been visible since the patrolling has started, an officer claimed.

Delhi Police also has a fleet of motorcycles patrolling the roads. But the decision to go for the armoured vans was taken after it was noticed that because of the fast moving carriageways in northwest Delhi, robbers, such as those from Mewat, were having an easy escape. The low visibility during the fog season is also used by robbers as a cover. Now the vans, on the road from the midnight to the wee hours, are increasing the police presence on the highways.

Title: Bhopal rings in 2020 at Upper Lake
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

dsf

BHOPAL: New Year celebrations in the City of Lakes reached a crescendo on Tuesday as the Boat Club was filled with Bhopalis watching a light and sound show that was followed by a spectacular dance performance by Zenith dance troupe form Delhi.

The stage shined with colourful lights as artistes overwhelmed the crowd. The evening’s performance began with a ‘Ganesh Vandana’ by the Delhi-based dance troupe followed by semi-classical dance performance on Bollywood numbers such as ‘Mohe rang do laal’ and Sufi dance on ‘Khwaja mere khwaja’ that were well received by the audience.

The real celebrations began when the 34 dancers rocked the stage with peppy dance numbers such as ‘London Thumakda’ and Punjabi songs that filled the atmosphere with high energy. During the performance, a 3D water projection created images of Lord Ganesha and Sufi saints with disco lights.

Puneet Kapur from the dance troupe told TOI that the artistes created the images for the projections and submitted them to the organisers.

Members of the Agnee band from Pune played everything form soulful music to Kabir songs to the delight of the audience. The crowd swayed with the music and had a good time.

Bhopalis also savoured on delicious street foods at the food carnival set up at on the road especially for the occasion.

“This is an amazing celebration that we got to witness today. The chill and the beauty of the performance along with tasty food added to the cheer. I had a great time with my family”, said Rajeev Tripathi, a businessman.

The 3D laser projection show was loved by the visitors who stood on selected spots near the fence of the lake to get a good view.

“The 3D show was extraordinary. Never in my life had I imagined that something so good can be witnessed here in Bhopal . I had heard of such laser shows in other big cities, but watching it in my city was a totally different experience”, said Pragya Shrivastav, a student who came to watch the show with her group of college friends.

Title: Punjab: Resignations pile up as BSP faces internal bickering, again
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

JALANDHAR: Hit by poor performance in the elections in Punjab, BSP’s state unit appears to be facing a fresh phase of internal bickering. After 15 office-bearers Sangrur district unit of the party resigned from their posts recently, now BSP state secretary Sukhwinder Singh Kotli has also quit.

In his resignation letter, Kotli said the party workers who were not behaving like sycophants were being insulted and party leadership was not sincere to the Dalit movement. He has said that he would continue working as an ordinary worker of the party as he had been doing for the last 34 years. Kotli was BSP Phagwara nominee in 2012 assembly elections and Jalandhar candidate in the 2014 parliamentary polls.

Two days ago, state general secretary Makhan Singh and over a dozen other office-bearers of various districts resigned from their offices. They had hosted former Delhi MLA Sandeep Valmiki, who had been expelled from party. Meanwhile, Valmiki also attended a programme at Phillaur on Tuesday where Kotli was also present.

When asked, Punjab BSP unit president Jasbir Singh Garhi rubbished Kotli’s allegations. Garhi also said he got Kotli appointed as the state secretary and then also included him in the panel which would represent the party at important platforms to take up different issues.

Title: With hospital closed, consumer court rejects claim
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Only one person working 24x7 at a closed hospital in Surat, resulted in the rejection of insurance claims made for repeated hospitalizations.

Gujarat State Consumer Dispute Redressal Commission quashed orders passed by the Surat consumer forum ordering Apollo Munich Health Insurance Co Ltd to pay consumers for hospitalizations in 2010-11 at one particular hospital.

The consumer commission quashed an order for payment of Rs 30,000 and Rs 24,000 to Shailesh Italiya for his two stints at Panchratna Hospital in the Udhna area. The commission upheld the insurance company’s claim that the hospital had been locked for nearly six months when Italiya claimed repeated hospitalizations for malaria.

The commission said that just one person is shown monitoring the patient for more than a week every time. The monitoring sheet reflected that it was filled in by the treating person. He was the only one who attended to the patient for 24 hours every day. This continuous monitoring by one person is not possible for 11 days. This showed that this was a fraudulent claim.

The commission observed this while reversing the forum’s order on claims made by a couple of other persons as well. Suresh Koshia’s wife was hospitalized at the same hospital, for which he claimed Rs 24,000, and later Rs 16,000 for his daughter’s hospitalization.

Similarly, Arvind Lukhi’s wife was admitted to the hospital in May 2011 for malaria. The forum ordered the insurer to pay the expenses, but the commission quashed the order only on the grounds that it was not believable that only one person could continuously attend to the patient for days together.

Title: Disqualification: Ex-AAP MLAs seek time
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Chandigarh: A decision on the petitions seeking disqualification of the former AAP functionaries who had switched parties ahead of the Lok Sabha elections could linger further on. At the end of the December 31 deadline given for filing their replies, none of the three MLAs had done so.

The three MLAs — Sukhpal Singh Khaira, Amarjit Singh Sandoa and Baldev Singh — were given time by the Punjab speaker to respond to the petitions to seek their disqualifications.

According to sources, in his e-mail, Khaira has sought more time pointing out that he was tied up with a family function, while Sandoa has sought a copy of the relevant legislations. Meanwhile, Baldev, in his reply, has said that the petition against him had been withdrawn by the complainant. Recently, Baldev, who was elected from Jaito on an AAP ticket, had returned to the party fold after joining the Punjabi Ekta Party (PEP) floated by Khaira. tnn

Title: Delhi: Wind gains speed, helps air quality improve a bit
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Delhi’s air quality returned to the “very poor” category on Tuesday. (File photo)

NEW DELHI: After recording three consecutive days of “severe” pollution , Delhi’s air quality returned to the “very poor” category on Tuesday. The overall Air Quality Index ( AQI ) was 387 as per the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) data.

Delhi’s AQI had touched 446 on Monday – a day when Delhi recorded dense fog and its lowest maximum temperature in 118 years. Experts say an increase in wind speed has helped disperse pollutants and prevent dense fog formation, and pollution levels are likely to go down further in the next 48 hours.

Track the pollution level in your city

“Wind speeds have increased to around 15 km/hr, helping in the dispersal of fog and pollutants. Easterly winds are expected to continue influencing the region in the next couple of days, which will lead to a rise in temperature that will check pollution. Wind speeds could pick up to 20-25 km/hr on January 2, so further improvement is expected,” said Kuldeep Srivastava, head of IMD’s regional centre.

The System of Air Quality and Weather Forecasting And Research (SAFAR) says “very calm” wind conditions, which had been prevailing over the last three days, have finished and wind speed is expected to increase further. “The AQI is forecast to improve to the middle-end of the very poor category by the New Year day. Further significant improvement in AQI towards the lower-end of very poor to poor category is expected by January 2,” said SAFAR.

The top three pollution hotspots for Wednesday are likely to be Badarpur, AIIMS/Adarsh Nagar and Rohini.

Data according to the CPCB’s central control room showed a significant dip in Delhi-NCR’s average PM 2.5 and PM 10 levels on Tuesday.

Title: Odisha CM announces Rs 50 crore package for Rajendra University
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Odisha chief minister Naveen Patnaik.

BALANGIR: Chief minister Naveen Patnaik on Tuesday announced a package of Rs 50 crore for the development of Rajendra University at the closing ceremony of its platinum jubilee celebration in Balangir .

The fund will be utilized to build an administrative building, auditorium, academic block, library, staff quarters and other necessary facilities.

Former Rajya Sabha MP A U Singhdeo recently wrote a letter to the CM urging him to allocate funds to the university for the development of its infrastructure. The people of the district lauded the CM’s announcement.

“Former chief minister and erstwhile Patna Maharaj Rajendra Narayan Singhdeo had immense contribution in setting up this great institution. It has been spreading the light of education in this part of Odisha . It is like a heritage institution,” Naveen said.

Patnaik greeted the people and expressed his pleasure at having joined the joyous occasion. The CM said his government was committed to developing the institution so it could successfully cater to the aspirations of young people in the region.

Women and child development minister Tukuni Sahu, chief secretary Asit Tripathy, Khandapada MLA Soumyaranjan Patnaik and Singhdeo were also present at the event.

Title: Flier from Muscat held with 2kg gold
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: In another case of gold smuggling by air, Ahmedabad customs nabbed a flier with smuggled gold at the Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International (SVPI) airport in the wee hours of Monday. Airport sources confirmed that a male flier was found to be in possession of 2kg of gold.

“The flier arrived from Muscat early on Monday morning. Officials of the air intelligence unit (AIU) found the passenger’s movements and body language suspicious and based on spot intelligence, examined the passenger,” said a top source.

With the gold price in Ahmedabad at Rs 40,435 per 10g on Tuesday, the value of the seized gold was Rs 80.87 lakh. Sources said the passenger was carrying the gold as a belt under his trousers. He was immediately detained and handed over to customs.

Currently, the passenger is being interrogated and further probe is under way.

In November, two major consignments of a total of 5kg gold were seized by customs at SVPI. In the first case, around 3kg was seized from a passenger travelling from Bangkok to Ahmedabad, and the second case involved 1.8kg gold was seized from a passenger who arrived from Abu Dhabi . Both passengers have been arrested. From April to December 2019, a total of 70kg of gold was seized at SVPI airport in Ahmedabad in 65 separate cases.

Title: Bizman held for fake plaint
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Chennai: Police have arrested a man, who runs a logistics firm in Ambattur, for lodging a false complaint that he was kidnapped by a history-sheeter called Dil Pandian and two others, at the Maduravoyal police station.

In a twist to the kidnap complaint by Mukesh, 33, the businessman , the Maduravoyal police arrested him and his driver on robbery charges after an investigation revealed that no abduction took place as he claimed. Police said Mukesh of Ayapakkam and his driver Om Prasath, 29, are co-accused in the murder of Dhanasekaran last year and face several cases, including robbery and extortion. Police have launched a hunt for one more person, Dil Pandian, also a murder accused. Police said a quarrel erupted between them under the influence of alcohol in the wee hours of Sunday when they were travelling in Mukesh’s car. While Mukesh got down and lodged a complaint that he was kidnapped, police later found that Dil Pandian and Om Prasath left his car and cellphones at his house in Ayapakkam. TNN

Title: Action Replay 2019: From new laws to new lows, Campuses burn
Content:
While protests overwhelmed Jawaharlal Nehru University at frequent intervals, Delhi University and Jamia Milli... Read More

NEW DELHI: The universities in the capital had a particularly eventful year in 2019. While protests overwhelmed Jawaharlal Nehru University at frequent intervals, Delhi University and Jamia Millia Islamia too saw a lot of ferment. The ripple effect was felt in several other institutes of higher education . Academic activities, even exams, made way for heated arguments about both institutional administration and national policies.JNU was the theatre of the most strident protests. If the fight against the ban on entry to the Parthasarathy Rocks and the legal drama surrounding the students’ union polls were raucous enough, the real furore began on October 28, when the students stood up against the hike in hostel fees. It was a stand-off that caught attention across India and caused a headache for the Union human resource ministry.The hostel fees issue took on the dimension of “commercialisation of education” and “anti-student government policies” and students across the country lent support to the fight. After the talks between the JNU administration and the rebels reached a deadlock, the HRD ministry stepped in, but it too failed to resolve the issues as December rolled into 2020. The confrontation at the university reached a high point with the students boycotting the semester examinations, forcing the administration to scramble for alternative means such as conducting exams on WhatsApp and email. Such ideas only earned the scorn of the teachers, who by and large also wrangled with the authorities through the year.In Delhi University, teachers gave protest a new meaning on December 4 by storming the vice-chancellor’s office, housed in what was once the abode of ultimate authority, the Vice Regal Lodge. The cause of war was the termination of ad hoc teachers. DU ’s letter of August 28 mandated only the appointment of guest teachers against vacancies arising for the first time in the current academic session, leading to halting of salaries of a few. Though the HRD ministry offered relief to the university’s ad hoc teachers last week, the issue of their absorption may perhaps find resolution only in 2020.In between, there was a hubbub in October over the alleged whitewashing of the Azadi Wall at Ambedkar University Delhi, proudly painted till then in the rainbow colours of the LGBTQIA community.As the year came to an end, the focus turned to Jamia Millia University, where a series of protests against the Citizenship Amendment Act and National Register of Citizens led to violence on December 15 and alleged illegal presence of police on the campus. Initially called by Jamia teachers, the protest rode on student power to gain mass following across the country. Several institutions, including IIT-Delhi, and eminent individuals rose up in solidarity. Among them, alumnus Rahul Roy said, “I am proud that Jamia is where the movement against CAA began.”

Title: Meenakshi Lekhi makes poll pitch by rooting for new law
Content:
Meenakshi Lekhi

Lekhi argued that the protesters were being misguided by Opposition

Lekhi argued that the

protesters

were being misguided by Opposition.

NEW DELHI: Meenakshi Lekhi , the BJP MP from New Delhi, on Tuesday started her election campaign in Delhi Cantonment assembly constituency by advocating the Citizenship Amendment Act .More than a thousand people had gathered at Kranti Chowk , in Sadar Bazar to hear the arguments of Lekhi and several senior ex-servicemen, including lieutenant general JBS Yadav, regarding CAA, which has caused controversy and led to agitations across the country.Lekhi argued that the protesters were being misguided by opposition parties and CAA only favoured persecuted minorities from neighbouring Islamic countries. She pointed out that no new refugees were covered by CAA, while also alleging that the protests had a foreign hand behind them. She compared the problems faced by minorities in these countries with“ISIS-like brutalities”.“CAA is for the oppressed minorities facing atrocities in Pakistan, Afghanistan and Bangladesh. Twitter trends show that foreign powers are involved in the protests. Two Twitter trends were running last night. While #IsupportCAA was being run by users from within India, another trend saying India doesn’t support CAA was being run by users in Pakistan and parts of America and Africa,” Lekhi said.The MP said, “Anti-social elements had instigated riots and set afire public property. Opposition parties have been saying that your citizenship is being threatened, but CAA is not going to affect any Indian citizen. There have been instances of forced conversions, religious violence and destruction of places of worship in the neighbouring countries. These persecuted people are being helped by giving some relaxations through this law.”Lekhi urged each person in the gathering to make at least 10 people understand the provisions of CAA. “Rumours are being spread regarding National Register of Citizens, which is going to be implemented to prevent intruders from entering India and carrying out acts of terror,” she added.Citing the example of persecuted Jews to support her argument, Lekhi said, “There has been significant fall in the number of minorities in the neighbouring countries. When Jews faced such persecution, a large number of countries gave them citizenship. Nobody at that time argued that Christians should also be given citizenship by these countries. If there is no equal persecution, there cannot be equal rules for relaxation in citizenship norms.”

Title: Delving into sounds, smells of heritage
Content:
The researchers found that traffic sounds were increasingly drowning all ambient noises at Sambhavnathni Pol, ... Read More

AHMEDABAD: Did you know how your past smelt or what sounds are attached to it? Do only old dilapidated intricately carved wooden havelis qualify as heritage? How do odours, sights or sounds stir collective memories and help a community engage with its own culture and history?To find answers to these questions, a joint team of students from Cept University and University of New South Wales, Australia, explored Zaveriwad , one of the oldest areas in Ahmedabad’s Walled City, and asked local residents to recall their memories of smells, sounds and voices from their past. Recordings were kept of the responses.The researchers found that traffic sounds were increasingly drowning all ambient noises at Sambhavnath ni Pol, Ambli Pol, Waghan Pol and Chaumukhji ni Pol covered under the study – making them indistinguishable from other parts of the city. In earlier times one usually heard the chirping of birds from the bird feeders (chabutara) sounds of women making meals and the usual chatter at the crossroads in the pols. A few also remembered the jeweller workshops and the sounds of the ‘derasar’ (Jain temple) where locals prayed and performed rituals.“Memory is a powerful tool that stays with people even when the tangible heritage is gone. We learned that many citizens, now settled elsewhere in Ahmedabad, still identify themselves with their respective pols. It distinguishes Ahmedabad, making it a living and breathing heritage city,” said Gauri Bharat, associate professor and head of the architectural history programme at Faculty of Architecture, Cept University.The students were exploring processes for identification, protection and conservation of these sensory experiences.Bharat said the area was selected for its rich history and Jain traditions. “The students talked to locals about their memory in terms of sound and sights. One of the responses recorded that a man had associated his pol with sounds of a next-door derasar and the trains at Kalupur which could be heard distinctly during quieter night hours,” she said.A group of students also mapped the distribution of activities in the area and studied the local culture and ethos. An exhibition based on the project was organized recently at Chaumukhji ni Pol.A pictorial representation of various pols by the Australian students mapped day-to-day activities, oft-spoken phrases and distinctive features such as subterranean derasar offering visitors a view of only the face of the Tirthankar. Participants said that Jain sadhvis explained the socio-religious nature of the area.Prof Ramji Savaliya, the former director of the BJ Institute of Learning and Research, said that the area is distinct in the history of Walled City of Ahmedabad due to its association with prominent citizens such as Shantidas Zaveri and affluent jewellers. “Even during the Mughal era, one finds records mentioning guards outside the pols for the security of the ‘wealth of the city.’ The area has retained some of its features even today,” he said.

Title: Highest in three years: 28,000 visit Vandalur zoo on Sunday
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Arignar Anna Zoological park in Vandalur

CHENNAI: With vacations for schools and colleges and ahead of the new year holiday, Vandalur zoo, among the favourite leisure destinations for many in the city, has been registering high footfalls over the past couple of days. On Sunday , the zoo received 28,000-plus visitors — the highest in the last three years.

Zoo managers attribute the spike in the number of visitors to the holidays of educational institutions and to the opening of the Otteri lake on the zoo premises. The lake has turned into a major attraction, said an official.

Talking about the number of visitors, the official said during the same day last year, 16,212 people visited the zoo. In 2017, the number of visitors was only 10,463. This year, the zoo received 28,262 visitors on December 29, a 77% rise, compared to 2018. Compared to the 2017 number, the rise is 174%, said the official.

In the last 10 days, the zoo received 1.32 lakh visitors. It was 1.06 lakh last year and the year before last, it was only 96,000. This clearly showed that the zoo has turned into a major attraction for visitors, said an official.

To provide better facilities to visitors, the zoo has hired two more battery-operated carts, another official said. It already has a dozen of them. These include eight battery carts with a seating capacity of 14, three with a capacity of eight seats and a six-seat cart. Except for the six-seat vehicle, the rest are used for public transportation. The six-seater is for visits by the director and deputy director with range officers to inspect various works.

Title: Delhi: Thieves drill hole into post office, get just Rs 487 in coins
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Police said the men drilled a hole in the wall behind the safe, and suspect that they might have been helped b... Read More

NEW DELHI: Thieves broke into a post office and got less than what they bargained for. They broke a safe and fled with a cash bag from Mansarovar , only to find that the bag contained a measly Rs 487 in coins that was left by the cashier the previous day.

Police said the men drilled a hole in the wall behind the safe, and suspect that they might have been helped by a child who worked at the office gate. The place had no security guards at the time of the incident, they added.

The officials discovered the theft on Monday morning when the deputy post master reached the locker room and found it ransacked. During inspection, he spotted the hole dug on the wall. The thieves used an iron rod to open the locker. However, the accountant had emptied it last Friday and had left coins in a bag behind.

In the complaint, the deputy post master told the cops that the office was shut around 5.30pm on Saturday. The cops suspect that the thieves would have scaled the boundary wall behind the building to gain entry. They added that hole in the wall was more than 15 inches thick, which would have taken the accused at least an hour to drill.

A case of trespassing and burglary has been registered and a probe initiated. Police said there were no CCTV cameras focused on the area through which the thieves gained entry into the office.

Title: No respite from jams, police may open one arm of Kalindi Kunj road
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Traffic diversions at Kalindi Kunj in the wake of the protests against Citizenship Amendment Act have made tra... Read More

NEW DELHI: Traffic diversions at Kalindi Kunj in the wake of the protests against Citizenship Amendment Act have made travelling between Delhi and Noida a nightmare.

DND Flyway and the Chilla route in Noida have witnessed a sudden rise in the volume of traffic given that over three lakh vehicles use them via the Mahamaya-Kalindi Kunj road on a weekday. Commuters get regularly stuck in snarls on the DND-Maharani Bagh stretch. A pileup on DND has become a regular feature, even during non-peak hours.

Delhi Police is now trying to explore the option of opening one carriageway of Kalindi Kunj road. Residents of Shaheen Bagh, who have been blocking the road for the past two weeks with the help of grilles uprooted from the central median, have refused to vacate the stretch and shift their protest to another location.

Last week, police had roped in local religious leaders to reach a settlement with the protesters. Senior officers said a forceful removal would spark tension in the area that has already been volatile since the violence at Jamia Millia Islamia on December 15. Most protesters TOI spoke to were adamant about not shifting to another location since they felt that moving away from Kalindi Kunj road would dilute their cause.

Vehicles going towards Noida are being diverted through Mathura Road to reach Ashram and take DND Flyway. To avoid the mess at Ashram, many drivers have been taking a detour via Noida Link Road from Akshardham. However, even this route gets choked during peak hours since it caters to most of the traffic from east Delhi.

Apart from cars, more than 5,000 trucks heading to Okhla Industrial Area pass through Kalindi Kunj. They are now being diverted through Ashram leading to a mess at the crossing due to the construction of an underpass going towards Nizamuddin.

Traffic police said the jams on DND Flyway are being caused by a 50% increase in the volume of vehicles travelling between Noida and Delhi. “Opening one carriageway will partially reduce this snarl,” said a police officer.

Commuters complained that their travelling time has more than doubled. Sanjay Sinha, a mechanical engineer from Noida working with a private firm in Jasola Vihar, would usually leave home around 9am to reach office 30 minutes later. However, these days he’s been leaving by around 7am. He manages to make it to work just in time.

The resultant delay has had a cascading effect on working hours. A few private firms have asked employees who come late to work to make up for the lost time by staying back in the evening. Those travelling to Jasola, Okhla, Sarita Vihar, Mithapur and Jaitpur are the most troubled as they have to take long detours.

RK Shahi, who has been taking an 18-km detour to reach his office in Faridabad Sector 24, said, “I have to travel from Greater Noida to Eastern Peripheral Expressway and reach my office through several rural areas. The distance from my home to office is 57km via Kalindi Kunj. After the diversion, it is now 75km.”

Title: NMC students to get free sanitary pads
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Nagpur: The Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) will provide sanitary pads to all needy students free of cost and disposal units at its schools.

The decision was taken after a survey conducted by NGO Amhi Amchya Arogyasathi.

Additional municipal commissioner Ram Joshi told TOI sanitary pads will be provided to around 3,500 students and disposal units to around 28 schools. “The NGO, after interacting with girl students in all NMC schools, had noticed that many girls skip school during menstruation cycle. To curb absenteeism due to this, Amhi Amchya Arogyasathi suggested providing sanitary pads to girl students free of cost. NMC will start providing sanitary pads as much as possible from now onwards. Schools will be allotted stock by making budgetary provisions from next fiscal,” he said.

Joshi said the NGO has also suggested improvements in the condition of toilets, which too will be done as early as possible.

Chairperson of women and child welfare consultative committee Sangita Girhe said she would explore possibilities to provide funds for free sanitary pads and disposal units from available the allocation for the committee.

Meanwhile, the civic body, in association with the NGO, organized an interactive session at Sane Guruji High School on Friday. Team leaders from all schools, education officer Priti Mishrikotkar, headmasters/headmistress, teachers etc were present. All presented their demands before the NMC officials and office-bearers.

Amhi Amchya Arogyasathi has already started to conduct workshops in NMC schools to spread awareness about various issues concerning girl students under its drive — ‘Nai Disha’. The NGO is working in various parts of Gadchiroli district for the same cause for the last few years.

Title: Glowing balloons, headbands & halos cut a sparkling red carpet for the New Year
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Pune: The city streets saw a surge of all things bright and flashy as thousands of Punekars stepped out of their homes, dressed in their best, to ring in the New Year with friends and family.

Twinning the spirit of the people, establishments across the city were also steeped in glittering lights to woo patrons.

Some arterial roads, including MG Road, JM Road and FC Road, were also bedecked, with fairy lights twinkling on street furniture and trees. Balloons could be seen bobbing over a sea of people as numerous vendors positioned themselves by the streets. LED balloons, LED hairbands, glow headbands, halos and many items found space on the pavements as the street hawkers reached the spot sensing good business.

While a number of people opted to enjoy parties away from the city or at various hotels and restaurants, many preferred to celebrate at home to avoid chaos. IT professional Snehal Ghate (25), who hails from Amravati, will be ringing in the New Year away from home for the first time. She plans to celebrate with her three flatmates in Baner. “My roommates and I have organized a small celebration just among the four of us. Since this is my first New Year away from my family, I thought I would be miserable but I am thankful, that they are around and we will celebrate it together, by cutting cake and wine. It will be like welcoming the New Year with my new family,” she said.

Clubs across the city saw patrons waiting to get into the party mood as loud music boomed in the surrounding areas. Local resident Prashant Pawar said, “My friends have come to Pune from various cities this year. Instead of having a house party, we are going clubbing to ring in the New Year. We have booked a car and driver so that we don’t have to drive in an intoxicated condition.”

Title: Action Replay 2019: Police force stretched, found wanting
Content:
File photo used for representational purpose

NEW DELHI: Crowd management by Delhi Police, which included handling violent confrontations, had to be intensified this year as the number of major protests rose to 94 compared with around 70 in the previous years. Social media and rumours fuelled flare-ups, the intensity of which police failed to anticipate, leading to loss of public property.“We adopted laid-down procedures and a graded approach in dealing with protests. However, managing rumours and social media was a major challenge,” accepted Delhi Police PRO Mandeep Singh Randhawa. With Jantar Mantar off-limit, protesters gathered in other parts of the city and the demonstrations escalated after police stopped them from marching to the high-security zones in Lutyens’ Delhi.The biggest challenge to police came in December when the Citizenship Amendment Act evoked intense passions. At Jamia Millia Islamia, half a dozen buses were burnt or damaged and police clashed with students. There were similar confrontations in Seelampur and Daryaganj.The first violent protest occurred in August when police tried to disperse a group of doctors protesting against the National Medical Commission Bill on Aurobindo Marg in south Delhi. In the ensuing clash, several doctors and policemen were injured.Later that month, there was violence when the cops failed to anticipate the magnitude of resentment after a Guru Ravidas temple built on government land was demolished. Protesters not only blocked central Delhi for hours, but slipped past security to reach the proscribed temple site. Several passers-by, policemen and protesters were injured in the stone pelting.Retired additional commissioner SBS Tyagi, a veteran of violent protests during his tenure as DCP (New Delhi), said that dealing with demonstrators required patience and a strong approach. “No matter what, the protesters must be made aware of the limit they shouldn’t cross. Anyone trying to break the law should be dealt with accordingly,” he added.Delhi Police faced the test in a clash with lawyers at Tis Hazari Courts in November. The furious melee led to several police officers being suspended. There were videos going viral on social media showing lawyers thrashing policemen. This was followed by an unprecedented protest by the outraged policemen from the lower ranks, who gathered in strength to demand their senior officers back them instead of taking disciplinary action against them.

Title: Cops’ witty tweets win hearts of netizens
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Pune: One does not usually associate men in khaki with light-hearted banter. But, the Pune police on Tuesday proved otherwise with a volley of funny tweets and responses.

The police had tweeted, “Charas, Ganja, Meow Meow. #NewYearResolution 2020 madhe he sarva nako bhau! #SayNoToDrugs” (Charas, Ganja, Meow Meow. Don’t include all this in your #NewYearResolution 2020 brother! #SayNoToDrugs).

It was followed by a bone tickling exchange between numerous citizens and the police which earned the latter brownie points from across the country.

A Twitter user responded, “Guys LSD is allowed”, to which the Pune police’s Twitter handle replied, “Tell us where to find it?”

Another Twitter user jumped into the conversation stating, “Agar maine aap logo ko adda bataya toh 10 pudiya meri? Chalega na sir?” (If I tell you where it is sold, I’ll take 10 packets? Is that okay sir?). The police continued with their witty comebacks. It said, “Aap saare rakh lena. Hum bas aapko rakh lenge. Chalega na sir?” (You keep everything. We will keep you. Is that okay sir?)

In another conversation that stemmed from the tweet, a user said, “Mujhe bhi chahiye” (Even I want it) and the response stated, “Your place or ours?” The user replied, “Your place is just like one-way ticket like God’s place”, to which the department said, “We promise to be great hosts.”

Another user joined in on the conversation saying, “I love and prefer GSD (German Shephard Dog)”. The police replied, “Paw’sibly the best choice indeed.”

The original tweet and responses garnered hundreds of likes and retweets from across the country. A Twitter user said, “This thread is simply outstanding. It is a lesson for all police departments of our country how to engage with the youth.” Another user said, “You’ve won the internet today.”

The thread left citizens wondering who was engaging in the conversation from the police.

The Pune police commissioner K Venkatesham said, “There is no one person behind these tweets. The Pune police must be credited for this. Sometimes they run the tweets and responses by me. I, too, was following the conversation on Twitter on Tuesday, alongside my work.”

Title: 14 hospital staffers stuck in elevator, relief after 2 hours
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Pune: Fourteen employees of Noble Hospital, including nurses, were trapped in a lift at a commercial complex located at Hadapsar on Tuesday morning. The fire brigade personnel rescued them around 10am, after a two-hour ordeal.

The four-storied commercial complex, located near Noble Hospital, consists of hospital units, a nursing hostel and shops.

The maximum carrying capacity of the lift is eight persons. However, 14 people residing in the hostel had entered the lift together. The lift was on its way to the ground floor when it was trapped between the first and second floors around 8am.

The alarm raised by the people trapped in the lift created a panic situation in the complex. The complex authorities responsible for maintaining the lift pressed technicians into service to bring the elevator to the ground floor but the effort was unsuccessful.

A medical officer from the hospital called the fire brigade around 9am. Since the Hadapsar fire brigade was on emergency duty at Shewalwadi, a fire tender from Kondhwa substation and an ambulance rushed to the spot to handle the emergency situation around 9.22am.

The firemen ensured that there was no ventilation issue in the lift. They also provided water to the people and consoled them, telling them they would be rescued soon.

Fire officer Shivaji Chavan said, “We rushed to the fourth floor and found that the rope of the lift had come out from the pulley. We then sought assistance from the technicians and got the rope fixed to the pulley. Then the lift was slowly brought down and stopped at a distance of 2ft above the ground floor so as to prevent it from crashing to the floor. Finally, all 14 people were able to come out of the lift safely with the help of a stool. No one was injured. ”

Chavan added, “The lift has a capacity of six persons. It can sustain up to 500kg at a time. As many as 14 people, weighing around 1,500kg, had squeezed into the lift disregarding safety instructions. The lift was trapped because the people ignored the safety norms. If they had exercised precaution, the incident could have been averted.”

The hospital shared information of the incident with the fire brigade after an hour, Chavan pointed out. “Had they alerted us immediately, we would have rescued them in the shortest possible time,” he said.

The hospital’s medical director, Dilip Mane, told TOI, “The lift is maintained by the commercial complex, not by Noble Hospital. The lift is also used by private persons. The incident happened because of overloading as the nurses were in a hurry to report to work. The technicians also played a key role in rescuing the nurses from the lift.”

Title: Chennai News - Times of India
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Chennai: A sub-registrar at Tiruttani , about 90 km from the city, has been suspended from service for registering 50 acres in three settlement deeds at an inflated rate of Rs 11 ,191 crore an acre , against the guideline value of Rs 24 lakh an acre.

The property, located in far flung villages in Tiruvallur district, was transferred from one private medical and educational trust to another named slightly differently for a total registered value of Rs 5,61,500 crore for 50 acres. The three settlement deeds were executed on November 29, though the property was attached by the Enforcement Directorate, which means no registration can be done.

Registration department sources on Monday said the inspector general of registration had suspended Tiruttani sub-registrar Selva Kumaran for his role in the transaction, pointing out that even T Nagar would not see land registered for Rs 11,191 crore an acre. A source said those behind the trusts could have sought to inflate the land value to get bank loans. TNN

Title: Punjab: Congress government to allow anti-CAA protest today
Content:
This story is from January 1, 2020

Amarinder Singh

CHANDIGARH: The Punjab government would not stop students from protesting against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) and “other controversial actions of the central government”, but it would also not allow peace in the state to be disturbed , Punjab chief minister Amarinder Singh has said.

Referring to the proposed January 1 state-wide protest by the Left-aligned student unions against CAA-NRC, Capt Amarinder said on Tuesday that protest was the democratic right of every citizen of India and people, including students, as long as such protests were conducted peacefully.

He said his government was totally opposed to CAA-NRC in view of the “fundamentally divisive and discriminatory” nature of the legislation initiated by the BJP-led government at the Centre.

During an anti-CAA sit-in organised by the Punjab Congress in Ludhiana on Monday, he had reiterated his government’s decision not to allow CAA to be implemented in the state.

Amarinder also urged the student leaders to keep a check for possible infiltration of ‘goonda’ elements among the protesters.
